name: Compulsory elective areas: economics, law and politics
degree-program: Dean of Studies for the Value Chain Management course
content: Content:In this module, accompanying specialist knowledge is to be acquired with which students can freely supplement their advanced modules in the master's degree program in Value Chain Management. Aim:The module enables students to supplement a specific training profile during the master's degree program by freely choosing courses from the Faculty of Economics' offerings. The module enables students to understand the interfaces between their discipline and important neighboring disciplines and to recognize them confidently in everyday professional life, as well as to bring directly required specialist knowledge of these neighboring disciplines into their professional life. The option to choose and the opening of optional additional work encourage students to choose their own course of study.

name: Compulsory elective area Economics and Law II
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration I - Business Taxation and Auditing
content: Content:When completing Module 3, students must complete two compulsory elective courses and one performance in the area of key competencies. In this module, the aim is not only to acquire accompanying specialist knowledge with which students can freely supplement their advanced modules, but also to promote personal leadership skills. Increased ability to interact is a central component of these leadership skills. The key competence can consist of the following services: Mentoring for first-year students of the Master's degree program in Accounting and Corporate Management for study organization; Proof through advisory protocols Supervision of learning groups for the repetition of technical basics for first-year students of the master's degree program in accounting and corporate management, e.g. annual financial statements, cost and revenue analysis Accounting, bookkeeping, taxes, financial management (confirmation of the supervising professorship) Commitment to improving the degree program, in particular through participation in the study commission Successful completion of a language course as an achievement of intercultural adaptation in exchange with other specialist students Aim:The module enables students to understand the interfaces between their discipline and neighboring disciplines and to recognize them confidently in everyday professional life, as well as to bring directly required specialist knowledge of these neighboring disciplines into their professional life. This also includes improved interaction and communication skills.

name: Multi-component plastic processing
degree-program: Professorship for Structural Lightweight Construction / Plastics Processing
content: Content:In addition to the integration of functions, plastics processing strives for resource- and cost-optimized process steps in the production of multi-component plastic components. In addition to teaching the basics of plastics processing, the module describes different processing methods and process combinations that are based on classic injection molding, extrusion and reaction technology as well as the pressing process. In addition, special processes such as back-injection and film technology are presented, analyzing the advantages and disadvantages, and explained using practical examples. In addition, the module focuses on the processing of fiber-reinforced semi-finished products as well as the conception and design of tool systems for plastics processing. The combination of different plastics and components also requires knowledge of the adhesion mechanisms and construction principles. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have basic knowledge in the field of plastics processing and process combinations for the production of multi-component plastic components. The students are able to conceptually select a suitable manufacturing process taking into account function and cost-effectiveness, to evaluate the special features of the process technology and to adapt the process technology parameters in a targeted manner.

content: Content: Subject and tasks of business taxation Taxation based on financial performance as a yardstick for fair distribution of burdens Measurement of tax burdens Methods of tax impact analysis Tax planning methods Effect of income taxes on the advantageousness of investment and financing decisions Effect of taxes on the periodic profit reporting Selected applications , e.g. o Sustainable non-cash compensation for employees o Real estate industry o Employee participation o Cryptocurrency o Leasing Aim:After completing the module, students understand the legitimacy of taxes. You can evaluate/determine the business or economic consequences of various taxation options. You know the methods of tax impact analysis and tax planning. You can integrate taxes into capital value models and complete financial plans, calculate after-tax returns, and interpret the results. You can formulate an objective function for the annual profit statement. You can use selected examples to explain the levers through which taxes influence the advantageousness of decision alternatives.

content: Content: Imparting basic knowledge of the Italian language (lexis, grammar, phonetics) and regional/cultural peculiarities Lexicon on simple topics: family and friends, language skills, daily routine, eating habits, leisure activities, place of residence /Accommodation Grammatical structures: articles, nouns, adjectives, adverbs, tenses (presente and passato prossimo), personal pronouns, negation Communication structures: introduce/describe yourself and others, describe/inquire about paths, simple goals express, report on the past The training is based on language competency level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Aim:Students can understand and use everyday expressions and very simple sentences aimed at satisfying specific needs. You can introduce yourself and others and ask other people questions about themselves. Completion of the module corresponds to language proficiency level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages ​​(CEFR).

name: Italian II (level A2)
degree-program: Head of the Italian department at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content: Expansion and consolidation of lexis and grammar Regional/cultural peculiarities Lexicon: training, family, hobbies, leisure and work Grammatical structures: (ir)regular <<Qi verbs, modal verbs, reflexive verbs, imperfetto and corional, possessive pronouns, direct and indirect personnel pronouns, relative pronouns light communication structures: talk about habits, make suggestions, make plea Do something, report on experiences and evaluate them. The training is based on language competency level A2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Aim:Students can understand sentences and commonly used expressions related to their area of ​​life. You can communicate verbally and in writing in simple, routine situations. Completion of the module corresponds to language proficiency level A2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages ​​(CEFR).

name: Italian III (level A2/B1)
degree-program: Head of the Italian department at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content: Expansion of lexis and grammatical knowledge Regional/cultural peculiarities Lexicon: travel, eating habits, illnesses and symptoms, studies Grammatical structures: comparison from passato prossimo and imperfetto, futuro, imperativo, direct and indirect personal pronouns, demonstrative pronouns, forms of comparison Communication structures: getting along in codified situations, giving instructions/commands, giving advice/recommendations, Talk about actions in the future, report on the past. The training is based on language competency level A2/B1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Aim:Students can understand the main points verbally and in writing when it comes to familiar things from work, university, leisure, etc. You can easily comment on familiar topics and areas of personal interest. You can report on experiences and give short reasons for plans and views. Completion of the module corresponds to language competency level A2/B1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages ​​(CEFR).

name: Italian IV (level B1)
degree-program: Head of the Italian department at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content: Consolidation and expansion of language skills Deepening of lexis in the area of work, studies Curriculum vitae Regional/cultural peculiarities Grammatical structures: congiuntivo presente, frasi passive, subordinate clauses with indicativo and congiuntivo, passato remoto, pronomi combinati The training is based on language proficiency level B1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Aim:At level B1, students achieve the ability to communicate coherently, both orally and in writing, about areas of personal interest and topics Â¿Â½ern. You can express your hopes and goals as well as reasons and explanations in a differentiated manner. Completion of the module corresponds to language proficiency level B1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages ​​(CEFR).

name: Vehicle powertrain
degree-program: Professorship for Alternative Vehicle Drives
content: Content:Drive technology is the most complex system in an automobile. This module provides an introduction to conventional and alternative drives. Types of drive are presented and the functions are explained, starting from their energy storage, energy converter, gearbox and differential up to the output on the wheel. The power requirements of a vehicle and the power flows from the energy storage are analyzed and calculated in detail. The students also learn about different maps of energy converters and the function of map conversion. The design of gear ratios for mechanical map conversion completes this module. Aim:The students know alternative and conventional vehicle drives as well as their structure and application in automobiles. The students can name the components of the vehicle powertrain for conventional and alternative drives and explain their function and understand the basic interrelationships between the components. Furthermore, the students are able to determine the power requirements of a vehicle at the wheel and fundamentally determine distance consumption.

name: Polish I (level A1)
degree-program: Head of the Slavic Languages ​​Department at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content: Sounds, stress and phonetic peculiarities of Polish Imparting basic knowledge of the Polish language (lexis, grammar, syntax) and regional/cultural information Introduction and Exercise lexis on simple topics such as family, shopping, living, leisure activities, eating habits, etc. Grammatical structures: decision question, personal and possessive pronouns, three conjugation groups, present forms, adjective endings, nouns and adjectives in the nominative, genitive and accusative case, preposition z The training is based on language competency level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Aim:Understanding and using familiar, everyday expressions and grasping simple phrases, answering simple questions about the person, the family, and leisure time The completion of the module corresponds to language proficiency level A1 of the Common Europe Â½ic Framework of Reference for Languages ​​(CEFR).

name: Design of Digital Systems
degree-program: Professorship of Circuit and System Design
content: Content: Design levels and strategies Processes and abstraction in system design System specification and HW/SW co-design Modeling, hardware description languages Tools for r simulation, verification and synthesis Aim:The students have an overview of design tools, processes, and methods for digital systems. You understand the need for design structuring and are familiar with the underlying philosophies, tools and their performance.

name: Advanced Mobile and V2X Communication
degree-program: Professorship of Communications Engineering
content: Content:1. Cellular mobile communications systems o Structure of mobile networks and fundamental problems o Cellular network structure, network planning o Cellular handover methods o Aspects of the 3rd generation mobile communications system (UMTS) o Technologies for the LTE and 5G mobile communications standards NR 2. Modern methods in wireless communication technology o Propagation conditions o Fading properties -Channel o Multi-carrier method and Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) o Error protection method o Basics of protection theory o Advanced methods for channel protection o MIMO systems o Simulation methods for data transmission systems Aim:The students know the architecture and functionality of cellular mobile networks and local radio networks for communication between vehicles or between vehicles and transport infrastructure facilities. You also know advanced communications engineering procedures and simulation methods for modeling data transmission systems. They are able to apply their knowledge and skills practically.

name: Digital Signal Processing 1
degree-program: Professorship of Digital and Circuit Technology
content: Content: Sampling and reconstruction Quantization o A/D converter o D/A converter o Quantization noise o Oversampling Discrete systems o Linearity and time invariance etc Causality and stability Digital filters o Z-transformation o FIR filters o IIR filters Aim:The students know the basics of digital signal processing and are able to independently design and program signal processing algorithms.

name: Basics of Microwave and Photonic Systems 1
degree-program: Professorship of High Frequency Engineering
content: Content:Basics of high frequency technology (definitions of terms of important variables and equations, overview of different frequency ranges and their application, sources and applications of electromagnetic waves) Electromagnetic wave propagation in various media Conducted electromagnetic wave propagation Smith Chart and its application Scattering parameters (S-parameters) Single-port systems Multi-port systems Impedance matching of systems Passive components Optical waveguides LED/Laser LiDAR Aim:The students have basic knowledge in the field of electromagnetic wave propagation and have knowledge of high-frequency components and their properties. This represents the prerequisite for further courses.

name: Next Generation Internet
degree-program: Professorship of Communication Networks
content: Content: Introduction and basics: basic terms; transmission and switching technology; Communication protocols and protocol mechanisms Basics of local networks (LANs): Overview of IEEE 802 LANs; Ethernet IEEE 802.3; VLANs Basics of IP Networking: Internet Protocol (TCP/IP); IP Addressing / NAT / DNS; IP routing; MPLS Internet applications: Example http protocol Selected mechanisms in IP networks: Quality of Service (QoS) mechanisms; Group Communication / Multicast; Mobility Mechanisms Hot Topics: Software Defined Networking (SDN) and Network Functions Virtualization (NFV); Time Sensitive Networking (TSN) and Deterministic Networking (DetNet); Peer-to-Peer (P2P) Networks; Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) Network Security: Introduction and Basics; cryptographic methods; Authentication mechanisms, key management and certificates, PKI infrastructure; Protocols for secure data transmission at the data link (L2), network (L3) and transport layer (L4); Overview and examples of cyber attacks on the Internet; Methods for cyber attack detection and defense Aim:The students have detailed knowledge of local networks (LANs) and IP networks, selected topics from the Internet and network security.

name: Design of Heterogeneous Systems
degree-program: Professorship of Circuit and System Design
content: Content: Design process of heterogeneous systems Modeling, description languages digital/analog/mixed-signal System specification How simulators work Mixed-signal coupling problems Aim:Students understand the need and principles of modern design workflows using hardware description languages. You will have an overview of the specifics of designing heterogeneous systems that can consist of components from different physical domains (electrical, mechanical, thermal, etc.). You know various design methods and tools for such systems and have developed an understanding of the philosophies and algorithms behind them.

name: Experimental Physics I
degree-program: Dean of Physics Studies at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content:Comprehensive and coherent presentation of the basics of classical physics in the context of experimental lectures in the areas of: Mechanics and thermodynamics Electricity and optics The path is based on experimental experience from qualitative observation to quantitative measurement to generalized mathematical description. The examples presented are embedded in the descriptive framework of classical physics. Basic procedures in classical physics are practiced using examples. name: Experimental Physics II

content: Content:Comprehensive and logically coherent presentation of the basics of modern physics in the context of experimental lectures in the areas: Atomic and molecular physics Condensed matter The path is based on experimental experience from qualitative observation to quantitative measurement to generalized mathematical description. The examples presented are embedded in the descriptive framework of modern physics. Basic procedures of modern physics are practiced using examples. Aim:The Experimental Physics II module provides an introduction to the basic principles and formal ways of thinking in atomic and molecular physics as well as condensed matter. The students are able to describe physical relationships and are capable of abstraction, choosing methods and building physical models. Ability to name recurring physical procedures and descriptions and to apply them to experimental questions in modern physics

name: Theoretical Physics I  Calculation Methods

The students learn the secure mastery of analytical procedures and their application to physical problems.

name: Mathematics I
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all courses in the Faculty of Mathematics (except Data Science, MINT, Advanced and Computational Mathematics)
content: Content: Basics of higher mathematics (propositional logic, sets, relations, numbers, elementary functions) Linear algebra (vector spaces, matrices, systems of linear equations, dot products, elements of analytical geometry , eigenvalues, singular values) Aim:The students know basic concepts of logic, set theory, linear algebra and analytical geometry. You can relate these to each other and show connections. Furthermore, they are able to independently apply the basics taught to problems and solve corresponding tasks.

name: Mathematics II
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all courses in the Faculty of Mathematics (except Data Science, MINT, Advanced and Computational Mathematics)
content: Content: Sequences and series, convergence Limits and continuity of real functions Differential and integral calculus in one variable Ordinary differential equations Taylor and Fourier series integral transformations Aim:The students are familiar with the basics of analysis, especially differential and integral calculus. You can differentiate and integrate functions of a variable. Furthermore, they are able to solve simple ordinary differential equations analytically. To do this, they master various techniques. The students know the most important convergence statements about Taylor and Fourier series and can develop given functions in these series.

name: Mathematics III
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all courses in the Faculty of Mathematics (except Data Science, MINT, Advanced and Computational Mathematics)
content: Content: Differential calculus for functions of several variables Integral calculus for functions of several variables Integral transformations Advanced algebraic structures Aim:The students master the differentiation of functions of several variables and can, in particular, classify the various derivation terms. You have mastered area, surface and curve integrals and can calculate them. The students know Laplace and Fourier transforms and can use them as analytical tools. The students master elementary number theory basics, algebraic structures such as groups, rings and fields, equivalence relations and factorizations as well as the basics of RSA cryptography.

name: Mathematics IV
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all courses in the Faculty of Mathematics (except Data Science, MINT, Advanced and Computational Mathematics)
content: Content: Vector analysis Function theory Probability theory Statistics Aim:The students know the differential operators of vector analysis, the most important statements about the existence of potentials as well as the integral theorems for curves and surfaces and can apply them. The students know the most important properties of holomorphic functions, in particular Cauchy's integral theorem and the residual theorem. The students know the basic concepts of probability theory as well as the most important discrete and continuous distributions as well as the central limit theorem. From statistics, point and interval estimators as well as statistical tests can be applied and interpreted correctly.

name: General Chemistry
degree-program: Dean of Chemistry Studies at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content:General chemistry Atomic structure, structure of the electron shell and the periodic table of the elements, chemical bonding, bonding theories, molecular structure and structural formulas Acids and bases General structure of solids Metals, metalloids, non-metals Overviews of the chemical properties of selected elements Basics of Kinetics and thermodynamics reaction equations material and energy balance Aim:The acquired knowledge of basic chemical laws enables students to recognize quantitative and qualitative chemical relationships. You will learn about the basic structure of matter and can use the theories of atomic structure to deduce the properties of chemical elements and compounds.

name: Chemistry of main group elements
degree-program: Professorship of Coordination Chemistry
content: Content:The module provides knowledge about material properties and the reaction behavior of inorganic compounds. Large-scale industrial processes in inorganic chemistry are discussed. The knowledge is deepened through selected demonstration experiments. The module teaches basic concepts of inorganic chemistry, basics of representation, properties and reaction behavior of the main group elements and their compounds. Aim:The students learn the basic structure of the periodic table and can derive chemical connections based on structural similarities between the elements of individual groups. You will be able to understand the basics of inorganic chemistry and transfer the reaction behavior to new classes of compounds. The students are able to understand and safely apply simple chemical models of structure and reactivity.

name: Chemical physics
degree-program: Dean of Physics Studies at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content:The Chemical Physics module provides a comprehensive and logically coherent presentation of the module subject matter. degree-program: Dean of Studies Sensory Science and Cognitive Psychology (B.Sc., M.Sc.) at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content: Basic concepts of human and technical sensory systems Basic concepts of human and machine cognitive processes Significance of sensory processes for the cognitive sciences Empirical research approaches in the area Sensor technology and cognition Social and ethical questions of research and application in the area of sensor technology and cognition Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of the basics of sensor technology, cognition and their connection as well as their social significance Ã¯Â¿Â½ Basic knowledge of empirical research concepts and methods in the field of sensor technology and cognition Ã¯Â¿Â½ Understanding interdisciplinary approaches and orientation in an interdisciplinary context

name: Organic chemistry 1
degree-program: Professorship of Organic Chemistry
content: Content:Structure, reactivity and nomenclature of organic compounds, chemical bonding, orbital model and hybridization, methane, alkanes, radicals, radical halogenation, alkenes, eliminations, carbenium ions, electrophilic and radical additions, alkynes, dienes, conjugation, carbocycles, carbenes, aromatic Compounds, electrophilic aromatic substitution, stereochemistry of organic compounds, isomerism, chirality, constitution and configuration, conformations, introduction to the basic spectroscopic methods for the study of organic compounds (MS, IR, NMR) Aim:The students get to know the basic groups of substances in organic chemistry and can independently assess the relationships between material properties, molecular structure and the reactivity of organic compounds. Furthermore, they can draw conclusions from given reaction mechanisms of certain groups of substances about mechanisms in structurally related compounds. The introduction to the most important spectroscopic methods in organic chemistry allows students to check the success of their syntheses in the laboratory.

name: Crystallography
degree-program: Professorship Materials for Innovative Energy Concepts
content: Content:Crystalline solids play an important role not only in materials science, but also in application. This module provides students with in-depth crystallographic knowledge in order to be able to work on material-relevant questions. Furthermore, the crystallographic standard works and databases are introduced. The lecture-accompanying exercise enables the knowledge learned to be consolidated using practical examples. Aim:The students can use the standard works and thus work on crystallographic questions independently. The exercise guides you to critically evaluate experimental results so that students are able to recognize their own mistakes.

name: Basics of computer science I
degree-program: Head of the Faculty Computing and Information Center of the Faculty of Computer Science
content: Content:light in the structure and mode of action of digital computers Insert in a concrete higher programming language simple sorting and search algorithms Introduction to the technology of software development Aim:The students are able to design simple algorithms, implement them in a modern programming language and thus solve tasks in the fields of natural sciences, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering and mathematics. They use simple search and sorting algorithms, numerical methods and recursive functions. Furthermore, you can apply the development process to simple problems in software development.

name: Electronic components and circuits
degree-program: Professorship of Electronic Components in Micro- and Nanotechnology
content: Content: Basics of semiconductor physics Components: semiconductor diodes, bipolar and field effect transistors, multilayer components, components of optoelectronics Basic circuits: mains rectification, voltage stabilization, frequency tuning, including small signal amplifiers lich four-pole description, power amplifiers, operational amplifiers Microelectronics: characterization and special features, digital circuit families, TTL and CMOS technology Aim:The students have knowledge of the function and description of components. You are able to analyze and dimension circuits and determine the properties of components and circuits in practical laboratory tests.

name: Numerics of partial differential equations
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all courses in the Faculty of Mathematics (except Data Science, MINT, Advanced and Computational Mathematics)
content: Content: Boundary and initial value problems in partial differential equations Finite difference method or finite volume method Projection method (including Ritz and Galerkin method) Method of Finite elements asproximation, stabilitars and convergence statements view error drops ztzungen light on marginal and initial value tasks ars algorithms and implementation of discretization methods Aim:In the module, students are introduced to the use of numerical methods for partial differential equations. The methods taught allow students to independently deal with questions that arise in practice regarding the numerical treatment of partial differential equations.

name: Surface and coating technology
degree-program: Professorship of Materials and Surface Engineering
content: Content:Relevant topics on coating and treatment processes are taught. In addition to the basics, the individual surface technology processes are explained and potential applications are shown. Practical and application-related seminar events deepen the theoretically acquired knowledge. Aim:The students know the chemical-physical-technological basics of the essential processes of surface and coating technology, including important pre- and post-treatment processes. You recognize and understand the fundamental relationships between the process characteristics and the resulting structures and properties of the layers. They are able to select layer systems based on the application and give sound reasons for their selection.

name: Law and technology (technical law)
degree-program: Professorship of Private Law and Intellectual Property Law (Law II)
content: Content: Technology law/technology law/law of new technologies Showing the interfaces between law and technology Product responsibility/liability (civil and criminal law bases also comparative law) Standardization, certification and accreditation European and national market surveillance Current topics related to technology law (depending on the group of participants), e.g. B. Cloud computing, e-commerce, electromobility, Industry 4.0, artificial intelligence Aim:After successfully completing this interdisciplinary module, students will be able to recognize, compare and analyze the interfaces between law and engineering/technology. Due to the high practical relevance of the module, non-lawyers are also able to apply legal content in a company-related manner.

name: Basics of data mining & big data
degree-program: Dean of Studies for the Business Intelligence & Analytics course
content: Content:The aim of Module 1 is to impart basic knowledge in the areas of business intelligence and business analytics. The module offers students an overview of the essential methods and technologies for evaluation and pattern recognition in data using statistical methods. In addition, an overview of the challenges and solution approaches of managing big data, i.e. H. of large, polystructured data sets. Aim:Students acquire basic methodological and technology-specific knowledge and skills in the subject areas of “Business Intelligence” and “Business Analytics” for analyzing data in the company. You will be able to evaluate structured data in a targeted manner using the available methods and technologies. In addition, the students should get to know the possible uses and challenges of big data, gain a basic knowledge of the technologies and be able to assess the feasibility or possible applications in a business context. The main focus here is on the analysis of large, polystructured data sets.

name: Qualitative methods in educational science
degree-program: Professorship of Educational Science
content: Content:The subject of the module is the theoretical and methodological foundations of the analysis of educational processes using qualitative methods of data collection and evaluation as well as the central aspects of the implementation and presentation of qualitative research projects in this field. Aim:The aim of the module is to enable students to critically analyze qualitative and empirical research work. In addition, they learn to examine educational processes using qualitative research methods and to provide a theoretical basis for this investigation. The students also practice typical forms of presenting research results.

name: Heterogeneity and education
degree-program: Professorship of Educational Science with a focus on intercultural pedagogy
content: Content:The contents of the module are basic structures of social diversity with regard to educational action. The intersectional interaction of different dimensions of inequality is examined in terms of its significance for educational processes and participation, and historical and social conditions of educational action are reflected. Aim:The students critically examine the expectations of educators when it comes to heterogeneous learning groups. They are sensitized to various inequalities and reflect on educational practice in its institutional, extra-institutional and social location in the context of diversity, migration and racism.

name: Research into educational and learning cultures, taking educational professionalism into account
degree-program: Professorship of General Educational Science
content: Content:Building on fundamental knowledge of the problem of educational professionalization and the core structures of formalized educational and learning contexts, this module examines central influencing and shaping factors in the formation, development and design of educational and learning cultures as well as their significance for conveys a contemporary pedagogical professional approach. In addition, a deeper insight into the diversity of differentiated educational and learning cultures is provided. Aim:The aim of the module is to sensitize students to the variety of different development and influence opportunities in institutional and extra-institutional educational contexts in order to consider potential interventions - and to perceive scope for design and to diagnose undesirable developments and, if necessary, correct them. In addition, the students should ultimately be able to use their own pedagogical effectiveness in different educational and learning contexts on the basis of a contemporary professional understanding ¯Â¿Â½to protect. Specific forms of operational pedagogy should also be taken into account here.

name: Structures, levels of action and design of adult education in different contexts of lifelong learning
degree-program: Professorship for Adult Education and Continuing Education
content: Content:In terms of content, the module builds on the introduced basic terms and conditions of adult education (social, educational policy, historical) in both national and European areas. Explicit reference is made to the micro, meso and macro levels of educational and learning cultures and their professional design. Against the background of a diversified system structure and continuing education landscape, development lines of the institutional constitution and the cultural genesis of adult education, modernization-theoretical challenges to adult pedagogical action and lifelong learning should be considered. Aim:The students learn about related and cross-disciplinary theories of modernity. They deal with theoretical and empirical concepts on education and learning in adulthood, on the institutionalization, cultural and program development and professionalization of lifelong learning. Furthermore, the concept of education is considered in its analytical, conceptual and normative dimensions. The aim is the in-depth discussion and knowledge of structures, levels of action and design of adult education in relation to institutional, political, economic, socio-cultural, difference theory and individual-biographical aspects.

name: Theoretical perspectives on education and learning in adulthood
degree-program: Professorship for Adult Education and Continuing Education
content: Content:As part of the module, basic and theoretical perspectives on aspects of lifelong learning are deepened in the context of intensive reading. The topics covered in detail are brought forward jointly by teachers and students. Aim:The aim of the module is to enable students to carry out a theory-based analysis of education and learning in adulthood as well as their social and institutional contexts and to equip them with a theoretical repertoire that enables them to do so Â¿Â½enables to research the respective structures in adult educational activities and work areas and to promote them professionally or to further develop them in a targeted manner.

name: Case- and profession-related analysis of educational and learning cultures
degree-program: Professorship of General Educational Science
content: Content:As part of the module, based on the research methodological and scientific knowledge imparted so far, methods and techniques for surveying or analyzing the current state of selected educational and learning cultures are taught and used on empirical research objects Practice and deepen. This includes, among other things: the study of structural and biographical conditions of learning in institutional and informal contexts. The question of professionalization of pedagogy is an essential aspect. Aim:The aim of the module is to enable students to specifically analyze and construct specific educational and learning cultures and contexts and to equip them with a methodological repertoire that enables them to light, to professionally research and promote the respective educational/learning structures and habits in different educational areas of activity and work in the sense of targeted further development.

name: Analyzes of adult education
degree-program: Professorship for Adult Education and Continuing Education
content: Content:As part of the module, building on the research methodological and scientific knowledge imparted so far, methods and techniques for analyzes for adult education are taught and practiced and deepened on empirical research objects. This includes, among other things: the research into structural and organizational conditions of learning in institutional and supra-institutional contexts, including program analysis, quality assurance, educational marketing and teaching-learning arrangements, but also modern educational biography. phies and individual or group-dependent learning processes and effects. Questions of pedagogical professionalism and professionalization as well as the conditions of learning cultures at the micro, meso and macro levels of education occupy a special place. Aim:The aim of the module is to enable students to specifically analyze adult education - as they learned in module AM2 - and to accompany them in answering relevant questions for this analysis and to equip them with a repertoire of analysis instruments and methods that enables them to research adult educational activities and work areas and to promote them professionally or in a targeted manner to develop further.

name: Social transformation(s)

content: Content:The module deals with the processes and consequences of social transformations (cultural, linguistic and media diversification, migration) and the systematic recording of these. Basic terms and models from various disciplines are discussed, placed in their historical context and reflected on with regard to their use in analysis and description. Aim:Knowledge of relevant transdisciplinary terms and models, ability to think systematically and critically reflect on the metatheoretical and normative foundations of empirical research and knowledge creation, communication and practical application of methodological knowledge of empirical social research

name: Basics of research methodology and statistics
degree-program: Professorship for Research Methods and Analysis Methods in Biomechanics
content: Content:In addition to the basics of scientific theory, essential aspects of investigation plans, data acquisition techniques and methods of statistical data analysis in empirical-quantitative research scenarios are taught. Aim:The module is intended to provide students with basic scientific theory concepts and basic methodological skills that enable them to carry out, analyze and critically reflect or evaluate scientific work in a theoretical and empirical manner.

name: General Psychology I (Cognition)
degree-program: Professorship of General Psychology and Human Factors
content: Content:history of cognitive psychology; research methods (experiment, simulation); Perception and attention, learning and memory processes, memory models, problem solving; deductive, inductive and abductive reasoning; Language acquisition, language comprehension and production, word recognition, sentence and text comprehension Aim:Teaching basic concepts, theoretical approaches and empirical findings from general psychology I (cognition); Knowledge of the most important research paradigms (experiment, simulation)

name: Fundamentals of engineering sciences
degree-program: Professorship of General Psychology and Human Factors
content: Content:The module introduces the working methods and methodology of engineering sciences using basic content and practical exercises. Contents from mechanical engineering, computer science and electrical and information technology are covered. In addition to the basics of drive and motion technology, students are taught the structure and operation of mechanical drive systems, simple gear models and graphical solution methods for the selection and use of mechanisms. The contents of the introduction to the Python programming language are data and object types as well as features and concepts of this common, high-level programming language. In the robotics internship, the conception, construction and programming of robots are demonstrated in example projects. Aim:The students are able to explain the basic principles of motion transmission from the drive to the output for selected practical examples, to transfer their knowledge to new mechanisms and to plan and build simplified transmission models through abstraction. You are familiar with the basics of a high-level programming language and can create simple programs. With the robotics internship, students acquire knowledge of the electrical, programming and image processing fundamentals of robotics.

name: Higher Mathematics I
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:Mathematics is an important fundamental discipline for engineering and natural science courses. It provides the instruments, mathematical structures and methods for solving technical problems. The main focus of the module is the following: Basics (logic, set theory, number ranges) Basic concepts of linear algebra Sequences and series Financial mathematics Aim:Sufficiently good knowledge of mathematics, including terms, structures and methods, is a basic requirement for the successful completion of a technical degree. The aim of the module is for the student to acquire the necessary basic knowledge. The student masters the mathematical concepts and the mathematical calculus with the aim of having a solid basis for the independent formulation and solution of mathematical problems, in particular occur in technical applications.

name: Basics of psychophysics
degree-program: Dean of Studies Sensory Science and Cognitive Psychology (BA, MA) at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content: Basic concepts and history of psychophysics Central psychophysical methods (e.g. signal discovery theory, adaptive procedures, scaling) Practical exercises for recording psychophysical measurements Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of basic psychophysical methods Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to independently implement psychophysical experiments

name: Basics of diagnostics
degree-program: Professorship of Personality Psychology and Diagnostics
content: Content:history of diagnostics; Methodological, strategic and ethical aspects of diagnostics; Introduction to test theories; Overview of diagnostic procedures in various areas of application; Basics of test construction, application and interpretation; Basics of partially standardized procedures Aim:Basic knowledge of the background and methods of diagnostic procedures

name: Introduction to organizational psychology
degree-program: Professorship of Work, Organizational and Business Psychology
content: Content:History of Work & Organizational Psychology; methods of organizational psychology; organizational theories; interaction and communication; gravity and organizational socialization; leadership; Teamwork; conflicts; organizational climate and culture; organizational development; personnel marketing; personnel selection; Performance evaluation; human resources development; Business psychology Aim:Introduction to content, theories, methods and results of organizational psychology

name: Human Factors / Engineering Psychology
degree-program: Professorship of General Psychology and Human Factors
content: Content: Cognitive ergonomics Workplace and work equipment design Product design Human-machine systems Automation Aim:The aim is to acquire in-depth knowledge of the human-work and human-technology interface in the area of ​​cognitive ergonomics/user-centered design (engineering psychology/human factors). The central topic is the user-oriented design of work equipment as well as technical systems and products.

name: Multivariate methods
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on empirical social research
content: Content:In this module, multivariate data analysis methods are presented and discussed and demonstrated using exemplary studies and independent work. In addition, special problems when conducting empirical studies are discussed. Aim:The aim of the module is to teach advanced scientific work and research methods in the social sciences as well as the basic ability to independently carry out and critically evaluate research work in order to acquire specific, job-relevant knowledge and skills to acquire qualifications.

name: Human-Computer Interaction II
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:Human-Computer Interaction II deals with interaction possibilities between humans and computers, especially with multimedia content. The goal is a user-friendly design of user interfaces. Aim:Students gain a deep understanding of the theories, concepts, methods, techniques and effects of media.

name: Product ergonomics
degree-program: Professorship of Industrial Science and Innovation Management
content: Content:User-friendliness, intuitive operation, self-explanatory are keywords with which products are often advertised and how customers primarily want new products. In practice it usually looks different: thick instructions only benefit those who read them. There are a multitude of rules for product design - these are often not sufficiently known or are put aside and not taken into account at all. There is also still a need for research here. In a semester-long project work, the analysis of special operating tasks and the design of a human-machine interface are carried out. The focus of the course is: System ergonomics, design of ergonomic products Human reliability Experiment design and statistical evaluation Usability engineering Aim:Basic knowledge of ergonomic product design and usability engineering

name: Perception and cognition
degree-program: Dean of Studies Sensory Science and Cognitive Psychology (BA, MA) at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content: Scientific principles of cognitive science Natural scientific principles of auditory and visual information processing Critical examination of specialist literature in the field of perception research and cognitive science Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of advanced methods and principles of perception research and cognitive science Ã¯Â¿Â½ Advanced understanding of the design and analysis of psychophysical studies

name: Traffic and mobility
degree-program: Professorship of Predictive Behavior Analysis
content: Content:The topic of traffic and mobility is viewed from a human and social science perspective. Key subtopics include: methods of traffic psychology, errors and accidents, drivers and age, driver condition and its effects, driver information systems, assistance and automation, suitability for traffic and driving licenses. Aim:The module is intended to familiarize students with the most important concepts, theories and relevant findings in traffic psychology. Knowledge of the most important research methods and experimental designs should also be imparted.

name: Basics of Robotics B
degree-program: Professorship of Robotics and Human-Technology Interaction
content: Content: Introduction to robotics (basic concepts, application of robots) Robot kinematics (notation, forward and backward calculations) Robot dynamics Trajectory planning (planning in joint coordinates, planning in operational space) Robot programming Aim:Acquisition of basic theoretical knowledge in the field of robotics and practice-oriented skills regarding robot programming as a viable basis for the independent development and implementation of automation solutions Use of robots

name: Introduction to artificial intelligence
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:Introduction to the field of artificial intelligence, covering the following topics: Agents and problem formulation Problem solving by searching Constraint problems Optimization Neural networks Statistics and protectors Probability theory Information theory Decision trees Reinforcement learning Bayes networks Aim:The student gains insight into the field of artificial intelligence.

name: Basics of assembly and handling
degree-program: Professorship of Assembly and Handling Technology
content: Content:The focus of this module is on providing basic knowledge of the machines and assemblies used in assembly and handling. Based on the requirements for the material flow and the required process parameters (e.g. when joining or assembling), the product requirements (e.g. for product design suitable for handling and/or assembly) and the usable operating resources (e.g . Gripping and clamping systems, magazines, bunkers, conveyor systems, rotary indexing tables, pick & place devices, robots), the material flow is analyzed and methods and calculation approaches are used for planning and operating assembly systems and Handling devices are presented and their use is described through many applications and design approaches. Aim:Based on organizational forms and process requirements as well as typical systems, machines and devices, the student learns how they work, characteristic parameters and application requirements for assembly and handling systems. He has an overview of the market situation and can analyze and explain typical plant systems. He is enabled to understand and evaluate individual components based on fundamental process, drive and movement-relevant knowledge. He is conceptually able to plan and design new individual components while taking basic movement parameters into account.

name: Practical introduction to computer graphics
degree-program: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:A practice-oriented introduction to computer graphics teaches basic terms, concepts and how to use software tools. One focus is the step-by-step implementation of a program for the interactive visualization of graphic 3D scenes during the course of the exercise. Aim:Overview of the field of computer graphics, knowledge of modeling and visualization tools, general knowledge of programming computer graphics applications

name: Virtual reality
degree-program: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:An introduction to VR technology with a presentation of central applications. After the VR-specific viewing and interaction devices and their operating principles have been introduced, the typical VR interaction techniques are up for discussion, which are used for navigating in VR worlds, for interacting with VR objects and for a cooperative Work in virtual environments can be used. A further focus is on aspects of modeling virtual worlds, their components, structure and interfaces, before the basic operation and system structure of typical VR systems as well as the use of special VR basic software for system development are considered. Aim:Basic knowledge in the field of virtual reality

name: Virtual and augmented reality in mechanical engineering
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:Computer-aided (virtual) modeling/design, simulation and analysis are now part of the everyday tools of the modern engineer. Virtual (VR) and augmented (AR) reality techniques play an important role in all product life phases - from development to production and service to retrofit. The module teaches how to handle and efficiently use virtual and augmented reality technologies in practical use and introduces the corresponding hardware and software. The exercises will deepen the content of the lecture and teach basic techniques for creating VR/AR applications from CAD data. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe the structure of various VR systems, Ã¯Â¿Â½ VR/AR presentations independently Â½ prepare a target definition (e.g. for the design review of new products), Â¯Â¿Â½ identify differences between 3D CAD and VR data, Ã¯Â¿Â½ explain procedures for 3D data acquisition Â¿Â½ren (e.g. motion capturing, terrestrial laser scanning), Ã¯Â¿Â½ to describe the basics of augmented reality.

name: Media psychology
degree-program: Professorship of Media Psychology
content: Content:The module teaches basics from the areas of media psychology, which are based on numerous other disciplines of psychology. This includes various approaches to understanding cognitive, emotional and motivational aspects of media use. Furthermore, the development of media use is discussed from an evolutionary and developmental psychology perspective. Aim:The students acquire knowledge about the psychological basics of media use and media effects as well as knowledge of the basics of internal and external representation systems.

name: Work science
degree-program: Professorship of Industrial Science and Innovation Management
content: Content:Ergonomics pursues the equal goals of increasing the effectiveness and efficiency of human work and human-technology interactions and of adapting working conditions and technology to people's physiological, psychological and social requirements. The module presents basic work science description and explanation approaches as well as work analysis and design principles, methods and instruments. These are used in many engineering-related professional fields and are constantly being developed and further developed as technological and organizational innovations progress. The main topics of the module are: Basics of human work and human-technology interaction Stress/stress concept, basics of work physiology and psychology Exemplary design areas of work organization Basics of occupational safety and health-friendly work design Exemplary design fields in the working environment Basics of anthropometry Basics of system ergonomics Ergonomic aspects of knowledge work Aim:The students acquire basic work science and orientation knowledge for a variety of engineering-related professions. You can apply selected occupational science methods and instruments and are able to assess and select in-depth courses on occupational science.

name: Design of the working environment
degree-program: Professorship of Industrial Science and Innovation Management
content: Content:The teaching module imparts knowledge of the physical principles, effects, calculation and measurement of classic work environment factors. The assessment and design or combating of the working environment that is harmful to people is carried out in practical exercises under laboratory conditions. The focus of the module's courses is the analysis and design of the following work environment factors: Noise in the workplace (sound propagation, superposition of sound, frequency analysis, sound insulation) Mechanical vibrations at the workplace (hand-arm vibrations, whole-body vibrations) Hazardous substances (air pollution at the workplace) Climate at the workplace (climate factors, cumulative climate measures) Industrial lighting (planning according to the efficiency method) Color design in the office and in production facilities Aim:The students gain in-depth knowledge of risks from the work environment and are able to evaluate work environment factors and apply selected measurement methods.

name: Work analysis and time management
degree-program: Professorship of Industrial Science and Innovation Management
content: Content:Industrial production depends largely on the temporal control and further temporal improvement of the production processes. Systematic analyzes of work activities and time-saving design of processes are crucial. The course teaches the following: Aim:Students understand the importance of expiration times for various operational purposes. You know the relevant work analysis procedures and design approaches for manual work processes and are prepared to apply these analysis procedures and design approaches in practice.

name: Work-and Healthprotection
degree-program: Professorship of Industrial Science and Innovation Management
content: Content:The European occupational safety legislation has issued binding regulations for all EU member states on the occupational safety-friendly design of products, processes and procedures. This means that every engineer, whether a designer, planner or work planner, must also have specialist knowledge of occupational health and safety in their employment contractual guarantor position. The main idea of the teaching module is the implementation of occupational health and safety in commercial companies. History of occupational safety, emergence of the occupational safety system Guidelines of the European Community for the protection of working people Legal basis in the national legal system Dual occupational safety system in Germany Hazard factors and occupational safety measures in the company Aim:The students have knowledge of the legal principles of occupational safety and health protection and are able to identify risks at workplaces in companies.

name: Organization and management of digital work
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on work and organization
content: Content:Fundamental questions, concepts, research results and methods of technology and internet sociology as well as work and organizational sociology are addressed with particular reference to new internet-based digital technologies. Aim:The task of this module is to provide students with important theoretical and methodological fundamentals as well as empirical research results from the two disciplines of work and organizational sociology as well as technology and internet sociology and thus to provide the basis for independent academic work to place in these fields. The students should also get to know different methods of work, organizational and technological sociology at an advanced level and thereby acquire the ability to independently deal with the various basic problems as well as theoretical and research methodological approaches.

name: Current developments in digital work
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on work and organization
content: Content:Current issues, concepts, research results and methods in technology and internet sociology as well as work and organizational sociology are discussed with particular reference to new internet-based digital technologies. Aim:The task of this module is to provide students with important theoretical and methodological fundamentals as well as empirical research results from the two disciplines of work and organizational sociology as well as technology and internet sociology and thus to provide the basis for independent academic work to place in these fields.

name: Basics of human resources management and leadership
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration VI Ã¯Â¿Â½ Human Resources and Leadership
content: Content: Historical development of the discipline and its current challenges Actors and fields of action in human resources management Behavioral science principles and instruments of personnel management Carriers and recipients human resources work as well as actors in the system of industrial relations Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Basic understanding of the content and problems of human resources management and leadership Ã¯Â¿Â½ Reflection and critical assessment of theoretical-conceptual approaches ½t out the area of ​​behavioral sciences, strategic management and human resources management - development of the ability to act in practical human resources work and human resources management

name: Applied organizational and business psychology
degree-program: Professorship of Work, Organizational and Business Psychology
content: Content: Personnel management and development Design of group work Health-promoting work Aim:The aim is to acquire in-depth knowledge of social processes in organizations from the field of organizational psychology. This includes leadership processes, group work and psychosocial stress in the workplace.

name: Work psychology
degree-program: Professorship of General Psychology and Human Factors
content: Content:organized labor; Analysis, evaluation and design of work activities, work equipment and work environment; Demand, strain and stress, work and personality, competence development, division of functions and information exchange in human-machine systems, automation strategies Aim:Teaching basic concepts, theoretical approaches and empirical findings from work psychology; Knowledge of the most important research paradigms (experiment, simulation)

name: Sociology of technology
degree-program: Junior professorship in sociology of technology with a focus on the Internet and new media
content: Content:The lectures cover the central concepts, theories, research methods and research areas as well as, if necessary, significant empirical studies and relevant professional fields of sociology of technology. Aim:The aim of the lecture is to provide an introductory overview of the areas of specialization and to impart broad, basic knowledge of sociological research fields.

name: Teaching and learning with media
degree-program: Professorship of Psychology of Digital Learning Media
content: Content:Imparting knowledge about cognitive psychology and connectionist theories, design recommendations and research on multimedia and interactive learning media Aim:Acquisition of basic knowledge and application skills in the areas of Ã¯Â¿Â½ cognitive psychology and connectionist theories for teaching and learning with media Ã¯Â¿Â½ design recommendations for multimedia and interactive learning media Ã¯Â¿Â½ current research findings on teaching and learning with multimedia and interactive media

name: visual communication
degree-program: Professorship of Visual Communication
content: Content:Imparting theoretical and methodological basics from the areas of visual communication and social research, visual studies, media and drawing theory as well as applied and historical (design and) image science Aim:Acquisition of knowledge of fundamental concepts and methods for understanding and examining current and historical visual media practices and media theories

name: Biopsychology
degree-program: Professorship of General Psychology and Biopsychology
content: Content:Methods and concepts of biopsychology; Anatomy of the nervous system, nerve conduction and synaptic transmission, neurological basics of psychological functions; evolutionary and genetic foundations of behavior, methods and findings of comparative behavioral research Aim:Knowledge of the basic findings and concepts of biopsychology including its methods

name: Gerontopsychology
degree-program: Professorship of Applied Gerontopsychology and Cognition
content: Content:Theories, methods and findings of gerontopsychology, basic content from neighboring disciplines in aging science, tasks, best practice examples and current developments in application fields of gerontopsychology (e.g. use of technology, mobility, work, education, health promotion, housing, care) Aim:In-depth knowledge of geriatric psychology including its application; Ability to receive knowledge-based and methodologically critical reception of gerontopsychological research literature and to analyze and work on problems from application areas of gerontopsychology

name: Deepening cognition, emotion, motivation
degree-program: Professorship of General Psychology and Biopsychology
content: Content:The module consists of two areas: Cognition: Cognitive processes and their modeling Emotion-Motivation: Emotional and motivational regulation in relation to individual behavior and social interaction Aim:In-depth treatment of the cognitive, emotional and motivational foundations of experience and action

name: Cognitive psychophysiology
degree-program: Dean of Studies Sensory Science and Cognitive Psychology (BA, MA) at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content: Methods and concepts of cognitive psychophysiology with a focus on electroencephalography (EEG) Design of suitable paradigms for the EEG-based recording of human information processing processes method-critical interpretation of EEG data practical exercises for recording EEG data basic concepts of evaluating EEG data exemplary knowledge of analysis software for EEG data Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ in-depth knowledge of recording, analyzing and interpreting EEG data Ã¯Â¿Â½ ability to independently evaluate EEG data Ã¯Â¿Â½ ability to Methodologically critical reception of specialist literature in the field of cognitive psychophysiology

name: Attention and eye movements
degree-program: Dean of Studies Sensory Science and Cognitive Psychology (BA, MA) at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content: Methods of attention measurement Models of attention processes Methods of eye movement measurement Applications of eye movement measurement Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of attention processes and Ã¯Â¿Â½models Ã¯Â¿Â½ Practical experience with current methods of eye movement measurement Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of modern analysis techniques for attention processes Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of modern analysis techniques for Â¿Â½r eye movements
