degree-program: Dean of Studies Sensory Science and Cognitive Psychology (BA, MA) at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content:Ues biophysical basics of neuronal processing ues circuit models of neuronal processing ues signal equ in neuronal systems neuronal coding uronal networks Transfer learning processes Aim:Knowledge of the biophysical principles of neuronal signal processing and their relationship to cognitive processes

name: Motor skills  development, control, learning
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Psychology (with a focus on prevention and rehabilitation)
content: Content:The module is intended to provide in-depth knowledge in various areas of motor skills research. This includes basic theoretical and physiological approaches to motor development, motor control and motor learning, technical training and training methods in specific target groups. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ In-depth knowledge of motor control and control Ã¯Â¿Â½ In-depth knowledge of various motor learning theories as well as their (neuro-)physiological correlates Ã¯Â¿Â½ In-depth knowledge of loads and strains on the musculoskeletal system of various Age groups and use in different settings

name: Basics of anatomy and physiology
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The module is intended to convey the biological basics of humans. Anatomical basics are acquired, which then explain the functional-anatomical connections of human movement. The physiological principles of metabolism (organs) are also discussed. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ basic anatomical and anatomical-functional knowledge Ã¯Â¿Â½ basic physiological knowledge and their influencing factors

name: Biomechanics and sensors
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:In the Biomechanics and Sensory Lecture, this module provides in-depth knowledge of the complex interaction between human sensory and motor skills from a biomechanical perspective. Another focus is on current scientific trends in this scientific area. Aim:The students gain comprehensive knowledge of the interaction between sensory and motor systems. This will enable you to record, analyze and interdisciplinarily link complex movement science issues.

name: Basics of biomechanics and movement science
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:In the Basics of Biomechanics and Movement Science lecture, basic knowledge of biomechanical connections is conveyed. Contents include the mechanical basics of kinetics and kinematics, the biomechanical principles and the biomechanical properties of biological structures in a movement science context. In the associated exercise, the lecture content is deepened using practical application examples. Aim:The qualification goal of this module is to acquire basic knowledge of biomechanics and movement science. These are intended to enable people to understand human movement and thus serve as a basis for the areas of prevention and rehabilitation, sports equipment and medical technology.

name: Databases in practice
degree-program: Professorship of Data Management Systems
content: Content: semantic and relational data modeling data models, data abstraction database design using semantic data modeling (ER model) relational data model (concepts, transformation from ERM to RM) Database queries with SQL (simple queries, complex queries, query-by-example) Data manipulation with SQL (insert, update, delete) Transaction management (term, properties, concurrency of DB operations) Security aspects (access control, views, SQL injection) Operational applications (date warehouse, data mining) Internet database connection (client-server architecture, servlets , JSP, XML, web services) concepts for optimization and access acceleration through indexing Aim:Knowledge of basic and practice-relevant architectural and functional principles of database systems

name: Human-Computer Interaction I
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:The courses on human-computer interaction I introduce the fundamental aspects of the design of user interfaces. Based on the possibilities and restrictions of human perception and information processing, aspects, rules and methods are explained that make it possible to design user-friendly interfaces. In addition, the students acquire basic knowledge of scripting languages, which can also be used in other areas of the course. Aim:The students can design classic user interfaces in such a way that the usability of the software is guaranteed. You can also complete simple programming tasks. The students can also design special and unorthodox applications for optimal usability.

name: Neurocognition I
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:Neurocognition is a new branch of cognitive science in which the consequences for cognition are drawn from the findings gained in neuroscientific research in recent years. The event introduces the modeling of neurocognitive processes in the brain. Neurocognition is a research field that lies at the interface between psychology, neuroscience, computer science and physics. It is used to understand the brain on the one hand and the development of intelligent adaptive systems on the other. Neurocognition I primarily presents various realistic neuronal models and network properties as well as learning in the form of synaptic plasticity. For a deeper understanding, the exercises also require practical tasks on the computer. Aim:Basic knowledge of neurocognition in theory and practice

name: Machine learning
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:This module introduces a sub-area of artificial intelligence (AI). The possibilities of transferring the ability to learn to the computer are discussed. The main focuses are: Introduction, classification, historical overview, neural networks, support vector machines, deep learning, reinforcement Learning Aim:Knowledge of machine learning techniques

name: Higher Mathematics II
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:Mathematics is an important fundamental discipline for engineering and natural science courses. It provides the instruments, mathematical structures and methods for solving technical problems. The focus of the module is as follows: Linear optimization Differential and integral calculus for functions of one variable Differential calculus for functions of several variables Ordinary differential equations Aim:Sufficiently good knowledge of mathematics, including terms, structures and methods, is a basic requirement for the successful completion of a technical degree. The aim of the module is for the student to acquire the necessary basic knowledge. The student masters the mathematical concepts and the mathematical calculus with the aim of having a solid basis for the independent formulation and solution of mathematical problems, in particular occur in technical applications.

name: Predictive behavior analysis in human-technology interaction
degree-program: Professorship of Predictive Behavior Analysis
content: Content:Methods of modeling and analyzing data streams from complex sensor systems for detecting human intentions and predicting human behavior Aim:Students acquire fundamental knowledge of statistical modeling and machine learning methods applied to large amounts of data in real time. The exercise teaches necessary programming skills using selected examples.

name: Project module
degree-program: Professorship of General Psychology and Human Factors
content: Content:The students work on a task on human-technology interaction or on the design of a socio-technical system in interdisciplinary small groups and present the results clearly and comprehensibly. The project topics can be part of ongoing research projects at professorships at the TU Chemnitz, in which cooperation partners from business or industry can be involved. The project groups are ideally made up of students with different bachelor's degrees. Supervision is provided by one or more professors who are involved in teaching the Master's program in Human Factors. Aim:When working on a cross-disciplinary problem using the knowledge and methodological skills acquired during their studies, the students become more confident and competent in making decisions in dealing with research and design problems through the requirements of problem analysis, time and project planning, and finding solutions interdisciplinary teamwork and project management that takes multiple goals into account.

name: Basic topics of critical intercultural communication
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:In the module, fundamental topics of intercultural communication are taught from a historical perspective (e.g. culture, multiculturality, foreign experience, mobility, communication, difference, recognition, identity, ethnicity, gender, Racism, digital everyday worlds) and perspectives in disciplinary, transdisciplinary and postcolonial contexts. Aim:The students are able to grasp the central topics of intercultural communication, explain them, describe them critically and place them in the historical disciplinary context. The students independently find topic- and subject-related basic literature.

name: Introduction to cultural and social science theories
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:In the module, basic terms and theories of intercultural communication and competence are taught from the perspective of the sciences concerned in their historical context (e.g. culture, society, action, structure and function, meaning, language, postcolonial perspectives, competence) and discipline. r, transdisciplinary and in a postcolonial context. Aim:The students can name, distinguish and classify different theoretical perspectives into the respective disciplinary and historical context. You can compare them and explain any criticisms. The students independently find topic- and subject-related basic literature.

name: Basics of qualitative methods
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:The module includes the teaching of basic methodological and methodological knowledge of empirical social research, which provides the starting point for understanding social and cultural science theories and empirical research in the field of intercultural communication. An overview of the methodological anchoring and procedures of qualitative social research enables targeted deepening and application of selected procedures in the further course of the study. Aim:The students have relevant knowledge of the methodology and methods of qualitative social research as well as their areas of application and range. You develop an understanding of the connections between theory and empiricism.

name: Digital cultures
degree-program: Junior Professorship Intercultural Competence: Focus on intercultural digital practices and transnational relationships
content: Content:In the module, basic terms of intercultural communication, intercultural competence and digital cultures are introduced (e.g. media theories, multimedia, networks, audiovisual communication, online and offline, interactivity and network 2.0, digital divide ) and disciplinary, transdisciplinary and postcolonial contexts. Aim:The students are able to explain the central concepts of digital cultures, describe them critically and classify them in the social context. You clarify facts and are able to illustrate or give a presentation. You will recognize connections between intercultural competence and everyday digital worlds from a culturally comparative perspective.

name: IKK topics
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:The module focuses on fundamental topics from the areas of digital cultures and communication as well as diversity and society. These include, for example: E.g. media theory, networks, audiovisual communication, online and offline, interactivity, network 2.0, digital divide, multimedia, diversity, identities, mobility, stereotypes , tourism, racism, community. The topics are perspectiveed in disciplinary, transdisciplinary and postcolonial contexts. Aim:Students are able to illustrate and present the topics covered and recognize connections between the topics covered. They can critically reflect on and discuss their knowledge of the topics addressed.

name: Global perspectives
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:The module offers an in-depth look at global perspectives and deals with the following topics, among others: cultural, historical and contemporary research into selected regions; general and exemplary analyzes of social, political and cultural phenomena such as globalization, migration, memory politics, regional and national identities. Aim:The students know the topics and methods covered and recognize connections between the respective perspectives and their subjects. The students can apply their knowledge of the topics and methods covered to specific questions.

name: Diversity & Society, Digital Cultures & Communication
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:The module focuses on selected topics from the areas of digital cultures & communication as well as diversity & society. In the area of digital cultures & communication, these include, for example, media theory, networks, audiovisual communication, online and offline, interactivity, network 2.0, digital divide, multimedia. In the area of diversity & society, these include, for example, difference, diversity, gender, identities, mobility, stereotypes, tourism, racism, community, inclusion, racism and exclusion. The topics are discussed from a transdisciplinary and postcolonial perspective. Aim:In project learning over two semesters in one of the main areas of focus, students can identify, develop and appropriately formulate questions and complex problems. You can conceive scientific questions, plan and carry out the work process and present the results of your work publicly alone or in a team.

name: Reading I  Cultural theory and practical fields
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:Through selected monographs that are considered classics or basic texts in the social and cultural sciences, students gain, among other things, in-depth access to the theoretical, scientific and social history of the subject , specific areas of application and intercultural topics. Aim:The students acquire knowledge about discursive specialist traditions, their social and political backgrounds and the resulting paradigms and self-images. You deepen and expand your knowledge of cultural theory using exemplary research fields in the synthesis of different historical and contemporary positions. You are able to compare theoretical and methodological viewpoints, to assess them critically and reflect and to review them.

name: Reading II  Theories and Empiricism of Critical Intercultural Communication
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:Through selected monographs that are considered classics or basic texts in the social and cultural sciences, students gain, among other things, in-depth access to the theoretical, scientific and social history of the subject , specific areas of application and intercultural topics. In addition, the students choose a monograph that fits their final topic and thus prepare their final thesis. Aim:The students acquire knowledge of specialist traditions, their social and political backgrounds and the resulting paradigms and self-images. You deepen and expand your knowledge of cultural theory using exemplary research fields in the synthesis of different historical and contemporary positions. You are able to compare theoretical and methodological viewpoints, to assess them critically and reflect and to review them.

name: English in Study and Technical Communication II (Level B2)
degree-program: Head of English department at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:Expansion of linguistic knowledge and skills with reference to study and career-oriented issues, independent research, reading and linguistic evaluation of subject-specific texts as well as application in professional discussions, text analysis and production (application documents, specialist essays), in-depth study academic/professional vocabulary in selected areas, leading consultations and discussions; The training is based on language competency level B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR) and includes a technical language component. Aim:Confidence in dealing with typical situations in everyday academic life, using specialist terminology and reading specialist texts, presenting facts and leading discussions on the topic, mastering oral language and written exchange of information; Completion of the module corresponds to language competency level B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages ​​(CEFR) with a specialist language orientation.

name: English in Study and Specialist Communication IV (Level C1)
degree-program: Head of English department at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:Deepening the specialist vocabulary in selected areas and systematically expanding the general vocabulary with reference to study- and career-oriented as well as intercultural issues, leading consultations and discussions, giving lectures including questions and answers, analysis and teaching text type-specific features for writing academic texts (scientific essays, summaries, project descriptions, letters of motivation); The training is based on language competency level C1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR) and includes a technical language component. Aim:Confidence in the oral and written exchange of information and in oral and written expression, security in presentations while adhering to formal criteria, acquisition of intercultural skills, achieving a range of stylistic variation in oral and written expression ; Completion of the module corresponds to language competency level C1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages ​​(CEFR) with a specialist language orientation.

name: French VI (Level B2)
degree-program: Head of the French department at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content: Practice all language skills (listening, speaking, reading and writing) using numerous general language topics, current, regional and intercultural topics as well as study and career-oriented issues and situations Consolidation and expansion of language skills practice of tense sequence, direct and indirect speech, accent via different language registers Working techniques: Expos The training is based on the language proficiency level B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Aim:Students can understand the main content on concrete and abstract topics; They also understand technical discussions in their own specialist area. They can communicate so spontaneously and fluently that a normal conversation with native speakers is a pleasure without much effort on both sides. Â½possible. name: Italian V (level B1/B2)
degree-program: Head of the Italian department at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:light consolidation and expansion of language skills light in the following grammatical structures: congunivo, conditional, comparationsures, comparations, one Elements of relevance Current topics are discussed, authentic listening and reading texts serve to expand the lexis. The training is based on language competency level B1/B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages. r languages (GER). Aim:Students can understand the main points when clear, standard language is used and when it involves familiar topics from work, university, leisure, etc. They can handle most situations that one encounters while traveling in the language area. You can express yourself easily and coherently about familiar topics and personal areas of interest. You can report on experiences and events, describe dreams, hopes and goals and give short justifications and explanations for plans and views. Completion of the module corresponds to language proficiency level B1/B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages ​​(CEFR).

name: Italian VI (level B2)
degree-program: Head of the Italian department at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content: Practice all language skills (listening, speaking, reading and writing) using numerous general language topics, current, regional and intercultural topics as well as study and career-oriented issues and situations Consolidation and expansion of language skills practice of tense sequence, direct and indirect speech, accent via different language registers. Completion of the module corresponds to language proficiency level B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages ​​(CEFR).

name: Logic programming
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science
content: Content:Basic concepts and application of logic programming Aim:The students are able to grasp the descriptive power of mathematical logic for real-world problems. You will be able to judge when it makes sense to use logic programming to solve real-world problems, while taking into account the limits of efficiency.

name: Quantum computing
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science
content: Content:Starting from classical computing, quantum computing is introduced as a generalization of randomized computing. Applications such as fast factorization algorithms (factorization of natural numbers in a polynomial number of steps) or fast searching Aim:The students are able to explain the concept of quantum computing as a generalization of randomized computing. They can transfer applications of linear algebra to the model of quantum computing and explain the possible applications of this concept.

name: Multicore programming
degree-program: Professorship of Practical Computer Science
content: Content:The content of the courses includes an introduction to the architecture of multicore processors, programming models for multicore programming and programming with threads. Various language and library approaches are presented for thread programming. Aim:The students know the properties of selected multi-core programming concepts and can use them to create software for multi-core architectures.

name: Parallel Scientific Computing
degree-program: Professorship of Practical Computer Science
content: Content:The module deals with applications and algorithms of scientific computing and their efficient implementation on parallel computers. Individual numerical algorithms and special applications are presented. Basic techniques to support parallel programming are also discussed. Aim:The students know the concepts of parallel programming, especially message passing, cost models and data distribution patterns. You know selected methods of linear algebra and numerics and can implement them using parallel programming.

name: Deep Reinforcement Learning
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:Reinforcement learning (RL) is an important part of machine learning in which an agent learns to interact with its environment through partial feedback (rewards). By extending RL with deep neural networks for function approximation, deep reinforcement learning has the ability to work directly with raw sensory data, enabling end-to-end learning. Contents of the lecture are: Basics of reinforcement learning Value-based methods Policy search and policy gradient Model-based reinforcement learning Multi-agent reinforcement Learning Aim:The students can describe the basics of deep reinforcement learning in theory and practice. In doing so, they take current scientific developments into account (state of the art). You can apply deep reinforcement learning algorithms to selected problems.

name: Empirical Software Engineering
degree-program: Professorship of Software Engineering
content: Content:New results in computer science (and especially in software engineering) often aim to make a system have better quality, have lower costs, be faster, be more maintainable, or be better understood by users. But how can such statements be substantiated, especially when people are involved? The lecture presents various empirical methods for evaluation and discusses which evaluation is suitable for which questions. Examples are mainly taken from the areas of software engineering and programming languages, e.g. E.g.: rigorous measurement of performance, benchmarks quantitative measurements, e.g. metrics, software repositories qualitative methods, e.g. interviews, case studies controlled experiments with developers necessary statistical basics Aim:The students have an overview of empirical methods for evaluating scientific questions. In addition, they are able to: Ã¯Â¿Â½ select and apply a suitable evaluation method for a scientific question, Ã¯Â¿Â½ scientific statements to critically question and assess their reliability, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to carry out a suitable evaluation in final theses.

name: Media encoding
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:Central aspects of information theory, coding of media data and compression algorithms are discussed. It is also discussed how these are used in the coding of individual media types. Aim:Students know the theories, concepts and methods for coding media with a particular focus on audio, image and video data. You will be able to select suitable methods for encoding and compressing media and apply them to selected examples.

name: Formal specification and verification
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Engineering
content: Content:Theoretical foundations of system modeling and simulation; System life cycle and system development processes; Formal specification techniques for embedded systems - Selected techniques from the aerospace industry; Formal verification of functional and non-functional properties of embedded systems; Security aspects of embedded systems and techniques for their verification Aim:The students are able to specify, verify and evaluate algorithms for controlling vehicles and aircraft.

name: Hardware development with VHDL
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Architectures and Systems
content: Content:The paradigms and concepts for implementing functionalities as combinatorial or sequential digital systems differ significantly from the established methods for programming using imperative programming languages. This module deals with the paradigms of hardware design and relates them to imperative programming approaches. VHDL is used as the description language. The focus of this module is: VHDL basics (concepts, syntax, semantics) Comparison to imperative programming languages Combinatorial systems and their modeling Sequential systems and their modeling Components of the register transfer level and their VHDL implementation Modeling and implementation of complex systems Practical experience in VHDL description The practical use of appropriate design programs for simulation and Synthesis of the VHDL descriptions is also taught. Aim:The students are able to explain a hardware design based on the VHDL description language, design it themselves and implement it in the associated design programs.

name: Software service engineering
degree-program: Professorship of Distributed and Self-Organizing Computer Systems
content: Content:Service-oriented architectures (SOA) represent an important standards-based and technology-independent component in the solution kit for modern software development on the web and in the cloud. The advantages of SOA as a paradigm for distributed computing and as the basis for modern, distributed software are diverse. There are numerous architectural styles for identifying, using, linking, implementing and distributing loosely coupled software services that are accessible via the Internet or Web. The module presents basic approaches, concepts, technologies, protocols and principles of modern software services and deepens their systematic use in the environment of web engineering as well as SOA and distributed software. The following aspects, among others, will be deepened: XML-based web services REST architectural style SOA components Principles and patterns, e.g. Business Process Choreography, Enterprise Service Bus ( ESB) Challenges for software services in the business environment Modeling and life cycle The approaches and concepts are illustrated by many practical case studies. Aim:The students can solve fundamental questions and problems in the operation of service-oriented architectures. You can apply classic protocols such as HTTP, SOAP and WS-* as well as service-oriented architectures and architectural styles. You can design, build, implement and operate software services in the context of distributed software.

name: Compiler construction
degree-program: Professorship of Practical Computer Science
content: Content:The lecture introduces concepts and techniques of compiler construction that are necessary for the development of a compiler. All conceptual phases of a compiler are addressed, from lexical analysis to code generation. In addition, techniques for efficient automated analysis and processing of hierarchically structured documents should be learned. The contents of the lecture are applied practically in the exercises. Aim:The students know the concepts and phases of compiler construction. You can practically apply basic compiler building techniques to selected situations and transfer them to other areas.

name: Operating systems for distributed systems
degree-program: Professorship of Operating Systems
content: Content:Special problems of operating systems in distributed systems; Algorithms for basic problems (mutex, termination, selection, etc.); clocks in distributed systems; group communication; allocation and load balancing; names; distributed operating systems; distributed transactions; Case studies (e.g. Mach, Plan9/Inferno, Amoeba) Aim:The students: Ã¯Â¿Â½ understand fundamental problems of distribution in relation to operating systems and can explain them, Ã¯Â¿Â½ know a selection of generic algorithms for solving Â¿Â½solving typical operating system problems (e.g. mutual exclusion, consistency, delivery order, call, selection), can apply and evaluate them, Â¯Â¿Â½ the overall design and individual design aspects of distributed applications evaluate operating systems, Ã¯Â¿Â½ know the design concepts of selected real operating systems for distributed systems.

name: Laboratory Embedded Software
degree-program: Professorship of Operating Systems
content: Content:The internship deals with applied modeling, analysis and development of embedded software systems. A project consisting of several sub-projects is developed on embedded hardware in accordance with given specifications. Aim:The students: Ã¯Â¿Â½ can use tools for developing embedded software (cross-compilers, graphical development environments, debuggers, tools for the creation process), Ã¯Â¿Â½ model and analyze algorithms and Architectures for embedded systems, Ã¯Â¿Â½ can debug embedded systems and analyze their runtime, Ã¯Â¿Â½ convert given specifications into concrete implementations.

name: Design of Software for Embedded Systems
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Architectures and Systems
content: Content:The lecture deals with development methods for software in embedded systems. In particular, the following aspects are dealt with: Characteristics of non-embedded and embedded systems Functional and non-functional requirements for embedded software (time behavior, efficiency, reliability, maintainability , portability, etc.) Programming paradigms for embedded systems (synchronous, time-controlled and scheduling-based programming languages) Support by middleware and operating system Trends and examples from practice Aim:The students are able to recognize the requirements and special features of embedded systems and distinguish them from those of other domains. Furthermore, you can differentiate between different development methods for embedded software and use them for specific applications.

name: Efficient algorithms
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science (Information Security)/Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science
content: Content: Introduction to randomized algorithms Analysis of the mean running time of algorithms More complicated data structures and their analysis Combinatorial search problems Aim:The students are able to work on problems using efficient algorithms. You can model real-world problems using probabilistic methods and estimate the complexity of algorithmic problems.

name: Security of distributed software
degree-program: Professorship of Distributed and Self-Organizing Computer Systems
content: Content:The offer focuses on the problem of security on the Internet and web, the application systems connected to it and distributed software in general. The module delves into four areas: 1. Area - Attacks on distributed software and distributed systems Classic attack techniques Web-based attacks Social engineering and other attack methods 2. Area - Security Introduction to methods and approaches of cryptography Approaches, services and tools for computer network security, e.g. B. IPSec, Kerberos, certificates, LDAP, RADIUS, firewalls, IDS, sniffers, scanners Management and security aspects of wireless local networks 3. Area - Identity Introduction In identity, dangers, risks, healing and security Identity & Access Management, e.g. B. Provisioning, Policies, Single Sign On (SSO), Directory Services, RBAC, 802.1X Federation of user rights, e.g. E.g. Shibboleth, WS-Federation, Liberty Alliance Project 4. Area - Application-oriented security Application-oriented security, e.g. B. in data exchange, mail and web applications Measures for systematic planning, execution and monitoring of security Trends, e.g. B. Self-management, self-healing Aim:Students can use mechanisms to secure computer systems as well as identity and authorization management. You can assess potential threats in distributed systems and applications.

name: Optimization in compiler construction
degree-program: Professorship of Practical Computer Science
content: Content:The courses deal with code generation (synthesis phase) and the associated optimization phases of compiler construction. The following topic areas are covered in detail: Generation of 3-address code from the derivation tree, especially for fields, generation of assembly code, register distribution, data flow analysis, optimizing transformations to improve program behavior, data dependency Sustainability analyses, program transformations for fields. Aim:The students know selected algorithms of the compiler's synthesis phase as well as selected optimizations of the compiler and can apply these to selected examples.

name: Real-time systems
degree-program: Professorship of Operating Systems
content: Content:Theory and practice of computing systems that are used to solve time-critical problems. The following topics are addressed: time management, standards, clocks; Scheduling procedures for periodic and aperiodic requests; resource management (priority inversion, ~ inheritance, ~ ceiling); mass storage management; caching and memory management; Fault tolerance in real-time systems; real-time communication mechanisms and protocols; Processor architectures for real-time systems; Real-time operating systems Aim:Students: ãlight basic problems with the work of real-time behavior and Kã asp ¯Â¿Â½ can derive requirements for real-time behavior from application scenarios and specify these requirements, Ã¯Â¿Â½ can use typical abstractions and model assumptions in the area of ​​real-time systems and evaluate them, Ã¯Â¿Â½ know basic approaches and algorithms to ensure real-time behavior (especially scheduling and resource management) and can apply them, and can evaluate and meaningfully develop such approaches.

name: Reliable systems
degree-program: Professorship of Operating Systems
content: Content: Terms and metrics of reliability Disruptive behavior Design patterns for fault tolerance Analysis of reliability Eating properties Diagnosis Approaches to increase the reliability of hardware and software Aim:The students: Ã¯Â¿Â½ know the attributes of reliable systems, their threats and the basic measures for dealing with them, Ã¯Â¿Â½ analyze the failures ¿Â½ the reliability of systems using various modeling approaches and metrics, Ã¯Â¿Â½ know basic design approaches to fault tolerance and can evaluate and apply them, Ã¯Â¿ Â½ know and apply selected algorithms for error analysis and tolerance, Â½ demonstrate partial correctness and termination of simple codes.

name: Human-Computer Interaction II
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:The module deepens the concepts of human-computer interaction I with a particular focus on: Ideation Serious games Information visualization aesthetics Post-WIMP interfaces Aim:The students can design and evaluate innovative (non-classic) user interfaces.

name: High performance and parallel computers
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Architectures and Systems
content: Content:Individual processors reach their limits in many applications, which has led to the development of modern high-performance and parallel computers, which are now used in many areas. Depending on their target application, such computers can differ greatly from one another, which has led to different hardware architectures and programming models. The following topics are covered: Vector processors and multimedia extensions Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) Multiprocessor systems of symmetric and asymmetric memory Cache coherence and memory consistency Networks on Chip (NoCs) Programming models such as CUDA, OpenCL, etc. Aim:The students are able to explain the need for the development of modern high-performance and parallel computers. By comparing the structure and properties of different hardware architectures and programming models, the students can deduce their use for the respective target application.

name: Network Security
degree-program: Professorship of Communication Networks
content: Content: Introduction and basics: terms, threat scenarios, security mechanisms Cryptography: introduction, symmetric and asymmetric procedures, hash functions Network access control: authentication mechanisms, Key management and certificates, PKI infrastructure Secured data transmission: Overview of security protocols at the security (L2), network (L3) and transport layer ( L4) Cyber attacks on the Internet: Overview and classification of attacks, attack examples Attack detection: Overview of attack detection methods, intrusion detection systems (IDS), examples Attack defense: Overview of defense methods, how a firewall works, examples Aim:The students have basic knowledge of security in communication networks as well as in-depth knowledge of selected aspects of network security.

name: Theoretical Computer Science II
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science (Information Security)/Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science
content: Content:Automata, grammars, Chomsky hierarchy, Turing machines, undecidability, NP-completeness Aim:The students can assess which problems can be solved algorithmically and name problems that cannot be solved algorithmically. You are able to provide the necessary mathematical proofs.

name: Operating systems II
degree-program: Professorship of Operating Systems
content: Content:Quantitative and qualitative modeling and analysis of operating system phenomena Aim:The students: Ã¯Â¿Â½ know a selection of modeling and analysis methods for the qualitative and quantitative description and analysis of operating system phenomena, Ã¯Â¿Â½ are able to map between model and system properties - create and justify these, Ã¯Â¿Â½ model elements, algorithms and properties of/in operating systems and analyze these models, Ã¯Â¿Â½ assess and evaluate design development on the basis of formal analysis differences in operating systems.

name: Solid Modeling
degree-program: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:Modern CAD systems use a volume-oriented modeling approach called solid modeling. Compared to a surface-oriented approach, the complete capture of the 3D geometry of an object allows consistency checks of the model to be carried out. The courses cover the basics of body modeling as well as the most important modeling approaches CSG, B-rep and cell dissection. Aim:The students know the basics of modeling volumetric objects, the most important techniques CSG, B-rep and cell dissection as well as procedures for checking consistency.

name: Geometric modeling topics
degree-program: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:These events provide an introduction to modern methods of geometric modeling and demonstrate their application in various areas such as design, manufacturing, entertainment and multimedia. The students acquire the teaching content by developing and implementing published research contributions. The subject areas considered include: spline-based interpolation and approximation of data sets, scattered data methods, multi-resolution modeling, CAD/CAM, non-linear spline curves, AI-based modeling approaches. Aim:The students have the skills to analyze geometric problems and use adequate algorithms from the above-mentioned subject areas for problem solving select and apply.

name: Neurocognition I
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:Neurocognition is a new branch of cognitive science in which the consequences for cognition are drawn from the findings gained in neuroscientific research in recent years. These findings put cognitive science on a new basis. The lecture shows how realistic neural models are generated and can be used to research how the human brain works. It is shown how typical intelligent activities such as learning, attention orientation, object recognition, etc. can be explained as operations in neural networks. For a deeper understanding, the exercises also require practical tasks on the computer. Aim:The students know the theoretical foundations of neurocognition and can apply them to selected examples. They also know different neuron models and can program them. The students are able to name and explain various learning rules and dynamic properties of neural networks.

name: Neurocognition II
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:Neurocognition II examines more complex models of neuropsychological processes with the aim of developing new algorithms for intelligent, cognitive robots. Topics include perception, memory, action control, emotions, decisions and spatial perception. For a deeper understanding, the exercises also require practical tasks on the computer. Aim:The students are able to explain computational models of visual attention, object recognition, action control, cognition and spatial coordination. You can analyze the models and apply them to selected problems.

name: Simulation and Performance Analysis of Communication Networks
degree-program: Professorship of Communication Networks
content: Content: Lecture: o Basics of simulation: simulation process, basic components of simulators, simulation techniques o Stochastic simulation techniques: Monte Carlo simulation and discrete-event simulation o Basics of probability calculation and statistics o Generation of random numbers and random distributions o Generation of the input variable s for the simulation o Evaluation of the initial variables (simulation results) o Design of simulation experiments o Special simulation techniques Internship: o Key points Selected tasks for simulating communication networks and systems are treated theoretically and practically. Aim:Acquisition of basic knowledge about simulation and performance evaluation of communication networks

name: Systems theory
degree-program: Professorship of Control Engineering and System Dynamics
content: Content: Introduction to systems analysis Description and analysis of dynamic (discrete-time and continuous-time) systems Introduction to stochastic processes Aim:Getting to know the most important properties and analysis methods of linear and nonlinear continuous-time and discrete-time systems; Introduction to stochastic systems

name: Advanced Management of Data
degree-program: Professorship of Data Management Systems
content: Content:Requirements for today's data management systems include scalability, continuous availability, frequent changes, location independence, the management of a wide variety of data types and the handling of very large and constant data growing amounts of data. Classic relational database systems are often unable to meet these requirements. The following are considered, among others: Object-relational and object-oriented systems NoSQL databases Graph databases Distributed databases Parallel data processing Internet data connection Security aspects Aim:The students are able to demonstrate and justify the limitations of relational database systems in general and in specific cases. By applying extensions and alternative data management paradigms, students will be able to organize data into alternative data management systems.

name: Databases and web technologies
degree-program: Professorship of Data Management Systems
content: Content:Basic techniques of Internet programming for accessing databases, database abstraction layers, semi-structured data, web services Aim:The students are able to access data in databases from the Internet using various technologies. They know the theoretical background of selected types of technology, select them for their purpose and apply them to selected problems. They also know various web services and use them.

name: Computer graphics II
degree-program: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:Continuing the introduction to computer graphics: real-time rendering advanced texturing techniques, multi-texturing generation of shadows volume visualization global illumination techniques and -effects, physically based rendering special modeling techniques The exercise deepens the acquired knowledge by implementing selected procedures using a contemporary graphical interface - faces, e.g. OpenGL. Aim:The students know advanced concepts of generative computer graphics. You can implement modern rendering techniques using graphical interfaces.

name: Image understanding
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:The module provides an introduction to image understanding, with a particular focus on the means and methods of artificial intelligence. The focus is on understanding images: Overview of image understanding Basics of digital image processing Image preprocessing Image segmentation Characteristics of objects Object recognition Three-dimensional image interpretation Motion analysis; Optical flow Aim:The students can explain elementary image processing operations, methods for object recognition and spatial image interpretation and apply them practically to selected examples.

name: Neurocomputing
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:Neurocomputing covers the basics through to sophisticated methods of neural processing. To do this, mathematical knowledge of linear algebra and statistics will be deepened. In contrast to neurocognition, neurocomputing focuses more on neural networks for solving applications than on explaining the function of the brain, although the approaches discussed can certainly be biologically inspired be. The module's topics include different neuron models, learning methods such as deep learning, reservoir computing, self-organizing maps, autoencoders and other current methods. Aim:The students know various methods of machine learning, especially neural networks, and can explain them. You can apply the required mathematical methods to selected examples.

name: Media retrieval
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:Media retrieval deals with the search in multimedia data sets with a particular focus on: Retrieval process Retrieval models Metadata Evaluation of retrieval systems Metadata generation Aim:The students know the theory, methods, concepts and techniques of information retrieval on multimedia data and can describe and compare these in an application-related manner. You are able to design and evaluate a search engine for data sets of selected media (images, text, sound, video).

name: Research seminar
degree-program: Dean of Studies for the Master's program in Computer Science
content: Content:Dealing with a scientific topic or subject area. In the seminar, a research question is independently identified and worked on in a given problem area. The students independently develop a topic, put it up for discussion in a presentation and then write a seminar paper that meets the criteria of a scientific paper. The topic should contribute as much as possible to building your profile and prepare you for the research internship and the master's thesis. Aim:The students are able to independently work on research-relevant problems, research and review the relevant state of research, give a scientific presentation and write a technical report.

name: Research internship
degree-program: Dean of Studies for the Master's program in Computer Science
content: Content:The topic of the research internship must be coordinated with a (junior) professor in the Faculty of Computer Science. It can be carried out at a (junior) professorship or in a company. The topic should be chosen so that its treatment prepares you as well as possible for the master's thesis. Aim:The students can: Ã¯Â¿Â½ work on a research-relevant topic over a longer period of time, Ã¯Â¿Â½ design a scientific procedure and implement a corresponding concept, Ã¯Â¿ Â½ research, prepare and implement necessary knowledge independently, Â½ apply scientific methods to a specific problem.

name: Advanced seminar in pure mathematics
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:Mathematical subject areas from pure mathematics are presented, which are prepared using given and/or independently selected scientific literature, summarized in writing and presented in the seminar. Aim:The students are able to independently read and understand challenging scientific texts on new topics. You are proficient in the written presentation and summary of mathematical findings. You can explain mathematical findings using suitable presentation techniques and enter into a scientific discussion about them.

name: Advanced seminar in applied mathematics
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:Mathematical subject areas from applied mathematics are presented, which are prepared using given and/or independently selected scientific literature, summarized in writing and presented in the seminar. Aim:The students are able to independently read and understand challenging scientific texts on new topics. You are proficient in the written presentation and summary of mathematical findings. You can explain mathematical findings using suitable presentation techniques and enter into a scientific discussion about them.

name: Modeling seminar
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:In this one-year seminar, you will work individually or in small teams on projects that address the following topics and problem areas: Mathematical modeling based on a practical scientific or engineering problem Investigation of mathematical Properties of the model (particularly solvability issues) numerical simulation/optimization of the model, thereby selecting and, if necessary, implementing suitable software for the problem under consideration Aim:The students are able to carry out mathematical modeling of scientific and engineering tasks and their numerical simulation. You are able to communicate in technical and physical terminology with scientists from other disciplines. You can work successfully in a team.

name: Digital Components and Architectures for Data Processing
degree-program: Professorship of Circuit and System Design
content: Content: Advanced architectural concepts of microprocessors and controllers (control unit, arithmetic unit, memory, bus systems) Additional digital programmable circuits and IP cores Classification and comparison options for digital circuits Couplings of circuit types to systems-on-chip Efficient and hardware-related programming Aim:The students have detailed knowledge of the structure and function of basic computer components. You know the main types of digital circuits, can define comparison criteria depending on the problem and make an optimal selection. You are able to use the special possibilities of computer architectures when programming software.

name: Computer vision 1
degree-program: Professorship of Digital and Circuit Technology
content: Content:This module includes a comprehensive overview of methods of two-dimensional digital signal processing as well as the basics of image creation. The specific topics include: Basics of two-dimensional filters Segmentation and classification of image data Morphological operations Histogram and point operations Machine learning Aim:The students have specialist knowledge of methods of two-dimensional digital signal processing.

name: Smart Sensor Systems
degree-program: Professorship of Measurement and Sensor Technology
content: Content: Introduction to intelligent sensor systems Basics of sensor technology Sensor properties Selected sensor principles Design of sensor systems Measurement data acquisition and sensor interfaces Advanced methods of analog-digital conversion Sensor signal processing Selected sensor applications Aim:The students are able to appropriately select sensors for measurement tasks and to design the corresponding sensor systems and interfaces.

name: Project Lab Embedded Systems
degree-program: Professorship of Measurement and Sensor Technology
content: Content: Requirements analysis Conception of solution approaches for embedded systems Component selection Hardware and software design system test Documentation Aim:The students are able to work together in project teams in a goal-oriented manner in order to independently design and implement embedded systems.

name: Real time systems
degree-program: Professorship of Operating Systems
content: Content:In practically all areas of application there are systems that have to meet time requirements. The Real-Time Systems module addresses problems resulting from these requirements and strategies for addressing them. The focus here is on various scheduling strategies and resource management concepts. Further application relevance is created by considering soft real-time systems (e.g. video streaming) or multi-core systems. The learning content of the module is conveyed in the form of lectures and exercises, whereby modern teaching methods such as group work, problem-oriented learning and flipped classrooms can also be used. Aim:Students can Ã¯Â¿Â½ explain fundamental problems in ensuring real-time behavior, Ã¯Â¿Â½ requirements for real-time behavior from application scenarios en derive and specify these requirements, Ã¯Â¿Â½ use typical abstractions and model assumptions in the area of ​​real-time systems and evaluate them, Ã¯Â¿Â½ apply basic approaches and algorithms to ensure real-time behavior (in particular scheduling and resource management), Ã¯Â ¿Â½ evaluate such approaches and develop them further in a meaningful way.

name: Hardware/Software Codesign I
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Engineering
content: Content: Insight into various design methodologies and structures for embedded systems Overview and comparison of target architectures and components for hardware/software systems Selected problems of hardware and software synthesis General partitioning techniques Hardware/software bipartitioning Aim:The students are able to specify, evaluate and systematically design hardware/software systems.

name: Verification of Digital Systems
degree-program: Professorship of Circuit and System Design
content: Content: Introduction to formal and informal verification methods Regression-capable random-driven verification concepts Assertion and coverage-based methods Binary Decision Diagrams Equivalence comparison, property checking Temporal logic and model checking Aim:The students have an overview of verification techniques for digital circuits and are familiar with algorithms, concepts and performance of selected verification methods. You can present relevant findings to a specialist audience in the form of a lecture and apply your knowledge and skills in practical laboratory experiments.

name: Test of Digital and Mixed-Signal Circuits
degree-program: Professorship of Circuit and System Design
content: Content: Basics of testing, types of errors Test strategies Generation of digital test patterns Test-friendly design Test hardware and software, test automation Special features of Mixed signal testing Aim:Students have an overview of testing methods and strategies and understand the influence of testing on the design process. You know devices and programs for testing as well as special procedures for automated testing and mixed-signal testing.

name: Applied Circuit Design and Testing
degree-program: Professorship of Circuit and System Design
content: Content: Design process and tools for digital ICs (Integrated Circuits), especially FPGAs (Field Programmable Gate Arrays) Presentation of the application fields (including rapid prototyping, signal, data and image processing) Test tools, test machines Creation of test cases, execution of tests Processing of complex design tasks Aim:The students are able to transfer a given specification to a digital system and verify the solution. You have in-depth knowledge of the necessary development steps and tools. You are able to test information electronic circuits and evaluate the quality of the solution achieved.

name: Automotive Sensor Systems
degree-program: Professorship of Measurement and Sensor Technology
content: Content:General aspects of the use of sensors in automobiles Sensors for engine management Sensors for the chassis Sensors for active and passive safety (e.g. ABS, ESP) Driver assistance systems Sensors for air quality monitoring Exhaust gas sensors Sensors for r acceleration, force, pressure, speed - self-monitoring and self-calibration for robustness Aim:The students have an overview of various principles and implementation options for sensors for automotive applications. You can carry out a targeted literature search, summarize the collected information in a written technical report and are able to present it to an audience.

name: Advanced Platforms for Automotive Systems
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Architectures and Systems
content: Content:Control units are embedded systems that implement a variety of functions in the vehicle. Both the number of control units and their networking are constantly increasing in modern vehicles. In order to master the complexity, specific architectures, development methods and processes are used. This module offers a basic introduction to the topic of developing control units in the automotive sector. The most relevant processes, methods and technologies are highlighted along the V model. The main focus here is: Technical structure of control units System architectures/communication buses, e.g. CAN, FlexRay, Automotive Ethernet etc. Software platform AUTOSAR Validation and verification techniques Aim:The students are able to describe the structure of automotive control units and demonstrate their development. They can name different system architectures or bus technologies, work out their advantages and disadvantages and derive a specific intended use from them.

name: Human success factor
degree-program: Professorship of Industrial Engineering
content: Content:Globalization, mobility, flexibility are today the keywords that characterize the professional requirements of the employees of OEMs and SMEs. In addition to professional qualifications, social skills such as teamwork, communication skills, willingness to cooperate and motivation are an important prerequisite for a successful career. Social skills play an important role, especially when taking on management tasks, for members of work teams or in project-organized activities. The event specifically focuses on teaching such skills. Furthermore, selected occupational injuries to the human body are examined under the focus of work physiology. Aim:The focus is on teaching personal, social and methodological skills. The courses cover topics such as conflict management, problem-solving methods, creativity and communication techniques as well as work-life balance, time and change management. The aim is to provide basic knowledge of the physiology of the human body and selected occupational diseases.

name: Basics of printing technology
degree-program: Professorship of Print Media Technology
content: Content:The lecture Introduction to Printing Technology provides an overview of conventional and digital printing processes, pre-press and post-press printing as well as the functions and structure of polygraphic machines. The lecture Printed Electronics I provides an overview of the physical, chemical, materials science and electronic fundamentals of printed electronics. Furthermore, an introduction to the components, the process technologies and the applications is given. Aim:Students acquire basic knowledge of modern printing technology as well as specific knowledge in the field of printed electronics.

name: Electrical engineering basics
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology
content: Content: Calculation of linear networks (node potential and mesh current method) Electrostatic fields, stationary electric flow fields, magnetostatics (field line images, movement of charges, Gaussian law, capacitance t, behavior of the field magnitudes at interfaces, energy and forces) Time-varying magnetic fields (law of induction, inductance ten, Mutual inductances, energy in the magnetic field, hysteresis, forces) Compensation or transient processes Alternating currents (complex calculation, pointers, locus curves, Filter, power) Transformer (structure, mode of operation, equivalent circuit diagrams) Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Mastery of basic electrical engineering methods Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to communicate and collaborate with electrical engineering specialists

name: EDA tools
degree-program: Professorship of Circuit and System Design
content: Content:The EDA Tools course covers two semesters with the design, modeling, description and synthesis of complex systems using commercial design tools. The specific contents are: Design tools types of synthesis, high-level synthesis, logic gate synthesis, logic optimizations, technology mapping, verification, finite automata, BDDs, simulation vs. formal verification, equivalence comparison, SAT solver , Temporal propositional logic, property testing Aim:The students are able to model complex systems using existing tools.

name: Introductory seminar in computer science
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Computer Science
content: Content:The introductory seminar introduces scientific work using selected computer science topics. Aim:The students are able to work scientifically.

name: Main topics: computer science
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Computer Science
content: Content:Computer science is a living science and quickly produces new insights. Such results are included in the Computer Science Topics module. Aim:Familiarization with current topics. Appropriation and discussion of cutting edge technologies.

name: Theoretical Computer Science I
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science (and Information Security)/Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science
content: Content:graph algorithms; random access machine; Determination of transit time; breadth and depth first search; Optimization; Shortest routes; Divide and conquer; Exponential Problems; Fulfillability Aim:Basic understanding of the problem of efficiency and correctness of algorithms and programs based on them as well as their importance in practice

name: Main seminar on the application focus
degree-program: Professorships with the main application areas, in detail: Ã¯Â¿Â½ Application focus Embedded Systems: Professorship of Computer Engineering Ã¯Â¿Â½ Application focus Media Informatics: Professorship Media Informatics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Application focus Distributed Systems: Professorship Distributed and self-organizing computer systems Ã¯Â¿Â½ Application focus Computer graphics /Virtual Reality: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:In the advanced seminar, students independently work on a topic related to their chosen application focus, present it to the group and write a term paper. Aim:The students are able to work academically independently.

name: Data security and cryptography
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science (and Information Security)
content: Content:Turing machines; predictability; NP completeness; classic and modern cryptographic methods; digital signatures; Hash functions Aim:Understanding aspects of the complexity of algorithmic problems and their importance for data security

name: Parallel computers
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Architecture and Microprogramming
content: Content:Whenever the performance of individual computers is not sufficient, parallel computers are built. The question arises as to whether the programming models known for individual computers can be adopted. What challenges do certain programming models pose to the hardware or what architectural concepts does the programmer need to know in order to be able to implement certain software concepts? In this module, concepts of modern parallel computer architectures based on multicores are discussed and considered in connection with various programming models. The following topics are covered: - Multiprocessor systems with shared memory - Virtual shared memory and global address space - Distributed memory and message-based communication - Communication networks, architectures and performance parameters - Cache coherence and memory consistency - Scalability and exascale computing. Program examples and benchmarks supplement the knowledge imparted with independent practical exercises on various parallel computer platforms. Aim:In-depth knowledge of modern parallel computer architectures

name: Computer architecture
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Architecture and Microprogramming
content: Content:Anyone who wants to program modern multi-core processors in a performance-oriented manner must acquire in-depth knowledge of certain hardware concepts in order, for example, to be able to adapt or optimize compute kernels or operating system routines for specific processors. The module provides relevant knowledge and covers the following topics: - Introduction to RISC instruction set architectures - Instruction set extensions multimedia, streaming and vector instructions - Parallelism at the instruction, thread and processor core level - Memory and cache - Hierarchies - Virtual memory, memory and system protection, transaction memory - Multi-core architectures, on-chip networks, core-core communication Simulations, program examples and benchmarks supplement the knowledge imparted with independent practical Exercises on different computer platforms. Aim:In-depth knowledge of modern multi-core processors

name: Computer organization
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Architecture and Microprogramming
content: Content:Almost all practical computer designs are based on a few elementary functional and structural principles. The more complex the systems become, the more important it is to have systematic basic knowledge for understanding them. The module aims to provide a consistent representation of everything from elementary processor to practically relevant system concepts and deepens these in the context of machine-oriented programming. The following topics are covered: - Elementary concepts of computer organization - Realization of a trivial processor or computer - Memory, bus, input/output system - Instruction set architectures and machine-oriented programming - Practically relevant system concepts using the example of a PC Practical exercises in the laboratory supplement the acquired knowledge using FPGA experiment boards and PC workstations Aim:Understanding of the elementary concepts of practically relevant computer designs

name: Design of distributed systems
degree-program: Professorship of Distributed and Self-Organizing Computer Systems
content: Content:The offer introduces the web phenomenon and the development of distributed applications and systems. The focus here is on the development process and evolution, i.e. the continuous development of the underlying requirements, architectures and technologies. Approaches to the systematic production of distributed systems are taught and central aspects in the design of modern solution approaches are deepened. The following topics are covered, among others: Web engineering The web and its effects on distributed systems Project management and teams in the context of distributed systems Process models for the implementation of distributed systems Solutions Requirements analysis and management Planning regarding content, user interfaces and application logic Approaches to application logic, e.g. messaging, RPC, CBSD, service-oriented architectures ( SOA), Software as a Service (SaaS), Mashups and Federation Content aspects, e.g. XML applications, semantics web, syndication, data-driven design User interface aspects, e.g. audience-driven design, CI/brand aspects, accessibility/WAI, navigation patterns, user interface as an experience (UIX) aspects of application logic, e.g. web service design, federation design, endpoint and wire- Design Test and Deployment Promotion, Maintenance and Evolution Aim:In-depth knowledge of methods, models, principles and tools in the field of web engineering; Ability to design, implement and operate sophisticated distributed applications

name: Computer networks
degree-program: Professorship of Distributed and Self-Organizing Computer Systems
content: Content:The use of modern information technology and globally networked computer systems has expanded in unexpected ways to almost all areas of everyday life. The module teaches the underlying concepts and principles of telematics as well as the basics for building computer networks. The following topics are covered: Models for communication, services and protocols ISO/OSI reference model and Internet model Network access technologies Switching and transport of data Internet protocols (Internet Protocol Stack), e.g. TCP, UDP, IP Coupling of computer networks, e.g. routers, gateways Security aspects Distributed systems and applications, e.g. FTP, mail, web Aim:A sound understanding of telematic methods, models, principles and tools as well as knowledge of essential network technologies and their operating principles

name: Security of distributed systems
degree-program: Professorship of Distributed and Self-Organizing Computer Systems
content: Content:The offer focuses on the problem of security in computer networks and the application systems connected to them. Possible attacks and vulnerabilities are shown, followed by a discussion of security concepts. Among other things, The following topics are covered: Introduction to identity, dangers, risks, healing and security Introduction to methods and approaches of cryptography Identity & Access Management, e.g. B. Provisioning, Policies, Single Sign On (SSO), Directory Services, RBAC, 802.1X approaches, services and tools for computer network security, e.g. IPSec, Kerberos, certificates, LDAP, RADIUS, Firewalls, IDS, sniffers, scanners Application-oriented security, e.g. in data exchange, mail and web applications Management and security aspects of wireless local networks Federation of user rights, e.g. Shibboleth, WS-Federation, Liberty Alliance Project Measures for systematic planning, execution and monitoring of security trends, e.g. self-management, self-healing Aim:Basic understanding of mechanisms for securing computer systems as well as identity and authorization management, safe use of XML applications and tools; Get to know systematic approaches to security in distributed systems

name: XML tools
degree-program: Professorship of Distributed and Self-Organizing Computer Systems
content: Content:The eXtensible Markup Language (XML) is the basis for a variety of developments in the area of the World Wide Web. XML plays a central role in the transport and integration of data as well as in many modern software applications. The offer provides a basic introduction to XML and its use in different contexts of distributed systems. Various current and practice-relevant tools are presented as applications of XML. The topics are based on the design structure of distributed systems and cover: Introduction to markup languages and XML Basic approaches, e.g. DTD, XML schemas, XML editors, XML - Applications, linking, XPath, Formats and tools in the area of user interfaces, e.g , Maps, Social Bookmarking, Search, Sight/Sound/Motion, Storage, Tagging Aim:Basic understanding of markup languages; confident handling of XML applications and tools; Ability to use XML applications and XML Web Services to implement sophisticated distributed applications; Basic knowledge of web semantics; Ability to use metadata technologies and realize semantic web resources

name: Basics of technical computer science
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Engineering
content: Content:modeling and specification techniques for digital functions; Optimization methods for digital circuits; Hardware description language VHDL, control unit and data path design Aim:Basic understanding of technical components and the design of digital circuits

name: Hardware/Software Codesign II
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Engineering
content: Content: Estimation of design parameters Rapid prototyping/emulation Hardware/software co-simulation Hardware/software co-specification with SystemC Overview of hardware/software interfaces Interface synthesis Aim:In-depth information on hardware/software code design

name: IT security techniques
degree-program: Head of the University Computing Center/Professor of Computer Engineering
content: Content:The module has a case study character. The focus is on the most modern IT infrastructure administered by the URZ: techniques for the adequate protection of communication relationships between partners, i.e. aspects such as privacy, integrity, authenticity and commitment and their sensible use as well as questions of Social engineering. The problems are viewed from both the perspective of the user and the administrator of networked IT systems. Aim:The students overview typical security threats in today's Internet. You know how practical mechanisms for defending against attacks work. They also know the security tools that are widely used in practice and are able to use services according to their own protection needs.

name: Industrial IT application of computer science
degree-program: Dean of Studies of the Faculty of Computer Science/Professorship of Computer Engineering
content: Content:Current topics in the IT industry related to computer science. The topics range from technical questions and solutions to problems to visions of the future. Examples of this include issues in web engineering, telecommunications, high performance computing, software architectures, project management and others. Aim:The students receive an overview of the problems and solutions currently discussed in industrial practice.

name: Parallel programming
degree-program: Professorship of Practical Computer Science
content: Content:The content of the lecture includes: Architecture and connection networks of parallel systems; Performance, runtime analysis and scalability of parallel programs; Message passing programming and implementation of typical communication patterns; Programming and synchronization techniques for shared address space with multi-threading; Coordination of parallel programs. In the exercises, programming models and techniques are practically applied to various applications. Aim:Knowledge of the architecture and network structures of parallel platforms; Knowledge of basic programming techniques for shared and distributed address spaces and their application to various applications

name: High-level programming languages
degree-program: Professorship of Practical Computer Science
content: Content:Concepts and implementation of higher-level programming languages; syntax descriptions; implementation aspects; imperative, object-oriented, functional and parallel programming concepts Aim:Acquisition of theoretical and practical knowledge of concepts and implementation of higher-level programming languages

name: Database basics
degree-program: Professorship of Data Management Systems
content: Content:data models; operations; SQL; data modeling; Physical data organization; data management; Transaction manager Aim:Knowledge of essential architectural and functional principles of database systems

name: Operating systems
degree-program: Professorship of Operating Systems
content: Content:classification of operating systems; architectural principles; Hierarchical layer model; Resources; forms of activity; Threads; control of critical sections; process communication; Deadlock; data transmission; memory management; mass storage; Administration; Security Aim:Acquisition of knowledge of essential architectural and functional principles of operating systems

name: Computer Aided Geometric Design
degree-program: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:To create computer graphics, geometric models of the objects to be represented are required. This lecture covers techniques and algorithms for generating and manipulating so-called free-form geometries, which are used in the geometric modeling of complex surfaces (e.g. automobile bodies, aircraft wings). Curves and surface representations Interpolation Approximation Spline curves Bezier curves and surfaces B- spline curves and surfaces Aim:Basic knowledge in the field of modeling free-form curves and surfaces

name: Computer graphics I
degree-program: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:Introduction to the field of computer graphics, dealing with the following topics: Structure of graphical systems Color models Windowing and clipping Raster algorithms Viewing transformations Hidden surface algorithms Lighting models Shading methods The OpenGL graphics standard is used.
