Aim:Basic knowledge in the area of ​​visualizing graphical models, knowledge of using OpenGL

name: Fundamentals of computational geometry
degree-program: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:This module teaches basic geometric knowledge that is relevant for understanding the processes and algorithms of computer graphics. Topics: Affine spaces Intersection problems Polygons Triangulation Convex hull Neighborhood problems Parameterized curves Aim:Basic mathematical and algorithmic knowledge to handle elementary geometric problems on the computer

name: Practical introduction to computer graphics
degree-program: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:A practice-oriented introduction to the field of computer graphics and virtual reality is intended to convey basic terms, concepts and how to use software tools. Aim:Overview of the field of computer graphics and virtual reality, knowledge of using modeling and visualization tools

name: Digital object reconstruction
degree-program: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:Computer graphic scenes and virtual worlds are based on digital object models. The creation of such models is still a complex and largely manual process. This module covers methods and algorithmic basics for the automated generation of digital models. Topics include: 3D data acquisition (e.g. scanners) Triangulation Segmentation of discrete data Filtering Aim:Basic knowledge in the field of reconstructing models from discrete data

name: Introduction to artificial intelligence
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:Introduction to the field of artificial intelligence, covering the following topics: Intelligent agents Problem formulation and problem types Problem solving through search Problem solving through optimization First-order logic, inferences Planning and action Probabilistic methods Learning agents Aim:The student gains insight into the field of artificial intelligence.

name: Machine learning
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:This module introduces a sub-area of artificial intelligence (AI). The possibilities of transferring the ability to learn to the computer are discussed. The main focuses are: Introduction, classification, historical overview, learning from examples, unsupervised learning methods, neural networks Reinforcement Learning Aim:Knowledge of machine learning techniques

name: Information Retrieval I
degree-program: Professorship of Information Systems and Software Engineering
content: Content:IRS problems, relevance, descriptors and indexing, normalization, Zipf law, stemming, proximity, fuzzy search, manual and automatic indexing, vector systems; Data structures for IRS, search algorithms, document clustering, word clustering, data compression, text mining, strings in molecular biology Aim:Basic knowledge of storing and searching large amounts of textual documents

name: Information systems
degree-program: Professorship of Information Systems and Software Engineering
content: Content:Information system in a company, recording requirements, interview; Software architecture of an information system; Input design, data acquisition, data collection, data validation, data entry; Reengineering of outdated information systems; Transaction processing information systems (OLTP); Analytical information systems (OLAP) for decision support; Data warehousing, data mining, neural networks, prediction with data mining and neural networks Aim:Basic knowledge of mass data processing problems and their solutions

name: Software engineering
degree-program: Professorship of Information Systems and Software Engineering
content: Content:principles of software engineering; development processes; process analysis and modeling; object-oriented analysis; UML; Draft; Testing Aim:Acquisition of theoretical and practical knowledge in analysis, modeling, implementation and testing of software systems

name: Media applications
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:Various fields of application (e-learning, retrieval, IP-based streaming, interactive TV, hypermedia, mobile devices, etc.) and their respective technological foundations (coding methods, file formats) are discussed. Aim:The students know the basic techniques and mechanisms of action of various media. You can produce and process different media.

name: Media design
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:The module introduces the basic mechanisms of action of various media types such as images, audio, video, etc., with the focus on design and ergonomic aspects. Aim:The students know the basic techniques and mechanisms of action of various media. You can produce and process different media.

name: Media management
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:The module introduces the entrepreneurial reality of media use. Topics include electronic markets, media law, open access and intellectual property. Aim:The students gain a deep understanding of the areas of application of media informatics techniques.

name: Media programming
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:Based on the Java programming language, various aspects of programming multimedia content are discussed, such as graphics programming, image manipulation, video audio streaming, telephony, etc. Aim:Students gain a deep understanding of the theories, concepts, methods, techniques and effects of media.

name: Media tools
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:The central content of the Media Tools lecture is the definition and explanation of central terms and techniques in media informatics in theory and practice. In the exercise, the students are trained in how to use the equipment of the Media Informatics Professorship. Aim:The students have a broad overview of the special technologies that are used in media informatics.

name: Key competency: Business Administration I
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration V - Organization and Work Science
content: Content:The module covers the following business basics: basic concepts of business administration; Companies as an object of knowledge in business administration; corporate goals; business and environment; Tasks and problems of corporate management; operational structures; processes, etc. Aim:Imparting knowledge of selected business categories and theoretical concepts and a basic understanding of business relationships; Development of skills for critical analysis of complex business issues Case studies in business administration Contents: Processing of cases relating to different operational problem areas. The respective case study groups analyze a case from the perspective of a theory and present it in the joint plenary sessions.

name: rhetoric
degree-program: Professorship of German Linguistics
content: Content:The focus is on knowledge of the basics of rhetorical communication. When working on forms of speech and conversation, a basic communicative and dialogic understanding is assumed. The focus of the approach can be, among other things: be: communication models speech design comprehensibility conscious use of body language stress and stage fright Conversation skills Connection between external speaking behavior and internal representation in rhetorical processes Speech design/speech expression. Aim:The students train their communicative skills with a view to the conscious use of communication strategies and adequate speaking means. Video feedback and personal feedback processes support students in realistic self-assessment of their own speaking skills in connection with giving and receiving feedback.

name: Media psychology
degree-program: Professorship of Media Usage (Media Sociology / Media Psychology)
content: Content:Imparting knowledge about the psychological and sociological foundations of media use and media effects Aim:Acquisition of basic knowledge and application skills in the areas of: Ã¯Â¿Â½ Cognitive, emotional and motivational basics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Social psychological and sociological basics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Children and media Development of the ability to work in a team, moderation and Media competence and presentation techniques

name: Conversation management
degree-program: Professorship of Personality Psychology and Diagnostics
content: Content:The module teaches the basics of communication and basic conversation skills. Role-playing games aim to test the previously learned techniques and their effects. The teaching of the content includes theory, discussions, individual and group work, role plays and exercises with feedback. Aim:The students should be taught basic skills in order to communicate successfully and argue effectively.

name: Presentation techniques
degree-program: Professorship of Personality Psychology and Diagnostics
content: Content:Presenting your own work and yourself are important elements of everyday working life. The module teaches self-presentation techniques and their effects. The exercises aim to find an individual presentation style that suits your own personality. The teaching of the content includes theory, discussions, individual and group work, role plays and exercises with (sometimes video) feedback. Aim:The students should be taught basic skills in order to present themselves and their own work appropriately and to argue effectively.

name: English in Study and Technical Communication II
degree-program: Head of the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:Deepening the specialist vocabulary in selected sub-areas, leading consultations and discussions, giving lectures, analyzing and communicating text type-specific features for writing academic texts (scientific essays, summaries, project descriptions, abstracts) Aim:Security when exchanging information verbally and in writing, security during presentations while adhering to formal criteria, achieving a range of stylistic variation in oral and written expression

name: Information literacy
degree-program: Head of the university library
content: Content: Basic terms of the information world The digital library (library associations, OPAC, EZB, ZDB, library services, electronic publishing) Basics of database research (thematic literature research) Construction of databases (search fields, indices, thesaurus, search logic) Presentation and research in subject-specific databases Internet (problems of searching on the Internet, specialist portals, search engines) Aim:Information competence refers to the abilities: Ã¯Â¿Â½ to recognize and formulate a need for information Ã¯Â¿Â½ to develop a search strategy, to find and use potential sources of information Ã¯Â¿Â½ to critically evaluate the search results, to evaluate and further process it in such a way that the original problem is effectively solved Ã¯Â¿Â½ to link the new findings with existing knowledge and to process them responsibly These skills become Information skills are taught as part of the course. The focus of the event is the selection of appropriate information media, the comprehensive and systematic search for subject-specific information, the teaching of search strategies and the evaluation of the information found.

name: Bachelor thesis
degree-program: Professorships with the main application areas, in detail: Ã¯Â¿Â½ Application focus Embedded Systems: Professorship of Computer Engineering Ã¯Â¿Â½ Application focus Media Informatics: Professorship Media Informatics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Application focus Distributed Systems: Professorship Distributed and self-organizing computer systems Ã¯Â¿Â½ Application focus Computer graphics /Virtual Reality: Professorship of Graphical Data Processing and Visualization
content: Content:As part of the module, a bachelor's thesis is created and defended publicly. The topic of the work is related to one of the main application areas. Aim:The students are able to scientifically work on a limited problem within a certain period of time.

name: Numerical methods for engineers
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Basic concepts (error analysis, condition concept) Algebraic equations (linear systems of equations, linear compensation calculation, non-linear equations, eigenvalues) Interpolation and approximation of functions (orthogonal polynomials, quadrature, splines, Fourier series, wavelets ) Basics of ordinary differential equations Aim:After completing the module, the students are able to select suitable numerical methods for engineering problems, to assess their stability and numerical complexity and to use these Apply appropriate software to specific problems. The aim of the internship is to acquire methodological skills in the independent application of numerical methods. The internship replaces part of the working hours that would otherwise be spent on self-study.

name: Current research areas Medical Engineering
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Equipment Technology
content: Content:The lecture presents current research areas in medical engineering. The focus is on conveying the breadth of applications and tasks in the design and interpretation of medical device technology. At the same time, an insight into current solution approaches and research results is provided. In the seminar, the content of the lecture is deepened by the students themselves developing and compiling the current state of research from the literature. Aim:The students are able to name areas of application of technology (focus on mechanical engineering) in medicine. You can evaluate equipment technology requirements from both an engineering and medical perspective. Furthermore, they are able to abstract presented technical solutions into principles, further develop them and transfer them to new applications.

name: Functional anatomy and biomechanics
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:The Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics lecture teaches the possibilities and limitations of the musculoskeletal system, particularly with regard to the functional interaction of its anatomical structures. The core content includes the differentiation of biological tissues, consideration of anatomical peculiarities of the spine, pelvis, knee and foot as well as the interaction of these anatomical structures from a therapeutically functional perspective. Basic knowledge of fascia as a body-wide network is also part of the course content. Aim:The qualification goal of this module is to acquire in-depth biomechanical knowledge. These are intended to enable us to understand the functional interaction of the human musculoskeletal system in order to make sustainable contributions in the areas of prevention and rehabilitation as well as sports and medical technology afford.

name: Medical law and ethics
degree-program: Professorship of Microsystems and Medical Technology
content: Content: Medical Devices Act, Medical Device Operator Ordinance, Medical Device Ordinance Guidelines for clinical studies Provisions and procedures for the introduction of new medical devices te Examination brochure, certification Ethical aspects in the development and use of medical technology as well as the implementation of medical studies Aim:Acquisition of basic knowledge of the legal requirements for the development, approval and introduction of new medical devices; Skills for assessing the ethical relevance of medical devices

name: Research methodology and statistics
degree-program: Professorship for Research Methods and Analysis Methods in Biomechanics
content: Content:In addition to the basics of scientific theory, essential aspects of investigation plans, data acquisition techniques and methods of statistical data analysis in empirical-quantitative research scenarios are taught. Aim:The module is intended to provide students with basic scientific-theoretical concepts and basic methodological skills that enable them to carry out, analyze and critically reflect or evaluate scientific work in a theoretical and empirical manner.

name: Clinical gait analysis
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:The clinical gait analysis exercise imparts basic knowledge about the physiological human gait, gait pathologies as well as their etiology and diagnostics. Using relevant movement science measurement methods, the theoretically developed content is deepened in the form of practical gait analyzes with healthy people and patients. Aim:The students will be able to independently carry out and interpret gait analyzes in the clinic using appropriate means of movement science. Deviations in the physiological gait should be able to be recognized. In addition, existing knowledge of movement science measurement methods is deepened and critically reflected through their clinical application.

name: Functional materials
degree-program: Professorship of Materials and Surface Technology
content: Content:Functional materials include a variety of materials that are characterized by their specific functional properties. The main focus of the module is on the causal mechanisms and the description of the effects. Emphasis is also placed on the manufacturing processes, the characterization of the properties of these materials and their application. Sub-areas include: shape memory effects, piezo effects, rheological effects, strictive effects, thermal effects, chemical effects, photo effects and surface effects. Composites receive special consideration as functional materials. Aim:In the module, students learn about functional materials and their underlying mechanisms and how to select them correctly for the specific application. The students are aware of the special importance of functional materials for automobiles.

name: Textiles in medical technology and medical textiles
degree-program: Professorship of Textile Technologies
content: Content:In textiles in medical technology and medical textiles, the basics of fiber materials as well as thread and surface formation are taught. The technological basis of these manufacturing processes and the physical requirements for processing the high-performance thread materials are presented. Building on this, the areas of application of medical textiles (dressings, bandages, surgical textiles, implants, prostheses) are explained. The differences between the various textile manufacturing processes and the resulting material properties of the medical products are highlighted using examples. The functionalization of the textile surfaces takes place in downstream finishing processes. These processes and the changes in the properties of textile materials that can be achieved with them are presented using practical examples. Aim:The students acquire basic knowledge of medical textiles and an overview of the technologies of common manufacturing processes. The general textile physics and technological fundamentals taught enable the students to evaluate the effects of modifications to the textile materials on the resulting properties.

name: Instrumentation in medical technology
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Equipment Technology
content: Content:The lecture and internship on instrumentation in medical technology convey the procedure and the special requirements for equipping medical devices and patients with measurement equipment. The basic procedure for selecting suitable sensors for different measuring tasks as well as the corresponding design and structure of the measuring chain are taught. Medical devices or test subjects are instrumented and the corresponding measurements are recorded, which contribute to the analysis of the human-technology interface as part of the data evaluation. Aim:The students can name the components of a measurement chain as well as basic requirements that must be taken into account when selecting adequate measurement technologies. Problems in the human-technology environment can be analyzed independently and suitable measuring equipment selected. Furthermore, the students are able to carry out measurement tasks independently and evaluate the resulting measurement data.

name: Measurement procedures, diagnostics and assessments
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science, Professorship of Sports Psychology (with a focus on prevention and rehabilitation)
content: Content:The module provides in-depth knowledge of the already acquired basics of the application of movement science and psychophysical measurement methods. The lecture includes the theoretical basics of application-oriented measurement technology, possibilities and limits of use as well as evaluation and interpretation of suitable parameters. In the exercise, this content is deepened by working on practical, current movement science and neuro- and psychomotor issues. Aim:The students acquire complex knowledge about the possibilities and limitations of common movement science and neuroscientific assessment procedures. This will enable you to select relevant measurement technology for specific questions, to interpret collected parameters and to discuss and critically evaluate findings from a movement science and sports psychology perspective.

name: Motion modeling and FMD
degree-program: Professorship of Assembly and Handling Technology
content: Content:The module is aimed at imparting theoretical and application-related knowledge in the subject area of modeling technical devices and systems. Movement modeling and multi-body simulation (MBS) includes the teaching of basic knowledge of the kinematic, kinetostatic and dynamic simulation of mechanisms, which are used, for example, in many processing machines, motor vehicles, assembly and handling devices, sports equipment ten and medical technology can be found. In addition to using analytical methods, you will also learn how to use MKS software. Aim:The student knows the basic philosophy and the area of ​​application of MKS systems. He is able to independently and comprehensively familiarize himself with the operation of simulation programs and thus to solve tasks in the modeling environment efficiently, to correctly interpret calculation results and their scope and assess significance.

name: Mechanical testing of medical devices
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Equipment Technology
content: Content:The seminar explains the tasks and significance of mechanical testing procedures for the development of medical products (e.g. prostheses and orthoses). The basic procedure for designing and setting up test procedures is shown. In particular, consideration is given to how the biomechanical reality can be reproduced in the application through test setups and testing procedures. Furthermore, it is taught how mechanical properties can be measured and evaluated using the test stand or on the test object. Aim:The students can describe the relevance of mechanical testing procedures as well as the approach to conceptual design. You are able to analyze biomechanical or mechanical conditions and to recreate and implement them in the form of a test setup or a testing procedure. The students are able to independently develop suitable devices, carry out mechanical tests and collect, analyze and evaluate relevant mechanical parameters.

name: Electric motor drives
degree-program: Professorship of Electrical Energy Conversion Systems and Drives
content: Content: Introduction Electric drive machines Mechanical components of electrical drive systems Physical principles of movement and heating Selection and dimensioning of drive motors for stationary operation variable-speed direct current drives drive systems with asynchronous and synchronous machines Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Acquisition of basic knowledge of the design and operating behavior of electric motor drives Ã¯Â¿Â½ Acquisition of the basic ability to solve drive-related tasks and to select drives appropriate to the application Ã¯Â¿Â½ Skills ¿Â½Ability to work with electrical engineers on a professional level

name: FEM I
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:This module imparts theoretical and application-related knowledge of the finite element method (FEM) in the area of linear tasks. On the one hand, the components of the FEM are treated as an approximation method for calculating the mechanical behavior of extensive flexible structures and also other field problems, e.g. heat conduction. These include, for example, the architectures of planar and three-dimensional finite elements and typical numerical solution strategies. Secondly, knowledge of the use and operation of existing programs and, in particular, the interpretation and evaluation of method results is imparted. Aim:The students are able to correctly interpret results from FEM calculations and assess their scope and significance. In addition, the students can quickly and comprehensively familiarize themselves with the operation of FEM programs and thus solve tasks efficiently.

name: FEM II
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:This module imparts theoretical and application-related knowledge of the finite element method (FEM) in its application to nonlinear problems. The different types of possible nonlinearities are presented and analyzed with regard to their implementation within FEM. Secondly, knowledge that goes beyond FEM-I is imparted on the use and operation of existing programs and, in particular, on the interpretation and evaluation of the results of the method. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the student is able to understand the theoretical concept of the nonlinear finite element method and, on this basis, to correctly interpret and assess simulation results. He has in-depth knowledge of the operation of FEM programs that has been expanded to include non-linear problems.

name: Experimental mechanics
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:The field of experimental mechanics deals with the application of experimental procedures to deal with practice-oriented technical problems, especially structural and material mechanics, which cannot be reliably solved using theoretical methods alone. A focus of the module is the measurement of strains with strain gauges (DMS), the most important method of experimental mechanics in industry. Based on the physical, mechanical and electrical fundamentals of the method, the application and evaluation as well as the use of strain gauges in transducer construction for mechanical variables such as forces, moments and distances are discussed , accelerations, etc. are treated. A second focus is the increasingly important optical methods for the experimental analysis of stress and strain fields. Examples of such methods are the Moir method and laser measurement technology, for the physical optical basics, measuring principles and possible applications are taught. Aim:In the module, students acquire both problem-solving skills and application-ready knowledge through the synergy of measurement and sensor technology as well as the basic engineering discipline of technical mechanics. The module is therefore also interesting for students who do not necessarily want to do experimental work in their careers.

name: Materials science  Structure formation processes
degree-program: Professorship of Materials Science
content: Content:The module deals with the theoretical basis for processes in materials that determine the formation of microstructures. The basics of the structural structure and characterization of solid matter, especially crystalline materials, as well as thermodynamic and kinetic processes and models are described, which provide a theoretical understanding of state diagrams, diffusion processes and lattice construction errors crystalline materials enable. In addition, precipitation processes and phase transformations are discussed and essential connections between processing, structure and the resulting properties are conveyed. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to understand the complex processes of structure formation in simple model systems through to the material production of modern engineering materials and to relate them to relevant properties. You have basic skills for the scientific and technological analysis of material-related problems and the optimization of materials.

name: Materials science  mechanical properties
degree-program: Professorship of Materials Science
content: Content:In the module, the connections between elementary deformation mechanisms at the microstructural level and the macroscopic mechanical properties of functional and structural materials are systematically developed. Crystal elasticity, anelasticity, dislocation plasticity at moderate and high temperatures as well as at different strain rates, twinning, fracture mechanics and forming aspects, fatigue, friction and Wear is considered. The lecture particularly conveys theoretical basics from metal physics and discusses these based on current applications and research topics. Aim:The teaching module enables students to understand the often complex interplay of deformation mechanisms on different length scales and to derive an understanding of the properties and microstructure optimization of modern engineering materials. This means they have basic skills for the scientific and technological analysis of material-related problems in the cross-sectional area of ​​mechanical properties.

name: Methodical construction
degree-program: Professorship of Machine Elements and Product Development
content: Content:The module teaches students basic methods and tools for developing and constructing machines and their assemblies. Creativity techniques are discussed that support the designer in finding solutions. In addition, the basics of methodical-systematic construction are covered using the individual phases of the construction process (specification of the task, conception, design, elaboration). The students gain an insight into construction-related cost accounting. Focus: Creativity techniques Planning the product Methodical approach to design Construction catalogs, parts lists Product classification Simultaneous Engineering Introduction to cost accounting Use of computers in construction Aim:The module promotes creativity through the acquired skills and learned methods and thus enables students to solve innovative tasks independently but also in a team-oriented manner. The courses are designed so that students effectively implement and deepen the required subject-specific knowledge when working on practical tasks. By working in small design groups, the ability to work in a team is initiated and promoted. In addition, students should develop the ability to critically evaluate designs from a cost perspective.

name: Joins in medicine
degree-program: Professorship of Welding Technology
content: Content:The students receive an overview of genetic engineering applications in the field of medical device technology. In addition, examples of fencing techniques for applications in the human body are presented. Aim:Students are able to wire ã ½ foe techniques based on specific medical/medical technology applications, ¯Â¿Â½determine operations, Ã¯Â¿Â½ define the necessary environment for operations.

name: Cost-oriented product development
degree-program: Professorship of Machine Elements and Product Development / Professorship of Business Administration III - Corporate Accounting and Controlling
content: Content:Ues ues anliche on the construction process - basics of the methodical construct of the construct of light asphes life cycle light basic terms of cost accounting and cost management light Construction-accompanying cost determination - procedure for approximate cost determination in the individual phases of the construction process Methods of early error detection and quality management in the construction process Target cost management / target cost construction / value analysis Life cycle costing and process cost accounting in product development Aim:Specific interdisciplinary knowledge in the area of ​​product development and cost management, which enables the design to be aligned with customer benefits and the costs arising in the product life cycle.

name: Introduction to innovation and technology management
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Innovation Research and Technology Management
content: Content: Consideration of primarily technologically influenced innovation processes in various fields of application and contexts from the creation of the idea to market launch or use Presentation of theoretical models, conceptual management processes and - methods and the results of empirical research lectures on theoretical principles as well as guest lectures on specific topics and the practice of innovation and technology management Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge, critical reflection and application of the theoretical foundations, methods and empirical findings of the subject Ã¯Â¿Â½ Familiarity with current findings, topics and trends in research Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to be independent Â¿Â½Analysis and successful design of management processes, problems and methods in the area of ​​innovation and technology management Â¯Â¿Â½ Preparation for the tasks as well as the ability to take on various roles in the area of ​​innovation and technology management technology management

name: Product and production ergonomics
degree-program: Professorship of Industrial Science and Innovation Management
content: Content:In the module, selected focal points of product and production ergonomics are deepened and fundamental concepts of technology and innovation management are presented. Product ergonomics looks at the user-friendly, usable design of products. Designers and developers in particular need corresponding skills. Production ergonomics deals with the design of working conditions with the aspects of increasing productivity and healthy, humane work. Future production engineers will need skills to design activities, workplaces and work organization. In areas such as assembly-friendly product design and the design of work and operating equipment, product and production ergonomics overlap. Technology and innovation management views product and production technologies as an important means of competitive differentiation and is dedicated to the emergence of innovations and the design of innovation processes. The main topics covered are: Historical and current developments in the world of work Human-machine systems Work organization, especially work structuring Product and system ergonomics Virtual Ergonomics Technology management Innovation management Aim:The students know concepts and have mastered selected design methods in ergonomics as well as technology and innovation management. You can classify and apply these in industrial practice.

name: Integrative lightweight construction technologies
degree-program: Professorship for Structural Lightweight Construction / Plastics Processing
content: Content:Taking into account the lightweight construction potential of polymer composite materials and based on bionic structural concepts, the course provides basic knowledge of active structural concepts and construction methods with a view to evaluating structural integration as well as increasing the performance and functional density for technical Applications conveyed. The students receive an overview of adaptive construction elements that can change the states or characteristics of a composite structure, and their significance in technical use. At the same time, an overview of manufacturing technologies that are suitable for producing passive and active functional components in mass production processes is given. The classification of adaptronic systems is carried out and explained using various application examples of active structural concepts. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have basic knowledge of lightweight construction potential in combination with increasing the performance and functional density in polymer composite materials. You are able to make and optimize decisions on complex and intelligent network structures. This means that future graduates can be employed both in the production process and in research and development.

name: Graphical programming of mechatronic systems I
degree-program: Professorship of Micromanufacturing Technology
content: Content:After a systematic introduction to the graphical programming language LabVIEW and getting to know the development environment, knowledge of data types and structures is imparted. Other topics include file input and output, the design of user interfaces as well as measurement data acquisition and its application for process visualization. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to independently find solutions for simple measurement and control tasks using the graphical programming language LabVIEW in the form of their own Develop a suitable user interface for the input and output of data.

name: Continuum mechanics II
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:This module provides in-depth knowledge of nonlinear continuum mechanics. For this purpose, curvilinear coordinates and associated oblique base systems are also introduced and corresponding tensor representations are agreed upon. The tensors of the Eulerian and Lagrangian representations and various objective time derivations are presented and compared. Aim:The students should gain an insight into the mechanics of large deformations and get to know tensor representations in oblique basis systems. On this basis, an understanding of geometrically and physically non-linear FEM problems is prepared.

name: Monitoring of vital functions
degree-program: Professorship of Microsystems and Medical Technology
content: Content: Medical necessity of monitoring Requirements for monitoring (medical and technical) Types of monitoring (applications, advantages and disadvantages) Technical implementation of monitoring (measurement methods , structure of the systems, electronics, shielding, EMC) Practical investigations on selected monitoring systems, electrical measurements within the respective circuits (e.g. in ECG systems) Aim:Acquisition of knowledge about the structure and function of monitoring systems for vital functions, about the advantages and disadvantages of individual systems and measurement methods as well as medical and technical requirements; Ability to estimate the effort involved in signal processing

name: Introduction to business administration for industrial engineers
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration III Ã¯Â¿Â½ Corporate Accounting and Controlling / Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Corporate Environmental Economics and Sustainability
content: Content:Basic concepts of business administration (BWL); Overview of the development of business administration, its concepts and methods with different perspectives (operations, environment, company structures, cultures, processes, management and leadership of companies, sustainable development, etc.) Aim:Knowledge of central business categories, theoretical concepts and methods in important basic areas of business administration and with regard to sustainable development

name: Project Management (MB)
degree-program: Professorship of Factory Planning and Factory System Operation
content: Content: Projects and project management Goal definition Problem-solving cycle Project setup, project organization Project structuring Project planning: dissolution uf , times, resources, costs Risk management in projects Project control Information and communication Software support The event is based on an internationally recognized standard for project management , the International Competence Baseline (ICB3) of the IPMA/GPM. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have acquired basic knowledge in the design, planning and management of one-off, complex and high-risk plans (projects). The students can classify and explain the important areas of project work - from project organization, project planning to implementation and processing right up to success control Express and, as a result, divide a project into appropriate phases and assign necessary tasks. Based on systems thinking and through reference to various application contexts, students are able to apply project management and problem-solving methods in a goal-oriented manner.

name: Material selection
degree-program: Professorship of Materials and Surface Engineering
content: Content:The student is provided with knowledge about the use and application of the most important materials and material states in mechanical engineering. In the seminar-style lectures, criteria for material selection are developed together on the basis of materials science relationships. Particular attention is paid to the precise analysis of the material stress and the stress collective. On this basis, suitable material parameters are sought that allow the designer/user to specifically select a suitable material, also taking economic and ecological aspects into account hold true. In addition to this more application-oriented material selection, the stress on the material during production and the influence on properties caused by production are also taken into account. The general principles of material selection are transferred to selected examples in the exercises. Aim:After successfully completing this module, the students will master the basics of selecting materials appropriate for use and processing. You are able to apply the basic principles of material selection independently and correctly.

name: Micro and ultra-precision machining
degree-program: Professorship of Micromanufacturing Technology
content: Content: Definitions Goals of miniaturization Classification and differentiation from processes in the semiconductor industry Greenness effects when scaling manufacturing processes Basics of ultrasound-assisted machining Metal-cutting manufacturing processes: micro milling and drilling Abrasive manufacturing processes: laser beam ablation, ion beam ablation, micro-spark erosion, electrochemical machining Ultra-precision machining: UP turning, UP milling and flycutting Aim:After successfully completing this module, students will be able to: Ã¯Â¿Â½ name and describe size effects that occur during the miniaturization of manufacturing processes, Ã¯Â¿Â½ machining and abrasive manufacturing processes for micro-manufacturing as well as its functional principle and process-specific advantages and disadvantages to be explained, Ã¯Â¿Â½ for a given micro-manufacturing task, taking into account the technological constraints Select manufacturing processes and, if necessary, necessary tools and determine relevant process parameters as well as the manufacturing processes used in ultra-precision machining with a geometrically determined cutting edge, requirements for the process and tool design as well as the machines to describe and name machinable materials.

name: Continuum Mechanics I
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:This module imparts knowledge of linear continuum mechanics. Tensor notation is introduced as a tool for a compact and clear representation of the relationships. On this basis, the continuum mechanical connections are developed against the background of a comprehensive but clear and intuition-accessible axiomatics. Aim:The students are able to record, understand and assess the load/deformation behavior of components with regard to the behavior and suitability of the corresponding component. They also have an in-depth understanding of numerical simulation methods such as the finite element method and their results.

name: Basics of hydraulics and pneumatics
degree-program: Professorship for Structural Lightweight Construction / Plastics Processing
content: Content:The lectures teach the basics of using hydraulic and pneumatic drive elements in mechanical engineering. The calculation bases are derived based on the physical principles. This is followed by explanations of the structure and functionality of the most important components. The course is rounded off with project planning and dimensioning guidelines. An internship complements the teaching content. Aim:Through this module, students are able to select fluid drives for specific applications and to plan and dimension them. The students continue to learn how to use fluid drives properly, both in the area of ​​developing machines and machine systems as well as in their use and maintenance.

name: Basics of adaptronics
degree-program: Professorship of Adaptronics and Functional Lightweight Design in Production
content: Content:The methodological basics for the development of adaptronic systems are taught. The core is a transformation of the system idea of mechatronics to the material level through the use of converter materials/smart materials. The material basics, the basic structure of adaptronic systems and possible application scenarios are covered. The focus is on the methodical development process and the simulation tools that can be used. The content of the lectures is deepened in the exercise using case studies. Aim:After completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ assess the application potential of smart materials and classify them according to application, Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe the necessary system components of an adaptronic system, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to use the necessary development tools appropriate to the situation and to recognize interdisciplinary fundamental connections in system development, starting from materials technology, construction and control technology, and to take them into account in the development process.

name: Topics of critical intercultural communication
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:The module looks at central texts of the mobility paradigm, transnational practices and the changed field research situations of multi-sited research and questions them with regard to their implications for r intercultural cultural and social theories and the experience of cultural difference, alterity and foreignness. The problems, tensions and connections between mobility and cultural theories in their historical and social contexts are particularly taken into account. Aim:The students can reproduce and summarize theoretical and empirical facts in their own words. They understand the connections between mobility and social and cultural theory. You can transfer the knowledge you have acquired to new concrete phenomena in their historical and social aspects.

name: Qualitative methods
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:Teaching important methods of (especially qualitative) empirical research in the social and cultural sciences, the ability to independently apply such methods in research projects (e.g. teaching research projects, master's theses). The methodology includes procedures for data collection, transcription and data analysis. Aim:The students have differentiated methodological skills. They are capable of independent methodological reflection and methodological criticism of scientific research and are able to independently plan and carry out methodologically controlled empirical studies in intercultural contexts or in relation to intercultural issues ¿Â½document and present empirical research results.

name: Digital everyday cultures and social practices
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:The module focuses on fundamental intercultural topics from the areas of everyday digital cultures and social practices. These include, for example: E.g. media theory, networks, audiovisual communication, online and offline, interactivity, network 2.0, digital divide, multimedia, diversity, identities, mobilities, representation sentation, stereotypes, tourism, racism, inclusion, community). The topics are discussed from a transdisciplinary perspective. Aim:The students are able to illustrate and give presentations on the topics covered. You recognize connections between the topics covered and can reflect and discuss them critically.

name: Intercultural communication and competence
degree-program: Junior Professorship Intercultural Competence: Focus on intercultural digital practices and transnational relationships
content: Content:The lecture critically presents the development of the term intercultural competence in the context of scientific and historical social developments and different fields of application. It deals with individual dimensions of the concept of competence. In addition, European and non-European competence concepts are compared and made useful for application-related questions. Aim:Students can reproduce and summarize concepts in their own words. You understand the connections between theoretical concepts and socio-cultural contexts and know the differences between European and non-European concepts. You can identify and evaluate fundamental problems of the concepts and transfer the knowledge you have acquired to concrete phenomena in their historical and social aspects.

name: Languages, media & literature
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:The module deepens and reflects on (research) perspectives, theoretical models and research methods with regard to questions of interculturality within the fields of literary studies, semiotics and German as a foreign and second language, which are tested on objects. Hermeneutic, semiotic, cultural diachronic and language didactic basic knowledge offer a methodological supplement for the analysis and interpretation of linguistic and literary phenomena in the context of intercultural communication. Aim:The students are able to independently discuss and critically question subject-specific methods and theoretical models that are part of the foundations of intercultural literary studies and semiotics, as well as in relation to transdisciplinary objects ¿Â½nd to test and apply.

name: Region & Communication
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:The module deepens and reflects on perspectives, terms, theoretical models and research methods with regard to questions of interculturality within the departments of European Studies, English and Media Communication. Theoretical approaches to various media and cultural practices offer a thematic and methodological complement to the analysis and modeling of relevant phenomenal areas. Aim:The students can independently compare, discuss, critically question and test and apply the subject-specific perspectives, terms, theoretical models and research methods covered in relation to transdisciplinary subjects. You can analyze, edit and independently present topics with different objectives.

name: Reading classic and current literature in the social and cultural sciences
degree-program: Professorship of Intercultural Communication
content: Content:In the reading course, students learn to understand and develop classic and current, contemporary designs in the social and cultural sciences. In addition to content aspects, the focus is on the techniques of professional reading and interpretation of scientific monographs. The subject of reading are classic and contemporary texts from the cultural and social sciences, but also other classic and contemporary works, insofar as they are relevant to the understanding of social and cultural sciences, are significant for the discourses of cultural theory or methodology. Aim:The students are able to understand and assess statements and arguments from the range of theories offered in terms of their relevance to the overall argumentative and theoretical context. You can trace, reformulate and summarize argumentative connections and take a stand on individual arguments and statements. The students are able to critically analyze texts and synthesize argumentative positions.

name: Basics of media psychology and instructional psychology
degree-program: Professorship of Media Usage (Media Psychology/Media Sociology)
content: Content:The module teaches the basics of media psychology and instructional psychology. The aim is to create a common knowledge base at the beginning of the master's program. The content of the remaining modules is based on these basics. Aim:Knowledge of the basic theories and paradigms of media psychology and instructional psychology as a basis for further studies

name: Deepening of methods
degree-program: Professorship of E-Learning and New Media
content: Content:In the module, the existing quantitative and social science knowledge is first repeated and then deepened. The module builds on existing knowledge of the General Linear Model. Further evaluation methods such as multivariate variance analysis, mediator/moderator analyses, structural equation models and connectionist models are introduced, which are used in the other master's courses. Aim:Knowledge of the logic of in-depth statistical analysis procedures, ability to apply the analysis procedures and interpret the results

name: Virtual Environments
degree-program: Professorship of Media Usage (Media Psychology/Media Sociology)
content: Content:The module deals with virtual environments, which have now established themselves as an important research subject in media psychology. Virtual environments include virtual and augmented reality as well as computer and video games. The focus of the analysis is on mental processing processes that take place during the use of virtual environments, as well as media impact aspects that result from their use. In this context, social processes associated with the use of virtual environments are also discussed. Aim:Acquisition of current knowledge about various forms of virtual environments, knowledge of the current state of research, implementation of studies on current issues

name: Basics of semiotics
degree-program: Professorship of German Linguistics, Semiotics and Multimodal Communication
content: Content:The module teaches and reflects on the theoretical and methodological foundations of semiotics. The students gain an overview of theories and models of semiotics as well as the history, fields of application and interdisciplinary references of semiotic schools and traditions. Aim:The students acquire in-depth knowledge of the theories and models of semiotics, understand the relevance of semiotic approaches in various application contexts, gain the ability to reflect on semiotic theory formation, the competence to select suitable methods in a problem-related manner, understanding Understanding semiotics as an interdisciplinary science with a fundamental function for the humanities, social sciences and human sciences.

name: Basics of multimodality
degree-program: Professorship of German Linguistics, Semiotics and Multimodal Communication
content: Content:In the module, theoretical principles and methods of multimodality research are taught and reflected upon. It provides an overview of approaches to linguistically and semiotically based multimodality research and deals with various traditions, analysis methods and fields of application. The focus is on speech-gesture relationships on the one hand and text-image relationships on the other. Aim:Students gain comprehensive knowledge of theories and models of multimodality research and an understanding of the relationships between semiotics and multimodality research. You will gain the ability to reflect and critically examine approaches to multimodality research, learn to relate these to various application scenarios and formulate contemporary research questions.

name: Methods
degree-program: Professorship of German Linguistics, Semiotics and Multimodal Communication
content: Content:The module teaches the methodological basics of empirical work and relates them to the methodological development of studies in various application fields of semiotics and multimodality research. Aim:The students learn the basics of empirical and experimental work in qualitative and quantitative research designs. You will acquire in-depth knowledge of the principles of study design, data collection and corpus design, transcription, annotation and evaluation of linguistic and multimodal data and will be able to use these independently in the development and implementation of Stu - apply to different subject areas.

name: German Studies: Intercultural perspectives on literature, language and communication
degree-program: Professorship of Modern German and Comparative Literature
content: Content:The module provides perspectives on literature, language and communication. Elementary perspectives, concepts, theoretical models and research methods are tested on various subjects with regard to questions of intercultural German studies, and the possibilities and limits of intercultural communication and understanding are explored. Aim:The students acquire basic knowledge of theories and research approaches in literary studies with an intercultural orientation. You can independently discuss, critically question and apply subject-specific methods and theoretical models that are part of the foundations of intercultural German studies, also in combination with semiotic and multimodal theoretical approaches ¯Â¿Â½tzen.

name: Digital media and media psychology
degree-program: Professorship of Media Psychology / Professorship of Visual Communication
content: Content:The module teaches the basics of media psychology and research into digital media communication and introduces media psychology and media communication science methods and research fields. A particular focus of media psychology is on cognitive processing processes and media effects of virtual environments (this includes virtual and augmented reality as well as computer games). Aim:The students acquire basic knowledge of theories and research approaches in media psychology and media communication research with a particular emphasis on digital media and virtual environments, learn about media research methods and deepen this knowledge in selected research areas. objects.

name: E-learning
degree-program: Professorship of Psychology of Digital Learning Media
content: Content:The module imparts knowledge about cognitive psychological and connectionist theories of teaching and learning, and introduces research and design of multimedia and interactive learning media. The basics of quantitative and experimental research designs for corresponding studies are taught. Aim:The students acquire basic knowledge about the functionality and design of multimedia and interactive learning media, the experimental testing of design recommendations as well as cognitive, motivational and emotional processes when learning with multimedia and interactive media. In project-related work, they also acquire teamwork skills, media skills and presentation techniques.

name: Reception cultures of the pre-modern period
degree-program: Professorship for German literary and linguistic history of the Middle Ages and the early modern period
content: Content:The module introduces fundamental reception theories using selected objects from a comprehensive perspective (historical and literary studies). The conceptual and theoretical foundations of transmedia research are taught, examples of reception processes are analyzed and the significance of pre-modern reception for today's media and cultural landscape (e.g. in the area of fantasy genres in literature and films). and computer games). Aim:The students learn about mental models from various specialist areas that can be used to describe cultural reception processes, learn the skills of transdisciplinary work and acquire the ability to apply the knowledge they have acquired through examples to different subject areas to be transferred.

name: English Studies: Intercultural perspectives on literature, language and communication
degree-program: Professorship of English Linguistics / English Literature
content: Content:The module opens up intercultural perspectives on literature, language and communication and conveys the basics of English language and literary studies. The focus is on social, cultural and textual science concepts and methods for describing the forms and functions of English worldwide, as well as skills for analyzing and problem-related investigation of various narrative forms and media from the field of English-language literature and culture. Aim:The students acquire knowledge of specific concepts and methods of English linguistics and literary studies and apply these to various questions.

name: Physics (with experiments)
degree-program: Dean of Physics Studies at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content:Logically coherent presentation of classical physics and introduction to modern physics as part of an experimental lecture in the areas of classical mechanics, thermodynamics, electricity/magnetism/optics, quantum concept, atoms/molecules oils/solids; Based on experimental experience, the essence of physics as a mathematized natural science and its technical relevance will be clarified. Important physical phenomena and their qualitative and quantitative description are presented. In addition to the focus on classical physics, more modern problems are also adequately dealt with. Aim:Understanding of physical relationships and scientific methodology; Ability to solve simple physics problems; Familiarity with simple experimental techniques and the principles of laboratory work

name: Higher Mathematics I
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all courses in the Faculty of Mathematics (except Data Science, MINT, Advanced and Computational Mathematics)
content: Content:Mathematics is an important fundamental discipline for engineering courses. It provides the instruments, mathematical structures and methods for solving technical problems. The main focus of the module is as follows: Basics (logic, set theory, number ranges) Basic concepts of linear algebra Sequences, series and limit values Financial mathematics Aim:Sufficiently good knowledge of mathematics, including terms, structures and methods, is a basic requirement for the successful completion of a technical degree. The aim of the training is for the students to acquire the necessary basic knowledge. The students master the mathematical concepts and the mathematical calculus with the aim of having a solid basis for the independent formulation and solution of mathematical problems, in particular occur in technical applications. The aim of the internship is to acquire methodological skills in the independent application of mathematical concepts and solution methods. The internship replaces part of the working hours that would otherwise be spent on self-study.

name: Higher Mathematics II
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all courses in the Faculty of Mathematics (except Data Science, MINT, Advanced and Computational Mathematics)
content: Content:Mathematics is an important fundamental discipline for engineering courses. It provides the instruments, mathematical structures and methods for solving technical problems. The focus of the module is as follows: Linear optimization Differential and integral calculus for functions of one variable Differential calculus for functions of several variables Ordinary differential equations Systems of linear differential equations Aim:Sufficiently good knowledge of mathematics, including terms, structures and methods, is a basic requirement for the successful completion of a technical degree. The aim of the training is for the students to acquire the necessary basic knowledge. The students master the mathematical concepts and the mathematical calculus with the aim of having a solid basis for the independent formulation and solution of mathematical problems, in particular occur in technical applications. The aim of the internship is to acquire methodological skills in the independent application of mathematical concepts and solution methods. The internship replaces part of the working hours that would otherwise be spent on self-study.

name: statistics
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all courses in the Faculty of Mathematics (except Data Science, MINT, Advanced and Computational Mathematics)
content: Content: Descriptive statistics Basics of probability calculation o Random variables and special distributions Inferential statistics o Parameter estimation o Significance tests Correlations and regression Selected statistical methods Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to apply basic knowledge to statistical investigations and analyzes of economic problems, interpret them and test their significance. During the internships, the students acquired methodological skills for solving mathematical concepts and can apply them independently.

name: Business English 2 (BE2)
degree-program: Program coordinator for business English at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:In this module, students become familiar with describing products and production processes, the marketing and distribution of products, and company successes in a foreign language. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to apply the acquired knowledge of English business language in a targeted and confident manner in oral and increasingly written specialist communication. Successful completion of the module corresponds to specialist language competency level B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.

name: Independent scientific work and presentations
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Innovation Research and Technology Management
content: Content:Basics of scientific work and the theory of science: Basics of science and scientific work Sources, procedure and form of scientific work Information offers and options for literature research Basics of scientific theory and methodology Quality criteria, misconduct and ethics in scientific work Business meets science: The lecture series Business meets science deals with practice-oriented problems and their economic preparation presented. This can be done, for example, by presenting seminars, projects and final theses from various economics courses. This makes it clear how practice-oriented tasks can be processed methodically. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the participants know the basics of scientific work and can apply them independently. They have the necessary prerequisites that enable them to access and deal with scientific texts professionally. This enables them to process and write scientific texts appropriately during their studies and in practice. In addition, they have gained introductory and overview knowledge of scientific theory and empirical methods. Finally, they are also made aware of the importance of methodological pluralism and ethics in science.

name: Competent and responsible decision-making
degree-program: Dean of Studies for the bachelor's degree program in Economics
content: Content: Decision theory basics (building blocks and classes of decisions, structure and meaning of decision models, principles of model building) Basics of algorithms and logical elementary structures, algorithm development and their representation in programming Ethical basics Economic theories and their consequences for economic analysis, decision-making, action and reflection Ethical, legal and practical foundations of responsible entrepreneurial action based on selected questions from various areas areas of activity in economics Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to think through a problem logically and can develop an algorithmic solution. With the help of a programming environment, you can implement your solution as a simple, executable software module. In doing so, they increase their creative potential and experience creative success. The students combine cognitive and affective competencies in (business) decision-making situations that are no longer suitable for a purely practical solution, and deal with them using ethical standards ¯Â¿Â½be.

name: Simulation game
degree-program: Dean of Studies for the bachelor's degree program in Economics
content: Content:The simulation game is an IT-supported business simulation that teaches participants about complex business relationships in a modeled market environment. Participants assume the role of decision makers in fictional competing companies and make strategic and operational decisions in areas such as research and development, procurement, manufacturing, sales, human resources, and finance and accounting. The goal is to maximize company performance. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have deepened and broadened their economic knowledge and can recognize and explain business connections. You are able to analyze and manage decision-making situations from different perspectives as part of group work and to integrate and present findings from collaboration.

name: Basics of business administration and accounting for technically oriented courses
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration I Ã¯Â¿Â½ Business Taxation and Auditing Professorship of Business Administration III Ã¯Â¿Â½ Corporate Accounting and Controlling Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Corporate Environmental Economics and Sustainability
content: Content: Basic concepts of business administration (BWL) Goods cycles, personnel, legal and technical-economic structures of companies Goals and target structures in companies /Operations Operational processes and decision-making situations in these processes Sustainability orientation of companies/organizations Basics of balance sheets, profit and loss accounts (P&L) and accounting Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to explain central terms, concepts and methods of business administration, apply these to practical cases and present basic business relationships and put them into context to be classified as sustainable development. They can also use the accounting technology for simple business transactions and assess the possibilities of carrying out the accounting automatically Ã¯Â¿Â½ears . You are able to derive balance sheets and income statements for companies from accounting. In addition, they can explain what the balance sheet and income statement generally say about the company.

name: production and logistics
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Production Management
content: Content: Introduction to business decision-making problems that can arise when designing processes and structures for operational service provision in the areas of material goods and service production Introduction Introduction to activity analysis Planning tasks in production and logistics management Presentation and discussion of basic mathematical concepts, models and quantitative methods for mapping and solving these planning problems Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to name and explain general terms in production and logistics. You can name elementary laws of production and logistics, describe production systems using activity analysis and distinguish and basically outline decision-making problems for the design of processes and structures in the production of operational services Â¿Â½en.
