degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration III Ã¯Â¿Â½ Corporate Accounting and Controlling
content: Content: Investments as a subject of corporate management Models for assessing the advantages of a monetary target Models for r advantageous decisions for several target variables Models for service life, replacement timing and investment timing decisions Models for program decisions in safety Models for individual decisions in the event of uncertainty Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to identify the characteristics and manifestations of investments. You can use models or methods for assessing the benefits of one or more target variables, for useful life, replacement timing and investment timing decisions, for program decisions Security and for individual decisions in the event of uncertainty. You know the areas of application and limitations of the models and methods. With the help of the methods, you can also solve complex, realistic problems depicted in a case study and reflect on your solutions.

name: financing
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Finance and Banking
content: Content: Basic terms and objectives of financial activity Types of financing: external and internal financing, equity and external financing, in particular loan financing and share issuance/capital increase Overview of various financing instruments, basic principles of derivatives, especially options Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to define and explain the basic concepts of financial activity as well as classify and compare financing objectives, types of financing and financing instruments.

name: Basics of business informatics
degree-program: Professorship of Business Informatics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Business Process and Information Management
content: Content:Overview of the subject area of business informatics, possible uses and benefits of information systems in a business context, essential fundamentals of information and communication technologies Methods for modeling operational information systems, especially process and data modeling Introduction to software development for information systems Current topics in business informatics, especially in Context of digital transformation Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to name general terms in business informatics and explain and apply basic methodological and specialist knowledge on the use of information and communication technologies. You can create process and data models based on requirements. The students are able to assess the benefits of application systems in operational practice and make an appropriate selection. They are also able to make initial assessments of the role of modern information and communication technologies in the course of digital transformation.

name: Technical mechanics 1 and 2
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:Technical mechanics is a fundamental engineering discipline. An indispensable part of the constructive development of machines, devices and apparatus is the mechanical analysis of the components or assemblies loaded by static or dynamic forces. The investigation of tension and deformation as well as movement behavior (e.g. in the sense of vibrations) is of equal interest. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the student is able to understand, evaluate and solve concrete and mechanical engineering-typical tasks on statics, strength of materials, kinematics and kinetics. In addition, the student has developed an intuitive understanding of mechanical design and dimensioning issues.

name: Construction theory/machine elements I
degree-program: Professorship of Machine Elements and Product Development
content: Content:This module teaches the basics of technical drawing. For this purpose, the relevant standards and rules are explained and the skills for creating a technical drawing are trained. At the same time, the basics of computer-aided drawing creation are taught and practiced practically. Aim:The students are able to analyze technical drawings of simple machine systems and create drawings themselves on paper as well as in digital CAD systems.

name: Construction theory/machine elements II
degree-program: Professorship of Machine Elements and Product Development
content: Content:This module teaches the basics of designing mechanical components. This includes their development and construction and the general basic knowledge for their calculation. These basic principles are then applied, in accordance with the state of the art, as an example for the design, dimensioning and recalculation of components and assemblies. This content is deepened using the example of shafts and axes. Aim:Under supervision, the students are able to design and calculate mechanical components. They have also demonstrated basic knowledge of the systematic design of mechanical components.

name: Construction theory/machine elements III
degree-program: Professorship of Machine Elements and Product Development
content: Content:This module teaches - based on the basic knowledge from construction theory/machine elements II - the basics of typical machine elements, their structure, design and calculation. These include springs, screws, shaft-hub connections, connection types, roller bearings and gears. In this context, the development and design of small assemblies is taught. Aim:The students know the basics of typical machine elements and are able to increasingly design and calculate small assemblies sustainably from technical and economic aspects.

name: Materials
degree-program: Professorship of Materials Science
content: Content:The lectures convey essential fundamentals of materials science and technology. In the exercises and internships, the content is repeated and deepened through practical application. The module considers the relationships between the microstructure of materials and the resulting properties as well as processing and stress aspects. In addition, due to the highly interdisciplinary nature of modern materials science, the chemical-physical basics, thermodynamic aspects and elements of mechanical materials testing are taught. Because of their particular technical importance, the main topics of ferrous materials, light metals and heat treatment are treated in detail. But other metallic materials, ceramics and polymers are also taken into account according to their technical importance. Aim:The students have basic knowledge of materials, their microstructures and typical properties as well as the possibilities of using materials sensibly and responsibly. This enables them to competently handle material-related tasks in mechanical engineering and related disciplines.

name: Basic scientific and methodological competence
degree-program: Junior Professorship in European Management/Professorship in European Integration with a focus on European Administration
content: Content: Introduction and practice of the most important forms of scientific work, in particular methods of literature research (university catalogs, bibliographies, databases, etc.), basic skills in writing and presenting texts (Stylistics, rhetoric) as well as guidelines for writing notes, minutes, presentations and term papers Imparting general basics of social science research Aim:The students have basic knowledge of academic work and social science research. When preparing and developing your own scientific texts, you will follow the applicable guidelines for scientific and methodological work.

name: Introduction to cultural studies
degree-program: Professorship of Cultural and Social Change
content: Content:Presentation of the essential content, theoretical approaches and methodological concepts of cultural studies; Imparting basic knowledge of the central cultural studies paradigms of the 20th century; Comparison of important theoretical and methodological approaches; Application of the cultural studies perspective to the states of East Central Europe; Imparting basic knowledge about politics, economics, society and culture in the East Central European states Aim:The students acquire basic knowledge of the most important theories of cultural studies and are able to explain cultural manifestations of modern societies independently and reflectively. You will develop a comparative overview of the specifics of the societies in East Central Europe and relevant theoretical approaches from area studies and cultural studies.

name: Introduction to the social sciences
degree-program: Professorship of Human Geography with a focus on European migration research
content: Content:Introduction to basic social science questions with special consideration of sociological, political science and historical questions and problems; Introduction to techniques and methods of empirical social research Aim:The students have knowledge of the historical and political structuring of European societies. They understand the central basic concepts and theories of sociology and can use them to explain social phenomena and development dynamics. They know the scientific-theoretical foundations of empirical social research and the essential work steps in conducting social science and humanities studies. They also take into account the possibilities and limitations of various research methods, can interpret research results and classify them in a broader social scientific context.

name: Introduction to economics
degree-program: Dean of Studies for the bachelor's degree program in Economics
content: Content: Basic concepts and methodological approaches of economics Basic knowledge of microeconomics and macroeconomics National accounting Basic concepts and an overview of the development of business administration, goods cycles, personnel, legal and technical-economic structures of companies. Goals and target structures in companies/businesses Operational processes and decision-making situations in these processes Simulation game: IT-supported company and market simulation in which the participants take on the role of decision-makers. Please take it Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to name central economic categories and theoretical concepts in the important basic areas and explain their connections. In addition, they can explain central terms, concepts and methods of business administration, apply them to practical cases and describe fundamental business relationships.

name: Introduction to European law
degree-program: Professorship of European Integration with a focus on European Administration
content: Content:Imparting knowledge about the process of European integration and the structure of the European Union (EU) as well as about the role of law in the process of European integration and about its effectiveness and meaning; Imparting knowledge about the most important organs and institutions of the EU, their respective positions in the institutional structure of the EU, their role in the process of European integration, their tasks and status abilities, their way of working and their mutual interaction as well as their constitutional development Aim:The students are able to name and explain basic knowledge of EU law and the institutional structure of the European Union. They know the structures created by European integration and can represent them.

name: European Management I
degree-program: Junior Professorship in European Management
content: Content: Conceptual background of international management Strategic management in an international context Basic strategies of internationalization Development of research in international management Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to reproduce and explain basic knowledge about the economic context of internationalization as well as in the area of ​​international management and organization theory.

They are able to appreciate simple economic issues from a public law perspective by recognizing the problems they contain and finding a justifiable solution .

You will be able to exchange information with corporate lawyers or lawyers.

name: Mathematical foundations of big data analytics
degree-program: Dean of Studies for Data Science at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:The characteristic of Big Data is that the amounts of data to be processed are too large, too complex, too fast-moving or too weakly structured to be evaluated using manual and conventional data processing methods. In this module, basic mathematical models in the area of big data analytics are presented and an application-oriented reference to relevant economic issues is established. Mathematical tools from applied mathematics (in particular numerical linear algebra, statistics, optimization, game theory, graph theory, ordinary differential equations) are explained and applied to current problems of data analysis in an economic context. Aim:Contents: The characteristic of Big Data is that the amounts of data to be processed are too large, too complex, too fast-moving or too weakly structured to be evaluated using manual and conventional data processing methods. In this module, basic mathematical models in the area of ​​big data analytics are presented and an application-oriented reference to relevant economic issues is established. Mathematical tools from applied mathematics (in particular numerical linear algebra, statistics, optimization, game theory, graph theory, ordinary differential equations) are explained and applied to current problems of data analysis in an economic context.

name: Scientific work, research methodology and statistics
degree-program: Professorship for Research Methodology and Analysis Methods in Biomechanics
content: Content:In the module, skills in researching and dealing with scientific literature are trained. In addition, the creation of formally correct scientific texts is practiced, in particular the correct citing of scientific sources. In addition to the basics of scientific theory, essential aspects of good scientific practice, study plans, data acquisition techniques and methods of statistical data analysis are taught in empirical-quantitative research scenarios. Furthermore, basic knowledge of the computer-aided performance of statistical analyzes is imparted. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of literature search, literature management and literature preparation Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of good scientific practice with a focus on citation and intellectual property Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of preparing papers and presentations Ã¯Â ¿Â½ Knowledge of structured scientific work Ã¯Â¿Â½ Teaching basic concepts of scientific theory and methodological skills Ã¯Â¿Â½ Basic skills in the theoretical and empirical implementation, analysis and critical reflection or assessment of scientific work

name: Basics of biomechanics and movement science
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:In the Basics of Biomechanics and Movement Science lecture, basic knowledge of biomechanical relationships is imparted. Contents include the mechanical fundamentals of kinetics and kinematics, the biomechanical principles and the biomechanical properties of biological structures in a movement science context. In the associated exercise, the lecture content is deepened using practical application examples. Aim:The qualification goal of this module is to acquire basic knowledge of biomechanics and movement science. These are intended to enable people to understand human movement and thus serve as a basis for the areas of prevention and rehabilitation, sports equipment and medical technology.

name: Basics of sports psychology
degree-program: Managing Director of the Institute for Applied Movement Sciences
content: Content:In the lecture, this module provides a systematic overview of the subject areas of sports psychology with particular attention to prevention, rehabilitation and fitness. The focus is particularly on teaching central theoretical and methodological approaches. In the accompanying exercise, selected topics are discussed in more detail based on the current state of research. Sports psychological interventions are also taken into account. Aim:The students acquire basic knowledge of the psychological requirements and effects of sporting activity. The knowledge is deepened in the accompanying exercise. In addition, basic knowledge of the research methods of sport psychology is acquired. The students should be able to reflect critically and constructively on theoretical and practical research approaches.

name: Basics of training science
degree-program: Managing Director of the Institute for Applied Movement Sciences
content: Content:The students acquire basic training science knowledge. This module teaches models and components of motor and athletic performance as well as the planning, implementation and analysis of training. There is an introduction to competition theory. Aim:The students know and understand training-related adaptation and learning processes and the associated biological processes.

name: Anatomy and Physiology
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The module is intended to convey the biological basics of humans. Anatomical basics are acquired, which then explain the functional and anatomical connections of human movement. The physiological principles of metabolism (organs) are also discussed. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ basic anatomical and anatomical-functional knowledge Ã¯Â¿Â½ basic physiological knowledge and their influencing factors

name: Humanities and social science foundations of sport
degree-program: Managing Director of the Institute for Applied Movement Sciences
content: Content:The module includes courses on social conditions and individual requirements and circumstances of active and passive sports with particular reference to aspects of prevention, rehabilitation and fitness sports. Aim:The module enables students to understand the socio-economic framework of sport and, based on this, to make deductions for specific target groups in order to prepare people for prevention - to win rehabilitation and fitness sports. To do this, they acquire basic skills from sports sociology, sports management and sports education.

name: Motor skills
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:In the Motor Skills module, the basics of movement regulation and movement learning in movements in everyday life and sport are developed. This includes the relevant theoretical paradigms for movement regulation and motor learning of the 20th and 21st centuries, their empirical foundations and their significance for the practice of motor learning. In the exercise, the essential derivations of the different theoretical approaches for learning human movements in relation to perception, coordination and methodology/didactics of motor aspects are closely interlinked between theory and practice Developed. Experimental and quasi-experimental investigation procedures in motor research questions are also part of the module. Aim:The students should be able to grasp, classify and reflect critically and constructively on the basic motor aspects of sport and exercise.

name: Theory and practice of health sports
degree-program: Managing Director of the Institute for Applied Movement Sciences
content: Content:The module imparts theoretical knowledge and practical skills in various areas of health sports. In addition, there will be a four-week internship in the area of preventive and fitness sports. Aim:The focus of health-related training is the acquisition of professional-field-oriented action and communication skills. The results of the training are a content-related, methodological and organizational ability to instruct and carry out health-related activities for a wide range of target groups with the objectives of PRF sport.

name: Clinical basics of internal medicine and orthopedics/traumatology
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The module includes the disease theory of epidemiologically relevant diseases. Basic clinical terms are explained. In the clinical areas of internal medicine (COPD, cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, tumor disease, rheumatism, lipid metabolism disorders, kidney disease, asthma, digestion) and orthopedics/traumatology (fractures, Injuries and diseases of the shoulder, hip and knee joints, spinal diseases, amputation), the causes, pathophysiology, diagnostics and therapy are presented and discussed. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ basic knowledge of clinical terminology, inflammatory processes, autoimmune reaction, osteoarthritis, microbiology, hygiene, arteriosclerosis Ã¯Â¿Â½ basic knowledge of pathology and therapy of clinical indications in internal medicine and orthopedics Â¿Â½the/traumatology

name: Basics of sports therapy and physiotherapy
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The module deepens and teaches the clinical basics as well as the therapy of clinical indications. Furthermore, an overview of the health systems and decision-making criteria for guideline components of therapy should be obtained. Therapy paths related to the field of sports therapy are shown and discussed. name: Sports medicine and nutrition
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The module is intended to cover the biological basics of reaction and adaptation processes in the context of physical stress and human movement. Performance-physiological aspects under stress are discussed. This module teaches aspects of the influence of environmental conditions on physical performance. The basics of nutrition are also taught. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ basic physiological and performance-physiological knowledge and their influencing factors Ã¯Â¿Â½ knowledge of healthy nutrition, incorrect nutrition, substitution and supplementation

Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of functional, motor, orthopedic and internal diagnostics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Assessment and assessment of measurement and test results

name: Sports therapy for internal and orthopedic/traumatological indications
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The module deepens and teaches the clinical basics as well as the therapy of clinical indications. Current evidence-based training and therapy resources and methods are presented and critically reflected. The first practical sports therapy units are implemented as part of therapy trials. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Acquisition of in-depth knowledge of the organization, effect and content of sports therapy principles Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to plan and carry out sports therapy units, create therapy concepts for orthopedic/ traumatological and internal indications

name: Assessment procedures in movement sciences
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:In the lecture Assessment Methods in Movement Sciences, basic knowledge of diagnostic procedures is imparted. In addition to the measurement technology basics and general assessment procedures, the content also includes the assessment of the procedures with regard to their functional application, particularly in the fields of prevention, rehabilitation and fitness. In the associated exercise, the basic knowledge acquired is deepened in active group work with a specific application focus and taking current research trends into account. Aim:The qualification goal of this module is to acquire in-depth knowledge of measurement methods in movement sciences and basic knowledge of common assessment procedures. These should enable you to understand the basic principle of the procedures and, for open research questions, an adequate selection of diagnostic methods in the areas of prevention and rehabilitation as well as sports equipment ¯Â¿Â½te and medical technology.

name: Possibilities and limitations of the musculoskeletal system
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:The Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics lecture teaches the possibilities and limitations of the musculoskeletal system, particularly with regard to the functional interaction of its anatomical structures. The core content includes the differentiation of biological tissues, consideration of anatomical peculiarities of the spine, pelvis, knee and foot as well as the interaction of these anatomical structures from a therapeutically functional perspective. Basic knowledge of fascia as a body-wide network is also part of the teaching. The focus of the lecture on Disabled and Age-Specific Stresses is the acquisition of knowledge about the possibilities and limits of the musculoskeletal system, particularly with regard to the changed resilience in old age and of people with disabilities. The teaching content includes, among other things, different stress and strain concepts, the specific functional or damage specifics, the resulting social impairments and the teaching of suitable sports therapeutic intervention approaches. In the topic of perception phenomena, both theoretical and physiological basics of human perception are taught, in particular aspects of self-perception and the perception of the environment. The associated exercise offers in-depth insights into relevant practical and research-related content. Aim:The qualification goal of this module is to acquire in-depth biomechanical knowledge. These are intended to enable us to understand the functional interaction of the human musculoskeletal system in order to make sustainable contributions in the areas of prevention and rehabilitation as well as sports and medical technology.

name: Applied methodological competence
degree-program: All professorships in the Faculty of Human and Social Sciences and English department heads at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:Project: The module includes collaboration on one or two scientific research projects at the Institute for Applied Human Movement Sciences. You can choose from 5 projects with subject-specific topics relating to psychological, sports medicine, methodological, movement science or social issues of the institute's professorships. Exercise: Expansion of linguistic knowledge and skills with reference to study and career-oriented issues and situations, teaching the significant differences between oral and written communication (types of text, appropriate register), writing application documents; The training is based on language competency level B2 of the GER (Common European Framework of Reference for Languages) and includes a technical language component. Aim:Project: Participation in the project particularly promotes methodological skills and the ability to work in a team. In addition, skills and abilities in the development, implementation and evaluation of project-oriented empirical work and the presentation of concepts should be developed and demonstrated. The students should show that they can define goals for a larger task, develop interdisciplinary approaches and concepts and present results in an audience-oriented manner . Exercise: Confidence in coping with typical everyday academic situations (introducing people and areas of responsibility, naming and describing academic structures, etc.), further development of reading and listening strategies. If you choose the exercise, the completion of the module corresponds to language competency level B2 of the CEFR (Common European Framework of Reference for Languages) with a specialist language orientation.

name: Theoretical foundations
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on sociological theories
content: Content:The module ensures a thematic framing of the course content and provides in-depth knowledge in the area of sociological theory. The focus is on the systematic recording and close discussion of social conflict lines and integration arenas. The seminar on the topic of lines of conflict and arenas of integration in modern society acts as a problem-related introduction to sociological theory at an advanced level. Central lines of conflict in society are identified, disintegration dynamics are shown, power relationships are analyzed and mechanisms of cohesion are discussed. The focus of the content is on current conflicts between rich and poor, East and West, functional elites and the population, young and old, men and women or labor and capital. The seminar on the topic of collective identity and political culture serves to analyze and evaluate contemporary identity-political interpretation struggles from a sociologically informed perspective. On the one hand, this involves reflecting on contingent sources of identity formation (language, religion, ethnicity, nation, etc.). And on the other hand, it is about a discussion of the crucial question in democratic theory about the conditions for the possibility of stable, multicultural collectives in a world in which localists and globalists collide. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Acquisition of advanced knowledge about sociological theories Ã¯Â¿Â½ Acquisition of sound skills for analytical penetration and theory-based explanation of social phenomena Ã¯Â¿ Â½ Appropriation of objects close to the subject Knowledge about social mechanisms of integration and disintegration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Acquisition of the ability for theoretical reflection and sociological assessment of social conflicts Ã¯Â¿Â½ Development of the ability for critical assessment Â½Development of social problem-solving strategies

name: Methodological basics
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on empirical social research
content: Content:The module covers advanced techniques in quantitative and qualitative empirical social research for collecting and examining cross-sectional and longitudinal data using different research designs. The seminar Qualitative Methods of Social Research deepens practical research knowledge of interpretive methods through the use of different qualitative survey and analysis methods. The focus is on practical implementation and reflection on one's own research activities. The main topics covered include: Different forms of guided interviews Different questioning and conversation techniques in qualitative interviews Coding paradigm of grounded theory Basic modes of interpretation Structural testing methods of quantitative empirical social research are deepened in the following two seminars: In Quantitative Methods of Social Research, advanced techniques for analyzing cross-sectional data with non-experimental and (quasi)-experimental research designs are discussed. These include: Advanced regression techniques Confirmatory factor analysis Structural equation modeling with cross-sectional data Multilevel modeling Quasi-experimental research designs The Political Seminar Settings and In terms of content and application, Values in Change deals with quantitative methods of analyzing longitudinal data to examine the stability or social change of socio-political attitudes and values as well as to statistically test causal hypotheses . This includes, among others, the following techniques: Causal inference and path and mediator analysis Panel regression Structural equation modeling with longitudinal data Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to explain the logic of key advanced qualitative and quantitative methods; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Explain when and how which methods can be used; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to interpret statistical key figures in multivariate procedures and qualitative results; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to adequately use advanced methods to answer your own research questions; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Developing an appropriate research design for your own empirical work; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to carry out your own statistical analyzes using statistical software (e.g. SPSS / STATA / R / Mplus); Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to critically reflect on the strengths and weaknesses of advanced statistical methods; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Understand, interpret and critically question empirical research reports; Official announcements ______________________________________________________________________________________________________________ No. 23/2019 of June 18, 2019 553 Appendix 2: Module description for the consecutive course of study in sociology with a focus on social cohesion and conflict management with the Master of Arts degree Ã¯Â¿Â½ Conduct qualitative interviews and be able to critically reflect on interview design; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to interpret qualitative data with the help of software for computer-assisted data analysis (e.g. MAXQDA).

name: Cohesion and conflict
degree-program: Managing director of the Institute for Sociology, junior professorship in the sociology of technology with a focus on the Internet and new media
content: Content:The module examines integration and disintegration processes in modern societies. The seminar Democracy, Civil Society and Extremism deals with the analysis of changes in democratic structures and processes. The core topics are questions of legitimacy, ability to integrate and performance of democracies. In this context, it is particularly important to provide an empirically based insight into the threat to the basic democratic order posed by the emergence of extremist groups and the success of populist parties. As part of the seminar Digital Community and Separation, integration and disintegration processes that are caused, supported and reflected by digital media are dealt with at an advanced level. With particular attention to an internet and technological sociological perspective, the use of social media, but also the internet in general, is discussed with regard to the two extremes of community and isolation. Aim:The aim of the module is to get to know and theoretically understand the current scientific discussion about integration and disintegration processes in modern societies. The aim is to expand the ability to confront theoretical approaches with empirical findings and to question them critically. It also shows how scientific results, for example from extremism research, relate to current everyday issues and what implications arise. Another aim of the module is to convey the theoretical and methodological foundations as well as empirical research results of the sociology of technology and the Internet in relation to digital processes of community and isolation and thus the basis for independent scientific work in these to place fields. The students should be able to understand the specifics of digital integration and disintegration analytically at an advanced level and to compare classic modes. It is also planned to transfer the theoretical foundations and empirical research results into current real-world contexts.

name: Inequality and solidarity
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on work and organization
content: Content:This module provides important theoretical and empirical approaches to inequalities and solidarity in modern societies. The module provides in-depth insights into connections in modern societies (e.g. capital and labor, level of prosperity and trust, etc.). In addition to theoretical models to capture such connections, students gain in-depth insights into recent developments and debates surrounding the central dynamics and challenges in the field of paid work, which are in the area of tension between globalization, digitalization and financialization. In addition, macro-influences on individual dispositions are empirically examined in an international comparison. Aim:The aim of this module is to acquire knowledge in a problem-solving manner. The aim is to achieve a common basic understanding of the sociological foundations of modern societies, the most important structural change processes and the current restructuring phase. In addition, the students should deal with the topics of inequality and solidarity at a high level and develop their results on an evidence-based basis, also with reference to international comparative references.

name: Professional internship
degree-program: Director of the Institute for Sociology
content: Content:In this module, students can apply the knowledge they have acquired during their studies as part of an in-depth professional experience. The aim of the module is to gain in-depth experience with practical professional requirements and to gain a targeted orientation about possible professional fields. Due to its thematic and methodological orientation, the course of study particularly qualifies you for the following professional fields: - consulting and speaker work in business, politics, health and social services - work in the field of adult education, - research and Teaching in university and non-university institutions, - editing and publishing work, - international development cooperation, - public, cultural and media work as well as - market and opinion research. The internship should also be part of this professional spectrum. The students are supported in finding and carrying out an internship. The internship times are determined by the students, but should not affect the proper course of studies. Aim:Development of orientation knowledge on possible professional fields, development of professional search strategies, acquisition of practical professional experience

name: migration
degree-program: Professorship for Cultural and Regional Studies in East Central Europe, Professorship for Human Geography with a focus on European migration research
content: Content:Migration is one of the central issues in the current social development of East Central Europe and has had a major impact on the states in the region in recent years and decades. Furthermore, through the connection to the important migration destinations (Western Europe, USA), Western influences repeatedly reach the areas of origin of the migration and provide impetus for r economic and social modernization processes that are now the focus of transfer research. The module looks at both historical and current developments in migration and their regional patterns. In order to deepen the understanding of migration processes, the main theoretical approaches to migration and integration are conveyed and methodically implemented in the form of an empirical project. Aim:In the module, students acquire knowledge of the conceptual foundations of migration research and the main migration processes in East Central Europe before and after 1989. In addition, methodological knowledge of empirical social research is acquired and applied in practice. In addition, the associated introduction to investigation planning and social-empirical methodology promotes the students' professional qualifications.

name: European history
degree-program: Professorship of European History of the 19th and 20th Centuries
content: Content:Identification and exemplary analysis of long-term processes of cultural, economic, intellectual and political integration or segregation in Europe since the 18th century; Imparting in-depth knowledge of the emergence and formation of modern European nation states as well as the cultural, economic, technological and social similarities in Europe that are developing beyond the national political dividing lines; Basic knowledge about Europe's role in the world, especially in the tension between its direct neighbors Aim:Acquisition of basic knowledge of European history as well as learning historical methods and working techniques. Both qualification goals are intended to prepare graduates for professional practice in the context of European integration.

name: History of ideas and intellectual history
degree-program: Professorship of Political Theory and History of Ideas
content: Content:In the module, a variety of methodological approaches to the history of ideas and intellectual history are discussed. On this basis, ideological trends (including conservatism, socialism, fascism, liberalism), processes of change in political thinking and dynamics of the knowledge society will be examined more closely in a contextualizing and historicizing manner. The temporal focus is on the long 20th century. Aim:1.) Professional skills: The students acquire in-depth knowledge in the area of ​​political theory and the history of ideas, in particular about the trends in the history of ideas since the 19th century. They are able to illustrate connections between intellectual problems, social actors and political ideas using highlighted examples. 2.) Methodological skills: The students can develop their own questions and work on them in writing and orally using suitable methods. 3.) Social skills: The students can work on a question in a team and present their topic to the seminar public.

name: Comparative government theory
degree-program: Professorship European government systems in comparison
content: Content:The module systematically compares government systems. The aim is to gain a broad insight into the structure and functioning of European government systems. Non-European references are also made and non-European government systems are included in the comparison - not least to make European characteristics clear. The focus is on comparing institutions, in which newer approaches (e.g. neo-institutionalism) are of course taken into account. Aim:The module serves both the normative and theoretical understanding of political issues and the systematic empirical investigation of political science issues.

name: Visual practices of identity construction and community formation
degree-program: Professorship of Visual Communication and Media Sociology
content: Content:Imparting in-depth knowledge of empirical methods of visual communication research, media and visual culture theory, and the history of visual media Aim:Ability to systematically collect and qualitatively evaluate empirical and historical visual media practices and cultures for the construction of identity and community in cross-media contexts and to classify them into media and cultural theory

name: Integration module
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on sociological theories
content: Content:The integration module deals with the central subject areas, theoretical tools and methodological procedures that are addressed within the scope of the degree program. The long-term institutional exchange between students from the first and third semesters is intended to promote a sense of belonging within the course of study and to facilitate the interactive exchange about the content of the course between different cohorts . In this way, mutual learning processes should be initiated. The focus is on the critical examination of planned or already implemented teaching research projects. The block seminar integration module: Preparation of teaching research projects serves as a forum for students in the first semester to develop and discuss ideas for the teaching research projects (M5-M7) that begin in the following semester. The preparation is made easier by the joint exchange with students from the third semester. In the seminar Integration Module: Presentation of the teaching research projects, the students present central results from their ongoing or completed teaching research projects to their fellow students from the first semester as part of the block event. In doing so, they acquire skills and competencies in the precise presentation, appropriate visualization and defense of their own research results. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Generation of viable ideas for your own research projects Ã¯Â¿Â½ Transformation of the course content through the interactive exchange between different course cohorts Ã¯Â¿Â½ Sharpening the eye for ¿ Â½For social phenomena Ã¯Â¿Â½ Deepening of existing presentation and argumentation skills through the presentation and defense of one's own studies Ã¯Â¿Â½ Deepening of the skills for critical commentary, assessment and discussion of sociological research

name: Didactic basics
degree-program: Professorship of Vocational and Business Education
content: Content:General open-subject didactics: The examination of the model of general open-subject didactics serves as a comprehensive introduction to fundamental didactic considerations that are necessary in the design of teaching and learning processes. This includes determining goals, making didactic decisions, selecting topics and methods, and evaluating. Macrodidactics: Within the macrodidactics course, the institutional framework such as legal and organizational conditions for didactic action are considered. Furthermore, the focus is on vocational training in a globalized world. National and international aspects of vocational training, current questions about vocational training and the basics of labor and vocational training law are discussed. Aim:Overall, the students' level of knowledge in the core areas (vocationomy and the basic subject) should be improved. In this module, students should acquire basic knowledge in the field of general didactics. You acquire skills for designing teaching and learning processes in vocational training. The students should acquire the skills to reflect and analyze educationally relevant problems as well as basic knowledge of school and labor law for vocational training.

name: Grundlagenwissen vokationomischer Nachbarwissenschaften
degree-program: Professorship of Vocational and Business Education
content: Content:In this module, students should choose from the range of related vocationomic sciences. In the business administration focus, knowledge from the areas of taxation and auditing, marketing and commercial management, accounting and controlling, finance and banking management, production management as well as industrial management and also business information technology should be imparted. In the economic focus, knowledge from the areas of microeconomics, macroeconomics, financial science and economic policy should be conveyed. Aim:The students adapt their knowledge of economics to the level necessary for the further course of their studies and continue to have the opportunity to acquire basic knowledge in other related disciplines that will help them specialize in further studies.

name: Philosophy of science and research methods
degree-program: Professorship of Vocational and Business Education
content: Content:Scientific-theoretical and methodological questions that are important in connection with vocationomy are discussed. Epistemological basics, logical-semantic prodeutics as well as argumentation and proof theory are covered. The problems of concept, theory and model formation in the natural, technical and human sciences are discussed. Quantitative and qualitative methods of empirical social research should also be dealt with centrally, starting with research planning and implementation, through the clarification of measurement theory problems and also questions of research design, data acquisition and collection . Aim:By taking part in this module, students should be able to reflect on other people's and their own scientific activities and to be able to place them within a broader meta-theoretical framework. In addition, basic methodological knowledge of empirical social research should be acquired or deepened.

name: Historical and systematic vocationomy
degree-program: Professorship of Vocational and Business Education
content: Content:Basic questions of vocational education: In the event, which is designed as a lecture seminar, the basic vocationomic phenomena of profession, work and education are addressed and reflected and discussed in a diachronic and synchronous perspective. Historical and systematic vocationomy: The core of the event is the examination of the systematics of the subject vocationomy and its systematic position in the canon of subjects. This is done on the basis of a historical examination of the genesis of the subject. This essentially includes the treatment of the central phenomenon in educational theory of the exclusion of vocational educational content from the educational mandate through new humanism. Another central topic of the lecture is the treatment of the complementarity theory of education. Aim:In this module, students should gain an overview of the historical genesis of the subject and understand scientific arguments in their respective historicity and contextuality, but also understand their relevance. Â½Check your ability to deal with current problems. In addition, they should acquire essential knowledge of the subject using a clearly structured system or transfer the knowledge they have already learned into clearly structured cognitive contexts.

name: Basic didactic internship with exercises for preparation and follow-up
degree-program: Professorship of Vocational and Business Education
content: Content:Practice of vocational training and further education, especially in the commercial area, as well as reflection on these experiences. In addition to participating in the teaching process and then reflecting on it, the students should prepare, carry out and think about teaching units themselves. Aim:The students should acquire knowledge and experience with regard to the preparation, implementation and evaluation of lessons in vocational (especially commercial) training and further education. They should also gain experience about everyday life at vocational institutions. In addition, the event is intended to prepare students for the training aptitude test to be carried out externally in accordance with the Instructor Suitability Ordinance.

name: Reference sciences of vocationomy
degree-program: Professorship of Vocational and Business Education
content: Content:Teaching and learning in the workplace and in the company (formerly in-company pedagogy): Special features of teaching and learning at the company learning location, including aspects of organizational and personnel development Economic education: considered the educational goal of commercial training In addition to economic specialist knowledge, you also need to have knowledge of the scope of economic anthropology and the explanatory approaches derived from it. In this context, (economic) ethical and moral pedagogical questions should be addressed. Aim:The students should deepen their basic knowledge of in-company training work in order to be able to understand fundamental pedagogical connections independently. From a business education perspective, this also includes the classification of commercial activities within the frame of reference for society as a whole. The students should therefore also deal with questions of the image of humanity and questions of ethical and practical morality in economic activity. They should be able to analyze and evaluate commercial actions on a theoretical level from various specialist perspectives and derive implications for concrete business educational issues.

name: Vocational training research
degree-program: Professorship of Vocational and Business Education
content: Content:The events in this module are specifically geared towards current questions in subject-specific research. The module can cover topics that relate to the areas of didactics and educational economics or vocationomically relevant questions from the neighboring scientific disciplines of economics, pedagogy, philosophy, sociology (especially educational sociology ) or psychology (especially learning theory). The module covers in-depth issues of didactic diagnostics and takes into account the growing importance of evaluation tasks in the field of vocational education. Aim:The students should be encouraged to engage in independent scientific engagement with current research topics. With regard to future teaching activities and evaluation tasks, central diagnostic knowledge and skills should be acquired.

name: European institutions/administration/law
degree-program: Professorship of European Integration with a focus on European Administration
content: Content:General or exemplary presentation, development and discussion of fundamental questions of EU law, in particular the role of law in the process of European integration, the emergence of EU law, the manifestations and effects of EU law. Law, the law-making actors and the implementation and enforcement of the law; Presentation and discussion of the most important EU institutions and their interaction; Dealing with important EU policy areas with an emphasis on legal aspects; Examination of the future of the EU, in particular its enlargement and contractual development Aim:Acquisition and reflection of basic knowledge in the field of European integration (with emphasis on the legal aspects), thereby contributing to the qualification of graduates for a professional activity with reference to European ¿Â½ic integration should be carried out.

name: Research methodology
degree-program: Professorship for Research Methods and Analysis Methods in Biomechanics
content: Content:The module is intended to hone the ability to work empirically and scientifically in a theoretical and practical way. To do this, we first examine general and subject-specific scientific-theoretical concepts. In addition, research methods, study designs and data analysis procedures for empirical research scenarios with a movement science orientation are developed. The training sessions teach the basics of programming and the implementation of statistical data analysis methods in movement science. The lecture and exercise Research Methodology II build consecutively on the lecture and exercise Research Methodology I. Aim:The students have in-depth theoretical knowledge of empirical research and data analysis methods as well as application skills for their practical implementation in suitable software packages. You are able to use computer-aided data analyzes in your own research work.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Pedagogical and psychological aspects of health promotion
degree-program: Professorship for Social Scientific Perspectives on Sport, Exercise and Health Promotion
content: Content:The module deals with educational and psychological research on the importance of activity behavior in prevention, rehabilitation and public health. Theoretical concepts (social cognitive theory, HAPA model) and approaches from health education and psychology are discussed in depth with regard to health promotion, taking demographic developments into account. Basics, concepts and methods (e.g. for increasing self-efficacy, action planning) for the initiation and maintenance of health behavior in the context of health promotion are discussed and related to specific target groups (e.g. children, older people) and settings (e.g. kindergarten, school, rehabilitation/care facilities). Aim:After completing the module, students will have in-depth knowledge of various health behavior models and their application for specific target groups as well as various determinants of behavior change. They also know and understand the importance of e-health and m-health in health promotion. The students are able to plan interventions for various settings and target groups and can design, implement, evaluate and reflect on health promotion programs in a theory-driven and evidence-based manner in the sense of methodological competence. You research and read relevant specialist literature independently and in a targeted manner. They write down and present the results of their work at a scientific level. The students are still able to carry out these activities in cooperation and shared communication (social skills). You can coordinate and structure work processes in small groups, argue your own point of view and critically reflect on and take into account the perspectives of others.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Biomechanical ergonomics
degree-program: Professorship for Research Methods and Analysis Methods in Biomechanics
content: Content:The module addresses the meaning and benefits of biomechanical methods in the context of workplace design - especially in physical activities. First, there is a theoretical foundation of biomechanical-ergonomic practices for the design and evaluation of work processes and work environments. Methods and models commonly used - in particular a selection of digital human models - are presented and critically reflected. In addition to the theoretical foundation, selected practical applications are examined in more detail. Based on this, consequences for the ergonomically sensible design of work processes and environments are derived. Aim:The students have in-depth knowledge of the interaction of biomechanical and health aspects in the workplace and the application-specific possibilities and limitations of biomechanical measurement systems. You can classify and interpret biomechanical-ergonomic measurement data in the working environment and critically reflect on biomechanical methods and the use of digital (human) models against the background of concrete applications.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Measurement and testing procedures in movement sciences
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:The module provides in-depth knowledge of the already acquired basics of the application of movement and neuroscientific measurement and testing methods. The lecture includes the theoretical basics of application-oriented measurement and testing procedures, possibilities and limits of use as well as evaluation and interpretation of suitable parameters. In the exercise, this content is deepened by working on practical, current movement and neuroscientific issues. Aim:The students acquire complex knowledge about the possibilities and limitations of common movement and neuroscientific measurement and testing procedures. Research problems are identified independently and analyzed using selected measurement and test procedures. This enables students to select measurement and test procedures relevant to specific questions, to interpret collected parameters and to discuss and critically evaluate findings from a movement and neuroscientific perspective.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Training science and diagnostics
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The module includes courses on specific topics in training science and various procedures and methods of physical performance diagnostics. The effect of physical training on the organism/organ systems and their importance for increasing performance are discussed. Furthermore, training trends and their physiological effects are discussed and critically reflected. Tests for diagnosing physical performance are discussed theoretically and carried out in practice, and options for analysis and interpretation are shown. Aim:The students have in-depth knowledge of the methodology, evaluation and interpretation of physical performance diagnostics. The students are able to design the content of effective training and movement concepts for the respective goal and to assess the effectiveness of training methods and training materials. You are able to adapt the training and exercise concepts to the specific requirements of the target groups.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Motor skills - development, control, learning
degree-program: Director of the Institute for Applied Movement Sciences
content: Content:The module is intended to provide in-depth knowledge in various areas of motor skills research. This includes basic theoretical and physiological approaches to motor development, motor control and motor learning, technical training and training methods in specific target groups. Aim:The students have in-depth knowledge of motor development, motor control and movement control. You have in-depth knowledge of various motor learning theories as well as of stresses and strains on the musculoskeletal system of different age groups and their use in different settings.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Physical activity and health
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The module contains specific topics on the health importance of physical activity. The effect and effectiveness of physical activity and exercise programs on the organism/organ systems in children, adults and seniors are discussed. Aim:The students have in-depth knowledge of the effectiveness of physical activity and specific movement concepts. The students are able to design the content and adapt it to the specific requirements of the target groups.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Health and quality management
degree-program: Professorship for Social Scientific Perspectives on Sport, Exercise and Health Promotion
content: Content:The module includes economic and management-related aspects, with particular attention to the quality factor, and their specific application in healthcare organizations. Essential management-specific facets are highlighted in order to develop a fundamental understanding of operational processes in healthcare organizations. In addition, quality-related standards in the health sector are conveyed and their controllability is reflected on. Aim:The students have knowledge about the economic characteristics of health-related markets, goods and their demand. The students are able to act competently in organizations in the healthcare sector thanks to their business knowledge.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Medical trainings therapy
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The module is based on the basics of anatomy and physiology as well as the medical basics of orthopedics, internal diseases and neurology. Theoretically and practically in-depth knowledge of sports and exercise therapy device-assisted measures for internal, orthopedic/traumatological and neurological diseases is acquired. In addition, special indication-specific test procedures for assessing body function and structure for clinical practice are discussed and tested. Aim:The students can carry out indication-specific individual training planning and training implementation for patients with orthopedic/traumatological/rheumatological, internal medicine and neurological diseases. You will master the safe and effective use of specific training equipment and resources. The students are able to use clinical test procedures for specific indications, assess the results and use them to control training.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Clinical internship
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The internship must take place in inpatient and outpatient rehabilitation clinics/health centers (scope: 150 AS). The practical activities should be carried out in medical training therapy, functional diagnostics and movement therapy group therapy. Under supervision, the students carry out functional and motor test procedures on patients, evaluate the test results and, together with their mentor from the respective clinical institution, consider the conception of the therapeutic approach. The students create training plans in medical training therapy and evaluate individual therapy courses. For this purpose, motor and functional test procedures are carried out on selected patients by the student under supervision. There is active participation in therapy control. Furthermore, a patient seminar will take place as part of the clinical facility's health education program. Aim:The students have practical experience in the clinical field of sports and training therapy. Under supervision, you can carry out functional and motor test procedures on patients, evaluate test results and design therapeutic approaches. Furthermore, the students are able to create training plans in medical training therapy and evaluate individual therapy courses as well as impart health-related and practical training expertise in a patient-friendly manner.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Sports therapy for neurological diseases
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:The module includes courses on the medical, sports and exercise therapy basics of neurological diseases. The epidemiology, etiology, diagnostics and medical therapy of diseases such as stroke, paraplegia, nerve lesions, muscle diseases, Parkinson's disease, visual impairment and dementia are covered. Sports and exercise therapy measures for the treatment of neurological diseases are discussed, which are developed both theoretically and practically (observations). Aim:The students have basic knowledge of the effects of exercise and training on neurological diseases. You can design, guide and assess treatment approaches in sports and exercise therapy areas with regard to their impact and effectiveness.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Sports medicine project
degree-program: Professorship of Sports Medicine / Sports Biology
content: Content:Empirical research work is carried out in the project. The students are actively integrated into the planning, implementation and evaluation of empirical research projects and acquire in-depth knowledge of current research topics, questions, specific methods and relevant literature in the field of sports medicine. Aim:The students know and understand the necessary work steps for planning, carrying out and evaluating empirical research work and can implement these under supervision. You have in-depth knowledge of current theories and specific methods related to the research topic being discussed. Students can practically apply statistical knowledge to analyze data sets and write research projects at a scientific level.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Movement science A
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:In the Biomechanics and Sensory Lecture, this module provides in-depth knowledge of the complex interaction between human sensory and motor skills from a biomechanical perspective. Another focus is on current scientific trends in this scientific area. The Clinical Gait Analysis exercise provides in-depth knowledge of the complexity of human walking movements. With the help of modern movement science measurement methods, theoretically developed content is applied in the form of practical gait analyses. The application of these measurement methods and their results are analyzed and discussed. Aim:The students gain comprehensive knowledge of the interaction between sensory and motor systems. This will enable you to record, analyze and interdisciplinarily link complex movement science issues. The students will be able to independently carry out instrumented gait analyzes on patients using selected measurement methods. Deviations in the physiological walking movement should be recognized and their effects on the complexity of the movement should be described and interpreted.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Introduction to health reporting
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on health research
content: Content:The module introduces concepts and methods of health reporting and descriptive epidemiology. Among other things, the students learn about different data sources, data holders, indicator sets and classifications of health reporting as well as their importance for public health. In addition, various indicators and methodological procedures of descriptive epidemiology are presented and calculated or applied by the students themselves in the context of selected application examples. Voluntary short presentations by students are planned. Aim:The students acquire in-depth knowledge of the most important methodological fundamentals and skills of health reporting/descriptive epidemiology. This lays the foundation for independent scientific work in this area as well as for researching and dealing with health-related data. At the same time, the focus is on later professional activity in the practice of health reporting.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Attention and eye movements
degree-program: Dean of Studies Sensory Science and Cognitive Psychology (B.Sc., M.Sc.) at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content:This module covers methods of attention measurement, models of attention processes as well as methods and applications of eye movement measurement. Aim:The students acquire knowledge about attention processes and models, about current methods of eye movement measurement as well as about modern analysis techniques for attention processes and eye movements.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: In-depth aspects of health management
degree-program: Professorship for Social Scientific Perspectives on Sport, Exercise and Health Promotion
content: Content:The module includes topics of corporate health management in different settings and highlights the various stakeholders in this area. In addition, topics related to starting a business in the health sector are covered. Aim:The students have knowledge of company health management and the organization of health promotion programs. You can design and implement health-related support programs in companies. The students also know and understand the business basics that are necessary for preparing and planning professional independence in the health and sports sectors.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Internship
degree-program: Professorship for Social Scientific Perspectives on Sport, Exercise and Health Promotion
content: Content:The internship can be completed in community health promotion facilities and in health care companies (scope: 150 AS). The practical activities should primarily be carried out in the area of health promotion and health management. The students gain practical experience in professional fields relevant to their studies and use the skills and competencies they have acquired. There is active participation in the internship facility. Aim:The students acquire in-depth knowledge of solving problems independently and in professional practice, and experience their effects and their exchange in their chosen professional field. The students can independently identify relevant movement-related, social and management-related professional fields in the health sector. You have initial experience of their professional requirements, professional behavior and work processes in a practice area of ​​your own choosing. The students are able to apply movement-related knowledge and methods in the areas of health management and health promotion under the guidance of a mentor to deal with complex problems and to further develop them in the context of practical activities. They also know the specific role expectations in their field of practice and can take these into account in their professional actions.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Movement science B
degree-program: Professorship of Movement Science
content: Content:In the Biomechanics and Sensory Lecture, this module provides in-depth knowledge of the complex interaction between human sensory and motor skills from a biomechanical perspective. Another focus is on current scientific trends in this scientific area. The biomechanical performance diagnostics exercise includes current questions about performance diagnostic aspects in movement science. In-depth knowledge of biomechanical performance diagnostics, analysis of scientific texts, processing of empirical research questions, data collection and evaluation in the area of prevention and rehabilitation is imparted. Aim:The students have extensive knowledge of the interaction between sensory and motor systems. You are able to record, analyze and interdisciplinarily link complex movement science issues. Starting with a literature analysis and the development of scientific questions and measurement methodology through to data acquisition, evaluation of results and interpretation, the biomechanical performance diagnostics exercise contributes to further scientific qualification.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Social science project
degree-program: Professorship for Social Scientific Perspectives on Sport, Exercise and Health Promotion
content: Content:The module discusses current empirical research work by the professorship responsible for the module. The students are actively integrated into the planning, implementation and evaluation of empirical research projects and acquire in-depth knowledge of current research topics, questions, specific methods and relevant literature in the area of work of the professor responsible for the module. Aim:The students have knowledge of planning, carrying out and evaluating empirical research work. They are familiar with current theories regarding social scientific approaches to sport and the application of specific methods to the research topics covered. The students can carry out statistical analyzes of a data set independently and have the ability to write down planned research projects in a compact form.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Social scientific perspectives on sport, exercise and health promotion
degree-program: Professorship for Social Scientific Perspectives on Sport, Exercise and Health Promotion
content: Content:The module addresses current developments and innovations in health and fitness sports from a socio-economic perspective. The peculiarities of various stakeholders and target groups are taken into account and derivations for the development of specific sustainable and future-proof offers (e.g. digitalization in the fitness industry) in developing markets (e.g. active tourism) are highlighted. Aim:The students are familiar with the changing conditions and requirements for health and fitness sports and can identify trends in this area. In addition, the students are able to correctly assess the challenges of the socio-economic framework for health and fitness sports and to draw scientifically based conclusions from them.
program: Movement science in prevention and rehabilitation

name: Wind and hydropower plants and their control
degree-program: Professorship of Electrical Energy Conversion Systems and Drives
content: Content: Modeling and optimization of control systems Physical fundamentals, structure/mode of operation, overall concept of wind turbines Physical fundamentals, structure/mode of operation, overall concept of conventional hydroelectric power plants, tidal and wave power plants Generators of wind and hydropower plants and their regulation Properties of batteries, selection criteria for their use, current and voltage regulation of the required chargers Aim:The students have knowledge of the structure and operation of modern wind and hydroelectric power plants. You know various control strategies for increasing energy efficiency in renewable electrical energy generation systems and can model control systems of modern electrical energy systems and mechatronic systems.

name: Stress on operating resources
degree-program: Professorship of Energy and High Voltage Technology
content: Content: Stresses on insulation due to external and internal overvoltages, traveling wave propagation and overvoltage protection, control of the power arc Switching arcs and contact theory Thermal and mechanical stress on equipment Aim:The students have knowledge of the classification and description of the stresses on equipment caused by internal and external overvoltages, traveling waves, arcs and short-circuit faults ¿Â½me, heat calculations, design principles of equipment, especially switches. You will be able to apply this knowledge practically in laboratory experiments.

name: Components of power electronics / power semiconductor devices
degree-program: Professorship of Power Electronics
content: Content:1. Special features of power electronic components 2. semiconductor-physical basics 2.1 Properties of the semiconductor, physical basics 2.2 pn-berglight 2.3 Insert in the manufacturing technology 3rd semi-cable models 3.1 PIN Diodes 3.2 Schottky diodes transistors 3.4 Thyristors 3.5 MOS transistors 3.6 IGBTs 4. Introduction to construction and connection technology Aim:The students have an understanding of the semiconductor physics processes in power components and have mastered the special features of the respective component. They can practically apply their knowledge and skills in laboratory experiments.

name: Theory of electrical machines
degree-program: Professorship of Electrical Energy Conversion Systems and Drives
content: Content: Force and torque formation, space vector theory, coordinate transformations Dynamic behavior of winding arrangements Dynamic behavior and investigation of special operating states of asynchronous and synchronous machines Description of the dynamic Behavior of the direct current machine with the help of equations of state Signal flow plans of the most important electrical machines Aim:The students know theoretical connections in electromagnetic energy conversion. They have knowledge and foeic knowledge of scientific calculation and analysis methods for dynamic pre-gender in electromagnetic energy converter and Kã asp Â¿Â½permanent processing of tasks to calculate the behavior of such systems. In addition, they have the ability to handle the control technology of automated drive systems.

name: Fuel cells and fuel cell systems I
degree-program: Professorship for Alternative Vehicle Drives
content: Content: Introduction to fuel cell and hydrogen technology (energy problems, history, types and areas of application, hydrogen properties) Hydrogen technology (production, storage, overall energy consideration) Physical-chemical basics of fuel cells (chemical reactions, thermodynamics) fuel cell systems (structure, module components, efficiencies) Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to explain and calculate the basic electrochemical system of a fuel cell, in particular the main reactions that occur, fuel cell types and their characteristics. The students can name the essential properties of hydrogen and recognize their potential hazards. They are also able to describe the structure and function of a fuel cell and a fuel cell system.

name: Reliability and robustness of power electronic systems
degree-program: Professorship of Power Electronics
content: Content: Construction and connection technology as well as thermo-mechanical problems of power electronic systems Calculation, design, realization of a power semiconductor component, interpretation, quality requirements, project management Destruction mechanisms in Power components, characteristic failure patterns Switching power supplies and DC-DC converters: topologies, exemplary design Selected topics of electromagnetic compatibility Integration of power electronic systems: monolithic integration, integration on circuit boards base , hybrid integration via simulation of selected dynamic switching and overload cases Aim:The students have knowledge and skills in the design and calculation of power electronic systems. Dynamic switching and overload processes can be reproduced through simulation and related to various fields of application. You are able to solve engineering tasks in this area independently and also act in an interdisciplinary manner.

name: physics
