degree-program: Dean of Physics Studies at the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content:Part 1: Mechanics: kinematics, dynamics, conservation laws, translational and rotational movements, oscillations and waves, gravity, relativity Thermodynamics: entropy, quantity of matter, chemical Potential Part 2: Electricity: charge, current, fields, matter in fields, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves Optics: light as a wave, interference, light as a particle, interaction with matter Nuclear and particle physics: isotopes, radioactivity, nuclear reactions, elementary particles Aim:The students are enabled to understand the fundamental connections of physics and to apply them to scientific questions.

name: Higher mathematics
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all degree programs in the Faculty of Mathematics (except Data Science and the International Master's and Doctoral degree programs)
content: Content:Mathematics is an important fundamental discipline for engineering and natural science courses. It provides the instruments, the mathematical structures and methods for solving technical problems. The main focus of the module is the following: Basics (logic, set theory, number ranges) Differential and integral calculus for functions of a variable Differential calculus for Functions of several variables Basic concepts of linear algebra and linear optimization Ordinary differential equations Aim:Sufficiently good knowledge of mathematics, including terms, structures and methods, is a basic requirement for the successful completion of a technical degree. The aim of the module is for the student to acquire the necessary basic knowledge. The student masters the mathematical concepts and the mathematical calculus with the aim of having a solid basis for the independent formulation and solution of mathematical problems, which occur particularly in technical applications. The aim of the internships is to acquire methodological skills in the independent application of mathematical concepts and solution methods. The internships replace part of the working hours that would otherwise be spent on self-study.

name: Chemistry of main and subgroup elements
degree-program: Professorship of Coordination Chemistry
content: Content:The module provides knowledge about material properties and the reaction behavior of inorganic compounds. Large-scale technical processes in inorganic chemistry are discussed. The knowledge is deepened through selected demonstration experiments. The module consists of two parts on the topic of main and subgroup element chemistry and is supplemented by a day excursion. Part 1: Basic concepts of inorganic chemistry, basics of the representation, properties and reaction behavior of the main group elements and their compounds Part 2: Basics of the representation of the subgroup elements and their compounds, group properties and complex chemistry, electron configurations, stability of Oxidation states, bonding models Aim:The students learn the basic structure of the periodic table and can derive chemical connections based on structural similarities between the elements of individual groups. You will be able to understand the basics of inorganic chemistry and transfer the reaction behavior to new classes of compounds. The students are able to understand and safely apply simple chemical models of structure and reactivity.

name: Introduction to preparative inorganic chemistry
degree-program: Professorship of Inorganic Chemistry
content: Content:Internship: Introduction to inorganic synthetic chemistry, taking into account generally applicable representation methods such as: B. redox reactions, neutralization reactions, salt formation, complexation and solid-state reactions; Single- and multi-step syntheses; Production and implementation e.g. B. of Grignard compounds or other metal-organic compounds for basic learning of the anaerobic working method; Isolation of the compounds represented by crystallization, distillation and column chromatography Check of the level of knowledge on the exact procedure for the representation of the compounds, hazard potential of the chemicals used and suitable protective measures , information e.g. B. About the structure of the compounds (solid-state structure or Lewis formula) and typical uses Elemental analysis, IR, UV/Vis and NMR investigations of synthe - tized connections with the aim of identity and purity clarification and for basic learning of these analysis methods Seminar: Accompanying seminar to the content of the internship experiments Aim:The students learn the basic requirements for representing inorganic compounds - even under inert gas - and expand their knowledge of general chemistry and inorganic chemistry. The various representation and isolation methods give you an impression of the effort and under what conditions inorganic substances can be synthesized. Taking possible reactivities into account, the students specifically learn how to make suggestions for the representation of simple inorganic compounds and how to implement these suggestions in practice. The students are able to suggest methods with which the identity or purity of substances can be determined.

name: Physical Chemistry 1: Thermodynamics
degree-program: Professorship of Physical Chemistry, Professorship of Physical Chemistry/Electro-chemistry [changing annually]
content: Content:Lecture "PC1 Thermodynamics" - Temperature measurement - Ideal and real gases - State variables and functions - Main principles of thermodynamics - Definition and meaning of: work and heat transfer as well as temperature, internal energy, enthalpy, entropy, free energy and free enthalpy heat engines, Heat pumps, efficiency, Carnot process Statistical definition of entropy (Boltzmann equation) Boltzmann distribution Phase equilibria, Clausius-Clapeyron equation, Gibbs pha - senregel Calorimetry, heat of reaction, Hess law Free enthalpy of reaction Entropy of mixing, energy of mixing Equilibria between coexisting mixed phases Phase diagrams of mixed phases - Raoult's and Henry's laws, distillation, extraction - chemical equilibrium, law of mass action - deriving physical-chemical laws - partial molar sizes, chemical potential Aim:The students are able to systematically explain natural phenomena, technical processes and chemical reactions on the basis of equilibrium thermodynamics, and to use methods for experimental determination and shearing. To propose the use of thermodynamic data to explain heat engines and heat pumps as well as alternative operating principles for the use of chemical energy to perform work or to transport heat ¿Â½ to explain the strengths and weaknesses of each active principle Ã¯Â¿Â½ to show ways to influence phase equilibria Ã¯Â¿Â½ to assess whether a particular one chemical reaction can in principle take place under given boundary conditions and what potential heat development can be expected Ã¯Â¿Â½ to develop strategies to increase the yield of chemical reactions Ã¯Â¿Â½ physical and to design and control chemical processes sensibly and to independently derive further physical-chemical laws from known, mathematically describable basic knowledge

name: Introduction to scientific working methods
degree-program: Director of the Institute for Sociology
content: Content:The module introduces the techniques of scientific work through practical exercises. Topics include: systematic literature search, information preparation, writing scientific texts, and learning presentation techniques. Aim:The aim is to acquire basic skills for independent scientific work.

name: General Sociology: Basics
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on sociological theories
content: Content:The module conveys basic knowledge of sociological theory and theory history on three levels. Firstly, basic information is provided on the history of the development of sociology, on the subject and methodological understanding of the sociological classics and on newer theoretical directions. This basic information is supplemented by self-study of selected texts. This second level offers the opportunity to familiarize yourself with sociological methods of argumentation and is intended to enable you to critically examine sociological theoretical approaches. Furthermore, the aim is to learn how to write scientific papers on relatively limited topics. Aim:Acquisition of the basics of the most important sociological theories, ability to critically examine sociological theories

name: Introductory lectures in special sociologies
degree-program: Director of the Institute for Sociology (with the professorships of sociology with a focus on health research, sociology with a focus on sociological theories, sociology with a focus on work and organization and the junior professorship of sociology of technology with a focus on the Internet and new media)
content: Content:The lectures cover the central terms, theories, research methods and research areas as well as, if necessary, significant empirical studies as well as relevant professional fields of the special sociologies represented at the institute - sociology of technology, sociology of health, sociology of health, etc Political sociology as well as work and organizational sociology. Aim:The aim of the lectures is to provide an introductory overview of the four specialist areas represented at the Institute of Sociology and to impart broad, fundamental knowledge of sociological research fields. The students should also be able to make a qualified choice of their further study areas (modules M9, M10, M11 and M12).

name: Special problems and techniques of qualitative social research
degree-program: Director of the Institute for Sociology
content: Content:Building on module M5, the module provides an in-depth understanding of the theoretical and research methodological foundations of qualitative empirical social research. The knowledge will be deepened in a second course using the example of selected problems and practical applications. Aim:The aim of the module is to acquire the basic theoretical and practical knowledge of qualitative empirical social research.

name: Social structure analysis and social comparison
degree-program: Director of the Institute for Sociology
content: Content:In this module, basic knowledge of social structure analysis as an important area of application of empirical social research and elementary skills in dealing with socio-demographic indicators are imparted. This includes an overview of the distribution of important social parameters in German society, knowledge of similarities and differences in the social structure of European societies as well as areas of application of social structure analysis different forms of social reporting. Aim:The aim is to acquire basic knowledge of important social parameters and their distribution in European societies.

name: Work and organizational sociology
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on work and organization
content: Content:The module deals in depth with basic concepts, central problem areas and theories, typical research methods as well as important studies and research results in the subject. The exercise focuses primarily on selected basic questions, while the seminar discusses current topics and problems in specific sociology at an advanced level. Aim:Building on the basics taught in module M3 in the corresponding lecture on work and organizational sociology, the aim of the module is for students to acquire in-depth knowledge of the subject, which will enable them to independently deal with topics on a broader basis, To deal with theses, theories and methods of special sociology and, if necessary, to independently carry out limited transfers to other scientific areas and/or to prepare the knowledge for application in practical fields.

name: Sociology of technology
degree-program: Junior professorship in sociology of technology with a focus on the Internet and new media
content: Content:The module deals in depth with basic concepts, central problem areas and theories, typical research methods as well as important studies and research results in the subject. The exercise focuses primarily on selected basic questions, while the seminar discusses current topics and problems in specific sociology at an advanced level. Aim:Building on the basics taught in module M3 in the corresponding lecture on the sociology of technology, the aim of the module is for the students to acquire in-depth knowledge of the subject, which will enable them to independently work on topics, theses and theories on an expanded basis and methods of special sociology and, if necessary, to independently carry out limited transfers to other scientific areas and/or to prepare the knowledge for application in practical fields.

name: Health Sociology
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on health research
content: Content:The module deals in depth with basic concepts, central problem areas and theories, typical research methods as well as important studies and research results in the subject. The exercise focuses primarily on selected basic questions, while the seminar discusses current topics and problems in specific sociology at an advanced level. Aim:Building on the basics taught in the corresponding lecture on health sociology in module M3, the aim of the module is for students to acquire in-depth knowledge of the subject, which will enable them to independently work on topics, theses and theories on an expanded basis and methods of special sociology and, if necessary, to independently carry out limited transfers to other scientific areas and/or to prepare the knowledge for application in practical fields.

name: Political sociology
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on sociological theories
content: Content:The module deals in depth with basic concepts, central problem areas and theories, typical research methods as well as important studies and research results in the subject. The exercise focuses primarily on selected basic questions, while the seminar discusses current topics and problems in specific sociology at an advanced level. Aim:Building on the basics taught in module M3 in the corresponding lecture on political sociology, the aim of the module is for students to acquire in-depth knowledge of the subject, which will enable them to independently work on topics, theses, to deal with theories and methods of special sociology and, if necessary, to independently carry out limited transfers to other scientific areas and/or to prepare the knowledge for application in practical fields.

name: Career orientation and internship
degree-program: Director of the Institute for Sociology
content: Content:The aim of the module is to gain experience with practical professional requirements and to acquire orientation knowledge about possible professional fields using the example of studies and reports from practitioners in sociology. On the one hand, insights into typical professional fields for sociologists are provided. On the other hand, the students are supported in finding and carrying out an internship. The internship times are determined by the students, but should not affect the proper course of studies. Aim:The aim is to develop orientation knowledge about possible professional fields, develop professional search strategies and gain initial practical experience.

name: Presentation and moderation
degree-program: Director of the Institute for Sociology
content: Content:In this module, basic theoretical knowledge as well as practical techniques for presenting and moderating are practiced. Aim:The aim is to acquire and practice presentation and moderation skills and thus key qualifications that are universally applicable in many professional areas.

name: Basics of a neighboring discipline
degree-program: Dean of Sociology Studies at the Faculty of Human and Social Sciences
content: Content:The lectures in the chosen subject area provide an orientating introduction with the opportunity to delve deeper into a scientific area related to sociology. Aim:The aim is to acquire important central terms, theories, ways of thinking and methods in the chosen area, which allow you to round off your knowledge of sociology and enable knowledge transfer. In addition, basic experiences of interdisciplinary work should be gained through insights into another subject.

name: Social psychology
degree-program: Professorship of Social Psychology
content: Content:methods of social psychology; social cognition; attribution; decision-making behavior; Settings and setting change; attitudes and behavior; Self and social identity, prosocial behavior; Aggression; affiliation and interpersonal attraction; social influence in groups; power and leadership; intergroup relations; Social Neuroscience; applied social psychology Aim:The students are familiar with basic social psychological theories as well as classic and current empirical studies in social psychology. You are able to critically read, discuss and classify empirical studies. You can transfer social psychological explanatory models to application questions.

name: Organizational Behavior
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration VI Ã¯Â¿Â½ Human Resources and Leadership
content: Content:This basic module deals with theoretical approaches to behavior in and of organizations as well as the basics of individual behavior and how it can be influenced. In addition, the basics of group behavior, group processes and their design, the importance of structures and systems, their change as well as organizational learning and knowledge management and the importance of institutional and strategic framework conditions for acting and designing in organizations are covered conveyed. Aim:The aim of the module is to provide students with knowledge of important behavioral science principles and theoretical approaches to organizational behavior. In addition, an understanding of behavioral science-oriented control of the behavior of individuals and groups in organizations and the development and change of organizations should be awakened. Another didactic goal is to expand social skills. The module is a summary of key findings from the professional field of organization/personnel/innovation of the bachelor's degree program in economics at Chemnitz University of Technology and therefore represents a bridge module.

name: Research, innovation and consulting methods
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Innovation Research and Technology Management
content: Content:The module imparts knowledge of empirical methods in social research. Furthermore, knowledge of consulting and innovation research, innovation and consulting methods and knowledge of project management are deepened. Aim:In addition to basic knowledge of qualitative and quantitative research methods and basic skills in their application, students should also acquire cross-approach knowledge about innovations in social systems, skills in internal project and change management, and advising organizations on behalf of their clients. Didactically, the ability to reflect on one's own consulting roles and functions should be strengthened and sharpened.

name: Framework conditions of management and organization
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Organization and International Management
content: Content:The module deals with the economic, legal and business framework conditions of leadership, human resources management, organization and innovation, in particular in the fields of: Strategic management Selected fields of functional management Employment and labor market Business and labor law as well as public law. Aim:The module serves to impart basic knowledge in the area of ​​strategic management of companies and organizations as well as the legal and economic fundamentals of personnel, organization and innovation and change in organizations. The students should be able to classify relevant problems and tasks from the fields of organizational management, in particular strategy, human resources, organization and innovation, into broader business, economic and legal contexts.

name: Organization theory
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration - Organization and International Management
content: Content:The module teaches essential classic and modern organizational theories and uses them to interpret and reflect on cases, current problems or situations in companies. This is done on the basis of the social and scientific theoretical foundations of the respective organizational theories as well as their central areas of application. Aim:Overall, the module is intended to enable students to carry out a theory-based analysis of current management and organizational problems or current development trends of different types of organizations, to derive and evaluate appropriate alternative courses of action and to critically reflect on the results of interventions.

name: Human Resource Management (HRM)
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration VI Ã¯Â¿Â½ Human Resources and Leadership
content: Content:The module provides an overview of the basics of behavioral science in a lecture, an accompanying exercise and an English-language seminar. This includes, above all, the development of a basic understanding of content and problem dimensions, theoretical approaches, fields of action as well as current challenges in human resource management, and the imparting of basic knowledge of labor law and forms and development trends in work regulation as well as working techniques in legal case processing (depending on the offer) and knowledge of current research and relevant problems on human resource management as well as strategic and international human resource management. Aim:The module is intended to create a basic or in-depth understanding of the content and problems of human resource management. The students should be able to reflect and critically evaluate theoretical-conceptual approaches from the field of behavioral sciences and human resource management as well as strategic and international human resources management and the ability to act Â¿Â½develop practical human resources work. Didactically, the communicative and argumentative skills as well as the working techniques for preparing a seminar paper and scientific argumentation skills are to be promoted.

name: Organizational learning and knowledge management
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration VI Ã¯Â¿Â½ Human Resources and Leadership
content: Content:In a lecture, an accompanying exercise and an English-language seminar, the module imparts in-depth knowledge of the development of the knowledge society, theories of organizational learning, the management of knowledge and skills and the knowledge processes in organizations, as well as instruments and Design fields of knowledge management. Knowledge-oriented leadership and incentive design, individual knowledge management, knowledge assessment and evaluation of knowledge management, instruments and design areas of personnel development, competence management and knowledge management are also discussed. Aim:The module enables students to thoroughly classify and evaluate theoretical approaches and practical instruments of organizational learning and knowledge management. Skills in dealing with intangible resources (knowledge, skills, etc.) and management skills in the global knowledge society are taught. In addition, the understanding of personnel development (HR development), competence assessment and competence development (competence management) and knowledge management (knowledge management) should be deepened. Didactically, the communicative and argumentative skills as well as the working techniques for preparing a seminar paper and scientific argumentation skills are sharpened.

name: Managing Global Networks and Cooperations
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration - Organization and International Management
content: Content:The English-language module Managing Global Networks and Cooperations deals with central aspects of networks and cooperations. The module also deals with the specific challenges of international networks and collaborations. Aim:The students should build up in-depth knowledge on the topic of Managing Global Networks and Cooperations, be able to classify and critically analyze current concepts and problems.

name: Leadership
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration VI Ã¯Â¿Â½ Human Resources and Leadership
content: Content:The leadership module deals with the most important leadership theories, concepts and practices as well as central leadership problems. The seminar also deals with current problems in leadership research and leadership practice. Aim:The students should build up in-depth knowledge of the topic of leadership, be able to classify and critically analyze current concepts and problems, and be able to act competently in appropriate situations.

name: Innovation and innovation management
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration - Innovation Research and Technology Management
content: Content:The module consists of a seminar in which current topics in the area of innovation research and innovation and technology management are to be discussed. Aim:The aim of the module is to practice engaging with empirical and scientific sources and methods in the field of innovation research as part of research-based learning and to develop your own critical reflection or research ideas. The students should be able to criticize methods, theories and recipe knowledge.

name: Application project and reflection: training, research and consulting
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration - Innovation Research and Technology Management
content: Content:In the two-semester application project, students are given the opportunity to apply and experience the content taught in modules 1 to 9 in a project in the areas of training, research or consulting. Aim:Social and technical skills in intra-company and cross-company cooperation, in project management, in intervention and consulting projects or research projects are trained. In addition, depending on the chosen project area, presentation skills and analytical and consulting skills as well as the ability to carry out independent scientific work are developed. Â½rft .

name: Technologies for micro and nano systems
degree-program: Professorship of Smart Systems Integration
content: Content: Process steps for Si MEMS/NEMS Process steps for non-Si MEMS/NEMS Si-based technologies Technologies for for alternative materials packaging and 3D integration technologies measurement technology for MEMS/NEMS examples for Si MEMS examples for r non-Si MEMS Examples of nanocomponents and NEMS Trends and roadmaps Aim:The students know the technological steps and process flows for manufacturing MEMS and NEMS components and systems. You have knowledge of technologies for innovative MEMS (Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems) and NEMS (Nano-Electro-Mechanical Systems) as well as for system integration.

name: Microsystem design
degree-program: Professorship of Microsystems and Medical Technology
content: Content: Design methods and tools for microsystems technology (MST) Modeling of heterogeneous systems with concentrated parameters Behavioral analysis of technical field problems with FEM Macro modeling of complex systems through order reduction Connection of component and system design The focus is on the holistic consideration of various physical domains during the individual phases of the design process. Commercial design systems such as ANSYS/Multiphysics, Matlab/Simulink and languages such as VHDL-A or Verilog-A are used. Aim:The students have knowledge of the design of microsystems. You are able to apply the relevant skills in analytical and numerical modeling, simulation and the design of complex heterogeneous systems in microsystems technology.

name: Components of micro- and nanotechnology
degree-program: Professorship of Electronic Components in Micro- and Nanotechnology
content: Content: MOS transistors with dimensions in the sub-100 nm range New MOS transistor concepts (multi-gate transistors, FinFETs, etc.) Single-electron transistors Quantum components (resonance tunneling diodes, RTDs, etc.) Bipolar transistors with dimensions in the sub-1 m range Carbon nanotubes Aim:The students have knowledge of the parasitic effects of MOS and bipolar components with very small dimensions. They have an understanding of fundamentally new construction elements, some of which are only possible by producing very small structures.

name: Reliability of micro- and nanosystems
degree-program: Professorship of Materials and Reliability of Microtechnical Systems
content: Content: Introduction and motivation, reliability Introduction to materials and manufacturing processes in assembly and connection technology Basics of materials and their deformation and failure behavior under thermo-mechanical load Mathematical description using vector analysis Basics of reliability assessment Basics of damage mechanics Fracture mechanics and crack concepts Experimental reliability Liquid investigations and statistical evaluation Error analysis procedures Application examples for the reliability of micro- and nanosystems Aim:The students master the basics of reliability assessment of components and systems. You know the current status of calculation methods and experiments.

name: Intelligent sensor systems
degree-program: Professorship of Measurement and Sensor Technology
content: Content: Basics of intelligent sensor systems Sensor properties Structures of sensor systems Interfering influences and protective measures Sensor signals Measurement data acquisition Sensor interfaces and measurement data acquisition Real amplifiers and amplifier circuits Advanced methods of analog-digital conversion In pedance spectroscopy Selected sensor applications Aim:The students are able to appropriately select sensors for measurement tasks and to design the corresponding sensor systems and matching circuits.

name: Circuit design
degree-program: Professorship of Circuit and System Design
content: Content: Introduction: Status and trends in microelectronics; Design process Overview of ASICs: user programmable (PLDs, FPGAs); mask programmable (gate arrays, standard cell circuits); Systems-on-Chip Design Methods: Specification; Synthesis; Simulation; Verification; Layout Test: Meaning; strategies; test-friendly design Aim:The students know the circuit design process and are able to use this knowledge to select ASICs for specific applications. You have the ability to apply design methods to existing and new circuit types and understand the importance of testing and appropriate testing strategies.

name: Business English 1 (BE1)
degree-program: Program coordinator for business English at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:As part of this module, students review and practice how to make and maintain contacts, make agreements and present companies in English. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to apply the acquired basic knowledge of English business language in a targeted manner and preferably in oral as well as written specialist communication. Successful completion of the module prepares you to achieve specialist language competence level B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.

name: Business English 3 (BE3)
degree-program: Program coordinator for business English at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:In this module, the topics of marketing, human resources and finance are discussed in a foreign language. The students are also given the task of analyzing and presenting English-language specialist texts. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to apply the acquired knowledge of English business language in a targeted and fluent manner in oral and written professional and scientific communication. Successful completion of the module prepares you for reaching the specialist language competency level C1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.

name: Mathematical basics
degree-program: Dean of Mathematics Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:Basic theories and skills in mathematics in the areas of: Linear algebra and analysis Optimization and financial mathematics Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to apply basic knowledge to mathematical investigations of economic problems and test their significance. You can analyze corresponding models using mathematical tools, draw relevant conclusions from them and interpret them in an economic context. During the internships, the students acquired methodological skills for solving mathematical problems and can apply these independently.

name: Accounting and basics of corporate taxation

content: Content:Accounting: Task and technology of commercial accounting (Doppik) Accounting technology using a sample chart of accounts Application of AI methods in the Accounting E-learning module Orderliness of accounting Inventory and inventory Balance sheet Postings to inventory and income accounts From the opening balance to the closing balance Organization of bookkeeping Postings with sales tax Commodity accounts Special features of the movement of goods Material delimitation Postings in the asset management area Personnel management area Production management area: recording of production steps Bookings in the financial sector Timing Business taxes and income tax Preparation of the annual financial statements Basics of corporate taxation: Profit as the basis for income taxation of sole proprietorships, partnerships and corporations Overview of the taxation of companies in the legal forms o the sole proprietorship o the partnership o the corporation basic features o the income and corporate tax o Trade tax o Property tax o Real estate transfer and sales tax as well as o Inheritance and gift tax Income from business operations in the income tax Principle of annual tax and progressive income tax rate Crediting of trade tax the income tax losses in income taxes withholding tax on dividends and capital gains Aim:After successfully completing the module, participants can explain the basics of income taxation of partnerships and corporations and calculate the tax burden on shareholders in simple cases. They understand that with double-entry bookkeeping, success is determined in two ways at the same time and can separate successes from mere transfers of assets. You know the basics of the types of taxes relevant to companies, in particular sales tax, property tax, real estate transfer tax and inheritance/gift tax. Participants have developed digital skills regarding the requirements of electronic booking systems, how AI systems work in this area and how to assess the benefits and dangers of using such systems.

name: Basics of management and entrepreneurship
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Innovation Research and Technology Management
content: Content: Management of organizations Management theories at a glance Personnel, organization and leadership Innovation and technology management Entrepreneurship Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have gained an overview of the most important management topics and theories and are able to reflect critically on them. You have learned the basics of entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial thinking and can apply them. The independent development and presentation of business ideas also promotes the development and expansion of social skills in the areas of group and project work as well as presentation.

name: Microeconomics I
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Microeconomics
content: Content: In-depth basic knowledge of microeconomics (strategic interactions, budget theory, production theory, competition theory) Simple methods of decision theory, game theory and optimization and their application in a microeconomic context Aim:After successfully completing the module, students will be able to explain and analyze topics in microeconomics such as strategic interactions, prices, markets and competition. You can understand and critically evaluate microeconomic aspects of economic and economic policy discussions. You know the simple microeconomic methods of decision theory, game theory and optimization and are able to use them.

name: Macroeconomics I
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Macroeconomics
content: Content: Aims of macroeconomics: The magic square Elements of national accounting Stylized facts and macroeconomic data Macroeconomic markets Unemployment, employment and inflation Growth and economic activity Monetary and fiscal policy History of macroeconomics Aim:After successfully completing the module, students will have developed a fundamental understanding of the relevant macroeconomic theories and methods for analyzing growth, sustainability, economic fluctuations, unemployment and inflation. You are able to grasp macroeconomic phenomena and political measures from a short and long-term perspective and to communicate them to scientists and specialists in economics and other disciplines .

name: Economic policy
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Economic Policy
content: Content:The event follows on from the previous economic events. While the focus in the microeconomics and macroeconomics modules was on the development of theories to explain economic events, institutional aspects and concrete framework conditions are now increasingly discussed taken into account. At the same time, the focus shifts from a general causal explanation to a specific goal orientation. The event is divided into four parts: introduction economic analysis of the political process macroeconomic policy micro economic economic policy Aim:After successful completion of the module, the students are able to link theoretical knowledge of microeconomics and macroeconomics with institutional conditions, to independently assess economic policy issues and economic policy measures Â¿Â½takes critical assessment.

name: Business English 4 (BE4)
degree-program: Program coordinator for business English at the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:In this module, students are familiarized with the structure and execution of business negotiations. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to apply the knowledge they have acquired in English business language in a targeted and business-fluent manner in oral and written specialist communication. Successful completion of the module corresponds to the specialist language competence level C1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.

name: Income taxes

content: Content: Income tax o Types of profit income o Types of surplus income o Offset of losses o Personal deductions and family benefit equalization o Tariff and tariff reductions o Tax reductions Invoices Taxation of companies o Co-entrepreneurship, in particular infection theory and commercial imprinting o Corporate income tax, in particular hidden distribution of profits and unity o Trade tax Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students can explain how the basic principle of fair burden sharing is reflected in German income tax, and the way in which it is implemented in German income tax, based on legislative decisions and explain economic aspects of taxation. You have knowledge of possible corporate tax systems, know the applicable system of German corporate and trade tax as well as the German form of group taxation. You are able to obtain information from legal sources and apply income, corporate and trade tax law to simple situations.

name: Marketing management
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Marketing and Commercial Management
content: Content: Marketing as a management task Paradigm shift in marketing towards relationship marketing Measurement methods in marketing management Quantitative evaluation methods in marketing management Management of customer relationships Marketing perspective on customer satisfaction and loyalty Customer value and evaluation of customers (in particular customer liftetime value) Branding (in particular the importance of marketing activities in resource-based management) Importance of brand strength and brand value Measurement and management of brand strength and value Selected management tools in marketing management (e.g. conjoint analyzes and data envelopment analysis ( DEA)) Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to name and explain the goals and tasks of marketing management. You can compare and evaluate marketing management decision options in different business contexts. You can independently develop new knowledge and skills in the field of marketing, for example by using scientific publication media in marketing management, and apply these to marketing management problems.

name: Business to Business Marketing
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Marketing and Commercial Management
content: Content:The module addresses the theoretical and practical aspects of business to business marketing in relation to the peculiarities of market development by companies, particularly in the technology sectors. For this purpose, the theoretical models and methods are discussed intensively in the lecture. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to reproduce and explain basic and in-depth knowledge of business to business marketing. You can plan and control the marketing process of technology-oriented companies, identify competitive advantages and position companies in the market through the use of marketing tools.

name: Strategic management
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration III Ã¯Â¿Â½ Corporate Accounting and Controlling
content: Content: Introduction to strategic management Phases and instruments of strategic planning Strategies for the entire company Strategies for business Fitential units Strategies for functional areas Strategy implementation Strategic control Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to identify the characteristics and tasks of strategic management with its elements strategic planning, strategy implementation and strategic control. You have gained knowledge of strategies at different company levels. They know selected strategic planning instruments, can apply them and reflect on their solutions. This includes complex, realistic problems depicted in a case study.

name: Start-up financing
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration IV Ã¯Â¿Â½ Finance and Banking
content: Content:In addition to basic financial and analytical knowledge, the module also provides knowledge about liquidity planning and sources of financing, an understanding of the role of lenders and investors and basic knowledge of the valuation of growth companies. The effects of start-up financing on later company phases (strategic financial management) are also discussed. The knowledge learned is deepened in case studies and applied practically. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to determine the financial needs of companies in the various start-up phases, strategically select potential financing partners and have an understanding of their perspective Funders obtained.

name: International Strategy
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Organization and International Management
content: Content:The module covers and discusses central concepts and theories of global strategy and international management. Furthermore, various market entry strategies are analyzed and economic, political, social and cultural context factors of international management are examined. The discussion focuses particularly on the tension between global efficiency and the local adaptation of multinational companies. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have built up in-depth knowledge of international strategy and international management and are able to critically analyze and apply central theories and concepts.

name: Basics of human resources management and leadership
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Human Resources Management and Leadership

You can reflect on and critically evaluate theoretical and conceptual approaches from the fields of behavioral sciences, strategic management and human resources management. In addition, they have developed the ability to act in practical human resources work and personnel management.

You can apply the quantitative and qualitative methods you have learned to industrial problems, model them and solve them. They are also able to reflect their basic understanding of the most important tools such as simulation, optimization and operational planning systems (APS).

name: Basics of technology and innovation management
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Innovation Research and Technology Management

degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Microeconomics

The bachelor's students are motivated to attend lectures in the master's seminar and vice versa. name: Environmental and resource economics
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Macroeconomics
content: Content:The module is intended to give students an introduction to the theories and stylized facts of environmental and resource economics. Topics such as environmental pollution, resource consumption, climate change, biodiversity and ecological inequality are covered. Concepts such as external effects, private vs. public goods, sustainability of renewable and non-renewable resources, material cycles and environmental economic budgeting are used. Aim:Upon successful completion of the module, students are able to make an informed assessment of the academic literature and current political debates on the topic and to independently work on environmental or resource economic issues.

name: European Economy I
degree-program: Junior professorship in international economic relations with a focus on Europe
content: Content:The event offers an introduction to the economic issues of European integration. Historical and political backgrounds are explained as well as theoretical and applied examples from micro and macroeconomics are used to illustrate the various fields of European integration from an economic perspective to illuminate perspective. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to identify and compare fundamental economic issues of European integration, as well as historical and political backgrounds using theoretical and applied examples to explain.

name: European Economy II
degree-program: Junior professorship in international economic relations with a focus on Europe
content: Content:The event offers an introduction to the macroeconomic issues of European integration. The event is suitable both as an introduction to macroeconomics in the short, medium and long term, as well as as a deepening and application of macroeconomic thinking using examples relevant to European economic policy Economic history and politics. A particular focus is on current questions of European economic policy, such as the liquidity trap or zero interest rate limit, national debt and the possibilities of political (self-) limitation and coordination in the European Monetary Union. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students will be able to identify and compare fundamental macroeconomic issues of European integration. You have developed a macroeconomic way of thinking and can apply this to economically relevant examples from European economic history and politics.

name: Basics of empirical economic research

content: Content: Insight into the application of important empirical methods (linear regression analysis, hypothesis testing, etc.) Support with appropriate statistics/econometrics software Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to critically assess the validity of empirical studies presented to them and to carry out their own empirical studies.

name: Project management
degree-program: Professorship of Business Informatics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Business Process and Information Management
content: Content: Basics of projects and project management Typical phases of a project and their design issues Methods and tools for planning, implementing, monitoring and controlling as well as handling projects (e.g. bar planning) Selected project management methods and project organizational forms including agile approaches Important success factors for projects Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to plan, carry out, monitor and control complex and extensive tasks in the form of projects. The students use the acquired knowledge of operational project management to successfully carry out projects. You are able to identify and use suitable methods and tools in the individual phases of project management. The students can choose the most suitable project management method (particularly classic vs. agile) for specific practical projects.

You can assess the respective advantages and disadvantages of various modeling languages ​​(in particular event-based process chains and business process model and notation) and have the skills Ability to model processes syntactically and semantically correctly using programs and manually. In addition, they can apply basic processes for process simulation, controlling and optimization. Knowledge of current trends in business process management enables students to recognize and assess their potential in digitalization projects.

content: Content:Overview of IT structures in various economic sectors; practical demonstration of business concepts implemented in information technology, especially production management/accounting; Imparting the knowledge and skills required to plan, control and monitor a company's information infrastructure Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have a basic understanding of operational application systems and their design, the horizontal/vertical integration of application systems in central economic sectors and their implementation using standard software as an example, which they can do with the help of the associated Â¿Â½technical vocabulary. Furthermore, the students have in-depth methodological and specialist knowledge as well as skills for planning, controlling and monitoring the information infrastructure in a company. In the exercise, in addition to the lecture, they got to know various information systems (especially open source solutions) and can use them.

They are able to carry out the design and dimensioning of the drive system and adapt it to the needs of the technological process. They are also able to practically set up and examine corresponding systems in the test laboratory.

content: Content: Number representation and rounding errors Condition and numerical stability numerical solution of linear systems of equations nonlinear systems of equations Inter polation and function approximation numerical integration (quadrature) Basics of numerical eigenvalue calculation Basics of numerical solution of initial value problems in ordinary differential equations Aim:The aim of this basic module is to introduce numerical mathematics. name: Introduction to Data Science

These include machine learning methods, the role of statistical and optimization methods as well as the most important software tools and programming languages.

name: Mathematical foundations of big data analytics
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all courses in the Faculty of Mathematics (except Data Science and International Master's and Doctoral courses)
content: Content:The characteristic of Big Data is that the amounts of data to be processed are too large, too complex, too fast-moving or too weakly structured to be evaluated using manual and conventional data processing methods. In this module, basic mathematical models in the area of big data analytics are presented and an application-oriented reference to relevant economic issues is established. Mathematical tools from applied mathematics (in particular numerical linear algebra, statistics, optimization, game theory, graph theory, ordinary differential equations) are explained and applied to current problems of data analysis in an economic context. Aim:The students acquire basic methodological and technology-specific knowledge and skills in the subject areas of "Business Intelligence" and "Business Analytics" for analyzing data in the company. You will be able to evaluate structured data in a targeted manner using the available methods and technologies and to be able to interpret the resulting consequences. In addition, the students should get to know the possible uses and challenges of big data, gain a basic knowledge of the technologies and be able to apply mathematical models suitable for economic problems .

name: Data security
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science (Information Security)
content: Content:Starting from a communication model (e.g. from philosophy lessons at school), the lecture deals with basic principles of modern encryption methods such as RSA, with simple classic methods such as the Hill cipher being presented first. Possible attacks against an opponent as well as possible defenses by the sender or receiver of a message are discussed. Furthermore, applications are discussed in detail, such as key exchange for communication (Diffie-Hellman process) and digital signatures. The necessary mathematical basics are discussed depending on the procedure. Aim:Students have an understanding and are able to explain and master modern communication principles (to a certain extent and to a certain extent). You will learn to analyze and better assess encryption methods in terms of their efficiency and security against an attacker.

name: XML
degree-program: Professorship of Distributed and Self-Organizing Computer Systems
content: Content:The eXtensible Markup Language (XML) is the basis for a variety of developments in the area of the World Wide Web. XML plays a central role in the transport and integration of data as well as in many modern software applications. The offering provides a basic introduction to XML and its use in different contexts of distributed systems, distributed software and the web. Various current application scenarios and practice-relevant tools are presented. The topics cover: Introduction to markup languages and XML Basic approaches, e.g. DTD, XML schemas, XML editors, XML applications, linking, XPath, XSL /XSLT Formats and tools in the area of data, e.g. SVG, RSS Formats and tools in the area of semantics, e.g. RDF, OWL, digital rights with Creative Commons Formats and tools in the area User interfaces, e.g. XHTML, Tagging Aim:Students are able to create XML applications and use XML tools. You can use XML to create sophisticated distributed applications. You can apply basic techniques from the Semantic Web as well as metadata technologies and use them to realize Semnatic Web resources.

In particular, the event promotes understanding of the interaction between technological innovation and commercial exploitation in the Internet economy.

name: Graphical programming of mechatronic systems
degree-program: Professorship of Micromanufacturing Technology
content: Content:Graphical programming of mechatronic systems I: After a systematic introduction to the graphical programming language LabVIEW and getting to know the development environment, knowledge of data types and structures is imparted. Other topics include file input and output, the design of user interfaces as well as measurement data acquisition and its application for process visualization. The first part of the module is completed by working on a project for automated measurement recording (certificate). Graphical programming of mechatronic systems II: In the second part of the module, advanced knowledge of programming in LabVIEW is imparted. The focus is on practical application in the context of current technologies for implementing measurement, automation and control tasks. All teaching units in the module take place in the computer pool. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to create programs for the data acquisition of physical quantities (acquisition, graphical representation and storage), the control of external devices To implement using the most common PC interfaces and to configure measurement cards with regard to the measurement task as well as to program simple applications in real-time and FPGA.

name: Sensor-actuator systems
degree-program: Professorship of Adaptronics and Functional Lightweight Design in Production
content: Content:The module imparts both theoretical basics and application-oriented knowledge on the development and operation of sensor-actuator systems. The starting point is an overview of available sensor and actuator technology, which is intended to enable application-specific evaluation and selection. In addition to understanding the system, the communication between individual components, which is essential for the function of sensor-actuator systems, is the focus of the module. Various interfaces and bus systems are presented and their effects on the functionality of the system are discussed. These are illustrated using concrete examples. Building on the general considerations of sensor-actuator systems, the special features of designing integrated sensor-actuator systems are conveyed. Aim:After completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ select sensors and actuators suitable for an application, Ã¯Â¿Â½ limits and possibilities of the signalsÃ¯Â¿ to assess transmission and evaluate the effects of communication standards on the functionality of the system and to transfer this knowledge to the design of integrated sensor-actuator systems.

name: Work-and Healthprotection
degree-program: Professorship of Industrial Science and Innovation Management
content: Content:The European occupational health and safety legislation has issued binding regulations for all EU member states on the occupational safety-friendly design of products, processes and procedures. This means that every engineer, whether a designer, planner or work planner, must also have specialist knowledge of occupational health and safety in their employment contractual guarantor position. The main idea of the teaching module is the implementation of occupational health and safety in commercial companies. History of occupational safety, emergence of the occupational safety system Guidelines of the European Community for the protection of working people Legal basis in the national legal system Dual occupational safety system in Germany Hazard factors and occupational safety measures in the company Aim:The students have knowledge of the legal principles of occupational safety and health protection and are able to identify risks at workplaces in companies.

Using practical examples, the systematic approach to working on scientific tasks and presenting results is taught. Aim:In the module, students acquire basic methodological knowledge for obtaining, evaluating and presenting scientific data. This enables them to strategically plan and optimize test series and to present the results scientifically and technically.

name: Safe mechatronic systems
degree-program: Professorship of conveyor and material flow technology
content: Content:The course imparts in-depth knowledge of safety technology; in particular, safety-related terms and their definitions are discussed and differentiated from one another. In addition to the introduction to relevant technical rules, their application is taught in particular in order to be able to identify and evaluate risks. At the same time, the quantification of security with the help of mathematical models is examined in more detail. In this context, the course also deals with the variables Performance Level (PL) vs. Safety Integrity Level (SIL) and their significance for practical application. Furthermore, safety concepts and their constructive implementation are discussed and safety functions in mechatronics are discussed. In particular, safe bus systems, safe sensors, safe actuators and safe controls are discussed and a distinction is made between safety systems and assistance systems. Examples of safe mechatronic systems from the areas of conveyor technology, drive technology, control technology or communication technology illustrate the above-mentioned safety-related aspects and show constructive implementations for integrated safety in the industrial environment. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ explain the general meaning of safety and safety technology Ã¯Â¿Â½ name and apply technical rules in the field of machine safety Ã¯Â¿Â½ the term Ã¯Â¿Â½riskÃ¯Â¿Â½ in safety technology Define the context Ã¯Â¿Â½ Describe the procedure for assessing risks and apply it in the specific case Ã¯Â¿Â½ Differentiate and apply relevant approaches to quantify security Ã¯Â¿Â½ Show proven security concepts Ã¯Â¿Â½ Describe safety functions and carry out their validation Ã¯Â¿Â½ Name examples of safety-related aspects

name: Machine dynamics of discrete systems
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Mechanics/Dynamics
content: Content:The task of machine dynamics of discrete systems is to develop and apply knowledge from the dynamics of discrete-modeled problems in mechanical engineering. This module teaches knowledge, skills and abilities that are independent of a specific type of machine or technical object and can be applied to any machine (drive and support systems). The machine dynamics of discrete systems deals with the determination of dynamic parameters and properties as well as the mathematical description and physical explanation of dynamic phenomena and effects on machines using analytical-computational methods. The basics of the subject are taught in the lectures, while the general connections are implemented and deepened in the exercises using concrete exercises. Aim:The students are able to determine dynamic parameters and properties and describe them mathematically.

name: Industrial control technology
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:Industrial controls for machines, systems and complex processes occupy a prominent place in automation technology. The module takes this fact into account. The focus is on the functionality, structure, programming, handling and operation of current controls. The course begins with an overview of automation in mechanical engineering. It also deals with indispensable basics such as Boolean algebra and sequential systems, the basic structures and functionalities of controls, regulated systems, trajectories and interpolation. Further focuses are the automation of machines (including machine models as well as movement sequences and path diagrams) as well as the structure, mode of operation, programming and handling of various industrial controls (PLC, CNC, MC). Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to: Ã¯Â¿Â½ apply the basics of Boolean algebra and the design of sequential controls in practice tasks, Ã¯Â¿Â½ the programming of a PLC according to IEC 61131 to be applied practically and to generate solutions for selected problems, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to explain the structure of industrial controls, Ã¯Â¿Â½ the basic principles of motion controls (path control and control), Ã¯Â¿Â½ recommend a suitable control system for typical applications in mechanical engineering, Ã¯Â¿Â½ designate coordinate systems and axes according to DIN 66217 and apply NC programming according to DIN 66025, Ã¯Â ¿Â½ to discuss the possibilities of MC controls.
