name: Real-time processing
degree-program: Professorship of Process Automation
content: Content:Automation control programs are expected to handle many tasks simultaneously and deliver results in a timely manner. This software technical problem will be discussed in detail in this lecture. Closely linked to this is the concept of concurrent tasks and the associated problems of synchronization, which are also discussed in the lecture. Keywords for the content: Problems of concurrent, distributed and real-time-dependent systems; task concepts; timely scheduling in single and multi-processor systems; synchronization problems; Synchronization of processes using semaphores, monitors and other methods Aim:The students will be able to identify potential problems in real-time systems with concurrent tasks and to develop and implement various solution approaches for modeling and synchronization in programming.

name: Traction and magnetic bearing technology
degree-program: Professorship of Electrical Energy Conversion Systems and Drives
content: Content: Traction technology: o Track guidance, wheel-rail contact o Driving resistance, tractive force, drive power o Traction power supply o Traction motors and their control o Power converter technology Magnetic bearing technology: o Physical basics, technical Applications, trends o Structure and mode of operation of active magnetic bearings o Control of active magnetic bearings o Dynamics of magnetic bearing rotors o Bearingless motors Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Acquisition of knowledge about the operating behavior of special mechatronic systems in traffic engineering and the ability to design and dimension components of such systems Ã¯Â¿Â½ Getting to know magnetic bearing technologies and their economics and ecologically sensible possible uses Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to examine mechatronic systems in an interdisciplinary manner using the example of active magnetic bearings

name: Modeling and identification of dynamic systems 2A
degree-program: Professorship of Control Engineering and System Dynamics
content: Content:- Introduction to system identification - Parametric dynamic models ) optimization methods and algorithms advanced concepts Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Identification and protection procedures Ã¯Â¿Â½ Procedure for obtaining entire system models from the measured data of the input and output variables

name: Generative manufacturing processes (3D printing)
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:Generative manufacturing processes are now an integral part of modern value chains. The processes are used from product development through to production. The focus of the module is the theoretical fundamentals of the process and the holistic view of the processes (process chains) of generative manufacturing processes, starting from the generation of the geometry to the use of the models or products. In addition to the motivators for the development of generative manufacturing processes, the different types of processes are examined and the main operating principles, materials and areas of application of the processes stereolithography, selective laser sintering/melting, 3D printing, fused deposition modeling, laminated object manufacturing and various Follow-up procedures conveyed. In the internship accompanying the lecture, various generative manufacturing processes are demonstrated and components are designed and partly manufactured independently. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to: Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe possibilities of data generation and acquisition as well as the basic flow of information for the creation of prototypes, models and products, Ã¯Â¿Â½ the basic physical principles for solidifying liquid or solid materials, Ã¯Â¿Â½ recognizing areas of application of generative processes, Ã¯Â¿Â½ a suitable industrial generative manufacturing process or system technology for a defined task with regard to process specifications and - To be boundary to name, name and the following process chains to be named - or functional model from the idea, through the design to the process-appropriate data preparation and generated using selected processes.

name: Cam gear and motion design
degree-program: Professorship of Assembly and Handling Technology
content: Content:Due to the increasing performance of today's drive technology, efforts are being made to adapt movement sequences as optimally as possible to given requirements. The aim of this module is, on the one hand, to provide the basics for describing a movement task, e.g. B. a technological process or a leadership movement. On the other hand, an engineer today is often faced with the question of which drive concept is really optimal for generating movement. B. you could decide between a mechanical, mechatronic or purely electronic basic concept. Taking into account the entire system behavior, basic selection criteria for possible drive solutions are compared and discussed. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have an overview of the systematics of non-linear drive systems aimed at cam gears or motion control systems. You know the basic analytical methods for calculating and designing a roller center path or drive function, for which the term “electronic cam” is used in servo drive technology today. Aligned with the latest drive concepts, students master the methods for applying graphically interactive motion design (including the design of transfer functions, approximation and interpolation approaches for guiding movements). They also know the design requirements and design methods for mechanical drive variants.

name: Basics of Computer Science II
degree-program: Dean of the Faculty of Computer Science
content: Content: Dynamic data structures and algorithms based on them (linear lists, ring lists) Introduction to object-oriented programming Text search algorithms Programming of human-machine interfaces Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Acquisition of in-depth knowledge and skills on the main focus areas mentioned as a viable basis for the formulation and solution of tasks in technology that use methods of Computer science can be effectively solved: the ability to design simple algorithms and implement them in a modern programming language

name: Measuring and testing technology for MST
degree-program: Professorship of Microsystems and Medical Technology
content: Content: Basics of length and profile measurement technology Testing and measuring methods for non-contact measurement of micromechanical components, measurement technology for recording geometric structural data Light optical Measuring methods and high-resolution measuring methods (microscopy, focusing measuring methods, interference measuring methods, atomic force microscopy) Measuring technology for recording static and dynamic system parameters (deflection, amplitude, natural frequency, frequency response, quality, transfer factor, Two-channel analysis, FFT, modal analysis) Vibration measurement technology for microstructures Simulation of the system properties based on measured values using modal analysis Modification and simulation on the modal dynamic model Internships on measurement methods in microsystems technology Aim:Acquisition of knowledge of methods and tools as well as skills for the metrological examination of micromechanical components.

name: Functional surfaces
degree-program: Professorship of Micromanufacturing Technology
content: Content: Areas of application of functional surfaces Design of functional surfaces Manufacturing processes for the production and replication of functional surfaces M opportunities for analyzing the surface characteristics The teaching units teach the requirements for functional surfaces from application-relevant areas such as medical technology, automotive technology, the electronics industry or optics. The main focus is on the design of functional surfaces in line with requirements, taking into account physical-chemical principles, as well as the consideration of suitable manufacturing processes for their production. In addition, there is an overview of the field of bionics, i.e. the reproduction of functional surfaces from nature and their transfer to technical applications. In addition, selected methods for characterizing the surfaces with regard to topography, internal stresses and function are presented. Aim:The aim of the module is to acquire knowledge about the application and selection of functional surfaces. The following learning objectives are pursued: 1. The students have discovered that functional surfaces have a wide range of possible applications and are able to report on them. 2. Students understand that the design of the surface structure has a decisive influence on functionality. 3. The students are able to name and describe individual examples of natural models for functional surfaces. 4. The students remember that the selection of manufacturing processes has a significant influence on the expression of the surface properties and thus on the function.

name: Mechatronics manufacturing resources
degree-program: Professorship of Micromanufacturing Technology
content: Content:Overview of manufacturing systems Manufacturing Tasks; components; manufacturing concepts; Manufacturing equipment Workpiece flow system Handling of workpieces, devices; workpiece clamping systems; gripper; handling facilities; workpiece storage; Workpiece transport/transfer; Workpiece identification Tool flow in the tools manufacturing system; Machine/tool interface; Handling of tools in the manufacturing system; tool identification; Tool setting Operating materials in manufacturing systems Cooling lubricants; suction systems; Component cleaning, control and monitoring of manufacturing systems, goals and structure of control and monitoring systems; Process monitoring in metal-cutting production; Process monitoring during forming and cutting. Seminar accompanying lectures to deepen knowledge of operating resources specifically for the production of mechatronic systems Aim:After successful participation in the module, the students can: Ã¯Â¿Â½ explain the functional principles, systems and areas of application of different equipment in production technology in general and specifically for mechatronics production, Ã¯Â¿Â½ the Represent the goals of different conceptual approaches to production planning and control with regard to the use of operating resources and materials and explain methods for achieving them.

name: Production Planning and Control
degree-program: Professorship of Factory Planning and Factory System Operation
content: Content: Goals and tasks of production planning and control (PPS) Data basis for the PPS (product structure, processes, resources) Company typology and design of the PPS Production program planning Requirements determination, inventory planning and control Deadline and capacity planning Order release and monitoring Production characteristics Special methods and strategies Setup and introduction of PPS systems Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to understand the essential connections between production planning and control as well as order processing in industrial companies, to design the corresponding processes and to apply the relevant methodological principles in a purpose-oriented manner. After successfully completing the module, students will continue to be able to evaluate modern planning and control strategies, determine the necessary prerequisites for their applicability and apply them to selected situations in the operational environment.

name: Precision machines for micro-machining
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:Precision machines, i.e. H. Machines for the high-precision machining and microstructuring of components are the prerequisite for the economical production of complex mechanical, mechatronic and opto-mechatronic assemblies. The course focuses on the basics of machine accuracy. This includes the measurement, testing and evaluation of accuracy parameters as well as rules and guidelines for the construction and operation of high-precision machines. In exercises, knowledge of experimental measurement of parameters and simulation of accuracy behavior is deepened. Aim:After completing the module, students will be able to: Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe the basic structure and components of machines for precision and micro machining, Ã¯Â¿Â½ methods for precision Â¿Â½ to apply the measurement and description of the accuracy of machines, to evaluate the measurement results in accordance with standards and to evaluate the resulting key figures (e.g. for comparing different machines), Ã¯Â¿Â½ to predict the accuracy behavior of machines using geometric models and to identify weak points in terms of accuracy, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to relate the static, dynamic, thermal and tribological behavior of selected machine components, Ã¯Â¿Â½ components and sensors in machines based on their operating principle, the To assess the operating conditions and the design with regard to their accuracy behavior, to independently formulate a requirement profile for a machine for a given micro-machining task.

name: Blasting techniques
degree-program: Professorship of Welding Technology
content: Content: Basics of laser technology Resonators/beam guidance and shaping Laser systems for material processing Laser safety Industrial applications Electron beam technologies The accompanying exercises cover the use of material processing processes with laser and electron beams and the demonstration in the laboratory. Aim:After completing the module, the students have in-depth basic knowledge of the physical and technical properties of beam manufacturing processes. They are also able to select technical concepts and technological processes from laser and electron beam technology for industrial applications.

name: Reliability and functional safety
degree-program: Professorship of Process Automation
content: Content:Reliability (occurrence of malfunctions without danger) and safety (malfunctions with potential for danger) play an important role in automation. The scenarios range from a plane crash and catastrophe in a nuclear power plant to the failure of a production line or quality control in production. When it comes to computer systems, a distinction must be made between hardware and software reliability. In addition, human error is playing an increasingly important role. These aspects are discussed qualitatively and quantitatively in the lecture, whereby methods of probability theory are introduced and used for the mathematical description. Structure: Definitions of terms of reliability and safety Mathematical methods for analyzing reliability and safety Calculation of the reliability of systems based on their components Failure Mode, Effect and Criticality Analysis Special aspects of software reliability Measures to increase reliability, redundant systems Human Error: Human error, causes and countermeasures Aim:The students learn about the various aspects of reliability and security and can analyze simple systems using mathematical methods, identify weak points and identify countermeasures.

name: CAM methods and application
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:With a simple tool geometry, such as a spherical or cylindrical shape, a cutting machine tool is able to produce a wide variety of geometries using complex tool paths. The essential information technology basis is the NC program, in which the necessary traversing movements and switching functions are defined. The content of the module is to combine technology and workpiece contours in an appropriate control program and to implement real components of mechanical and vehicle construction largely independently using various cutting processes and corresponding CNC machine tools. Various methods are presented, from manual and flexible programming to workshop-oriented programming and the use of a CAM sequence. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe the assemblies of a CNC machine, in particular the operation of an NC axis with a position measuring system and position control loop as well as the reference points in the machine's working area, Ã¯Â¿Â½ Under instructions, set up a CNC milling machine and determine the required tool correction values, Ã¯Â¿Â½ Manually create NC programs for geometrically simple parts in water abrasive jet cutting and milling, Ã¯ Â¿Â½ to set up practice-relevant CAD/CAM(NC) process chains for workshop-oriented and external, PC-oriented programming, Ã¯Â¿Â½ with support in a complex external programming system for the 3rd and 5th - Describe the geometry of axis milling and select the technology for successful production as well as analyze and independently optimize existing production.

name: Soldering
degree-program: Professorship of Composites and Material Composites
content: Content:The module provides an insight into the current state of development of soldering technology. After presenting the metallurgical and physical principles of soldering, one of the main problems in soldering is dealt with: the removal of foreign layers (especially oxide layers), which make it difficult for the solder to wet the base material surfaces. Furthermore, important soldering processes as well as typical solders for soft and hard soldering of various base materials are explained. The soldering of non-metallic materials, such as ceramics, glasses and graphite, as well as the special features of soldering these materials are also covered. Further sections deal with design guidelines for the correct construction and testing of solder connections, solders and fluxes. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have knowledge of soft and hard soldering of a wide variety of materials (similar and different soldering connections). You are able to select suitable soldering materials and soldering technology for specific applications.

name: Development and design of production technology
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:Methods for developing and designing production technology require a holistic mechatronic approach in addition to structural design. In this way, the conflict of objectives, which is crucial for production technology: high productivity versus high precision, can be resolved at a high level become. The module covers fundamental aspects of mechanical engineering design and development, starting with drive assemblies through the machine to the manufacturing system. This includes interdisciplinary solution approaches that are necessary for a targeted improvement of machine parameters. Starting from the classic spindle-nut systems, the focus is on drive principles that enable the machine developer to design machines and components more accurately and productively at the same time. These include highly dynamic parallel kinematics as well as piezoelectric precision drives and their combination. In addition, basic principles of machine installation and functional machine safety are discussed. The module also includes the structure and components of multi-machine systems. In addition to the linking of machines, process integration in machine tools and the modularization of production technology are discussed here. Finally, machine technology options for increasing and quantifying productivity and profitability are presented. Based on the lecture, the teaching material is deepened in exercises and internships. The classic calculation exercises are supplemented by exercises with simulation software in the PC pool and internships in the test field. A collection of tasks helps students apply the knowledge they have learned using small examples. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to: Ã¯Â¿Â½ reproduce components, peripherals and structure of machine tools, Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe design conflicts in production systems with regard to productivity versus accuracy in general and using concrete examples , Ã¯Â¿Â½ carry out calculations for typical design tasks, Ã¯Â¿Â½ analyze the behavior of machines in the time and frequency domain using simulation software and given models and vary both parameters and model elements, Ã¯ Â¿Â½ to describe special methods for solving engineering issues in production systems and to carry them out using examples.

name: Mathematical models in economics
degree-program: Dean of Studies for all courses in the Faculty of Mathematics (except courses in Data Science, MINT, Advanced and Computational Mathematics)
content: Content:Basic concepts of mathematical economics (consumer behavior, production management, market equilibria, pricing of goods, location planning, raw material allocation, etc.), linear, discrete, stochastic, dynamic and game theory models from micro and macro economics, such as input-output analysis, discrete choice experiments, economic growth, oligopoly, diffusion of innovations, income inequality, etc. Aim:The students are able to model problems with economic relevance. You can classify them, classify them and analyze them using appropriate mathematical tools. They are aware of the limited ability to interpret the results obtained in this way and are aware of the importance of the model assumptions. You can adapt the models you have learned slightly and exchange ideas about them in a mathematically precise way.

name: Advanced Microeconomics
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Microeconomics
content: Content:Building on the introductory microeconomics, this lecture examines more advanced approaches in microeconomics: the general equilibrium theory (budget optimum, Lagrangian approach, one-hedge approach) is covered llenden sentence , Slutsky decomposition, criticism of equilibrium economics), the theory of stochastic equilibria in economic distributions (maximum entropy), behavioral economics and dynamic systems and their application to microeconomic systems and network theory and their application to microeconomic systems. The application to examples from business and the theoretical-historical classification of the approaches discussed are part of the event. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to classify, understand, evaluate and apply advanced microeconomic methods. You are familiar with the most important approaches and theorems of general equilibrium theory. However, you also know the limitations of general equilibrium theory. You are familiar with alternative approaches as well as their advantages and disadvantages and can apply them to microeconomic issues and beyond. The alternative approaches include dynamical systems, network theory, maximum entropy and behavioral economics.

name: Advanced Macroeconomics
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Macroeconomics
content: Content:The module covers advanced topics in macroeconomics. Students learn in depth the stylized facts and various theories about growth, development, business cycles and macroeconomic policy. Models from different schools of thought are critically discussed and compared with each other. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to engage with the macroeconomic academic literature as well as current political debates. You have developed critical thinking skills to evaluate the possibilities and limitations of various economic theories/models for real-world problems. You can work on macroeconomic issues independently.

name: Empirical economic research I
degree-program: Junior Professorship in Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Empirical Economic Research
content: Content:The module provides extensive insight into the application of important empirical methods (supported by statistical software). Contents include linear regression model, multiple regression, inference, hypothesis testing, model validation, nonlinear models, instrumental variables, panel data. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to assess the validity of econometric studies presented to them and to carry out their own empirical studies.

name: Empirical economic research II
degree-program: Junior Professorship in Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Empirical Economic Research
content: Content:The module provides an in-depth insight into the application of important empirical methods (supported by statistical software). Contents include time series data, ARMA models, dynamic protectors, forecast models, multivariate time series models, deterministic and stochastic trends, (co-)integration. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to assess the validity of econometric studies presented to them and to carry out their own empirical studies.

name: Finance
degree-program: Dean of Studies for the Master's program in Economics
content: Content: Public goods Samuelson model Clarke tax Majority vote Tax incidence Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to describe economic relationships in the field of finance in depth.

name: Economy and growth
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Economic Policy
content: Content:This module provides an overview of two important macroeconomic phenomena: economic activity and growth. The two phenomena are presented on a conceptual level and their relationship to each other is discussed. In order to shed light on the long-term development of market economies, the first main section of the module first turns to economic growth. Post-Keynesian growth and distribution models, the workhorse of neoclassical growth theory, the Solow model and also the more modern endogenous growth theory are discussed. In the second part, the module turns to the economic phenomenon. Various approaches to measuring and forecasting economic development are discussed, such as economic indicators and econometric methods. Various economic theories and economic models are explained, essentially proceeding chronologically. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to: Ã¯Â¿Â½ classify the economic phenomenon, the growth of the economy and the relationships between the two on a conceptual level, Ã¯Â¿Â½ various methods of measurement and to know and critically assess the forecast of economic development, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to know and critically classify older and newer economic theory explanation approaches, Ã¯Â¿Â½ basics of the post-Keynesian and the exogenous and endogenous neoclassical growth theory and to assess their significance.

name: Climate Economics
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Macroeconomics
content: Content:This module covers advanced topics in environmental economics. The focus is on the macroeconomic analysis of climate change. Topics include, for example, the limits of growth, tipping points, damage functions, degrowth vs. green growth and the assessment of political options for action. In particular, integrated ecology-macroeconomic models are used for this purpose. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to engage with the relevant academic literature as well as current political debates. You have developed critical thinking skills to evaluate the possibilities and limitations of various economic theories/models for real-world problems. You can work independently on questions relating to the economics of climate change.

name: Economics of inequality
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Macroeconomics
content: Content:The module is designed to give students an introduction to the measurement, data, causes, effects and policy implications of income and wealth inequality. In the practical part, economic inequality is examined using microdata. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to engage with relevant academic literature and current political debates. You can also independently work on questions related to economic inequality.

name: Innovation economics
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Microeconomics
content: Content: Basics of the classification and analysis of innovations from an economic perspective Analysis of the influence of innovation and technology on the economy and economic growth Patents and economics of intellectual property Modeling competition and technological change with replicator dynamics and Wright's Law Fundamentals of the economics of information and communication technologies Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to classify the role of innovation, technology and technological change in economics. They know a wide range of models used, can use them and identify the advantages and disadvantages of each. You are familiar with application examples (e.g. from the information and communications technology sector) and can describe these in innovation-economic terms. You can name stylized empirical facts of technological change and explain their influence on the possible success or failure of innovation policy measures.

name: Computational Economics II
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Microeconomics
content: Content: Use of advanced computer-aided methods to investigate economic issues Preparation of data for specific analysis techniques Natural language processing techniques and their application in Context of Economic Research Applying a variety of advanced computational techniques to economic problems in a programming language Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to work on more complex economic problems using computational economics methods. You can use data in an appropriate manner and prepare it for this use if necessary. You know solutions to typical problems that arise in computational economics (long calculation times, curse of dimensionality, non-reproducibility of calculations due to stochastic influences), you are familiar with some of the ideas Â¿Â½Using Natural Language Processing.

name: Employment theory
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Economic Policy
content: Content:The module presents approaches developed over the course of the 20th century to explain employment levels and unemployment. A distinction is made between structural-related and level-related unemployment and the question is examined as to whether technical progress is exacerbating unemployment. The focus is on macroeconomic controversies, i.e. different varieties of neoclassical and Keynesian theories are confronted with each other. While the first part of the event has the character of a lecture, the second part is intended to involve the participants in the teaching in the form of a flipped classroom. Thesis papers must be written, presented and discussed for each scientific essay with reference to the history of employment theory. Aim:After successful completion of the module, the students are able to understand macroeconomic controversies on questions of the determinants of employment levels and the causes of unemployment as well as suggestions for reducing them in the respective economic theoretical paradigms to assign and critically assess. The development and defense of thesis papers strengthens the ability to work scientifically as well as the ability to engage in discourse.

name: money and credit
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Economic Policy
content: Content:The module provides in-depth insights into the most important aspects of monetary economics such as the measurement and social costs of inflation, money creation, interest rates, money demand and monetary policy. The teaching is paradigm-oriented, i.e. the individual aspects are usually examined from both a neoclassical and a Keynesian perspective. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to address controversial questions in public, such as the importance of inflation or the role of central banks in combating it, as well as conventional and unconventional monetary policy tools Assign crisis management to the respective economic theoretical paradigms and assess them critically.

name: Sustainability management
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Corporate Environmental Economics and Sustainability
content: Content:Integrative management skills are essential for today's entrepreneurial and operational activities and decision-making. The integration of sustainability aspects is less an addition than a different perspective and a systemic conceptualization of management activities. The module covers all essential company functions, such as: B. sustainable procurement, production, logistics, supply chain management, organization, marketing, etc. In addition, essential instruments and standards are presented. In addition to the theoretical and conceptual work, various examples from different industries are discussed and analyzed. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to: Ã¯Â¿Â½ name actors, problems and connections between the functional areas in their sustainability activities (knowledge), Ã¯Â¿Â½ interactions and systemic processes in sustainability management (understanding), Ã¯Â¿Â½ assessing concepts of sustainability in different contexts (application), Ã¯Â¿Â½ determining sustainability instruments and limits of sustainability innovations in holistic value chains (Analyze), Ã¯Â¿Â½ to assess (assess) the prerequisites and conditions of sustainability-oriented strategies, innovations and instruments.

name: Basics of energy law
degree-program: Professorship of public law, in particular public commercial law
content: Content: General part o Classification: interfaces between energy and environmental law o Terms, concepts, principles of environmental protection o Legal sources of environmental (protection) and energy law o Environmental protection in federal and state (constitutional) law o Instruments/procedures of Environmental protection related to energy o Liability for environmental damage and sanctions o Environmental information o Legal protection Special environmental law o Immission control law related to energy law o Nuclear law related to energy law o Waste law o Water, Soil and nature conservation law with reference to energy law General environmental law (systematics, general principles of environmental protection, legal sources of environmental protection law international/European/national, environmental protection in federal and state [constitutional] law, instruments of state Environmental protection, liability for environmental damage, sanctions for violations, special environmental law (focus on pollution control law, waste and soil protection law, water law) - individual topics are among others: o polluter pays/precautionary principle o environmental compatibility o representative actions o co-audit o integrated procedures o inspection permit o plan approval/approval including public/authority participation o circular economy models, Intervention in nature and landscape Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have developed an understanding of the fundamentals and limitations of law in solving ecological problems, particularly in the energy sector, and are able to do so explain. In addition, they are able to name and explain general questions and important individual areas.

name: Renewable energy law
degree-program: Professorship of public law, in particular public commercial law
content: Content:The module deals with the basics of renewable energy law in general - primarily the presentation of the legal context using the example of wind energy as the currently dominant form of energy production from renewable energy sources. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to explain in-depth environmental law issues with regard to current private and public law issues relating to renewable energies.

name: Selected socio-economic problems of the present
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Macroeconomics
content: Content:The module deepens the content of special economics (SVWL) economic inequality, relates it to the content of other SVWL and expands it with economic or interdisciplinary approaches. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to understand the connections between selected socio-economic problems of the present, also in connection with other SVWL, and the aspects covered in the selected course offering Analyze techniques and methods.

name: Introduction to the human geography of Europe
degree-program: Professorship of Human Geography with a focus on European migration research
content: Content:Overview of the history of ideas, methods and theoretical concepts of human geography; Introduction to the most important sub-disciplines of human geography (population, urban, social and economic geography), local, regional and supra-regional perspectives are taken; Analysis of selected current questions and problems with regard to European regions and societies Aim:The students have basic knowledge of human geography and its sub-disciplines. They are able to reflect and explain issues of European social and regional development on different scales.

name: Special problems and techniques in quantitative social research
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on empirical social research
content: Content:This module covers advanced experimental, quasi- and non-experimental research designs and data collection techniques in quantitative social research as well as specific problems in conducting empirical studies. Aim:The students have an overview of common problems when conducting empirical studies and have mastered solution strategies to deal with them.

name: Quantitative methods of social research
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on empirical social research
content: Content:The module covers advanced statistical techniques in quantitative empirical social research for analyzing cross-sectional data with different modeling variants. These include: Advanced regression technique Confirmatory factor analysis Structural equation modeling with cross-sectional data Multigroup analysis and moderator analysis Mediator analysis Missing Value method The seminar includes both the theoretical introduction to statistical techniques and concrete data analysis using practice tasks in the computer pool. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to explain the logic of key advanced quantitative methods; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Explain when and how which methods can be used; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to interpret statistical key figures in multivariate procedures; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to adequately use advanced methods to answer your own research questions; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to carry out your own statistical analyzes using statistical software (e.g. AMOS / R / Mplus); Ã¯Â¿Â½ Be able to critically reflect on the strengths and weaknesses of advanced statistical methods; Ã¯Â¿Â½ Understand, interpret and critically question empirical research reports

name: Technology management
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Innovation Research and Technology Management
content: Content:Every organization has and uses technology, so the strategic management of technology as a resource is an integral part of the strategic management of companies. This is the subject of this module. Individual topics include: Basics of innovation, R&D management and technology management Technology protection Technology assessment and prediction Technology strategies Case studies Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to explain, critically reflect on and apply the theoretical foundations, methods and empirical findings of technology management. You are also familiar with current research findings, topics and trends and can compare and discuss them.

name: People and technology I
degree-program: Professorship of People and Technology
content: Content:The module teaches basics from interdisciplinary areas of human-technology interaction, which concern both human information processing and the design of individual human-machine interfaces. Aim:The students have basic knowledge of theories, approaches, methods and problem areas of interdisciplinary research on human-centered technology.

name: People and technology II
degree-program: Professorship of People and Technology
content: Content:The module imparts knowledge from interdisciplinary areas of human-technology interaction, which affect both trends in technology development and complex socio-technical scenarios. Aim:The students have advanced knowledge of theories, approaches, methods and problem areas of interdisciplinary research on human-centered technology developments. You will develop the ability to analyze and evaluate the possible effects of technology on people and society.

name: Diversity and intergroup relations
degree-program: Professorship of Social Psychology
content: Content: Challenges and opportunities of diversity in society and in regional contexts in terms of culture, age and gender; Dealing with theoretical foundations and applied questions regarding social opportunities and challenges of demographic change and diversity Basic psychological processes (categorization, stereotyping, social identities, individual differences) Acculturation Perception of diversity (diversity beliefs, multiculturalism, color blindness) Dealing with diversity (intergroup contact and threat) Social Roles and power in diverse societies Promoting diversity (intercultural competence, diversity training) Aim:Students are able to delve deeper into current research findings on intergroup relations and diversity. You can critically question empirical study results and classify them in current theoretical contexts. You can theoretically classify and evaluate practices of dealing with social diversity; They can develop theory-based, practical measures for dealing with diversity and consider implementation and evaluation.

name: Selected problems in the methods of economics
degree-program: Professorship of Economics Ã¯Â¿Â½ Microeconomics
content: Content:The module deepens the content of special economics (SVWL) Computational Economics, relates it to the content of other SVWL and expands it with economic or interdisciplinary approaches. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to analyze selected problems of economics methods, also in connection with other SVWL, using the approaches and methods covered in the course offering.

You are able to use appropriate design software in a goal-oriented, practical manner.

name: Numerical Methods for Materials and Reliability of Micro and Nano Systems
degree-program: Professorship of Materials and Reliability of Microtechnical Systems
content: Content: Teaching the basics of FEM (theoretical and practical) Modeling, network formation, boundary conditions and solution algorithms Thermomechanical effects such as bending, thermal expansion, residual stresses; chemical shrinkage, diffusion and heat conduction modeling of elastic, elastic-plastic, visco-elastic and visco-plastic material behavior determination of damage-mechanical error parameters static and transient problems Basic principles of crack description using fracture mechanics Neural networks: basics, training and validation, evaluation criteria Examples from reliability forecasting Aim:The students have an overview of numerical methods of reliability assessment. You will master the basics of finite element modeling (FEM) with geometry structure, network design and selection of boundary conditions and understand the mathematical relationships that underlie this process. In addition, they have knowledge of constitutive material equations and modeling strategies as a basis for error physics evaluation and have a basic understanding of the use of neural networks. They are able to apply their knowledge to typical application-relevant problems in thermo-mechanics using the example of common packaging architectures.

name: Failure Analytical Methods for Micro and Nano Systems
degree-program: Professorship of Materials and Reliability of Microtechnical Systems
content: Content:Motivation and connection to the challenges of system integration: micro- and nanosystems, reliability, failure modes, industrial relevance; Methods: Optical microscopy and sample preparation, ultrasonic microscopy (SAM), scanning electron microscopy (REM) and focused ion beam technology (FIB), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), electron X-ray diffraction (EBSD) , X-ray diffractometry (XRD) and X-ray tomography (XCT), Raman spectroscopy, atomic force microscopy (AFM), infrared thermography and excitation sources, thermoreflectance, X-ray photon electron spectroscopy (XPS), characterization at cryogenic temperatures (Fl liquid nitrogen and liquid helium). Aim:The students have knowledge of error analysis methods for micro- and nanosystems and understand the underlying physical principles. They are able to apply their knowledge to typical scenarios in material and defect analysis as part of system integration in the micro and nano range. In doing so, they can establish a connection to thermo-mechanical reliability. From the internship they know typical results (error patterns) as well as limitations and have knowledge of contrast formation and parasitic effects. You have a strong interdisciplinary understanding of materials and electronic systems in fundamentals and applications.

name: Flexible electronics

The basics of material properties and the synthesis of relevant materials are taught. Questions about technological process compatibility are addressed and methods for characterizing flexible electronic components are presented. This includes electrical contacting, mechanical and electrical testing as well as optical and magnetic examination. Advanced: Deepening methodological and engineering knowledge in order to establish connections between balanced To be able to represent various technological fields and the simulative possibilities right through to assembly. The content of the specialization forms the basis for an individual training in the breadth of engineering sciences at the interface to business science.

name: Electrical engineering  basics/in-depth

content: Content:Basics: The basics provide basic knowledge of electrical engineering that is of interest for each of the specializations in modules 4.6 to 4.9. Specialization: In the specialization, knowledge of electrical engineering is imparted, which facilitates entry into one of the specialization areas of modules 4.6 to 4.9, whereby the specific selection should also be based on the interests of the students. Aim:The students have basic knowledge in the field of electrical engineering, which is essential for further training. As part of in-depth offerings, they have created the prerequisites for specialization within the framework of advanced modules 4.6 to 4.9.

name: Economics  Procurement, Production, Supply Chain Management
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration VII Ã¯Â¿Â½ Business Production Management and Industrial Management
content: Content:In the module, the problems and solution approaches in procurement and production management from the bachelor's training are deepened. Particular emphasis is placed on new and sophisticated scientific methods in decision-making. The findings from these two subjects flow into a holistic view of interconnected companies, into supply chain management. Here, too, in addition to management approaches, quantitative methods for generating networks and the inclusion of soft facts play an important role. Aim:Students acquire a profound understanding of the complexity of networked production processes. You will be able to develop approaches to efficient production control based on different situations and to prepare the use of efficient procurement strategies. You understand the conflict between the individual benefit maximization of individual companies in a production network and the benefit maximization of the entire network and have mastered theoretical approaches to overcome this conflict.

name: Economics  Corporate accounting and controlling
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration III Ã¯Â¿Â½ Corporate Accounting and Controlling
content: Content:The module teaches specific problems and solutions to short-, medium- and long-term management of companies. The questions addressed relate to the design of individual activities of management processes at various levels (goal setting, forecasting, evaluation, control including deviation analysis, etc.). The coordinated management of various company areas is also discussed (strategy determination, investment policy, design of key performance indicators, budgeting, transfer pricing and incentive systems, etc.). Particular attention is paid to control systems for specific areas and success factors of companies as well as their integration. Aim:The students acquire a profound understanding of a wide range of problems in the short, medium and long-term management of companies, their areas and success factors as well as the business management methods suitable for the respective problem situations. You can apply these methods, assess their advantages and disadvantages and make a context-related choice of method. They also acquire the tools for designing comprehensive control systems.

name: Mechanical engineering  Logistics and factory planning
degree-program: Professorship of Factory Planning and Factory Operations
content: Content:The module teaches specific problems and solution approaches in the planning and operation of factory and logistics systems. Building on this, knowledge in the use of special planning tools - in particular digital simulation and computer-aided factory planning - can be acquired. Modern logistical material and information flows are presented particularly from the perspective of the requirements of automobile manufacturing and are illustrated and deepened through excursions. Furthermore, the basics of technical logistics can be acquired. Aim:By gaining in-depth knowledge in the area of ​​planning and operation of factory and logistics systems, students are enabled to provide factory planning services using proven methods and modern software tools and to solve problems in production planning and control to solve.

name: Mechanical engineering  Industrial engineering
degree-program: Professorship of Industrial Science and Innovation Management
content: Content:The aim of the module is to promote the understanding of a holistic view of the production process and the diverse design options for improving working conditions in unity with the increase increase in productivity. Industrial Engineering offers a wide range of topics for mastering management tasks and targeted training in procedures and methods that are necessary to manage business and production processes in a complex environment to structure. The industrial engineer plans and organizes the use of personnel, systems and equipment and the use of materials in order to improve the efficiency of the work systems. He acts as a rationalization specialist in determining cost reduction potential in manufacturing processes, creating planned production costs and target times. Special tasks include: Participation in the design of assembly-friendly, user-friendly and customer-oriented products Creation of functional descriptions, organizational plans and project information Analysis of work patterns, structuring Tasks, organization of work processes, workplace design and evaluation, deployment of workers, creation of plant layouts and operating data, such as program and requirements planning, production costs, production processes and production plans ne, inventory, appointment and capacity management, order release and monitoring Methods, models and procedures of production control Development and operation of work and Environmental protection management systems Aim:By acquiring in-depth knowledge in the engineering subject areas, students are enabled to master work-scientific design methods in technical management and to be able to apply them professionally in key areas of industrial production. Â½nnen. Building on this knowledge, they are able to familiarize themselves with practical work systems in mechanical and vehicle construction and to solve engineering tasks on a scientific basis.

name: Mechanical engineering  Production technology for industrial engineers

content: Content:The module is based on value chains in the manufacturing industry, i.e. from construction, through work planning, to production and assembly, taking into account the requirements required for industrial engineers Knowledge of production technology, measurement technology, cost accounting, process evaluation, etc. The theory-related teaching units are supported by calculation exercises, practical insights and demonstrations in the test field, the processing of a case study and independent constructions (five r 3D printing) in depth and applied. Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ effective and economical use of production machines, including taking into account design conflicts regarding productivity vs. accuracy Ã¯Â¿Â½ application of methods of technical production preparation and creation of Manufacturing documents and carrying out cost-effectiveness comparisons Ã¯Â¿Â½ Selection of suitable measurement methods for evaluating geometric properties of components as well as selection of suitable testing equipment and their application in test planning Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of MÃ¯ Possibilities and areas of application of generative manufacturing processes as well as the independent creation and generation of a geometric or functional model from the idea through construction to process-appropriate data preparation

name: Electrical engineering  Automation

content: Content:In the module, automation problems and solution approaches are discussed in greater depth. For her, technical measurements are of great importance, the recording of which is treated in detail in the relevant subjects. With the subjects of process data communication, control technology, real-time processing and the basics of robotics, particular emphasis is placed on the automation of industrial processes, e.g. regarding device selection, networking and programming. Aim:The students acquire in-depth knowledge in core areas of automation technology. With these you are able to analyze technical processes and assess, select and implement various methods for automating these processes.

name: Electrical engineering  Electrical energy technology

name: Electrical engineering  Microsystems and microelectronics

content: Content:In the module, problems and solution approaches in microsystems technology and microelectronics are discussed in greater depth. In detail these are: the design process, the design methods and the testing of user-specific circuits (ASICs) sensors and measuring system, their measurement signals and interference influences and methods of Signal analysis and signal processing non-contact testing and measuring methods of geometric structural data; Recording of static and dynamic system parameters of micromechanical components Manufacturing technologies and process steps for silicon MEMS/NEMS, their packaging, measurement and 3D integration technologies using selected examples Modern IC Micro- and nanoelectronics technologies and processes; Numerical methods, models and programming for semiconductor and equipment simulation Design and dimensioning of functional groups and technical devices Medical technology applications (imaging diagnostics, use of medicine - technology in intensive care medicine) Aim:The students acquire in-depth knowledge in core areas of microsystems technology and microelectronics. With these you are able to design microelectronic and microsystem components and sensors, and to define and verify the technological manufacturing processes. Methods and procedures for the metrological analysis of components and sensors and sensor signal processing are discussed and the application and use in a device technology environment with mechanical function groups is carried out. Imparting the basics for the use of technology in medicine.

Ã¯Â¿Â½ Communications engineering: Basic knowledge of the operating principle and performance parameters of modern electronic communication technologies Ã¯Â¿Â½ Circuit design 1: Gain an overview of the design process; Acquisition of skills for application-specific selection of ASICs, based on knowledge of design methods; Acquiring the ability to acquire in-depth, application-specific knowledge; Understanding of the importance of testing and appropriate testing strategies

name: Seminar/project work

content: Content:Disciplinary or interdisciplinary project or seminar work in which the acquired knowledge is applied and consolidated and problem-related knowledge and skills are independently deepened. This can be done both on a theoretical basis and with a clear practical relevance. Aim:In particular, Module 5 supports the goals stated in the study regulations. The focus is on promoting adaptability and resilience by emphasizing projects, training analytical skills, time management, willingness to learn independently, and thinking in contexts as well as the further development of commitment, willingness to perform and motivation in project and/or seminar work. Presentation and discussion skills are also supported. Training is given in the use of data processing and presentation media for the procurement, processing, preparation and presentation of data. This module therefore serves in particular to prepare for the master's thesis.

name: technical Physics

content: Content:Logically coherent presentation of classical physics and introduction to modern physics as part of an experimental lecture in the areas: Classical mechanics/electricity/magnetism/optics Quantum concept/atoms/molecules/nuclear physics Solids/interfaces/surfaces/thin layers The aim is to start from the experimental Experience the essence of physics as a mathematized natural science and its technical relevance are made clear. Important physical phenomena and their qualitative and quantitative description are presented. In addition to the focus of classical physics, more modern problems are also adequately dealt with. In lecture-accompanying exercises, the active understanding and willingness to apply the knowledge imparted are trained. In a physics internship, simple experimental skills and the basics of laboratory work are learned. The focus should be on carrying out the test and documenting and evaluating the measurement data obtained. Aim:Understanding of physical relationships and scientific methodology; Ability to solve simple physics problems; Familiarity with simple experimental techniques and the principles of laboratory work

name: Advanced seminar in automotive technology
degree-program: Dean of Studies for the bachelor's program in Automotive Informatics
content: Content:In the advanced seminar, the students independently work on a topic of automotive technology, present it to the group and write a paper. Aim:The students are able to work academically independently.

name: Optimization for non-mathematicians
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:Mathematical optimization deals with the task of minimizing an objective function over a given admissible set. The module is designed for non-mathematical courses and provides a rough overview of procedures and techniques for formulating and solving classes of fundamental optimization problems. Aim:To correctly formulate and classify optimization problems, to model them in a targeted manner and to choose suitable solution procedures as well as to implement simple solution procedures algorithmically. Group work in the exercises promotes teamwork.

name: Vehicle powertrain
degree-program: Professorship for Alternative Vehicle Drives
content: Content: Introduction to vehicle drive technology Power requirements of a vehicle Maps Map conversion Gear grading Drive types Energy storage - energy converter - transmission - output - differential - influence on fuel consumption Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Acquiring knowledge about alternative and conventional vehicle drives as well as their structure and application in automobiles Ã¯Â¿Â½ The students should get to know the components of the vehicle drive train for conventional and alternative drives as well as understand the basic interrelationships between the components.

name: Control systems
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:The level and effectiveness in mechanical engineering are increasingly being shaped by automation technology. She masters the control of machines and systems, the automation of entire production sections or the coordination of flexible manufacturing systems. The basics of control and regulation technology are essential tools for the automation of machines and systems. Basic knowledge of the description, calculation and engineering mastery of control and regulation technology is imparted. Starting from basic concepts and basic cybernetic structures, types of representation and calculation rules of Boolean algebra and the design of simple, binary sequence controls, the course leads up to implementation industrial controls. In the Control engineering part, the control loop and its components are analyzed and the first possible descriptions in the time and frequency domain are presented. This makes it possible to derive statements about the behavior when interacting, about stability and setting rules. Aim:After completing the module, the students are able to: Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe digital systems in general and the programmable controller (PLC), Ã¯Â¿Â½ derive examples of sequential processes on production machines, these for ¿Â½ to analyze the design of binary controls and to develop a LAD/FBD Ã¯Â¿Â½ program in a PLC, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to analyze Boolean equations by transforming and Simplify, Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe simple technical systems in the time domain and frequency domain and analyze them in a practical attempt, Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe the basic control loop including standard controller (PID), Ã¯Â¿Â½ to classify the stability problem, to calculate and check controller parameters for simple routes using setting rules.

name: Electrical engineering/electronics I
degree-program: Professorship of Electrical Energy Conversion Systems and Drives
content: Content:The module deals with the physical basics of electrical engineering, introduces the field concept as well as the terms voltage, current, resistance and power and Kirchhoff's theorems and calculates simple RLC networks. Aim:The aim of the Electrical Engineering/Electronics I module is to acquire basic knowledge in the areas of electrical engineering and electronics. In addition, the students acquire knowledge and skills in scientific work, calculation and analysis methods, which enable them to work with electrical engineers on a professional level.

name: Human-Computer Interaction I
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:The module introduces the basics of human-computer interaction. Basic mechanisms of action of various types of media are discussed, with the focus on aesthetic design and ergonomic aspects. Aim:The students know the basic techniques and mechanisms of action of various media. You can produce and process different media.

name: Functional programming
degree-program: Professorship of Practical Computer Science
content: Content:Practical and theoretical concepts and methods of functional programming languages as well as an introduction to functional programming using the Haskell programming language; The focus is on functional data structures, type systems and evaluation strategies. Aim:learning the basic principles of functional programming languages ​​as well as the ability to create functional programs

name: Humanoid robots
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:The lecture provides an introduction to robotics, with a particular focus on biologically inspired humanoid robots. Various methods of programming robots to solve sensory-motor tasks are presented, which will be discussed in greater depth in the internship. The following topics are discussed in detail: sensors and actuators, kinematics, control of mobile robots, biologically inspired robots, humanoid robots, social robots and human-robot interaction, automotive informatics, roboethics. Aim:Basic practical knowledge of autonomous mobile robots (programming, sensors, robot-specific problems)

name: object oriented programing
degree-program: Professorship of Software Engineering
content: Content: History: from Simula and Smalltalk to Java and Eiffel Design concepts: classes, objects, inheritance, encapsulation, late binding Language concepts in comparison: C++, C#, Eiffel , Java Design Patterns (Software Design Patterns) in OOP like Factory, Singleton Practical programming in an OO language, IRS problems, relevance, descriptors and indexing, normalization, Zipf law, stemming, Proximity, fuzzy search, manual and automatic indexing, vector systems, data structures for IRS, search algorithms, document clustering, word clustering, data compression, text mining, strings in molecular biology Aim:The students learn and apply concepts, methods and techniques of object-oriented programming (OOP).

name: Rhetoric and communication
degree-program: Professorship of German Linguistics, Semiotics and Multimodal Communication
content: Content:The focus is on knowledge of the basics of rhetorical communication. When working on forms of speech and conversation, a basic understanding of communication and dialogue is assumed. The focus of the exercise can be: communication models, types of speech design, conversation skills, the connection between speaking posture and speech expression, structuring and preparation of topics. Aim:The students train their communicative skills with a view to the conscious use of communication strategies and adequate speaking means. They improve their conversation and speaking skills and acquire techniques and principles for creating linguistically and visually convincing and appealing conversations and speeches. Video feedback and personal feedback processes support students in realistic self-assessment of their own speaking skills.

name: Translation skills
degree-program: Professorship of English and Digital Linguistics
content: Content:In this module, students expand their basic knowledge of translation with a focus on application and professional orientation. Translatological principles such as text fidelity, addressee sensitivity and text adaptation across language and cultural boundaries play just as much a role as linguistic accuracy, knowledge of text types, communicative and stylistic effects of linguistic decisions and those required for translation work Research and editing skills. The module consists of a practical language exercise with a high practical component, in which the students acquire the necessary skills for their translation project (see below), and the linguistic seminar Translation: Linguistic Perspectives and Digital Technologies, which introduces the theoretical linguistic foundations and current digital technologies (digital dictionaries, corpora, machine translation). This also includes a practical translation project (e.g. as part of the English-German translation of subtitles for the Schlingel children's film festival). Students who did not acquire their university entrance qualification in a German-speaking country can apply to the examination board for the practical translation exercise through a one-semester course in German (with a learning objective of at least level A2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages). Aim:The students can translate texts from different areas in a linguistically correct, stylistically appropriate and appropriate manner. They are able to approach any text from a translational perspective and, using current digital technologies, to process it in a way that is appropriate for the recipient and to justify their decisions linguistically.

name: Academic Skills
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:The module gives students the opportunity to further develop their already very good written and spoken English skills so that they can communicate in the academic world in a way that is appropriate to the situation and the recipient. English for Academic Purposes offers the basics and advanced skills of academic work in English: Students learn to critically analyze academic texts. Students also train to gain access to relevant academic resources and gather targeted information. Particular attention is paid to the detection of predatory publishers. In addition, participants familiarize themselves with the challenges of academic writing by being confronted with various rhetorical and stylistic elements that are typical of academic texts. Due to the key role that academic writing plays in communicating research results and the dialogue with the research community, strategies for writing an academic paper are developed several times throughout the semester. The students are also supported in finding how they can structure their self-study. In addition, students will be familiarized with and learn various citation standards (APA, MLA and Unified Style Sheet for Linguistics). the necessary skills to transmit academic writing in one of these styles. Aim:The students can learn independently and in a self-organized manner. You can critically analyze scientific texts. You will learn vocabulary and formulations as well as tips on building and structuring a scientific paper and can apply these to your own research work. Students will be able to write an article for an academic journal using appropriate rhetoric and style. In addition, they are able to gain access to a wide variety of scientific sources and identify predatory publishers.

name: Multimedia skills
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:In multimedia skills for conferences, meetings and business audit presentations, the focus is on types of text that occur particularly frequently in both the open labor market and the academic world, such as pr sentations, debates and discussions. The module is intended in particular to further expand and promote the students' communication skills, leadership skills and presentation skills. At the same time, the practical application of new digital media is practiced. Aim:The students can communicate, evaluate and criticize scientific research results - including their own research results - also verbally and appropriately in a rhetorical and stylistic manner. You master effective presentation techniques.

name: Digital Skills
degree-program: Junior Professorship TESOL / Advanced Academic English
content: Content:In this module, students deal with digital teaching and learning methods that are important for their further studies or their future career. You will learn about current reference frameworks and tools that will help you assess and develop your digital competence. By testing and criteria-based analysis of various digital applications and resources, you gain a deeper understanding of digital teaching and learning media. In addition, they independently or collaboratively create digital materials, such as audio and video files, social media posts and online surveys. The content of the module helps you to develop a conscious and critically reflected approach to digital media. Aim:After completing the module, the students have an overview of current digital teaching and learning methods. You can assess your own digital competence using relevant frames of reference and plan steps to further optimize your digital competence. You have strategies for the goal-oriented selection, use and design of digital resources. This also includes digital communication and collaboration skills as well as the ability to create your own digital teaching and learning materials. You can compare and critically evaluate digital tools based on criteria in order to recognize and use their advantages and limitations for specific purposes.

name: Project management skills
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:The module builds skills that are important both in the open labor market and in the academic world. In the Project Management exercise, a cross-semester project (publication, study trip, conference, etc.) is discussed, planned and carried out independently in intercultural small groups (approx. 6-12 participants). and finally documented in a product (e.g. WWW pages). Aim:The students acquire teamwork skills in the Project Management exercise; They can communicate better in a team and do targeted work together. Through the project work, the students also acquire other key qualifications, such as problem-solving skills, communication skills, project planning, risk management and leadership skills.

name: Professional Skills
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:The module builds skills that are important both in the open labor market and in the academic world. The Writing in Professional Contexts exercise focuses on media-mediated texts, in particular the connection between linguistic skills and the communication possibilities of new media as well as linguistic and textual preparation techniques such as proofreading, editing or layouting. The exercise further offers students the opportunity to build skills in various types of text (e.g. newspaper articles, annual reports, marketing texts, formal emails, science blogs, etc.) used in different professional fields, e.g. B. (scientific) journalism, marketing, and in the areas of (technical) editing. The students also learn to write texts for different target groups and to make scientific research results accessible to a wider audience. In this way, students are introduced to different styles of professional writing by familiarizing them with various rhetorical and stylistic elements typical of this type of text. The module also promotes the students' professional interest and creativity. Aim:In the Writing in Professional Contexts exercise, students acquire the ability to write a variety of text types for different target groups and to confidently use appropriate rhetoric and style. In addition, the students' professional skills and interests are developed and the students acquire knowledge of journalistic research and preparation techniques, flexibility of expression in written English and they gain insights into editorial activities.

name: Cultural Skills
degree-program: Professorship of English Literature
content: Content:This module is, firstly, about the theoretical development of concepts of alterity (e.g. collective constructions such as "Us and The Others" or xenological constructs of the foreign or foreignness), while at the same time the application reference should be made clear. Secondly, it is about learning practical cultural work. Aim:The students master methods and theories for analyzing literary and other media texts, including central categories of literary studies, cultural studies and media studies. In the area of ​​social skills, they can take their own and others' perspectives and change perspectives. You have mastered an alternative understanding of roles, e.g. that of the partial integration of other people's routines. You will master the cultural skills (cultural organization, cultural work) within and outside the academic environment and will be able to analyze environments influenced by foreign cultures and culture-dependent perspectives and behaviors.

name: Practical skills
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:Career field orientation through an internship in a professional field corresponding to the field of study, e.g. translation agency, language school, adult education, publishing house (proofreading, editing), newspaper/magazine (writing texts, editing), online publishing , independent school or educational institutions (international kindergarten), press office, foreign language assistance, cultural institution (e.g. museum, theater, film/cinema), library. The internship can also be completed abroad. Completion of the Communication and Leadership seminar offered in English Aim:The students choose an internship position that suits their focus from various offers that they obtain on their own and apply for. You can express yourself as you wish and adequately present your strengths and concerns in a letter of motivation. During the internship you can apply the skills and competencies you have learned during your previous studies. You can plan work processes, develop proposed solutions and assess tasks. By writing an internship report, students can evaluate their own work and the skills and abilities they have gained. By successfully completing the Communication and Leadership seminar, students can practically test leadership roles, create their own brand, communicate in collaborative contexts or fulfill leadership roles in digital contexts.

name: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL)
degree-program: Junior Professorship TESOL / Advanced Academic English
content: Content:This application-oriented module prepares students to teach the target language English in a variety of educational contexts. This includes, among other things, language courses in adult education, at (private) schools and universities, in freelance work as well as in-house training and further education. The students critically examine foreign language acquisition theories and methods of teaching English. Methods of face-to-face, blended and online teaching are discussed, tested and linked together in a targeted manner. The close connection between theory and practice enables students to gain initial teaching experiences, to position them theoretically and to reflect critically. The theoretical and methodological foundations (Introduction to English Language Teaching) find practical application in the independent development (Curriculum Planning and Materials Development) and testing (Classroom Observation and Teaching Practice) of teaching and learning materials for the English lessons. These sub-elements are linked together in a final folder and contextualized, evaluated and reflected in writing. Aim:After completing the module, the students have a broad knowledge and critical understanding of foreign language acquisition theories and methods of foreign language teaching. You are able to analyze, modify and evaluate teaching and learning materials for English lessons. You can design courses independently or collaboratively and develop teaching and learning materials for specific learning goals and learning groups. The students integrate analog and digital resources in a targeted manner. You will learn about methods of classroom observation and evaluation and apply them in practice. They also gain their own teaching experience as part of micro-teaching or with a potential future employer. They reflect critically on these experiences in order to be able to continually optimize their professional actions in teaching practice.
