name: Digital English Linguistics
degree-program: Professorship of English and Digital Linguistics
content: Content:The subject of the module is the guided acquisition of the latest quantitative and qualitative empirical research methods in English and digital linguistics and their application in research-oriented projects. In the Digital Research Methods in Linguistics seminar, students use practical exercises to deal with the theory and practice of experimental design, empirical data collection and analysis, and the competent handling of primary data of linguistics. They also gain basic knowledge of statistics, programming (e.g. with R) and data visualization and learn how to use current professional software. In the Current Topics in Digital Linguistics and Applied Digital English Linguistics seminars, students expand their knowledge of digital linguistics and design and implement their own empirical studies and digital projects. Aim:The students are able to work on empirical research questions they have developed using appropriate methodology based on the specialized linguistic and methodological knowledge they have learned. You can collect, analyze and interpret data as well as visualize and discuss the results.

name: English Literatures
degree-program: Professorship of English Literature
content: Content:Deepening knowledge in the area of English literary and cultural history as well as media studies-oriented literary studies; Overview of individual eras and literary genres, development and reflection of connections between literary texts and social processes in historical and current cultural and media contexts; Literary and cultural studies methods and theories are developed by the students and applied in individual case analyses. Aim:The students master theories and methods for analyzing literary and other media texts, including central categories of literary studies, cultural studies and media studies. You can recognize and analyze connections, traditions and breaks within English literary studies in their intertextual and intermedial dimensions. You have interpretative and aesthetic skills.

name: Comparing Societies, Politics, and Cultures in Anglophone Countries
degree-program: Professorship of British and American Cultural and Regional Studies
content: Content:Teaching social science theories and methods (quantitative, qualitative, comparative); Deepening knowledge of the social, political and economic constitutional conditions of British and American society and culture (e.g. Issues in Comparative Government and Politics); Extending such knowledge to local and regional subdivisions (e.g. Scotland, Wales, New England, the South etc.) as well as other Anglophone cultures and societies (e.g. Australia, New Zealand, Canada etc.); Comparative analysis of the similarities and differences in the structure and development of Anglophone societies and cultures or individual social, political or cultural phenomena and practices (e.g. Music and National Identity in English-Speaking Countries) Aim:The students have gained a deeper understanding of theoretical and methodological approaches to the analysis of societies, political systems and cultures. You are capable of critical methodological reflection regarding the applicability of specific theories and methods. You have a deeper understanding of the interrelationship between culture, society and politics in Anglophone societies. This enables them to explain specific social patterns and development paths (especially their critical junctures) of English-speaking societies as well as to comparatively interpret cultural peculiarities and similarities and they can do this in oral and written form present form.

name: Modeling and identification of dynamic systems
degree-program: Professorship of Control Engineering and System Dynamics
content: Content: Model concept and methods of model building Introduction to system identification (basic terms, definitions, etc.) Introduction to identification procedures (designations, bias, consistency, compensation calculation , among others) Identification procedures for dynamic systems Aim:The students know different types of models and typical model building procedures and are able to apply them.

name: Nonlinear control / nonlinear control
degree-program: Professorship of Control Engineering and System Dynamics
content: Content: Introduction and general properties of nonlinear systems Lyapunov theory based controller design Singular disturbance theory Dissipative itt and passivity Differential geometric methods Modern methods of nonlinear control Aim:Students will be able to derive controller design procedures based on basic structural properties. You know modern non-linear control concepts and can design non-linear control loops in state space.

name: Robot controls
degree-program: Professorship of Robotics and Human-Technology Interaction
content: Content: Basics of controlling robots: control in joint space, in Cartesian space Robot dynamics Robot control architectures (central and decentralized controls) Computed torque approaches Gravity compensation Active and passive compliance Impedance based control Hybrid robot controls, force, path, speed Action primitives Safe human Robot interaction, robot path planning running and gripping Aim:The students have in-depth knowledge in the field of stationary robotics. Based on this knowledge, you will be able to find solutions to engineering problems relating to the development and application of robotic systems.

name: Robot vision
degree-program: Professorship of Robotics and Human-Technology Interaction
content: Content:The lecture covers the contents of robot vision. First, the basics of image processing and camera calibration as well as hand-eye calibration are discussed. This is followed by signal processing methods for image processing and image enhancement. Methods of feature recognition are then discussed. In the second part of the lecture, methods of 3-dimensional computer vision are presented. This includes stereo vision, the coded light approach and other methods for depth vision. Algorithms for image segmentation and classification are also discussed. The position protection of objects for interaction with robots is another topic of the lecture. Aim:The students understand the basics of image processing and get to know the most important algorithms for processing visual information in robotics. With this knowledge, you are able to develop your own image processing algorithms for robotics.

name: Statistics, reliability and isolation coordination
degree-program: Professorship of Energy and High Voltage Technology
content: Content: Empirical statistical and theoretical distribution functions Proof of the independence of measurement series through statistical test procedures, planning of experiments Magnification law Adaptation of the insulation capacity to expected stresses Determination of point availability in electrical networks Aim:The students have knowledge of the basics of isolation coordination, know the basic concepts of reliability and can determine these mathematically. You have knowledge of statistical distribution functions and their application to describe the insulation capacity and the resulting electrical stress. Based on their knowledge, they are able to plan high-voltage tests and test procedures to prove the independence of measurement series.

name: Advanced methods of control engineering / Advanced Control Methods
degree-program: Professorship of Control Engineering and System Dynamics
content: Content:As part of the courses, advanced methods of control engineering are presented and applied using examples. Possible subject areas are: robust control adaptive and learning control procedures constructive concepts and algorithms hybrid control procedures stochastic control procedures Aim:The students have knowledge of advanced control methods and are able to apply them to complex problems in a targeted manner.

name: Autonomous systems
degree-program: Professorship of Process Automation
content: Content:Today's automation is characterized by "simple" controls and regulations; In complex situations, people still have to intervene. Autonomous systems, on the other hand, decide independently, even in more complex situations, how they must behave in order to achieve their goal. These include autonomous robots that move in a natural environment and carry out tasks independently (as service robots in factories or hospitals or even on Mars), in the future Future driving assistance systems in cars that enable highly automated or even completely autonomous drivers and intelligent factories (Industry 4.0). Such systems must perceive their environment via sensors, evaluate and interpret the information and generate appropriate behavior. The courses provide an overview of current methods of autonomous systems. In the practical part, various tools (e.g. ROS Robot Operating System) and procedures will be implemented and tested experimentally. Additional information about the content can be found on the website of the Professorship for Process Automation. Aim:The students know the current state of research in this area and are able to independently acquire sophisticated specialist knowledge, apply it practically and present it.

name: Project internship autonomous systems
degree-program: Professorship of Process Automation
content: Content:Autonomous systems, such as service robots or self-driving cars, decide independently how to achieve a specific goal and, to do this, must perceive their environment via sensors, evaluate the information, interpret it and adopt appropriate behavior generate. This course is a supplement and deepening of the teaching content of the module Autonomous Systems and builds on the knowledge acquired there. In the project internship, students work in groups on a complex practical task over a longer period of time. For example, methods for image processing, pattern recognition, navigation, localization and behavior control are used. In the accompanying seminar, the groups' work progress is presented, in-depth specialist knowledge is imparted and current topics in autonomous systems are presented and discussed. Additional information about the content can be found on the website of the Professorship for Process Automation. Aim:The students are able to put the previously acquired knowledge of autonomous systems into practice, even in complex tasks, by working independently and in a group. You can acquire specialist knowledge independently, question it and be able to present it.

name: Advanced Robotics / Deep Learning for Robotics
degree-program: Professorship of Robotics and Human-Technology Interaction
content: Content:The module focuses on advanced methods of robotics. Thematic focuses include: Stochastic and probabilistic methods Neural networks and deep learning Reinforcement learning Deep reinforcement learning Recurrent networks Applications of learning algorithms in robotics Aim:The students have the latest knowledge in the field of artificial intelligence in order to use it in robotics. You are able to use methods from the areas of deep learning and reinforcement learning that are used in robotics.

name: Advanced Robotics Lab
degree-program: Professorship of Robotics and Human-Technology Interaction
content: Content:In this module, the specialist knowledge acquired in the robotics lectures is practically deepened. To do this, the team carries out a practical task on the robot. The students learn to solve complex tasks together. The specific task can be chosen from one of the following areas: Robot control Image processing/robot vision Neural networks and deep learning Reinforcement learning Deep Reinforcement Learning Recurrent Networks Aim:The students are able to practically apply their theoretical knowledge in the field of robotics and solve a complex task in a team.

name: Seminar robotics and human-technology interaction
degree-program: Professorship of Robotics and Human-Technology Interaction
content: Content:As part of a seminar, various new methods and procedures from the field of robotics and human-technology interaction will be presented. Key topics include: Robot path planning Robot action planning Sensor data processing Human-technology interaction Machine learning Image processing Robot controls Aim:The students are able to independently deal with a topic from the field of robotics and human-technology interaction, to prepare a lecture on this topic and to present it to an audience.

name: Diagnostic and measurement technology
degree-program: Professorship of Energy and High Voltage Technology
content: Content: Measurement of the peak value of high voltages, transient measurement systems Partial discharge and loss factor measurement technology Measurement of relaxation currents and recovery voltages Diagnosis and measurement technology for r cables, gas-insulated switchgear (GIS) and transformers Aim:The students are familiar with the aspects of condition assessment and maintenance of electrical energy system equipment. You know testing and diagnostic procedures for determining insulation capacity.

name: Technical thermodynamics I
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content:The module is divided into eight chapters. After conveying the general basics, the statements of the 1st and 2nd laws of thermodynamics are explained, whereby the state size entropy is introduced hours and the energy is divided into exergy and anergy. This is followed by an introduction to the thermodynamic properties of pure fluid substances (homogeneous phases and phase equilibrium). The most important cycle processes for energy conversion (thermal power plants, combustion power plants, refrigeration machines, heat pumps) are then discussed using examples. Furthermore, there are short introductions to the areas of flow processes (nozzles, diffusers, engines), the thermodynamics of mixtures (mixtures of ideal gases, ideal gas-steam mixtures, moist air). ) as well as heat transfer (heat conduction, convective heat transfer, heat transfer, heat radiation). Aim:The students can analyze and calculate simple energy technology processes as well as simple flow processes using thermodynamics and evaluate them in terms of energy and exergy. The acquired knowledge about the thermodynamic properties of fluid substances enables students to understand the behavior of fluid substances and to obtain the material data required for calculations. Overall, the students can apply the knowledge and skills they have acquired to concrete thermodynamic problems.

name: Fluid dynamics
degree-program: Professorship of Fluid Mechanics
content: Content:Fluid dynamics is a fundamental engineering discipline. For the design and development of machines, devices and apparatus, flow theory is the basis of engineering tools. The focus here is often on the movement behavior of liquids and gases and their effect on solid components. The focus of the lecture is on both the theoretical derivation and the application of fundamental laws that are of particular importance for technology. The treatment of these theoretical connections takes place with the aim of providing the students with a viable basis for solving fluid mechanics problems on their own convey. This project is supported by the discussion of selected application examples. Aim:The students have demonstrated the basic knowledge necessary for understanding fluid dynamics and are able to apply it. You have an in-depth understanding of detailed questions and can analyze fluid mechanics issues independently.

name: Process thermodynamics
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content:The course builds on the basic knowledge acquired in the Technical Thermodynamics I module. Using selected, modern thermodynamic processes to provide electrical energy, heat or cooling for households, industry and commerce, technical systems are evaluated from an energetic and exergetic perspective. Contemporary boundary conditions from the area of tension between society, politics and industry (keyword: energy and raw material transition) are also taken into account. Aim:The students can analyze somewhat more complex thermodynamic processes energetically and exergetically. Based on this, they can critically assess possible application scenarios, taking into account given boundary conditions (e.g. society, politics and industry) and derive appropriate improvement concepts from them. In addition, they are able to prepare the results of their work according to scientific standards and to present and reflect on them in front of an expert committee.

name: Basics of electrical engineering
degree-program: Professorship of High Frequency Engineering / Professorship of Electrical Energy Conversion Systems and Drives
content: Content: Calculation of linear networks (node potential and mesh current method) Electrostatic fields, stationary electric flow fields, magnetostatics (field line images, movement of charges, Gaussian theorem , capacity, behavior of the field size at interfaces, energy and forces) Time-varying magnetic fields (law of induction, Inductances, mutual inductances, energy in the magnetic field, hysteresis, forces) compensation or transient processes alternating currents me (complex calculation, pointer, locus, filter, power) Transformer (structure, mode of operation, equivalent circuit diagrams) Asynchronous machine, synchronous machine Basic concepts of analog and digital electronics Aim:The students know the basic methods of electrical engineering, electronics and electromagnetic energy conversion and are able to apply their knowledge in practical laboratory experiments.

name: Electrical engineering/electronics
degree-program: Professorship of Electrical Energy Conversion Systems and Drives
content: Content:As part of the module, basic knowledge of electrical engineering is imparted, which is necessary on the one hand for understanding the operating behavior of electrical machines and electronic circuits and, on the other hand, for the maintenance, construction and development of new technologies. The focus is on recognizing physical-technical and economic connections. In the field of electronics, the basic components, technologies and circuits are covered. The practical laboratory training enables the students to deepen and consolidate their knowledge of measurement methods in electrical engineering, the operating behavior of the most important electromechanical energy converters and the operation of basic electronic circuits. Aim:The students have basic knowledge in the areas of electrical engineering, electromechanical energy conversion and electronics and can apply this in setting up and carrying out practical laboratory experiments. Thanks to their knowledge and skills in the area of ​​scientific work, calculation and analysis methods, they are able to work with electrical engineers on a professional level.

name: Electromagnetic energy converters
degree-program: Professorship of Electrical Energy Conversion Systems and Drives
content: Content: Physical basics of electromagnetic energy converters Direct current machines, electromagnetic and permanent magnetic excitation Single-phase transformers, three-phase transformers, special designs Basics of induction machines Asynchronous machines with short-circuit current shore and slip ring rotors Synchronous machines with full-pole rotors and leg-pole rotors Small and special machines Important measuring and testing procedures f r electrical machines Aim:The students have knowledge of the structure, mode of operation, stationary operating behavior and mathematical description of electromagnetic energy converters and are able to carry out experimental work on them .

name: Internship and practice of communication
degree-program: Professorship of General Psychology and Biopsychology Professorship of Social Psychology
content: Content:In the module, an insight into possible fields of work is gained through an internship. In addition, practical exercises on conducting interviews or negotiations and conflict resolution provide essential professional skills selective skills acquired. Aim:The students have key professional skills in selected applied practical professional fields and in the psychological practice of communication. You are able to conduct psychological discussions and negotiations and contribute to resolving conflicts.

name: Research methods
degree-program: Professorship of Research Methodology and Evaluation in Psychology
content: Content:Deepening and expanding the psychological-methodological fundamentals from the bachelor's degree (including additions to data collection, further multivariate procedures, computer modeling, qualitative procedures, alternative inferential statistical approaches, special features of evaluation research, decision theory). The seminar is strongly practice-oriented and is usually offered on one of the following subject areas: evaluation research in practice, mathematical psychology, computer modeling of social or cognitive processes, multivariate methods, experimental individual case analysis, specific methods. Aim:The students have in-depth knowledge of psychological methods; They develop sound methodological skills for planning empirical studies and applying appropriate procedures in all phases of empirical research.

name: Methods and areas of application of diagnostics
degree-program: Professorship of Personality Psychology and Diagnostics
content: Content:Acquire knowledge and skills about the diagnostic process, get to know areas of application of psychological diagnostics, know the possibilities and limitations of diagnostic assessment methods, judgment and decision models, deepening test theory and test construction, psychological assessment Aim:The students acquire in-depth knowledge of the background and application of diagnostic approaches. They know the steps, procedures and models of the diagnostic process and can implement the diagnostic process in various application areas.

name: Deepening the basics of cognition, emotions, motivation
degree-program: Professorship of General Psychology and Biopsychology Professorship of Research Methodology and Evaluation in Psychology
content: Content:The module covers advanced psychological aspects of cognition (cognitive processes and their modeling) as well as emotion and motivation (emotional and motivational determinants of behavior). Topics that are being worked on in research projects at the Institute of Psychology will be explored in greater depth. In addition, there is a focus on the comprehensive consideration of physiological, evolutionary, social and (epi)genetic influences in the context of emotion, motivation and behavior. Aim:The students acquire in-depth knowledge of the fundamentals of experience and action in relation to cognition, emotion and motivation, phylogeny and adaptation, ontogeny and biological processes as well as resource management. You are able to apply this knowledge in various areas of psychology and related disciplines.

name: Education and support
degree-program: Professorship of Educational Psychology and Developmental Psychology
content: Content:Promoting children, young people and adults (up to old age) through education and training; empirical educational research and its methods; family, social and cultural framework conditions of educational processes; intervention research and its methods; promoting development and personality; promoting ethical behavior; gifted education; Support in old age Aim:Students acquire in-depth knowledge of funding in the areas of developmental, educational and clinical psychology as well as an understanding of research and research methodology in these areas.

name: Applied gerontopsychology
degree-program: Professorship of Applied Gerontopsychology and Cognition
content: Content:Theories, methods and findings of gerontopsychology, basic content from neighboring disciplines in aging science, tasks, best practice examples and current developments in fields of application of gerontopsychology (e.g. use of technology, mobility, work, education, health promotion, housing, care) Aim:The students acquire in-depth knowledge of geriatric psychology, including its application. You will be able to receive knowledge-based and methodologically critical reception of gerontopsychological research literature and to analyze and work on problems from application areas of gerontopsychology.

name: Predictive behavior analysis
degree-program: Professorship of Predictive Behavior Analysis
content: Content:The module provides a theoretical understanding and practical experience with fundamental concepts of data analysis, cognitive modeling and machine learning for processing data in general and predicting human behavior in particular. The focus of the event is on general methods and basic algorithms, their advantages and disadvantages and typical areas of application. Aim:The students have successfully acquired methods and practical examples for statistical modeling and machine learning applied to large amounts of data. You will be able to use this knowledge with the help of the programming skills you have developed in the typical application areas of predictive behavior analysis and machine learning.

name: Cognitive modeling
degree-program: Professorship of Predictive Behavior Analysis
content: Content:Knowledge about the function of cognitive processes in the areas of memory, perception, thinking and decision-making and language is conveyed and their implementation in cognitive architectures such as ACT-R or other modeling paradigms is presented. Methods for replicating experimental data and the quality of cognitive modeling approaches are discussed. Aim:Students will have a critical understanding of fundamental cognitive theories and how these can be implemented. You can analyze cognitive tasks, model them using statistical, computer science and psychological methods and question and further develop existing concepts.

name: Human factors
degree-program: Professorship of General Psychology and Human Factors
content: Content: cognitive ergonomics workplace and work equipment design product design human-machine systems automation Aim:The aim is to acquire in-depth knowledge of the human-work and human-technology interface in the area of ​​cognitive ergonomics/user-centered design (engineering psychology/human factors). The central topic is the user-oriented design of work equipment as well as technical systems and products.

name: Work and organizational psychology
degree-program: Professorship of Work, Organizational and Business Psychology
content: Content:Theoretical foundations and scientific methods of work and organizational psychology research, current empirical findings in work and organizational psychology and their practical significance; Deepening of the content acquired in Module N in the bachelor's degree program in Psychology. Aim:The students Ã¯Â¿Â½ have an overview of current research in the areas of work and organizational psychology, Ã¯Â¿Â½ can critically evaluate the theoretical foundations and empirical findings of this research , Ã¯Â¿Â½ can critically discuss the practical use of scientific findings, Ã¯Â¿Â½ can independently derive new research questions from the areas and carry out studies to empirically test them develop, Ã¯Â¿Â½ have an understanding of the influence of social developments on the working and professional world (e.g. demographic change, digitalization).

name: Clinical psychology and psychotherapy (mental disorders and psychotherapeutic interventions)
degree-program: Professorship of Clinical Psychology and Psychotherapy
content: Content:The module consists of two content areas: 1. Deepening psychotherapeutic interventions Structural, professional and social legal framework conditions for clinical action (PsychThG, Psych-RL, licensing and training regulations); Therapy planning and structuring; intervention-related diagnostics; influencing factors; clinical effectiveness testing and evidence-based psychotherapy; Health care research and health care situation; exemplary intervention methods 2. Deepening mental disorders In-depth presentation of selected psychological disorders, including mental disorders and behavioral disorders caused by psychotropic substances (F10-19); impulse control disorders (F63); schizophrenia and psychotic disorders (F20-29); Affective disorders (F30-39); anxiety disorders (F40-43); Dissociative disorders (F44); Somatoform disorders (F45) Aim:The students acquire disorder and intervention-related knowledge and practical skills for the guided application of diagnostic and psychotherapeutic methods and interventions on patients.

name: Scientific work and scientific communication
degree-program: Executive Director of the Institute of Psychology
content: Content:practical scientific work in a working group of a professorship at the Institute of Psychology, documentation, design and presentation of research work, specific techniques for scientific work, presentation and discussion of the master's thesis Aim:Experience and skills in conducting research projects: literature research, analysis of the state of research, research planning, data collection and analysis, data interpretation and theoretical integration. The students acquire the ability to familiarize themselves with new subject areas and practice using psychological methods and theories. You will be able to work on given scientific questions. Scientific work is planned, carried out, evaluated, documented and presented independently or in a team. The critical examination of research approaches and results is taught, essential techniques for scientific work are acquired and the appropriate preparation and presentation of research work is learned.

name: Pedagogy
degree-program: Executive Director of the Institute for Pedagogy
content: Content:The subject is further problem and action connections in educational science, adult and further education, economic education and educational research with reference to the relevant fundamentals, basic concepts and traditions of thought. Aim:A further overview of the cognitive interests and methods in a selected area of ​​pedagogy is provided.

name: Media technology
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:The central content of the media technology lecture is the definition and explanation of central terms and techniques of media production in theory and practice. In the exercise, the students are trained in how to use the equipment of the Media Informatics Professorship (television studio). The central content of the module is the definition and explanation of central terms and techniques of audiovisual media with particular consideration of image, audio and camera, video, editing and lighting technology as well as 3D modeling, motion graphics and basic media processing tools. Aim:The students have a broad overview of the technology for producing audiovisual media. You are able to produce short video documentaries. The students know the basics of production technology. You can create, edit and process audiovisual media.

name: Work science
degree-program: Professorship of Industrial Science and Innovation Management
content: Content:Ergonomics pursues the equal goals of increasing the effectiveness and efficiency of human work and human-technology interactions and of adapting working conditions and technology to people's physiological, psychological and social requirements. The module presents basic work science description and explanation approaches as well as work analysis and design principles, methods and instruments. These are used in many engineering-related professional fields and are constantly being developed and further developed as technological and organizational innovations progress. The main topics of the module are: Basics of human work and human-technology interaction Stress/stress concept, basics of work physiology and psychology Exemplary design areas of work organization Basics of occupational safety and health-friendly work design Exemplary design fields in the working environment Basics of anthropometry Basics of system ergonomics Ergonomic aspects of knowledge work Aim:The students have basic work science and orientation knowledge for a wide range of engineering-based professions. You can apply selected occupational science methods and instruments and are able to assess and select in-depth courses on occupational science.

name: Sociology of social change
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on sociological theories
content: Content:Introduction to the driving forces, mechanisms, effects and pathologies of social change with special consideration of political actors and social power and dominance relationships Aim:Students acquire fundamental knowledge in the field of the sociology of social change. You understand the central conceptual tools and theories of sociology and can use these to explain social development dynamics and persistence tendencies. They know the central concepts and findings of political sociology and can assess the possibilities and limits in the political shaping of social change.

name: Sociology of technical change
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on work, economics and organization Junior Professorship of Sociology with a focus on technology
content: Content:Introduction to the social potential and challenges of technical change with special consideration of the associated changes in work, business, organization and communication Aim:Students acquire fundamental knowledge in the field of the sociology of technical change, with particular attention to the areas of the Internet, work, economics and organization.

name: Sociology of demographic change
degree-program: Professorship of Sociology with a focus on sociological theories Professorship of Sociology with a focus on health research Professorship of Sociology with a focus on empirical social research
content: Content:Introduction to the social potential and challenges of demographic change and the methods for its empirical investigation with particular consideration of social-structural and health-related disparities Aim:The students acquire fundamental knowledge in the field of the sociology of demographic change, with particular attention to the subject areas of social structure and health as well as the quantitative methods of social research.

name: Biomechanical ergonomics
degree-program: Professorship for Research Methods and Analysis Methods in Biomechanics
content: Content:The module addresses the meaning and benefits of biomechanical methods in the context of workplace design - especially in physical activities. First, there is a theoretical foundation of biomechanical-ergonomic practices for the design and evaluation of work processes and work environments. Methods and models commonly used - in particular a selection of digital human models - are presented and critically reflected. In addition to the theoretical foundation, selected practical applications are examined in more detail. Based on this, consequences for the ergonomically sensible design of work processes and environments are derived. Aim:The students should be made aware of the interaction of biomechanical and health aspects in the workplace, know the application-specific possibilities and limitations of biomechanical measurement systems, classify and interpret biomechanical-ergonomic measurement data in the working environment, and learn biomechanical methods and the use of digital (human -)Be able to critically reflect on models against the background of concrete applications.

name: Health and quality management
degree-program: Professorship for Social Scientific Perspectives on Sport, Exercise and Health Promotion
content: Content:The module includes economic and business management aspects and their specific application in healthcare organizations. The aim of this module is to convey the economic characteristics of health-related markets, goods and demand. In addition, business processes are examined in order to develop a fundamental understanding of business objectives and operational processes in healthcare organizations. Aim:Acquisition of the necessary business management fundamentals that enable competent action in organizations in the health sector; Imparting skills (planning, organizing, leading, budgeting, controlling) for taking on management tasks in healthcare organizations

name: Business Administration / Organization and Human Resources
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Organization and International Management Professorship of Business Administration Ã¯Â¿Â½ Human Resources Management and Leadership
content: Content:Offer 1: Human Resource Management HRM Overview of behavioral science basics, basic understanding of theoretical approaches, fields of action and current challenges in human resources Management (HRM) Offer 2: Organizational theories Essential organizational theories and in-depth study of social and organizational theoretical fundamentals Offer 3: Leadership theories Essential current leadership theories and - concepts and their application Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Offer 1: Human Resource Management Ã¯Â¿Â½ HRM After successfully completing the module, the students have developed a basic understanding of the content and problems of human resource management and are able to to reproduce and apply their specialist knowledge and to analyze relevant questions. Ã¯Â¿Â½ Offer 2: Organizational Theories After successfully completing the module, students are able to analyze management and organizational problems from various perspectives using theory. Ã¯Â¿Â½ Offer 3: Leadership Theories After successful completion of the module, students are able to explain, compare and contrast new theories and concepts of leadership to assign the respective explanation and design contribution to management problems.

name: Basics of psychophysics
degree-program: Dean of Studies Sensory Science and Cognitive Psychology (B.Sc., M.Sc.) of the Faculty of Natural Sciences
content: Content: Basic concepts and history of psychophysics Central psychophysical methods (e.g. criterion-free measurement, signal discovery theory, adaptive procedures, scaling) Application of psychophysical methods to measure perception and cognition Combination psychophysical and psychophysiological measurements experimental design for psychophysical studies practical exercises for recording psychophysical measurements Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Knowledge of basic psychophysical methods Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to select suitable psychophysical methods Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to critically classify methods and results of psychophysical studies

name: Cognitive systems
degree-program: Professorship of Applied Gerontopsychology and Cognition Professorship of General Psychology and Human Factors Professorship of Research Methodology and Evaluation in Psychology
content: Content:The content of the module is theories and findings on higher cognitive performance, the interaction of cognitive functions and the technical support of cognitive processes. Aim:The aim of this module is to acquire in-depth knowledge of integrating theories of cognitive systems that enable you to analyze cognitive performance and identify support options.

name: Higher technical mechanics
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:In this module, higher technical mechanics is taught as a supplement to the subject area of technical mechanics with particular attention to strength of materials. A key focus is on linear structures and flat surface structures within the framework of linear elasticity theory. The lectures and exercises are limited to the treatment of small deformations. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to solve problems from the field of higher technical mechanics, in particular fundamental tasks on line structures (string, Timoshenko beam) and surface structures (membrane, boiler forms, disc, plate) as well as torsion, to understand, assess and solve independently. In addition, the students gain knowledge of suitable finite element formulations for beams and plates. In particular, in the exercises accompanying the lectures, the students gain experience in solving concrete, mechanical engineering-typical tasks and develop an intuitive understanding of mechanically influenced design and dimensioning issues.

name: Technical thermodynamics II
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content:The module is divided into six chapters. Building on the Technical Thermodynamics I module, the thermodynamic considerations of thermal power plants are first expanded and an introduction to the area of heat integration/warmth is introduced Recovery. The thermodynamics of the mixtures will be discussed later, with ideal gas-steam mixtures being discussed using moist air as an example. In addition, mixtures are examined in the context of chemical reactions using the example of technical combustion. Real mixtures, phase equilibria and simple thermal separation processes are then discussed. Finally, the state behavior of real substances (pure substances and mixtures) is discussed in detail. Aim:The students understand the application of thermodynamic methods to more complex material systems and other important technical processes. You can apply the theoretical models according to the circumstances and make sensible use of calculations and process-describing diagrams for design tasks.

name: Manufacturing process design (work preparation)
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:The methodology of technical production preparation is taught. The core is the methodically correct forward thinking of the production and assembly of a product. The students receive an overview of the terminology, the tools, the necessary production documents, the informational and technical connections of technological planning. Basic methods and options for computer support are discussed. In the exercises, the lecture material is deepened in a practical way in the form of a case study, the results of which are the most important production documents for a specific workpiece. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ classify manufacturing and assembly processes with regard to process elements, quantity structures and organizational forms, Ã¯Â¿Â½ individual parts in the assembly network with regard to production- and functional design to evaluate, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to apply the various principles and associated work planning processes depending on the situation and to create appropriate production documents, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to subject technological production variants to a cost-effectiveness comparison and to apply appropriate calculation methods, Ã¯Â¿Â½ To classify and systematize manufacturing tasks and manufacturing processes, to technologically design assembly processes and to calculate cycle times.

name: Drive, mechanism and movement technology
degree-program: Professorship of Assembly and Handling Technology
content: Content:Based on an extensive system, the fundamental knowledge required for the calculation and design (analysis and synthesis) of uniformly and unevenly translated gears is presented. nisse conveyed. The focus is on the following areas: Systematics, designs and basics of motion analysis Methods for the kinematic, kinetostatic and numerical analysis of gears and plane mechanisms, also with regard to their CAD and MKS application Type selection and dimensional determination of unevenly translated gears in their function as transmission or guide gears Basics of the Cam gears and electronic cams Determination and optimization of motion functions for servo drives using motion laws or motion design Aim:The general goal of this module is to acquire the necessary basic knowledge about the kinematic and kinetostatic laws and procedures that are of crucial importance for the development and calculation of nonlinear drive systems . Supported by many application examples, the students learn the theoretical connections for different drive structure concepts as well as efficient and graphically oriented design methods for the analysis and synthesis of mechanisms, which are created using modern numerical methods - or CAD systems can be optimally used. This means you are able to plan and dimension not only direct drive solutions but also other mechanical or mechatronic drive solutions.

name: Technical product development
degree-program: Professorship of Machine Elements and Product Development
content: Content:In the module, the students independently develop innovative solutions to technical problems within a project plan to be created. The students should orientate themselves methodically on VDI 2221. As a rule, the topics are related to research projects or company development projects. During processing, you will be supported by your supervisor in finding and developing creative solutions. Regular consultations are planned for this purpose. The entire work result is prepared as evidence (specifications of the task, methodology for finding a solution, overall drawing, detailed drawings, parts lists and dimensioning invoices, other product documents), with larger Value is placed on a complete product specification (tolerance concept) and a consistent data structure. After the work has been completed, the work results are presented and defended in the form of a lecture. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to independently carry out the methodical development and construction of practical, innovative projects, including the creation of complete constructive documents, and to present their work results in front of a to present and defend an expert committee.

name: Virtual and augmented reality in mechanical engineering
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:Computer-aided (virtual) modeling/construction, simulation and analysis are now part of the everyday tools of the modern engineer. Virtual (VR) and augmented (AR) reality techniques play an important role in all product life phases - from development through production and service to retrofit. The module teaches how to handle and efficiently use virtual and augmented reality technologies in practical use and introduces the corresponding hardware and software. The exercises will deepen the content of the lecture and teach basic techniques for creating VR/AR applications from CAD data. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe the structure of various VR systems, Ã¯Â¿Â½ VR/AR presentations independently Â¿Â½ to prepare a target definition (e.g. for the design review of new products), Ã¯Â¿Â½ to identify differences between 3D CAD and VR data, Ã¯Â¿Â½ procedures for 3D data acquisition explain (e.g. motion capture, terrestrial laser scanning), Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe the basics of augmented reality.

name: Technical strength calculation
degree-program: Professorship of Machine Elements and Product Development
content: Content: Determination of the stress state of typical mechanical engineering components using the finite element method and application of suitable strength hypotheses, Basics of vibration resistance (time and fatigue strength), Experimental determination of vibration resistance and their statistical evaluation, Introduction to operational strength (stress time function, collective formation, service life calculation), Handling and application of practical strength verifications, such as the FKM guideline, Introduction to the fracture mechanics design concept. Accompanying the lectures and exercises, the students are required to prepare a document in order to apply the knowledge they have acquired to a practical mechanical engineering problem. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ solve the strength-related problems that arise in the area of ​​product development, taking into account the specific requirements of mechanical engineering, Ã¯Â¿Â½ Designing and calculating mechanical components based on strength using different methods.

name: Machine learning and optimization in technical product development
degree-program: Professorship of Machine Elements and Product Development
content: Content: Introduction to the basic concepts of optimization, Mathematical basics, Optimization algorithms, Parameter optimization, Component optimization, Topology optimization, Introduction to the basic concepts of machine learning, Basics of artificial neural networks (ANN), Data preparation and training, KNN in the context of product analysis Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ identify and formulate optimization problems in the context of product development, Ã¯Â¿Â½ optimization problems in the context of product development through appropriate choice and development of parameterization, model and to solve search algorithms, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to understand and apply important machine learning procedures, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to understand how problems can be solved efficiently using machine learning procedures ¯Â¿Â½nen.

name: Advanced course 3D CAD
degree-program: Professorship of Machine Elements and Product Development
content: Content: Advanced solid modeling, Parametric modeling and gear geometry, Organization of construction elements (structuring of the part family tree), Organization of assemblies, Creation of standard-compliant Drawings of machine elements (shaft, gear, gearbox), use of standard parts databases and external assemblies, creation of parts lists, introduction to the assembly process chen modeling using the example of a gear, parameter control of parts and assemblies Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ design complex components using advanced solid modeling methods, Ã¯Â¿Â½ efficiently manage large assemblies, Ã¯Â¿ Â½ designing complicated shapes through surface modeling, Â½ dealing with third-party parts (standard and purchased parts).

name: Motion design, cam, stepper and planetary gears
degree-program: Professorship of Assembly and Handling Technology
content: Content:Due to the increasing performance of today's drive technology, efforts are being made to adapt complex movement sequences as optimally as possible to given requirements, directly or using gears. The aim of this module is, on the one hand, to provide the basics for describing a movement task for technological processes (e.g. for cycle lines, handling and assembly), management tasks ( e.g. feeding technology or robotics) as well as general drive trains (e.g. vehicle technology) in the context of movement design. With regard to the question of which drive concept is optimally suited, in addition to direct drives/MCS (motion control system/electronic cam), a wide variety of gears and mechatronic structural variants are used in drive systems to transmit movements and forms of movement to transform. With a view to the entire system behavior, basic methods and calculation approaches are shown and for various drive concepts with planetary gears, cam and cam stepper gears, but also high-ratio gears, such as cyclo or wave gears (harmonic drive) , discussed and also presented in the test fields during events. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to describe and optimize movement sequences analytically and to apply the methods of graphic-interactive movement design, later also software-based. Based on this, you can analyze the structure and properties of linear and non-linear drive systems and develop your own concept solutions, especially for cam and cam stepper drives. You know the basic designs, operating modes and graphic-analytical methods for calculating the speeds, torques and performance ratios of planetary gears. In addition, they are able to determine optimal combinations of servo drives with downstream planetary gears.

name: FEM II
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:In this module, theoretical and application-related knowledge of the finite element method (FEM) is imparted in its application to non-linear problems. The different types of possible nonlinearities are presented and analyzed with regard to their implementation within FEM. Secondly, knowledge that goes beyond FEM I is imparted on the use and operation of existing programs and, in particular, on the interpretation and evaluation of the results of the method. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the student is able to understand the theoretical concept of the nonlinear finite element method and, on this basis, to correctly interpret and assess simulation results. He has in-depth knowledge of the operation of FEM programs that has been expanded to include non-linear problems.

name: Experimental continuum mechanics
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:The teaching area deals with the theoretical basics and the application of special experimental procedures for structural analysis and materials mechanics. It represents an important expansion of the Experimental Mechanics module. It provides in-depth knowledge of how electrical strain gauges work, such as the measurement of large deformations, temperature self-compensation and measurements in the high temperature range. Another focus is the metrological determination of residual stress states using the borehole method. In the field of optical processes, the technique of phase shifting, which is important for various applications, is introduced and applied to the measuring principle of electronic speckle pattern interferometry. The measuring principle of fiber Bragg grating sensors is discussed as well as the increasingly popular method of 3D gray value correlation. The methods of thermoelastic stress analysis and laser Doppler techniques round off the teaching program. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the student knows modern and theoretically demanding experimental procedures for measuring or evaluating mechanical variables and can apply them, comparing both the level of measurement technology and the mechanical problems increased to the Experimental Mechanics module.

name: Product data technology
degree-program: Professorship of Virtual Manufacturing Technology
content: Content: Basic definitions of terms Methods and functions of a product data management system (PDM system) Product and process modeling Process management (modeling methods, tools) Methods for specifying product data models Methods for describing metadata Product data exchange Introduction to a selected PDM system Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have specialist knowledge of the structure, function and application of product data technology in the field of mechanical and automotive engineering and can independently adapt a PDM system for future tasks in mechanical engineering and apply in automobile production.

name: Constructing with plastics
degree-program: Professorship of Plastics
content: Content:Constructive design, material, processing methods and component properties represent a more complex relationship with plastics than is known for metallic materials and make it more difficult to use common design and calculation methods. The key to the extreme integration density of plastic components and plastic structures lies in understanding the time, temperature and load-dependent material properties and the possible manufacturing processes. The module includes: Data on the plastics industry and an overview of plastics applications, structure and general material properties of plastics, influencing factors plastics processing Focus on tool design (manufacturing capabilities) Characteristic values for the design and their determination (Overview of test methods and influencing factors en) Manufacturing-friendly design in injection molding, design rules and examples Application and design examples Joining of plastics (screw, snap, welded connections) Tribology, plastic applications in tribological systems Aim:The student masters the fundamental connections between the internal nature of the material and the thermal/mechanical and time-dependent material behavior of thermoplastics and thermosets. He overviews the wide range of processing methods and masters the theoretical basics of the essential shaping processes of primary and forming. He is able to assess and select application and construction-relevant parameters for optimal utilization of the material potential in order to design and dimension plastic structures in a way that is suitable for production and application.

name: Corrosion and wear
degree-program: Professorship of Materials and Surface Engineering
content: Content:The basics of corrosion (the formation of corrosion damage) are discussed. This includes the representation of the corrosion system, the explanation of the corrosion process (including thermodynamics and kinetics), types of corrosion, corrosion phenomena and corrosion products. This is followed by statements on the corrosion behavior of selected materials, the evaluation of the corrosion behavior and the corrosion damage analysis. Starting from the basic structure of the tribosystems, the basics of wear (the formation of wear damage) are discussed. This includes the presentation of the characteristics of tribosystems (e.g. movement conditions, microgeometry) and the discussion of the basic wear mechanisms as well as the presentation of well-known wear theories. This is followed by information about the assessment of wear behavior (tribological test chain), wear diagnostics and wear damage analysis. Aim:The students know the basic corrosion reactions and the basic wear mechanisms and can explain the underlying (electro)chemical, physical and tribological processes. They recognize that corrosion and wear resistance are system properties, can describe important types of corrosion and wear and are able to assign these to real practical examples - no. On the basis of this, the students can identify application-related suitable corrosion and wear protection measures and categorize them. You know the most important corrosion and wear testing procedures and can critically evaluate the measurement results achieved with them.

name: Modeling and integration of mechatronic systems
degree-program: Professorship of Adaptronics and Functional Lightweight Design in Production
content: Content:As part of the module, both theoretical basics for the cross-domain design of mechatronic systems as well as application-oriented skills for simulative support of the development process are taught. The starting point for the considerations is various systems available on the hardware side and as CAD models, which are used to determine the methodology and practical procedure for creating suitable, possibly coupled, simulation models as well as for co-design of hardware and control/regulation is learned. Aim:After completing the module, the students are able to use a methodically sound approach to modeling and system integration of mechatronic systems, and to create and evaluate cross-domain simulation models of mechatronic systems and Ã¯Â¿Â½ to identify potential for improvement and to develop it on the software or hardware side.

name: Machine tool properties analysis
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:The module deals with the classification and assessment of properties on machine tools. The main focus is on the characterization of the geometric, kinematic, static, dynamic, thermal and acoustic behavior. Each behavior is systematically analyzed according to the classification options, the occurrence, the influencing factors and the effects on the overall machine tool system. On the one hand, the necessary measurement principles, the possible sensors and the boundary conditions to be considered are presented and, on the other hand, the underlying standards and legal guidelines are also discussed. By getting to know relevant simulation approaches, the computational determination of special properties in machine tool construction is taught. Furthermore, indirect evaluation methods are presented, which allow statements to be made about the machine and process capability through the processing of test workpieces. Aim:After completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ classify properties on a machine tool and explain the factors that influence these properties, Ã¯Â¿Â½ various to classify measurement principles and to apply selected methods (laser interferometry, vibration analysis, thermography), Ã¯Â¿Â½ to know simulation models relevant to machine tool construction, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to select the effects based on measurement results Â½calculate the properties of the resulting workpiece accuracy, Ã¯Â¿Â½ discuss measurement and simulation results with regard to their informative content, Ã¯Â¿Â½ suggestions for improving evaluated To formulate properties, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to calculate the machine or process capability.

name: Design of cutting manufacturing processes
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:Machining is the primary technology used for secondary shaping and finishing in vehicle and mechanical engineering. The implementation of economical production requires the use of efficient and safe process technologies, which in turn require powerful tools and machines as well as support measurement systems. As part of the seminar, students are provided with in-depth knowledge of machining production as well as current topics and trends from science and industrial application and discussed. Other focal points include tool selection and production as well as process optimization. As part of exercises and internships, students are shown application-oriented technologies. Furthermore, training on how to independently create a finite element simulation of a machining process as well as exercises on statistical methods for process optimization of industrial processes are integrated into the module. In addition, excursions to innovative companies with metal-cutting production are planned. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ have in-depth knowledge in the area of ​​machining production, Ã¯Â¿Â½ design machining processes in a goal-oriented manner, Ã¯Â¿Â½ a tool selection with regard to technological and economic aspects - carry out pects, Ã¯Â¿Â½ discuss current trends and technological developments in the field of metal-cutting manufacturing technology and Ã¯Â¿Â½ independently carry out a process and tool design based on an FEM simulation ¯Â¿Â½hear.

name: Forming tools
degree-program: Professorship of Forming Shaping and Joining
content: Content:Knowledge of the structure, operation and construction of tools for sheet metal and solid forming is imparted. The special features of the respective forming process are discussed. The required forming forces and the forming work are determined and the kinematics of the forming machine are taken into account as an essential parameter for the tool design. Calculation methods for the design of tools, the choice of materials and surface treatments/coatings for tools as well as economic aspects in tool design are explained. Aim:After completing the module, the students are familiar with using a CAD system and have gained insight into the job-specific approach of a tool designer. They are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe the structure and areas of application of various types of tools, Ã¯Â¿Â½ derive requirements for the tools based on the load caused by the forming process, Ã¯Â¿Â½ materials, surface ¯Â¿Â½ to select surface treatments and coating systems for the tool active elements, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to carry out the calculations required for a tool design, Ã¯Â¿Â½ for example a Schn oath tool to construct.

name: Simulation in forming technology
degree-program: Professorship of Virtual Manufacturing Technology
content: Content:The module includes the course simulation in forming technology. The focus of the course is: Areas of application of the finite element method (FEM) Basics of FEM FEM theory in forming technology Structure and functionality of FEM Systems Simulation examples Selected FEM systems for forming technology for mechanical engineering and automobile manufacturing Aim:The students have ready-to-use specialist knowledge of the structure, function and application of FEM simulation in forming technology. After completing the module, the students have basic knowledge of FEM simulation of forming problems and can independently adapt several FEM systems to future tasks in mechanical engineering and automobile production apply.

name: Production measurement technology
degree-program: Professorship of Manufacturing Metrology
content: Content:The geometric properties of components, e.g. B. Shape, position and roughness largely determine their function. The production measurement technology forms the basis for the conformity assessment of the components based on the technical product specification. As part of the module, comprehensive knowledge of measurement methods and their assignment to geometric properties are imparted. This is the prerequisite for selecting suitable measuring devices in the development and manufacturing process. Further focal points include the introduction to the system of geometric product specification and testing, the measurement of geometric properties through extraction, filtering, association, the explanation of the structure and the functionality of selected measuring devices as well as the basics of test planning and measuring device calibration. The knowledge acquired in the lecture is deepened in internships and applied independently. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to distinguish geometric properties from one another and select suitable measuring methods/devices for their evaluation. You know the basics of calibrating test equipment in production measurement technology as well as test planning. In addition, the students are able to independently carry out simple measurement tasks regarding roughness as well as dimensional and shape deviations.

name: Automation of machines
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:Industrial controls for machines, systems and complex processes occupy a prominent place in automation technology. The module Automation of machines is intended to deepen the understanding of the different control classes. At the beginning, various display options for automation tasks are presented. By analyzing specific machine functions, the special features of programmable logic controllers (PLC), numerical controls (CNC), robot (RC) and motion controls (MC) are worked out. In addition, an insight into the project planning and programming is provided for these control classes. This is demonstrated in practical practical exercises. Using many examples relevant to automation technology, frequently recurring basic functions are abstracted and these are classified in terms of control technology. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ derive hybrid function plans according to the VDI/VDE 3684 guideline for medium-sized tasks, Ã¯Â¿Â½ the automation of basic technological functions differentiate and recognize their properties, Ã¯Â¿Â½ analyze complex applications (printing, forming and injection molding machines) from these aspects, Ã¯Â¿Â½ AblÃ¯Â¿ Â½runs according to S7 Graph, to generate motion control applications according to PLCopen and CNC programs according to DIN 66025, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to explain the control circuits of a servo converter.

name: Virtual process chains in forming technology
degree-program: Professorship of Virtual Manufacturing Technology
content: Content: Virtual product, virtual product development process CA techniques: process integration, interfaces Method planning Product and process modeling Methods of process simulation Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ The students have ready-to-use specialist knowledge of virtual products and their product development processes as well as the methods and programs used. Ã¯Â¿Â½ After completing the module, the students have basic knowledge of systems and methods of virtual product and process modeling and process simulation. You will be able to independently apply the relevant methods and selected systems to solve future tasks in the field of mechanical engineering and automobile production.

name: Forming and gear cutting machines
degree-program: Professorship of machine tool design and forming technology
content: Content:Building on basic knowledge of manufacturing technology, machine elements and machine tools, the module includes getting to know the mode of operation, the operating conditions and the construction principles of the most important functional and quality-determining assemblies in forming machine tools with their development trends. This is followed by the imparting of knowledge and skills for calculating, dimensioning, designing and planning the selection of these assemblies. The teaching content relates to frames (materials, design with regard to static and dynamic behavior), drives (motor flywheel crank, servo drives, hydraulic drives) and supports Guides (design of the guide surfaces, compensation for tipping). In the gear cutting machines section, you will learn about the structure, kinematics and use of cutting and forming machine tools for the production of gears. The consideration is based on both design and manufacturing aspects. The basis is the geometry of cylindrical and bevel gear teeth, gear characteristics and their dependence on the gear kinematics. The machine side is based on the kinematics of metal-cutting processes (spurting, milling, peeling, grinding, scraping, honing, lapping) for the production of cylindrical and conical gears Implementation content of the module. They are characterized in terms of tool structure, settings and movements, additional equipment and machine modifications, workpiece quality, economic efficiency indicators, process-related errors and deliberately created profile deviations. The exercises include the calculation, dimensioning and selection of assemblies of forming and gear cutting machine tools using practical examples. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ select, calculate, dimension and structurally design important assemblies of forming machine tools in a functional and quality-appropriate manner, Ã ¯Â¿Â½ to apply these skills when using forming machine tools in production (e.g. of automobiles and in their supply industry), Ã¯Â¿Â½ to analyze and evaluate manufacturing processes for the production of gears and, on this basis, new machine structures to design or evaluate existing machines with regard to their application, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to evaluate constructive and manufacturing details of gear technology in connection with the workpiece, machine and tool and to evaluate them under quality and to further develop from an economic perspective.

name: Efficient process chains
degree-program: Professorship of Micromanufacturing Technology
content: Content:The module conveys the basics and procedures for designing resource-efficient processes and process chains. After an overview of methods for structuring manufacturing processes as well as technology and production planning, the technological basics of selected cutting, abrasive and forming manufacturing processes are presented with examples from the areas of thread production, hard and Non-circular machining, deep hole drilling, dry machining, deburring, burr avoidance, etc. conveyed. These are evaluated and compared in terms of their resource efficiency in the context of the entire process chain. Process chains and equipment for the production of rotationally symmetrical and prismatic components from the areas of mechanical engineering and automobile production are then explained and discussed in greater depth using concrete examples. Aim:After successful participation in the module, the students are able to explain the reasons for the need to increase the efficiency of process chains and the basic structure of process chains from the semi-finished product to the finished workpiece for the production of rotationally symmetrical and prismatic components using a work sequence graph, to analyze and explain existing process chains with regard to possible optimization potential. to develop solution suggestions.

name: Fluid drives
degree-program: Professorship for Structural Lightweight Construction / Plastics Processing
content: Content:The lecture, which is based on the knowledge of the course Fundamentals of Hydraulics and Pneumatics, is divided into a theoretical and an application-related topic complex. In the first part, knowledge and methods for modeling, control and simulation of electro-hydraulic drive systems are imparted. The second part includes a systematization of fluid technology for mobile and stationary applications. Areas of application and requirements are defined and basic fluid technology components and systems are presented. Subsequently, further knowledge in the areas of project planning, construction and analysis of fluid power systems is imparted using various application areas. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have broad knowledge and the methodology for planning controlled and regulated fluid power systems. You are able to handle fluid drives properly both in the development of machines and machine systems as well as in their use and maintenance.

name: Optical technologies in production measurement technology
degree-program: Professorship of Manufacturing Metrology
content: Content:The module offers an overview of non-contact, optical measurement methods that are used in the industrial practice of geometric production measurement technology. Functionality, application potential and selection criteria are explained and compared with conventional, mostly tactile methods. In a semester-long internship series, students have the opportunity to get to know modern, optical measuring devices in detail and to carry out measurements themselves. The focus here is particularly on influencing factors. s, reproducibility and comparability are the focus of considerations. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have a comprehensive, practice-oriented understanding of the possible uses, potential and limits of optical technologies. The students also have knowledge of the metrological implementation of various measuring tasks and are able to carry out simple measurements and select measuring methods.

name: Ceramic and metallic lightweight materials
degree-program: Professorship of Composites and Material Composites
content: Content:Ceramics and composite materials based on them are discussed. Light metals based on aluminum and titanium as well as high-strength lightweight steels are also considered. The production, the specific processing properties and the resulting characteristic technological properties of the materials and material groups are presented and discussed in a comparative manner. In addition, current and future fields of application of these material groups are considered with particular consideration of the development of hybrid components. The exercises serve to specifically apply and systematically deepen the content taught in the lecture. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to understand, design and design the production, processing, the resulting properties and the resulting fields of application of the relevant lightweight construction material groups and their combinations apply them critically and safely.

name: Polymer materials
degree-program: Professorship of Plastics
content: Content:According to their thermal-mechanical behavior, plastics are divided into thermoplastics, thermosets and elastomers. Their processing and application properties can also be enhanced in a variety of ways, e.g. B. can be modified by softening, foaming, filling, reinforcing, crosslinking, blending, copolymerizing, etc. The product properties therefore depend not only on the corresponding type of plastic, but also on the physical processes and/or chemical reactions during processing. Process-structure-property relationships are explained and deepened through experiments. There will also be a presentation of selected, special plastic testing methods. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to describe the material behavior of the main groups of plastics, show possibilities for modifying plastic properties to optimally utilize the material potential and describe the component behavior and areas of application Â¿Â½tzen.

name: Material composites
degree-program: Professorship of Composites and Material Composites
content: Content:The module provides basic knowledge of the manufacturing processes, properties and areas of application of material composites. In particular, form-fitting, force-fitting and material-fitting processes for connecting dissimilar materials such as metals, ceramics, plastics and fiber-reinforced plastics are at the forefront of knowledge transfer. In addition to the industrially important bonding, the cohesive processes also include soldering and the joining of different combinations of materials using modern welding and pressure welding processes. Another focus of the module is the transfer of knowledge in the area of hybrid networks. The focus is on core composites (sandwiches), multilayer composites (cladding and hybrid laminates) and hybrid component structures that are manufactured in highly integrative manufacturing processes. Interface problems as well as the targeted modification of interfaces are discussed. The students gain insight into important mechanical-technological, structural-analytical, chemical and physical characterization methods for material composites. The module also includes current trends and research results from the projects of the Chair of Composites and Composites. Aim:The students have very good knowledge of the field of material composites. They are able to distinguish the character of the connection (force fit, form fit, material fit). They know common manufacturing processes for dissimilar material compounds and their challenges as well as possibilities and potential for the practical use of material compounds.

name: Heat treatment of metallic materials
degree-program: Professorship of Composites and Material Composites
content: Content:The heat treatment of metallic materials is an essential part of the manufacturing process of metallic semi-finished products or end products in order to achieve the desired processing and/or usage properties. Compliance with special material-dependent process sequences is essential for setting the properties. The module includes the three basic types of heat treatment for ferrous and non-ferrous metals: I. Thermal processes, such as annealing, hardening, tempering, tempering , precipitation hardening II. Thermo-chemical processes, such as non-metal, metal and non-metal-metal diffusion processes III.
