Thermo-mechanical processes The basic process sequences and possible uses of the processes as well as system technology and error analysis are taught theoretically in the lecture and through an internship with excursions to regional locations Companies deepened. Aim:The students have basic knowledge of the thermal, thermo-chemical and thermo-mechanical treatment of steels, cast iron materials and non-ferrous metals and have an understanding of the metal-physical processes ¯Â¿Â½nge in the various heat treatment processes. They are able to estimate the expected changes in properties caused by heat treatment processes, to evaluate technological process characteristics and thus the connection between treatment variability, process parameter design and property optimization to dominate.

name: Damage analysis
degree-program: Professorship of Composites and Material Composites
content: Content:After explanations of the technical, economic and legal consequences of errors and damage, the complex system of damage analysis is discussed. assessment, damage assessment, damage mechanisms and causes of damage play a central role. The interaction between calculation, design, materials, production, assembly and operation is made clear. In the seminar, cases of damage are examined practically and presented in short lectures. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to plan and carry out the damage analysis process themselves and are sensitized to essential problems in the application and use of components. In addition, the students are able to prepare and present technical issues appropriately.

name: High temperature materials
degree-program: Professorship of Composites and Material Composites
content: Content:In the module, students learn the most important basics about the use of high-temperature materials. The following topics are dealt with in group work: Behavior of metallic materials under mechanical stress at high temperatures (influence of static and dynamic stress, material parameters and their determination, metallurgical processes during creep and the Influence of structure and structural instability on material behavior) High-temperature corrosion (especially oxidation, carburization and hot gas corrosion) High-temperature materials (warm solid St hle, superalloys and ceramics as well as their practical use). Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have comprehensive knowledge of the behavior of materials when used at high temperatures and can select suitable high-temperature materials according to the requirements profile. In addition, the students are able to develop and present a question independently as well as in group work.

name: Fatigue of materials
degree-program: Professorship of Composites and Material Composites
content: Content:The module provides basic knowledge of fatigue processes under single-stage vibration loading at constant temperature. The focus is particularly on the interactions between stress, microstructure, deformation or damage mechanisms and service life of steels and light metals. Furthermore, important factors influencing the fatigue strength are discussed and non-destructive measurement methods for the characterization of the alternating deformation and fatigue behavior are presented. In the seminar, practical design methods for classic fatigue strength are presented and applied using examples. In addition, current research work on the topic will be presented and discussed. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have comprehensive knowledge of fatigue processes and the relationships between microstructure, deformation or damage mechanisms and service life . The students are able to evaluate the fatigue strength of cyclically stressed metallic materials and know computational and experimental methods to determine fatigue behavior.

name: Glass lightweight materials
degree-program: Professorship of Composites and Material Composites
content: Content:After teaching the physical-chemical basics of the structural structure and production of glasses, their properties as well as testing and characterization methods for these materials are discussed. One focus is the connection between the chemical composition, processing, structure and properties of the glasses. Furthermore, an overview of technical applications of glass materials is given and the specific features of material selection are discussed. The exercises serve to specifically apply and systematically deepen the content taught in the lecture. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have extensive scientific and practical knowledge of the connection between the structure, production and properties of glass materials. They are able to select appropriate characterization methods for glasses and to select materials appropriate to the application.

name: Electrochemical coating
degree-program: Professorship of Materials and Surface Technology
content: Content:In this module, relevant topics of wet chemical coating processes are addressed and comprehensively taught. Contents are: Electrochemical basics Modeling of electrochemical processes Basics of electroplating Layer systems Coating processes Electrochemical analysis Layer characterization The module follows the content of the 1-semester overview lecture on surface and coating technology and deepens it with regard to industrially relevant coating processes. By involving regional company representatives from the coating industry in the exercises, a particularly high level of practical relevance is created. Aim:The students can describe the essential processes of pre- and post-treatment as well as layer formation and understand the underlying (electro-)chemical processes. This enables them to select suitable layer systems for the application, to justify their selection and to recognize starting points for process, structure and property optimization.

name: Thermal coating
degree-program: Professorship of Materials and Surface Technology
content: Content:The focus of this module is on the coating processes or coating process groups Thermal spraying Hardfacing welding CVD processes PVD processes For these coating processes, the environmental relationships of the coating process as well as cross-process questions regarding the selection method for layers are discussed. Since thermal coatings are primarily used in tribological or chemical applications, the basics of wear and corrosion are discussed based on appropriate applications and the potential for wear on the coating side is determined. and corrosion protection derived and presented. Surface coatings can also be used to specifically change a number of other properties (electrical and thermal conductivity, physical behavior, color, gloss, etc.), which is why we will discuss this in the course of this module these properties are also taken into account. It is recommended that you attend the Electrochemical Coating course at the same time. Aim:The students know various groups of thermal coating processes that are particularly relevant to industry. They are able to correlate possible layer and substrate materials, layer formation and adhesion mechanisms as well as the resulting layer properties with the applicable coating processes and thus based on the requirement profile for technical surfaces ¿Â½to make a process and material selection for a possible thermal coating process.

name: Material modeling
degree-program: Professorship of Materials Science
content: Content:The module introduces theoretical and numerical approaches that enable simulation of processes in and properties of engineering materials. An overview is given of various basic methods used for modeling material behavior at different length scales. This particularly includes atomistic aspects, thermodynamic and micromechanical approaches, as well as continuum-based methods. Particular attention is paid to the numerical description of the mechanical material behavior. The students also evaluate current specialist literature on the subject of materials modeling, which they report on as part of a final presentation. Aim:The students know the possibilities and the inherent limits of various methods for modeling material properties or behavior, especially on the atomistic or microstructural length scale. They are able to distinguish between knowledge- and application-related approaches and, within the framework of further engineering studies, to select suitable methods and to develop their practical application in concrete program packages themselves as well as to critically evaluate and present results from current specialist literature.

name: Simulation in lightweight structural engineering
degree-program: Professorship for Structural Lightweight Construction / Plastics Processing
content: Content:The lectures cover the basics of using simulation methods in lightweight structural engineering. The behavior of components during the manufacturing process itself, as well as the flow behavior during injection molding and resin transfer molding (RTM) processes, the shrinkage and warping behavior during the cooling process, and the induction of process-related factors are examined Internal stresses as well as the processes of typical manufacturing processes in lightweight construction technologies are considered. Furthermore, special attention is given to the changes in the properties of plastics during the processing process. A large part of the lecture is devoted to the simulations of thermomechanical interactions of polymer melts in the injection molding tool and the resulting restrictions for the associated tool design. The content is rounded off with considerations on the linking of complex lightweight construction technologies. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students have the basic knowledge for simulating processes and components in lightweight structural engineering. You are able to design and optimize such complex processes.

name: Heat transfer
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content:The module is divided into eight chapters. After an introduction with a view to the different types of heat transfer, the first two basic mechanisms of heat are discussed: heat conduction and heat transfer. Thermal transmission introduced. Based on this, heat exchangers are discussed as essential heat engineering devices. The material transfer is then considered, whereby the analogies between heat conduction and diffusion as well as heat and material transfer are highlighted. The conditions during heat transfer in systems with phase change are then characterized using the examples of condensation and evaporation. Finally, heat radiation as the third essential heat transfer mechanism will be discussed. Aim:After successfully completing the module, students understand the basics of heat and mass transfer. You can analyze the physical processes involved in heat transfer problems and various options for specifically influencing heat transfer ½transitions develop and apply the general relationships to frequently occurring standard situations.

name: Materials and welding
degree-program: Professorship of Welding Technology
content: Content:The course provides an overview of the behavior of metallic materials during welding. The thermal cycle during welding and its influence on the resulting material properties of steel, aluminum, magnesium, titanium, nickel and other metallic materials and alloys are discussed. Measures and options for improving welding suitability and quality assurance are discussed. Furthermore, material-specific damage cases in welded constructions and their causes are discussed. Aim:The students have knowledge of the effects of welding processes on the properties of metallic materials. They can assess the weldability of metallic materials and know the characteristics of important material groups with regard to their welding technology. You are also able to select suitable welding processes for specific materials.

name: Testing plastics
degree-program: Professorship of Plastics
content: Content:Constructive design, material, processing methods and component properties represent a more complex relationship with plastics than is known for metallic materials. The focus is on understanding the time, temperature and load-dependent material properties in connection with the possible manufacturing processes. The testing technology and the evaluation of measurement results are correspondingly demanding, which are used both to determine parameters for dimensioning and for component testing itself. In the lecture, testing methods for plastic analysis, for determining thermal and mechanical properties as well as special tests on components are presented and supported by exercises and internships with a high proportion of independent work nt. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to describe the fundamental relationships between the internal nature of the material and the thermal/mechanical and time-dependent material behavior of thermoplastics and thermosets, influencing factors Â¿Â½Ã¯Â¿Â½, to analyze cases of damage in practice and to assess and select appropriate testing technology as well as application and design-relevant parameters for optimal utilization of the material potential .

name: Introduction to crystallographic texture analysis
degree-program: Professorship of Materials Science Dean of Studies for all degree programs in the Faculty of Mathematics (except for the Master's degree program in Data Science and the International Master's and doctoral degree program)
content: Content:The module deals with the quantitative description of polycrystalline materials and their anisotropic properties. Elementary electron microscopic methods (in particular the method of electron backscatter diffraction, EBSD) and the basics for the description, evaluation and representation of crystalline structures and crystallographic textures are taught. In addition, the mathematical description of tensorial quantities and suitable averaging procedures are in the foreground. In addition to a description of plasticity within the framework of Taylor and viscoplastic-self-consistent models, the handling of orientation distribution functions from EBSD and X-ray diffractometry measurements is also discussed. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to qualitatively and quantitatively describe, analyze and evaluate the anisotropic properties of polycrystalline materials from experimental data.

name: Experimental methods of fluid and thermodynamics
degree-program: Professorship of Fluid Mechanics
content: Content:1. Basics 2. Pressure measurement 3. Flow and flow measurement 4. Temperature measurement 5. Measurement of caloric variables 6. Humidity measurement 7. Error analysis Aim:The student has knowledge of measurement procedures in fluid dynamics and thermodynamics and is able to select suitable measurement principles and measurement methods based on the requirements of a measurement task. According to the respective advantages and disadvantages, the student can evaluate the specific measurement methods and use the most suitable method. The knowledge acquired about the causes, avoidance and treatment of measurement errors enables the student to identify and eliminate possible sources of error in advance of measurements. At the same time, the student can quantify existing measurement deviations using error calculation or estimation.

name: Machine dynamics of continuous systems
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Mechanics/Dynamics
content: Content:The consideration of continuous, elastic systems is playing an increasing role in mechanical engineering. Higher performance while simultaneously reducing material costs require an ever more precise analysis of the behavior of elastic systems. Particularly in the desired lightweight construction of support and drive systems, the consideration of elasticities becomes imperative. The lecture essentially deals with modeling and calculation as well as the interpretation of movement phenomena in order to be able to infer the causes of vibrations. The knowledge imparted in the lecture is deepened in the exercises using concrete tasks. Aim:The students are familiar with the mechanisms that cause vibrations in elastic systems as well as their mathematical description and calculation and can physically understand and influence vibration problems in elastic components.

name: Durability and fracture mechanics
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:As part of this module, the basics of operational strength and fracture mechanics are taught. The focus is on protecting material fatigue and calculating the service life of components made of technically relevant materials. The following topics are covered: fatigue, voter lines, fracture mechanics concepts, crack growth. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the student has knowledge of modern principles and concepts of operational strength and fracture mechanics and is able to produce numerical results regarding dynamic and static Evaluate component strength.

name: Numerical dynamics of flexible structures
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Mechanics/Dynamics
content: Content:This module is about modeling and numerical simulation of large movements of flexible structures. Modern methods of model building and model calculation (e.g. finite element method) are discussed. In particular, nonlinear systems are dealt with, whereby the question of the choice of suitable generalized coordinates is discussed. In the exercises, the general connections are deepened using examples and implemented on the computer in the internship. For this purpose, the learned methods are implemented using a high-level programming language. Aim:The students are able to model and simulate dynamic structures independently.

name: Numerical dynamics of thermomechanically coupled structures
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Mechanics/Dynamics
content: Content:In addition to flexible structures with purely mechanical properties, the increasingly important lightweight structures made of plastics play a particularly important role in the everyday life of a mechanical engineer. These materials have a highly inelastic material behavior, which is accompanied by an influence on the component temperature. This lecture deals with the modeling and numerical simulation of such structures under large deformations. Modern finite element methods are used as simulation methods. In the exercises, the formulations are deepened using numerical examples. To do this, the methods learned are programmed themselves. Aim:The students are able to independently model and simulate larger thermomechanically coupled dynamic systems.

name: Material modeling
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:In this module, knowledge is imparted in order to recreate observed material behavior using continuum mechanics. Elastic, viscoelastic and elastoplastic models are presented, which are also suitable for large deformations. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the student is able to understand continuum mechanical material models for large deformations and has the tools to develop such models themselves.

name: Rheology
degree-program: Professorship of Fluid Mechanics
content: Content: Basics of the flow behavior of simple and complex fluids Basics of other properties and phenomena of liquids through interphase action with other fluids Scientific and engineering measurement relevant material data to describe fluid behavior Aim:The students are familiar with the different flow behavior of fluids and know various experimental measurement options for characterizing a fluid. Through this and also through the insight into the special phenomena of the interphase actions of several fluids with at least one liquid, the students are able to select suitable measuring devices and measuring methods ¿Â½to be able to scientifically investigate simple and complex fluids and apply them in engineering technology.

name: Calculation of anisotropic structures
degree-program: Professorship for Structural Lightweight Construction / Plastics Processing
content: Content:In the first step, the course teaches the elasticity theory basics for anisotropic material behavior of the single layer in order to derive the multilayer theory based on this. The multi-layer composites made of fiber-reinforced materials represent pioneering lightweight construction solutions, especially in aerospace, vehicle construction and general mechanical engineering. The students learn this using the classic laminate theory as a mathematical tool to record complex stress and deformation behavior of planar structures made of fiber-plastic composites (FRP) as a result of mechanical, thermal and media-related loads. Furthermore, general and fracture type-related failure hypotheses are presented, which are used in different design concepts. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students can calculate components and structures made of a material with anisotropic material behavior. This means they are able to design structural behavior for multi-layer composites in a way that is load-appropriate through the targeted layer orientation and layer structure.

name: Assessment and optimization of energy efficiency
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content: Systematics and terms upstream chain up to the consumer o General description of the processes (production, conversion, transport, distribution, storage) o Differentiation between long-distance supply and local conversion and application o Balancing of energy processes Transmission (renewable energy, fossil energy sources, electricity, heat, cooling), primary energy, secondary energy, final energy, useful energy, auxiliary energy, etc Calculation of the key figures (primary energy factor, energy expenditure figure, specific emissions) Consumer processes, general description of the processes o Demand determination o Production o Heating loads o Cooling loads Reference to the regulations Relation to measurement Interfaces o Energy-efficient production o Certification of products if necessary o Inclusion of mobile systems (e-mobility) if necessary o Factory planning o District concepts (industrial, municipal) o Social aspects (e.g. rebound effect) o Energy policy programs (e.g. E.g. EU, federal government) Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to: describe the complex processes from energy production to conversion and storage, distribution and use in a rough energy industry structure, to classify, apply, represent, analyze and assess their consequences, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to understand and apply relevant regulations, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to easily calculate and evaluate complex processes, Ã¯Â¿Â½ specialist to explain, characterize, use and communicate cross-cutting issues (e.g. sectors).

name: Apparatus technology
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content:Energy and process engineering systems essentially consist of different devices for heat and material transfer, pipes and pipe networks as well as fittings. Basic knowledge of their function, design, nature, assembly and the influence of the processes taking place therein, in conjunction with the applicable guidelines and regulations, is essential for a targeted and safe operation Operation absolutely necessary. The module covers these aspects in their entirety, with individual aspects, including practical aspects, being highlighted in detail. Aim:The students can apply design guidelines, applicable standards and calculation principles for simple apparatus, pipes and pipe systems as well as the fittings integrated into them. Apparatus technical systems can be analyzed and evaluated with regard to safe operating conditions.

name: Refrigeration technology and supply
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content: Introduction (terms, parameters, deployment, application) Components: 1) Compression refrigeration machines (compressors, refrigerants, condensers, evaporators), absorption refrigeration machines, adsorption and steam jet refrigeration machines 2) recooling 3) storage (cold water, ice, snow) District cooling systems Heat pumps Air conditioning and ventilation technology Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to describe components and systems of refrigeration technology and supply, including heat pumps as well as air conditioning and ventilation technology classify, represent, apply and analyze, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to plan, calculate and evaluate processes as well as Ã¯Â¿Â½ cross-disciplinary issues at the interfaces to air conditioning technology, energy supply, Ã¯Â to explain, characterize, use and communicate ecological assessment and economic efficiency.

name: Solar thermal energy
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content: Basics (climate, radiation, shading) Low temperature range: Components (collectors, storage, security technology, etc.) and systems (small systems, large systems, local heating , heat consumption, operating modes, costs) High temperature range: components (collectors, storage) and systems (power plants) Aim:After successful completion of the module, students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe, classify, apply, generalize, represent and analyze issues in the addressed subject area, Ã¯Â¿Â½ components and systems of to plan, calculate and evaluate typical low-temperature systems simply and in detail (technically, economically, ecologically), Ã¯Â¿Â½ Interfaces to other specialist areas/trades (heating technology, district heating supply , refrigeration and air conditioning technology, building physics) to specify, characterize, use and communicate, to understand and critically understand subject-specific methods/tools (e.g. consumption measurement, use of subject-specific programs). to apply and Ã¯Â¿Â½ summarize and defend work results in writing and orally according to scientific standards.

name: Simulation in thermal energy technology
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content: Introduction (goals, concepts, terms) Application of simple programs (e.g. Polysun, CASAnova) Modeling of energy technology processes Application of mathematical methods Transient simulation (solution approaches and procedures, structure and function of TRNSYS, modeling of loads, radiation, components, etc., simulation of a small solar thermal system) Station Re simulation (introduction to the EBSILON program system, recapitulation of the power plant technology, presentation of the components, simulation of various thermal power plant and condensation power plant circuits, a gas turbine system and a combined cycle power plant) Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe and apply the mathematical and other theoretical fundamentals, Ã¯Â¿Â½ abstract, model and simulate technical systems and components, Ã¯ Â¿Â½ to critically assess the models, the numerical solutions and programmatic implementations as well as the results, Ã¯Â¿Â½ to summarize and defend their results in writing and orally in accordance with scientific standards, Ã¯Â¿Â½ a complex program system for system simulation (either TRNSYS or EBSILON) as well as the necessary skills for the preparation and follow-up of the tasks.

name: Power and heat supply
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content: Basics of energy sources, energy consumption, supply systems (terms, concepts, parameters, ecology) Power plant technology (combined heat and power plants, steam power plants, Gas power plants, combined heat and power) District heating (pipeline technology, hydraulic circuits, transfer stations) Thermal energy storage (terms, processes, procedures, Processing, constructions, operating methods, system integration) Practical recapitulation Aim:After successfully completing the module, students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ name, classify, represent, apply and analyze energy sources, conversion, transport and storage technologies, Ã¯Â¿Â½ complex power processes - and heat supply to be easily planned, calculated and evaluated as well as cross-disciplinary issues at the interfaces to the energy industry, heating technology, ecological assessment and electrical energy supply to explain, characterize, use and communicate.

name: Numerical methods of heat transfer
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content:Numerical methods have become an integral part of engineering research and development. After a discussion of the aspects to be taken into account in numerical solution methods, the module introduces a large commercial program system based on CFD (Computational Fluid Dynamics). Instructions in its application are provided using examples from the area of heat transfer. Proof of successful induction is then provided in an individual task and the presentation of the results. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ apply modern mathematical methods to solve typical engineering tasks, Ã¯Â¿Â½ work independently with these program systems and to assess calculated results and to Ã¯Â¿Â½ summarize and defend their results in writing and orally according to scientific standards.

name: Chemical industry processes and products
degree-program: Professorship of Chemical Technology
content: Content:The module provides an understanding of chemical, technical, economic, ecological and social aspects in the chemical industry and follows production lines from raw material to product. The lecture focuses on the raw material base of the chemical industry as well as the basic chemicals. As part of a seminar, students present selected applications and end products, the preliminary products of which are manufactured by the chemical industry from basic chemicals. Examples of this include superabsorbents (baby diapers), car paint, rubber (car tires) or liquid crystals. Aim:The students learn business interrelationships and application technology aspects of the chemical industry. Innovative and creative thinking is encouraged and gives students the opportunity to actively participate in later operational processes and the development of new products.

name: Higher flow theory
degree-program: Professorship of Fluid Mechanics
content: Content: Fluid motion differential analysis Navier-Stokes equations Turbulence Boundary layer equations CFD introduction Aim:The students have an in-depth insight into the movement behavior of flows and are familiar with the derivation and the basic solutions to the fundamental problems Familiar with respiratory mechanics equations.

name: Similarity theory and dimensionless metrics
degree-program: Professorship of Fluid Mechanics
content: Content:The focus of this module is on dimensionless key figures and their application to model technology and thus the question: Under what conditions can the knowledge gained from model tests be transferred to a main version? After an introduction showing the advantages of using dimensionless groups, introductory examples are covered. A calculus technique is then derived and applied, which makes it possible to obtain a corresponding number of dimensionless similarity laws from any relevance list of dimensional physical influencing factors. Other key topics include partial similarity and analogy techniques. Aim:The students have an understanding of the application and advantages of dimensionless groups and are able to develop similarity laws, under which model tests can be carried out to investigate prototypes or main details ¿Â½develop and carry out implementations.

name: Plastic joining and assembly technology
degree-program: Professorship of Plastics
content: Content:The lecture includes an overview of joining processes in plastics processing, the presentation of their mechanical implementation using examples from the areas of heating element, vibration and extrusion welding as well as the design of f appropriate components. Furthermore, material and manufacturing-related influences (from the original molding process) on the quality of the joint are discussed and corresponding test methods are presented. An internship for the above-mentioned Joining procedures and testing techniques deepen the lecture material. Aim:The student receives an overview of joining processes and their practical application. He is able to select and design the optimal type of joint depending on the component and its use. He can counteract influences from the material and the processing ¿Â½tzen.

name: Assembly and handling technology/robotics
degree-program: Professorship of Assembly and Handling Technology
content: Content:The focus of the module is to impart theoretical and application-related knowledge in the subject area of drive systems and devices for assembly and handling tasks, including industrial robot technology. Starting from drive-relevant assembly and handling requirements, basic design knowledge for automated assembly systems is taught from the perspective of movement-oriented process and system planning. Typical system components, such as workpiece transfer or pick-and-place devices, are named and their structure and functionality are explained. The structure of mechatronic axes and the mathematical description of spatial rigid body kinematics are taught as the basics of industrial robotics. Based on this, a calculation of the robot kinematics is derived for the typical designs, and the usual parameters required for robot selection are explained. In addition, the latest developments, such as: B. from the field of collaborative robotics, and their requirements discussed. Aim:The student knows the automation levels of assembly and handling systems. He is able to independently familiarize himself with the requirements of assembly and handling tasks, evaluate the effort required to (partially) automate processes and plan the necessary measures , as well as to sketch and calculate movement requirements for automated assembly systems. He is also able to classify industrial robot systems, analyze their structure and derive a parametric forward transformation for serial manipulators.

name: Welding processes and equipment
degree-program: Professorship of Welding Technology
content: Content:The students receive an overview of industrially used welding processes and their possible applications. Pressing and fusion welding processes in different performance categories are discussed. The focus is on teaching technological processes, the necessary system technology and the possible range of uses of the individual welding technologies. Aim:The students are able to select welding processes and the necessary system technology for specific tasks.

name: Special areas of conveyor and feeding technology
degree-program: Professorship of conveyor and material flow technology
content: Content:The increasing automation and interlinking of production processes requires ever more reliable conveyor and feeding systems. The course provides extended insights into special problems and current research trends in conveyor and feeding technology. Interdisciplinary theoretical knowledge is applied to practical examples and deepened. The focus of the content is: energy-efficient system solutions for piece and solid goods Overview of the passenger numbers RDER Technology and their safety devices light. Systematics for the design and dimensioning of conveyor systems Aim:The students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ describe the cause of current development trends and independently select system solutions for specific applications, Ã¯Â¿Â½ special ones To evaluate and select conveyor and feed concepts, to explain manufacturing processes and application criteria of system components, to delineate safety aspects and application limits Â¿Â½explain, Ã¯Â¿Â½ scientific research methods and Ã¯Â¿Â½ apply cross-disciplinary prior knowledge to conveyor and feeding systems.

name: Robot controls B
degree-program: Professorship of Robotics and Human-Technology Interaction
content: Content: Basics of controlling robots: control in joint space, in Cartesian space Robot dynamics Robot control architectures (central and decentralized controls) Computed torque approach tze Gravity compensation Active and passive compliance Impedance based control Hybrid robot controls, force, path, speed Action primitives Safe Human-robot interaction, robot path planning Aim:Acquisition of in-depth knowledge in the field of stationary robotics as a basis for solving corresponding engineering questions regarding the application and development of robot systems

name: Design and calculation of welded connections
degree-program: Professorship of Welding Technology
content: Content:Comprehensive basic knowledge of the strength behavior, dimensioning and design of welded connections is imparted. The students receive an overview of the design rules and calculation methods of selected welded constructions. Furthermore, the basics of representing welded connections in construction documents are taught. Aim:The students have elementary knowledge of the design and calculation of welded structures and are able to plan and design welded structures according to applicable regulations and standards.

name: Modeling and simulation in joining technology
degree-program: Professorship of Welding Technology
content: Content:The module provides the basics of modeling and simulation methods used in joining technology. The focus is on modeling and simulative representation of joining processes and their effects on the component properties. Electrotechnical, fluidic, thermodynamic, material and construction aspects are considered. Aim:After completing the module, the students are able to Ã¯Â¿Â½ assess the advantages and disadvantages of different models, approaches and software packages for joining technology be able to map engineering tasks using simulation and evaluate the results.

name: Functional programming
degree-program: Professorship of Practical Computer Science
content: Content:Practical and theoretical concepts and methods of functional programming languages as well as an introduction to functional programming using the Haskell programming language. The focus is on functional data structures, type systems and evaluation strategies. Aim:Learning the basic principles of functional programming languages ​​as well as the ability to create functional programs
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Operating systems
degree-program: Professorship of Operating Systems
content: Content:Architecture principles, processes, scheduling, process interaction, resource management, kernel and main memory, I/O Aim:Acquiring knowledge of the design and functionality of operating systems; Ability to qualitatively evaluate operating systems
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Computer organization 08.06.10
degree-program: Professorship of Computer Architecture and Microprogramming
content: Content:Almost all practical computer designs are based on a few elementary functional and structural principles. The more complex the systems become, the more important it is to have systematic basic knowledge for understanding them. The module aims to provide a consistent representation of everything from elementary processor to practically relevant system concepts and deepens these in the context of machine-oriented programming. The following topics are covered: Elementary concepts of computer organization Realization of a trivial processor or computer Memory, bus, input/output system Instruction set architectures and machine-oriented programming Practically relevant system concepts using the example of a PC. Practical exercises in the laboratory complement the acquired knowledge using FPGA experiment boards and PC workstations Aim:Understanding of the elementary concepts of practically relevant computer designs
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Databases and web technologies
degree-program: Professorship of Data Management Systems
content: Content:Basic Internet programming techniques for accessing databases, ODBC, JDBC, DCE, CORBA, COM/DCOM, portal technology, XML, web services Aim:The students should learn theoretically and practically how data in databases can be accessed from the Internet. The aim is, among other things, to understand web services and be able to use them.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: algebra
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Elementary group theory (semigroups, Lagrange theorem, factor groups) Group theory (Sylow sets, solvable groups) Construction with compass and ruler Body theory (decomposition fields, normal and separable extensions) Main theorem of Galois theory Resolution of algebraic equations Aim:Learning the strictly formal handling of abstract operations that satisfy simple laws. The basic concepts of algebra covered in the basic courses Linear Algebra and Analytical Geometry I and II are now expanded and deepened in the corresponding chapters. The focus is on group theory, body theory and Galois theory. The students become familiar with the independent approaches of algebraic methods and theories and their connections to other mathematical disciplines.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Analysis of partial differential equations
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Classical solutions for Laplace, heat conduction and wave equations Sobolev spaces Generalized L solutions for r partial differential equations Aim:The aim of this module is to teach the basics of the analysis of linear, partial differential equations.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Representation theory
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Auslander-Reiten theory, Homological methods of representation theory, Combinatorial methods of representation theory, Tilting theory Aim:Possibility of independent reading of scientific works in the field of representation theory
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Introduction to discrete mathematics
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:Basic terms, sentences, proof techniques and algorithms are presented from central areas of discrete mathematics, such as combinatorics, graph theory, matroid theory and complexity theory. Aim:The module provides essential tools for formulating and solving combinatorial counting and optimization problems and teaches basic skills in algorithmic thinking, such as correctly estimating the running time of algorithms and the Estimating the complexity of optimization tasks.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Research module mathematics (large)
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:In order to provide insight into current research topics, areas of application, modeling techniques, concrete scientific work or preparatory topic-specific basics, special events in mathematics are offered at irregular intervals in which typical proof techniques and methodological approaches are offered ts are developed. Aim:The aim is to form a broad basis for scientific work in a current mathematical topic.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Basics of optimization
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Optimality conditions for free and restricted optimization Convexity, separation sets, Lagrangian function Linear optimization (theory and L solution procedure) Implementation with software technical aids in the exercises Aim:Mathematical optimization deals with the task of minimizing an objective function over a given feasible set. The module provides an initial overview of this area and introduces the theory and procedures and techniques for solving classes of fundamental and well-understood optimization problems. It forms the basis for correctly formulating and classifying optimization problems, modeling them in a targeted manner, choosing suitable solution procedures and analyzing solutions with regard to their correctness and sensitivity to investigate qualitatively and to implement simple solution procedures algorithmically. Group work in the exercises further promotes teamwork.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Numerics of partial differential equations
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Boundary and initial value problems in partial differential equations Finite difference method or finite volume method Projection method (including Ritz and Galerkin method) Method of Finite elements asproximation, stabilitars and convergence statements view error drops ztzungen light on marginal and initial value tasks ars algorithms and implementation of discretization methods Aim:The aim of the module is to introduce the field of numerical methods for partial differential equations, while at the same time providing an overview. A number of basic terms are taught that underlie the concept of finitization. In addition to this knowledge, the students acquire the competence to be able to constructively discretize basic types of scalar partial differential equations using finitization procedures, and also to be able to assess the errors of the methods and the properties of the discretization schemes. The basics taught support both the technical requirements for more advanced modules and the ability to develop more general tasks using appropriate specialist literature.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Variation methods
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Boundary value problems and initial boundary value problems in linear partial differential equations for selected physical and technical applications Classification into elliptic, parabolic and hyperbolic differential equations Linear operators and functionals in Hilbert space the energetic Hilbert space variational formulation of the boundary value problems in elliptic differential equations the energetic method Aim:The aim of this module is an introduction to the mathematical modeling of physical processes that lead to partial differential equations as well as the mathematical analysis of the resulting tasks. Basic concepts and results of functional analysis are taught. With this knowledge, students also acquire the ability to formulate connections between applied sciences in a precise mathematical form as well as to analyze and produce evidence themselves.

name: Ordinary differential equations
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Existence and uniqueness theorems for initial value problems Linear systems of ordinary differential equations Boundary and eigenvalue problems Basic concepts dynamic he systems Aim:Ordinary differential equations represent one of the most important tools for studying evolutionary processes that are characterized by determinacy, differentiability and finite dimensionality. They are widely used in physics, mechanics, biology, economics, etc. and are an indispensable part of a solid mathematics education. Students should learn to solve linear differential equations and get to know the theory of solvability of nonlinear equations.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Convex analysis
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Convex functions, subcontinuous and weakly subcontinuous functions Subdifferentiability Conjugate functions Fennel-Rockafellar Duality theory Lagrangian Functions and saddle point statements Application to approximation problems Aim:Convex analysis is the basis for understanding and many further investigations in convex as well as nonlinear and multi-objective optimization including numerical procedures and methods. The aim of the lecture is to give the participating students a basic overview of the various sub-areas and applications of convex analysis in order to enable them to understand the results and methods of convex analysis themselves. To be applied constantly in theory and practice. The module places particular emphasis on the central categories of conjugation, subdifferentiability and duality as well as their connections.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Measurement theory
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Rings, algebras and sigma algebras Contents and measures Lebesguema Measurable functions and convergence theorems Lebesgue integral and limit theorems Integration in product spaces Aim:The aim is to introduce measurement theory and Lebesgue integration theory. The fundamental terms and connections are conveyed. In addition to knowledge, students acquire the skills to deal with complex concepts and their interaction. The foundations for stochastics are created.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Mathematical statistics
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Basic concepts of mathematical statistics Empirical measures Estimation theory Test theory Selected procedures of Mathematical statistics Aim:The aim of this module is the systematic introduction to statistical thinking and reasoning. In addition to teaching basic statistical methods and principles, emphasis is placed on developing appropriate methodological skills with regard to the application of statistical procedures. Students acquire knowledge of the application, interpretation and significance of statistical studies and analyses.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Non-Euclidean geometries
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Fundamentals of mathematics (classical and modern axiomatics, basic requirements for an axiom system, construction of axiomatically based theories) Affine and projective incidence geometry (basic theorems, (finite) models, Examples of undecidable statements) projective geometry (projective maps, Erlanger program, duality principle) hyperbolic geometry (axiomatic structure, Klein, Beltrami and Poincar models, Proofs of most important theorems, basic metric connections) Minkowski geometry (basic concepts by modifying basic concepts of Euclidean geometry, proofs of important theorems, basic properties of known special norms (e.g. B. Maximum norm)) Outlook on further non-Euclidean geometry (elliptical and Riemann geometry, Minkowski's space-time world) Aim:The main aim of this module is the introduction to non-Euclidean geometries with an emphasis on the axiomatic method, but also, in contrast, very concrete model mathematics. Above all, the basics of axiomatic thinking, insights into hierarchy systems in mathematics (e.g. Erlanger program) as well as skills in (also) constructive proof are to be taught. Emphasis should also be placed on clear connections.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Nonlinear optimization
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Free optimization: optimality conditions, convergence concepts, basic numerical optimization methods, such as Newton's method, line search, trust region, etc. Optimization with constraints: optimality conditions , basic numerical optimization methods, such as penalty and barrier methods, SQP methods etc. Aim:Building on the Basics of Optimization module, theory and numerical methods of smooth nonlinear optimization with and without constraints are introduced. The module is intended to enable you to determine or create suitable procedures for specific optimization problems and to competently evaluate them with regard to convergence, efficiency and solution properties.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Numerics of ordinary differential equations
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Initial value problems: stability concepts, one-step procedures (in particular implicit and linear-implicit Runge-Kutta methods, step size control), extrapolation methods, multi-step procedures Boundary value problems: shooting procedures, difference procedures, collocation methods Aim:The aim is to deepen the methods for the numerical solution of initial value problems and to learn the basic methods for boundary value problems, each for ordinary differential equations. In addition to the derivation of algorithms, the consistency, convergence and stability of the methods are examined in order to enable an application-oriented evaluation of the different approaches. In addition, the implementation of the learned algorithms into computer programs is learned.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Vector analysis
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content: Integral calculus for functions of several real variables Surface integrals Gau and Stokes theorem Nabla operator, gradient, divergence, rotation Aim:In this introduction to vector analysis and integration theory, the fundamental concepts and relationships are taught. In particular, the interaction between analysis and linear algebra plays a role in vector analysis. In addition to knowledge, students acquire the skills to deal with complex concepts and their interaction.
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Applied Statistics
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Mathematics
content: Content:Methodological internship on statistics using a statistical program system (e.g. SPSS), data preparation, descriptive and inductive statistics, in particular mean tests, variance analysis, linear regression, curve fitting, contingency analysis, non-parametric test as well as exploratory data analysis, time series analysis Aim:The students learn how to use a statistics program system. In particular, important methods and procedures in descriptive and inductive statistics are presented, which are important for working with statistical data, especially in professional practice.

degree-program: Dean of Studies in Electrical Engineering and Information Technology at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology
content: Content: Calculation of linear networks (node potential and mesh current method) Electrostatic fields, stationary electric flow fields, magnetic statics (field line images, movement of charges, Gaussian law, capacitance t, behavior of the field magnitudes at interfaces, energy and forces) Time-varying magnetic fields (law of induction, inductance ten, Mutual inductances, energy in the magnetic field, hysteresis, forces) Compensation or transient processes Alternating currents (complex calculation, pointers, locus curves, Filter, power) Transformer (structure, mode of operation, equivalent circuit diagrams) Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Mastery of basic electrical engineering methods Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to communicate and collaborate with electrical engineering specialists
