name: Basics of Robotics A
degree-program: Professorship of Robotics and Human-Technology Interaction
content: Content: Introduction to robotics (basic concepts, application of robots) Robot kinematics (rotation matrices, homogeneous coordinates, Denavit-Hartenberg notation, quaternions, direct and inverse task of kinematics, kinematics of velocities ) Robot dynamics Trajectory planning (planning in joint coordinates, planning in operational space) Aim:Acquisition of basic theoretical knowledge in the field of robotics and acquisition of practice-oriented skills regarding robot programming as a viable basis for the independent development and implementation of automation solutions the use of robots
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Numerical methods in electrical engineering
degree-program: Professorship of High Frequency Engineering and Theoretical Electrical Engineering
content: Content: Numerical solution of symmetric-definite equation systems Partial differential equations of the 2nd order Difference method; Finite difference method (discretization, solution method, calculation of magnetic fields in the plane) Finite element method (calculus of variations, Lagrange energy in the magnetic field, time-constant and variable fields) Equivalent charge method (superposition of fictitious charges, potential specification, consideration of multi-material dielectrics) Finite network method; Hybrid method (electrostatic fields, eddy current fields, discretized field equation for moving media and for retarded fields) Moment method (basics, discretization) Aim:Knowledge of numerical methods and skills in producing numerical solutions to electromagnetic problems
program: MINT: mathematics, computer science and natural sciences,

name: Basics of educational science
degree-program: Professorship of General Educational Science
content: Content:Introduction to educational science; Overview of the history of pedagogy; general or exemplary presentation of basic questions and basic concepts of educational science, traditions of thought, classics and the most important trends; Introduction to the understanding of profession, discipline and their connection; scientific work Aim:Acquisition of basic knowledge for understanding educational science, its history, currents and theoretical traditions, the most important basic concepts and pedagogical teachings as an overview knowledge and orientation; Acquisition of basic knowledge and skills regarding techniques of scientific work and research methods in educational science, acquisition of the ability to present facts

name: Introduction to adult education and further training
degree-program: Professorship for Adult Education and Continuing Education
content: Content:Basics and basic concepts of adult education and further training; social, educational and historical conditions; Subject areas of professional field-specific action, central tasks and institutional constitution; concepts of lifelong learning; Learning in adulthood, including basic questions of social-structural and biographical learning requirements Aim:The module introduces adult education and further training as a professional field and scientific reference discipline for adult pedagogical activities. The students learn about various fields of action and tasks as well as specific approaches, theoretical and educational policy concepts and institutional forms of lifelong learning. You will acquire knowledge to understand adult education in the education system, further training practice and the contextualization of lifelong learning.

name: Introduction to intercultural pedagogy
degree-program: Junior professorship in educational science with a focus on intercultural pedagogy
content: Content:In dealing with fundamental positions of intercultural pedagogy, areas of requirement and problems in this area are introduced. The students become familiar with the basic terms and empirical findings. In particular, socio-political implications are reflected from the perspective of intercultural pedagogy. Aim:Acquisition of knowledge about fundamental perspectives of intercultural pedagogy, its application, social necessity and limits

name: Basics of psychology
degree-program: Managing Director of the Institute of Psychology
content: Content:Introduction to the basics of psychological sub-areas; Communication of basic concepts, theoretical approaches and empirical results Aim:Basic knowledge of theories, methods and findings of basic psychological research

name: Basics of Sociology
degree-program: Managing Director of the Institute for Sociology
content: Content:The module imparts basic knowledge in the area of sociological theories and theory history, which is linked to basic knowledge of social science research methods. Aim:The students acquire knowledge of the basic theoretical requirements of sociological analyzes and are enabled to critically engage with sociological theories. You will gain an insight into the complex relationship between theoretical and empirical connections.

name: Technical management
degree-program: Professorship of Factory Planning and Factory Operations
content: Content:The technical management module contains basic knowledge for efficient, holistic planning, control and operation of the factory, for example in relation to production operations. In this context, the following focal points are covered in the module: - Basics of company redesign and redesign in the technical, technological, organizational, social, ecological and business management areas - Product definition, product creation, product manufacturing - Determination of company locations - Content and methodological aspects the planning and realization of factories - design of complete system solutions for product, material, information and recycling flows - future production and factory systems Aim:The aim of the study and qualification is to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the structure and functions as well as the planning, operation and management of production companies from a technical and organizational perspective. Information and communication technologies to be used are also presented.

name: Basics of assembly and handling
degree-program: Professorship of Assembly and Handling Technology
content: Content:The focus of this module is on providing basic knowledge of the machines and assemblies used in assembly and handling. Based on the process parameters (e.g. when joining or assembling), the product requirements (including product design suitable for assembly) and in particular the usable equipment (such as gripping and clamping systems, magazines and bunkers, F wheel systems, rotary indexing tables or pick-and-place devices) methods and tools for the planning and operation of assembly systems and handling devices are presented and their use is described in many applications. Aim:Starting from process requirements and based on typical machines and devices found in this environment, the student learns how they work, their characteristic parameters and operational requirements and how to apply them to modern assembly and handling systems. He receives an overview of everything from the market situation to the concepts regarding sensors and control technology. This enables him to plan and adapt system systems depending on process requirements with knowledge of basic parameters and providers - without having to carry out his own drive and movement-relevant development steps for the design, layout and optimization of new assemblies.

name: Technology of process engineering processes
degree-program: Professorship of Technical Thermodynamics
content: Content:The first part of the module includes elementary process engineering methods and basic process engineering operations. The second part provides an overview of the problems and tasks of the practical implementation of processes in large-scale technical systems. Aim:The aim of the module is to familiarize students with the processes involved in material transformation. The focus of the presentation is on awakening an understanding of mechanical, thermal and chemical aspects of material transformation and their connection to apparatus and systems through complex consideration of process steps, without going too far ¿Â½to delve too deeply into details. In this context, the basic operations relevant to the process in question are explained and the necessary information on their large-scale technical implementation is given.

name: Advanced seminar in computer science
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Computer Science
content: Content:Here, individual aspects of a given problem area are independently identified and processed. The seminar is offered on the pillars of the degree program. The students independently develop a topic, put it up for discussion in a presentation and then write a seminar paper that meets the criteria of a scientific paper. Aim:The students are introduced to the independent processing of research-relevant problems.

name: Internship Research focus on embedded, self-organizing systems
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Computer Science
content: Content:The students apply the theoretical principles acquired in the lectures in practice. You independently plan and implement a project from the research focus of embedded, self-organizing systems. The project work is assigned individually by the professors belonging to the research focus. Aim:The students learn how to independently plan and carry out a project from the research focus of embedded, self-organizing systems.

name: Internship research focus on intelligent, multimedia systems
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Computer Science
content: Content:The students apply the theoretical principles acquired in the lectures in practice. You will independently plan and implement a project in the research area of intelligent, multimedia systems. The project work is assigned individually by the professors belonging to the research focus. Aim:The students learn how to independently plan and carry out a project from the research focus on intelligent, multimedia systems.

name: Internship Research focus on parallel, distributed systems
degree-program: Dean of Studies at the Faculty of Computer Science
content: Content:The students apply the theoretical principles acquired in the lectures in practice. You will independently plan and implement a project in the research area of parallel, distributed systems. The project work is assigned individually by the professors belonging to the research focus. Aim:The students learn how to independently plan and carry out a project from the research focus on parallel, distributed systems.

name: Parallel algorithms
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science
content: Content:The classic algorithms of discrete algorithms are transferred to the parallel computer. Parallel complexity classes, issues of communication between processors. Aim:Recognizing and understanding the question of which problems can be efficiently parallelized. Understanding of communication issues and their importance for parallel computing.

name: Probability and algorithms
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science
content: Content: It is shown how the concepts of probability calculation appear in discrete algorithms. In addition: Randomized algorithms and random inputs Aim:Recognizing, understanding and applying random phenomena

name: Approximation algorithms
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science (and Information Security)
content: Content: Runtimes and qualities of algorithms online and offline situations and geometric applications Simple approximation strategies such as greedy methods and their analysis for special problems such as Maximum Independent Set, MAXCUT - randomized procedures, rounding techniques and linear programming - conversion of randomized procedures into deterministic procedures, linear and quadratic optimization problems and sampling - non-approximability results Aim:The aim of this module is to learn techniques for the algorithmic approximation of the optimal solutions to problems in polynomial time, the exact solution of which can generally only be determined with a lot of computational effort. Techniques for estimating the achievable qualities of the solutions supplied are also learned. With what you have learned, you gain the competence to use approximation methods suitable for specific application problems and to be able to assess their quality.

name: Data security and cryptography II
degree-program: Professorship of Theoretical Computer Science (and Information Security)
content: Content:Current cryptographic methods from the following subject areas are considered: Visual cryptography Secret sharing schemes Cryptographic protocols Aim:The aim of this module is to learn additional techniques and procedures in the area of ​​data security. With what you have learned, you gain the competence to apply procedures suitable for specific application problems and to assess their quality.

name: XML tools
degree-program: Professorship of Distributed and Self-Organizing Computer Systems
content: Content:The eXtensible Markup Language (XML) is the basis for a variety of developments in the area of the World Wide Web. XML plays a central role in the transport and integration of data as well as in many modern software applications. The offer provides a basic introduction to XML and its use in different contexts of distributed systems. Various current and practice-relevant tools are presented as applications of XML. The topics are based on the design structure of distributed systems and cover: Introduction to markup languages and XML Basic approaches, e.g. DTD, XML schemas, XML editors, XML - Applications, linking, XPath, Formats and tools in the area of user interfaces, e.g , Maps, Social Bookmarking, Search, Sight/Sound/Motion, Storage, Tagging Aim:Basic understanding of markup languages; confident handling of XML applications and tools; Ability to use XML applications and XML Web Services to implement sophisticated distributed applications; Basic knowledge of web semantics; Ability to use metadata technologies and realize semantic web resources.

name: Industrial IT application of computer science
degree-program: Dean of Studies of the Faculty of Computer Science/Professorship of Computer Engineering
content: Content:Current topics in the IT industry related to computer science. The topics range from technical questions and solutions to problems to visions of the future. Examples of this include issues in web engineering, telecommunications, high performance computing, software architectures, project management and others. Aim:The students receive an overview of the problems and solutions currently discussed in industrial practice.

name: Language understanding
degree-program: Professorship of Artificial Intelligence
content: Content:The module provides an introduction to the area of language processing. The focus is on understanding written natural language and recognizing spoken natural language. The main focuses are: Introduction - Overview General terms Linguistic units Levels of speech recognition Methods of syntax analysis Semantic processing of written natural language Recognition of spoken natural language Applications Aim:Knowledge of basic techniques for analyzing spoken and written language

name: Media ergonomics
degree-program: Professorship of Media Informatics
content: Content:Media ergonomics deals with interaction possibilities between humans and computers, especially with multimedia content. The goal is a user-friendly design of user interfaces. Aim:Students gain a deep understanding of the theories, concepts, methods, techniques and effects of media.

name: Business Administration I
degree-program: Professorship of Business Administration V - Organization and Work Science
content: Content:The module covers the following business basics: basic concepts of business administration; Companies as an object of knowledge in business administration; corporate goals; business and environment; Tasks and problems of corporate management; operational structures; processes, etc. Aim:Imparting knowledge of selected business categories and theoretical concepts and a basic understanding of business relationships. Development of skills for critical analysis of complex business issues, especially through case study-based exercises.

name: English in Study and Technical Communication II+ (certificate level 3)
degree-program: Head of the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:Deepening the specialist vocabulary in selected areas, leading consultations and discussions, giving lectures, imparting knowledge about possible target countries (GB/USA), Analysis and communication of text type-specific features for writing academic texts (scientific essays, summaries, project descriptions, abstracts) Aim:Security when exchanging information verbally and in writing, security during presentations while adhering to formal criteria, achieving a range of stylistic variation in oral and written expression

name: English in study and specialist communication I+ (certificate level 2+)
degree-program: Head of the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content:Expansion of linguistic knowledge and skills with reference to study and career-oriented issues, independent research, reading and linguistic evaluation of subject-specific texts as well as application in professional discussions, text analysis and production (application documents, specialist essays ), deepening the academic/professional vocabulary in selected areas, leading consultations and discussions, giving lectures Aim:Confidence in dealing with typical situations in everyday academic life, using specialist terminology and reading specialist texts, presenting facts and leading discussions on the topic, mastering oral language and written exchange of information, security in giving presentations in compliance with formal criteria

name: English Language Training: Foundations I
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:Building on the knowledge acquired at the Abitur level, in this module students train and consolidate their knowledge of the English foreign language in the basic areas of grammar, lexis and phonology. In the Foundation Course (FC), listening and reading comprehension are trained and students are prepared to use the language appropriately in writing and speaking in a stylistically and contextually appropriate manner. All four skills are trained in order to be able to express not only factual content, but also speaking intentions safely and successfully. In Vocabulary Building, English vocabulary is practiced, reinforced and deepened. Aim:The students acquire confidence in dealing with the vocabulary of the English language and its composition (Vocabulary Building course). You can use the language flexibly in everyday situations in a culturally acceptable way and are able to respond appropriately to register and formality in most situations (FC).

name: English Language Training: Foundations II
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:Building on the knowledge acquired at the Abitur level, in this module students train and consolidate their knowledge of the English foreign language in the basic areas of grammar, lexis and phonology. In the Integrated Language Course (ILC), listening and reading comprehension are further trained and students are prepared to use the language appropriately in writing and speaking in a stylistically and contextually appropriate manner. All four skills are trained in order to be able to express not only factual content, but also speaking intentions safely and successfully. Aim:Students acquire the ability to use the English language flexibly in everyday situations in a culturally acceptable manner and are able to respond appropriately to register and formality in most situations .

name: English Language Training: Intermediate I
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:Following on from the basic modules English Language Training: Foundations I-II, this module addresses the skills of language use - initially in receptive listening/reading (listening/reading). later in the productive area of speaking (pronunciation). In Pronunciation, segmentalia and suprasegmentalia and their graphic representation are in the foreground. Continuous vocabulary expansion and stylistic variation play an important role, as does the expansion of the students' phonetic knowledge. Aim:The students can fluently use a wide range of linguistic structures and rhetorical figures when speaking, and they are able to understand and confidently interpret speaker intentions. They can react communicatively appropriately in predictable and increasingly unpredictable situations, and they use the language with confidence and efficiency, taking intercultural aspects into account.

name: English Language Training: Intermediate II
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:Following on from the basic modules English Language Training: Foundations I-II, this module addresses the skills of language use - initially in the grammatical area (Grammar) and later in the productive area Writing Continuous vocabulary expansion and stylistic variation play just as important a role as the expansion of the students' grammatical and pragmatic-cultural knowledge. Aim:Students can fluently use a wide range of linguistic structures and rhetorical figures in their writing, and they are able to understand and confidently interpret author's intentions. They can react communicatively appropriately in predictable and increasingly unpredictable situations, and they use the language with confidence and efficiency, taking intercultural aspects into account.

name: English Language Training: Advanced Professional Skills I
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:Building on the basic module English Language Training: Intermediate I, this module focuses on language use skills. Continuous vocabulary expansion and stylistic variation play just as important a role as the expansion of the students' grammatical, phonetic and pragmatic-cultural knowledge. The module gives students the opportunity to further develop their already very good written and spoken English skills so that they can communicate appropriately to the situation and addressee both on the open labor market and in the academic world. The focus here is on types of text that occur particularly frequently in the professional fields just mentioned, such as presentations, debates and discussions. At the same time, the practical application of new media is practiced. Aim:The students can fluently use a wide range of linguistic structures and rhetorical figures when speaking, and they are able to understand and confidently interpret speaker intentions. They can react communicatively appropriately in predictable and increasingly unpredictable situations, and they use the language with confidence and efficiency, taking intercultural aspects into account. The students acquire the ability to appropriately implement expository and argumentative text types in oral English in a variety of situations in the academic and professional world; this includes mastering effective presentation techniques.

name: English Language Training: Advanced Professional Skills II
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:In this course, students learn to translate texts effectively. Various approaches to translation such as text analysis, text typology, contrast analysis, free and close translation etc. are used to guide students in identifying and solving translation issues and problems. Different texts and text genres are used to give students practical experience in dealing with authentic texts and to develop strategies for dealing with different texts in the future. Aim:The students have the ability to translate texts from different genres effectively and in a target group and culturally aware manner. Students will be able to successfully apply translation principles and strategies, and will also be able to use research tools when translating if necessary.

name: Academic Skills & Information Technology
degree-program: Coordinator for Language Acquisition English (Language Practice)
content: Content:In the Academic Study Skills & Information Technology course, students learn to study independently and in a self-organized manner. The course offers the basics of academic work, such as critical reading and academic writing. The students learn to pay attention to sources and the author's intentions, they learn vocabulary and formulations as well as tips on the structure and structure of a scientific work and apply these to their own research work. Search strategies for working with scientific databases and electronic journals and the critical evaluation of their results depending on relevance and reliability are also presented. Students will also become familiar with various citation standards and learn the skills necessary to transcribe academic writing in one of these styles. In addition, students receive assistance on how to structure their self-study. Aim:The students acquire the ability to critically analyze scientific texts. In addition, students can write an academic text using appropriate rhetoric and style. In addition, the students are able to gain access to a wide variety of academic sources and identify “predatory publishers”. In addition, students acquire the ability to learn independently and in a self-organized manner.

name: Foundations of English Linguistics
degree-program: Professorship of English and Digital Linguistics
content: Content:In this introductory module, students acquire basic knowledge of the central areas and concepts of English linguistics such as phonetics, morphology, syntax and semantics and learn the terminological tools for describing and discussing linguistics Phphenomena. The application of linguistic theories and methods is practiced in the form of exercises. The English Linguistics seminar takes up topics from the Introduction to English Linguistics lecture and deepens them. Aim:After completing the module, the students can define the most important basic terms in English linguistics and discuss basic questions in English linguistics in a fact-based manner. They are able to analyze concrete linguistic material using learned models, for example morphologically or syntactically, and to critically question linguistic concepts.

name: Applied and Cognitive Linguistics
degree-program: Professorship of English and Digital Linguistics
content: Content:The module offers students an overview of topics and methods in applied linguistics and cognitive linguistics. With the focus on application, possible topics in the module include (but not exclusively) corpus linguistics, lexicography, forensic linguistics and computational linguistics. Cognitive aspects that concern the basics of human language processing are dealt with, for example, in the areas of first and second language acquisition, bilingualism and cognitive grammar. In the Applied and Cognitive Linguistics seminar, students are introduced to the methodology of scientific work and suitable computer applications used in linguistics and apply these in research-oriented projects. Aim:After completing the module, students can define the most important basic terms in applied and cognitive linguistics and discuss issues in these areas in a fact-based manner. You are able to carry out your first research-oriented linguistic projects independently.

name: Language variation and change
degree-program: Professorship of English and Digital Linguistics
content: Content:The subject of the module, which examines the connection between linguistic variation and linguistic change, is the guided and independent scientific examination of specialized theories, research subjects, research results and methods of diachronic and variety linguistics. The central subject of the History of the English Language lecture is the linguistic-historical overview of the development of the English language on various structural levels (e.g. pronunciation, grammar) from Old English to the present. Depending on the current seminar focus, the Language Variation and Change seminar offers an insight into the diverse possibilities of variation in the English language, such as regional (e.g. British and American English), social, individual and situation-specific (register) Variation. The methodological aspects of linguistic research are deepened and applied by the students in their own research projects. Aim:After completing the module, students will be able to describe principles of linguistic change and formative events in the development of the English language. They can explain the historical basis of linguistic irregularities in contemporary English and identify, name and describe linguistic variation in contemporary English. The module enables participants to take a competent and fact-oriented stand on a wide range of diachronic and variety linguistic topics and to independently and scientifically investigate linguistic variation.

name: English Literatures and Cultures: Basics
degree-program: Professorship of English Literature
content: Content: Basics of the genre and text type specifics of English literary studies Theories and methods of English literary studies oriented towards cultural and media studies Aim:The students acquire core skills (reading skills, text comprehension, philological-hermeneutic interpretation) for analyzing English-language texts in various genres and media. The students can independently work on English-language texts from the target cultures on the basis of theoretical and methodological questions and text access.

name: English Literatures and Cultures: Contexts
degree-program: Professorship of English Literature
content: Content:Overview of the canon of English literary and cultural history in different eras and target cultures Deepening and analysis based on selected texts and media from cultural-historical contexts Aim:Based on the acquired knowledge of literary and cultural-historical connections, students are able to contextually classify texts with a view to social, political and cultural constitutional conditions. You can research independently and edit and analyze selected texts from the target cultures on the basis of broad background knowledge. The students can formulate their own ideas and arguments based on selected texts.

name: English Literatures and Cultures in Practice
degree-program: Professorship of English Literature
content: Content: Practical insights into the literary and cultural sector and getting to know the associated fields of activity Deepening of selected aspects from English literary and cultural history Application of cultural studies methods and theories on the analysis of different types and forms of texts as well as media texts Aim:The students independently edit and analyze texts from the target cultures based on broad background knowledge. They present the results in their own texts, which are based on the specifications and standards of scientific practice. In addition, students can use different academic and subject-related presentation formats. You develop skills in the various components and fields of activity of the literary and cultural sector.

name: Introduction to Anglophone Area Studies
degree-program: Professorship of British and American Cultural and Regional Studies
content: Content:Introduction to the interdisciplinary nature of the research and teaching field and the most important theoretical and methodological approaches of different disciplines: history, sociology, political science, ethnology, cultural studies and geography. Presentation of the differences and similarities between various English-speaking countries with regard to historical development paths and current social, political and cultural structures, constitutional conditions and problems. The understanding of the theoretical and methodological approaches (lecture Theories and Methods in Anglophone Area Studies) is demonstrated in an exam using the example of the societies and cultures learned in the lecture Comparing Britain and the US checked. In addition to the attentive reception of the lecture (including notes), the independent reading of scientific texts in preparation for and follow-up to the lectures is essential. In addition, the content should be discussed in small student groups. Aim:Students are able to understand foreign cultures and societies from different theoretical perspectives. You are familiar with different disciplinary, theoretical and methodological approaches to the research field. You will be able to understand their application using the example of various Anglophone countries. You have acquired key knowledge of the history, culture, society and politics of English-speaking countries (particularly Great Britain and the USA). On this basis, students can describe, assess and compare current developments and specific problems in these countries. You are in a position to contribute to solving them.

name: Anglophone Area Studies
degree-program: Professorship of British and American Cultural and Regional Studies
content: Content:Dealing with historical and contemporary social scientific analyzes of Anglophone societies with particular consideration of their cultural, economic and political constitutional conditions and forms. Aim:The students master the basic techniques of social science work and academic writing (in English) and can apply these to a subject in the research field of Anglophone Area Studies. You are able to identify research problems independently. You are able to independently critically examine various social science theories and methods as well as their application to empirical research questions (on Anglophone societies). You can discuss these in a written, structured manner and come to your own scientifically based position.

name: German literature and cultural studies
degree-program: Professorship of Modern German and Comparative Literature/Professorship of German Literary and Linguistic History of the Middle Ages and the Early Modern Period
content: Content:The module provides an overview of literary history from the Middle Ages to the present in the context of media and cultural historical developments. This also deepens knowledge of genre theory and approaches to literary analysis and interpretation. Aim:The students learn to understand, analyze and interpret literary texts in the context of their historical, media, cultural and poetry-theoretical requirements.

name: German linguistics and German as a foreign and second language
degree-program: Professorship of German Linguistics, Semiotics and Multimodal Communication/Professorship of German as a Foreign and Second Language
content: Content:The module includes the teaching of fundamental perspectives, basic concepts and findings from German linguistics and first and second language acquisition research. Furthermore, the module provides an overview of theories, methods and findings in the area of scientific language, technical language and educational language. Aim:The students acquire basic knowledge in the areas of linguistics and German as a foreign and second language. You will gain the ability to reflect and critically examine communicative processes, acquire basic methodological skills and a (meta-) communicative key qualification.

name: History of the European nations
degree-program: Professorship of European History of the 19th and 20th Centuries
content: Content:The modern European nation states are generally products of the long 19th century, the period from the beginning of the French Revolution to the outbreak of the First World War. As part of the module, the various variants of the state-building process will be discussed in the context of bourgeois national and emancipation movements as well as the phenomenon of nationalism. Aim:The students deepen their knowledge of European history of the 19th and 20th centuries. They are able to describe the emergence of nation-state ideas and their individual implementation and to highlight the differences in individual development patterns. Methodological skills: Students are taught to independently develop scientific questions and research concepts and to work on these using suitable methods. Social skills: The students learn to work on a scientific problem, to present their topic as part of the seminar using suitable presentation media and to write it down.

name: Basics of pedagogy
degree-program: Executive Director of the Institute for Pedagogy
content: Content:Basics of educational science, adult education and further training, general open didactics, intercultural pedagogy and educational research Aim:The students acquire basic knowledge of the issues, theories and methods of pedagogy and its sub-disciplines.

name: Political Science
degree-program: Executive Director of the Institute for Political Science
content: Content:Orientation A: Basics of Political Theory and History of Ideas The module provides an overview of the thematic range of the political science sub-area "Political Theory and History of Ideas". Essential stages in the history of ideas and basic concepts of political theory are presented. Orientation B: Basics of International Relations The module provides basic theoretical, methodological and empirical knowledge in the political science sub-discipline of international relations. It introduces the most important theories and concepts in foreign policy research and international politics and uses them to examine current issues in the field. The lecture provides an introduction to theory-driven foreign policy research, while the exercise focuses on concepts, actors, structures and problems in international politics. Alignment C: Basics of Comparative Politics The module provides an overview of basic concepts, research fields, questions and central topics in the political science sub-field of comparative politics. Aim:Orientation A: The focus of this module is on understanding the issues and methods of political theory and the history of ideas. The students acquire rhetorical skills and can write written work. Orientation B: Successful participation in the module enables students to a) understand and classify the most important theories and concepts in foreign policy research and international politics; b) apply these theories and concepts to analyze current empirical research questions in international relations and c) critically engage with academic literature on selected sub-areas of the subject. Orientation C: Students can understand and classify questions, methods and topics in comparative government. They are able to process information independently and develop strategies for solving scientific problems.

name: Latin I  introductory course
degree-program: Managing Director of the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content: Introduction to general grammar (linguistic propdeutics) Basics of Latin grammar (a, - o-, 3rd declension; important pronouns; all conjugations; all tenses in the indicative; A.c.I / N.c.I.; participles) Basic vocabulary of approx. 700 words Introduction to the linguistic-cultural tradition of history/cultural history of antiquity and the reception and impact of the Latin in modern languages Aim:Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to recognize and name linguistic structures Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to translate simple to moderately difficult Latin texts Ã¯Â¿Â½ Insight into the ancient traditions of Europe

name: Latin II  advanced course
degree-program: Managing Director of the Center for Foreign Languages
content: Content: Continuation of Latin grammar (u and e declension; subjunctive; future tense I and II; subordinate participial constructions; indirect speech / indirect question) Basic vocabulary of another approx. 600 words Introduction to working with the dictionary Introduction to the linguistic-cultural tradition of Europe since the end of antiquity Aim:Ues fã “foeicity for the analysis of complex syntactic structures ues foe fve <QAETHOTH ON LIKTUE and ãlight's original production of original, Middle Ages and Frã GmbH modern times medium to advanced level of difficulty Ã¯Â¿Â½ Ability to use a Latin-German dictionary Ã¯Â¿Â½ Insight into the linguistic and cultural influence of antiquity in Europe and the historical conditions of language change

name: Technical mechanics
degree-program: Professorship of Solid Mechanics
content: Content:Technical mechanics is a fundamental engineering discipline. An indispensable part of the constructive development of machines, devices and apparatus is the mechanical analysis of the components or assemblies loaded by static or dynamic forces. The investigation of tension and deformation as well as movement behavior (e.g. in the sense of vibrations) is of equal interest. Aim:After successfully completing the module, the student is able to understand, evaluate and solve concrete and mechanical engineering-typical tasks on statics, strength of materials, kinematics and kinetics. In addition, the student has developed an intuitive understanding of mechanical design and dimensioning issues.
